HEADLINE: Dance as Art Form As Well as Exercise

BYLINE: By DAN MARKOWITZ 

DATELINE: MAMARONECK

 BODY:
THE person who coined the saying, "Those who can, do; those who can't, teach," did not know Joe Cavise. The former Broadway dancer who performed in "Cats" and the movie version of "A Chorus Line," has for the last seven years been the co-owner with his wife, Lori, of Dance Cavise, a studio here.
In addition to teaching classes in ballet, modern, jazz, tap, hip hop and ballroom, Dance Cavise offers fitness and stretch classes for adults and a creative-movement class for small children. 
 The Off Center Dance Theater, a professional company of which Mr. Cavise, 38, is artistic director, and a junior company perform throughout the county at theaters, schools and hospitals. Both companies will perform today at 2 P.M. at the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College.
Mr. Cavise stressed that his studio does not fashion instruction merely toward a year-end recital. He and his wife, a fine arts major at Clark College in Worcester, Mass., where she met Mr. Cavise, an economics major, try to "teach proper technique, alignment and an understanding that dance is an instructional cultural art," he said.
"They have to learn before they can perform," he added, referring to his pupils. For students, terms like chase, jete, battement, tour jete and pirouette become rote.
In its classes at the studio, Dance Cavise offers a two-track program for its students, who number about 600 and range in age from 3 to18. The first is the recreational track for children who "look at dance more as an exercise and fun and at the same time are building self-esteem and understanding the structure of the art," Mr. Cavise said.
The second track is the professional one for those students "who have what I consider a combination of desire and talent to excel at the art and become a professional," he said.
"They don't have to have both, but if they have one or the other, I can, and my job is to, take the other half and pull it out of them," Mr. Cavise explained.
Michelle Brigante, 19, who has danced with Mr. Cavise ever since he opened his first studio here, said that he "changed my life." Ms. Brigante's mother entered her in dance classes when she was 10 because, as she said, "I was always dancing around the house."
At first, Ms. Brigante added, she was not interested in performing and in fact quit dancing for a time when she was 17.
But with Mr. Cavise's tutelage, encouragement and coaxing, she is now readying herself to audition before a panel of professional dancers in Manhattan for the Off Center Dance Theater Company.
Ms. Brigante is currently working at Dance Cavise as a substitute for two of the teachers, Dina Giordano and Jamie Himpel, and dreams of dancing and acting professionally.
"Joe always pushed me to see what I have inside of me, and to put that out for everybody to see because he knows that I have it," Ms. Brigante said.
"He's my mentor and inspiration. I love to be on stage and make people laugh and cry with me. It's a rush. It makes you feel wonderful, superior to everyone."
Alexis Brandt, 13, has taken classes at Dance Cavise for four years and is part of the junior company. As a teaching demo, she receives a scholarship to cover her tuition in the program and works with younger dancers. She started dancing because she "liked moving around and expressing myself that way." Now she aspires to dance with the senior company.
"I like performing," she said, "being in front of people and trying to be very good." Alexis dances four days a week, which leaves her little time to engage in sports, which she said is fine with her. "I like dance better. It's non-competitive and exercises the entire body."
Brett Fox, 7, is one of the few boys in Dance Cavise, but he loves it. "I like theater, and I love to move flexibly and act and perform," he said. His 10-year-old sister, Heather, who is an apprentice in the Dance Cavise junior company, and his mother teach him how to tap dance in the studio built in their basement.
Does Brett mind that he is one of the few boys brave enough to don leotards and dance in classes composed almost entirely of girls?
"No," he said. "I do like girls."
An intercollegiate wrestler, the 5-foot-5, 140-pound Mr. Cavise said when he took his first dance class at 9 that he knew it was "in my blood." He added, "I realized this was a form of expression that fit me."
Peter Hutchings, 13, who has been dancing with Mr. Cavise since he was 5, started classes because two of his friends were doing so. They have since quit, but Peter said he loves it. "It's exciting," he added. "When I first started taking classes, I would walk out of the studio and dance down the sidewalk."
A soccer player and runner at Hommocks Junior High School here, Peter said: "Dancing is much harder than playing sports because when you're on a team, a lot of the time you're running up and down the field and either you have the ball or someone else does, but you're not in sync with them. In dance, everyone has to be together. You have to know what everyone else is doing. It takes total thought, endurance, and it's great exercise."
Boys at school will sometimes chide him by saying, "Go take a ballet class," Peter said. Actually, jazz is his dance form, but he admits that most people, when they think about dance, think of "ballet, tutus and Swan Lake." He said he is inspired by Mr. Cavise and such great male dancers as Mikhail Baryshnikov.
"Right now, it's a wonderful thing to do," Peter said. "Joe is energetic all the time. I'm really happy I've been able to dance with him. He makes me feel stronger. I don't expect to go all the way to Broadway. If I did, that would be marvelous."
At 11, Mr. Cavise quit dancing and did not return to it until he was 13. He attributed the interruption to the pressure of puberty. "I try to tell the boys that dance can be macho," he said. "Some boys think that dance is threatening to their masculinity. But you can dance and be a better athlete than some sportsman. And I think that keeps them going." Mr. Cavise teaches a beginning class for boys.
The passion in Mr. Cavise's eyes when he talks about dance and in his body when he performs it is evident. His students pick up on it and seem to feed off it. Mr. Cavise also knows firsthand how physically grueling and competitive a professional dancer's life is. Still, he sings its rewards and looks for and relishes those students who want to be stars.
"A dancer has to use arms and legs and face and head to tell a story," Mr. Cavise said. "That necessitates an emotional control as well as a physical skill." As a teacher, Mr. Cavise knows how to build such an awareness. As a performer, he knows when he sees a child who has the same insatiable urge to dance that he has.
"I always tell people," he said, "I can see a dancer come and go, and I always know who will definitely come back and who won't because I can feel who has it in their blood and in their heart."
Dance Cavise is offering classes, called Camp Cavise, this summer. Those interested should call 381-5222 for details.

HEADLINE: Want an Easy Day Trip? Try a State Park

BYLINE: By JACKIE FITZPATRICK 

 BODY:
THERE was a nip in the air and a strong breeze that made the cattails dance, the water shimmer and the sand blow, but that didn't deter Jackie Harris, Elizabeth Oliver and Lillian Thomas from a hike around Hammonasset Beach State Park in Madison.
The three women are members of the Senior Hikers of Wethersfield and they've hiked many a Connecticut state park. They said they are partial to Hammonasset, to Rocky Neck State Park in Niantic and to the area around the Housatonic Meadows State Park in Cornwall Bridge. 
 Wherever they go, their group of about 25 makes tracks. "On some hikes we've gone five miles," said Ms. Thomas. "We always pack a picnic lunch." No matter which park they hike, they said they always happen upon something beautiful; on one day recently it was wild roses, white and faded pink, that dotted the grasses and shrubs that hugged the Madison shoreline. The hikers were just a handful of the 1.5 million people expected to visit Hammonasset state park this year, up from 1.3 million people last year. State parks are becoming the major destination for day-trippers, hikers, bikers and vacationers from within the state and from others.
"People are discovering and rediscovering our state parks," said Anthony Cantele, the acting director of state parks. "There is so much pretty scenery in Connecticut and there's quite a bit of history too."
With the economy being what it is and "with gas prices being what they are, lots of people are deciding to vacation closer to home," he said. Numbers have been up over the last several years at state parks, and this growth shows no sign of slowing.
Although the weather this spring has been nothing short of fickle, park rangers and supervisors all over the state say they are bracing for brisk business.
The Department of Environmental Protection puts out a Connecticut Scenic Road Map that lists state parks and scenic preserves, public boat launch sites and little tidbits about the different scenic routes and the charm each one brings. (The information number is 800-CT-Bound.) The State Department of Transportation also publishes a bicycle route map that provides numerous bike routes. The most visited park in Connecticut is Hammonasset where people can swim, see wildlife along the shoreline or stay over for a few days in a camp site.
One recent morning, 80 first graders were bursting off two school buses, bounding into a brown clapboard house that is home to the Meig's Point Nature Center, where they could dip their hands into a touch tank full of sea creatures, learn all about Connecticut's native snakes and take a nature walk around the beach.
The center offers nature workshops, a junior naturalists' program, salt marsh walks and early morning bird walks where people can look for a snowy egret, a tricolored heron or a red-throated loon.
Kate St. Laurent, a park interpreter, said she's seen growing interest in the marine environment among people of all ages but especially among families with young children. "They want to understand more about it," she said.
Down the road from the nature center, Rosie and Chris Pudvah were enjoying the Hammonasset campgrounds with their two sons, Eddie, 5, and Matt, 2. They were in from Meriden for a couple of days, testing out a new camper. Usually, they just pitch a tent. "The kids can take off on their bikes and play. We have the beach right here," Mr. Pudvah said. "We're outside people and we like this."
Hammonasset gets many regulars who return year after year as well as a growing number of people just discovering the park, said Roger Kinderman, a parks supervisor. "We get people who've come back for 30 years and they'll say I met my wife at this beach," he said. "There are a lot of memories here."
"Camping has also really caught on in Connecticut," he said. "We're right between Boston and New York and with the economy people aren't traveling to Disney. Camping here is only $12 a night and we've got the largest public beach in Connecticut."
The Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection has 1,400 campsites and offers a directory of those campgrounds. Among them is Hopeville Pond in Jewett City where folks can play on baseball fields, set up volleyball nets and swim in the pond, said Mike Reid, the park supervisor. "It's a very pretty park," he said. Visitors can camp or just spend the day picnicking.
George O'Brien, the park and recreation supervisor at Lake Waramaug State Park in New Preston, said the natural beauty is what draws people, as well as the price, at $10 a night, so much so they're booked for summer holiday weekends by January each year. "It seems to appeal to everyone, older people, kids," he said.
Those who must have a spot for fishing, Mr. Cantele said, might want to try the Peoples Forest on the Farmington River and Housatonic Meadows in Cornwall Bridge. "That's a very popular trout stream," he said.
Day-trippers can wend their way to Osbornedale State Park in Derby and take in not only the rolling hills and meadows but also the Frances Osborne Kellogg estate. Or they can take a ride to Gillette Castle in East Haddam, which drew more than 100,000 visitors last year, according to Park Ranger Donald Goss. Another 250,000 people dropped by to hike or visit the state park where the castle is situated, on 200 acres with a goldfish pond.
William Gillette, who was considered one of the great figures of the American stage, built his castle between 1914 and 1919, with walls of granite three and four feet thick at the base and two feet thick at the tower, a sprawling place of his own design with 24 rooms, and electric light fixtures made with bits of colored glass from bottles Mr. Gillette had gathered from friends.
It became a state park after the actor instructed the executors of his estate to be certain that "the property did not fall into the hands of some blithering saphead who has no conception of where he is or with what surrounded."
"We probably have a 10 percent increase in visitors every year," said Mr. Goss. "People are fascinated by the castle and by Gillette. He was an interesting character. He played Sherlock Holmes -- he was Sherlock Holmes."
The design of the castle, and perhaps the thought that at one time a man could truly be the king of an actual castle, also intrigues visitors. "The castle has 47 different doors, all designed by Mr. Gillette," Mr. Goss said.
Hikers have lots of possibilites in Connecticut, with trails at most of the state forests and parks. One of the most often visited, where the numbers of hikers and climbers continue to increase, is Sleeping Giant State Park in Hamden.
Mr. Cantele said Sleeping Giant is considered one of the best hiking areas in New England. It attracts people from all over and has an active association whose members regularly clear trails and who have a long history of defending the park from development including quarrying -- which at one time took the hair right off the head of the giant, before it was halted.
Sleeping Giant even has its own history book, "Born Among the Hills," written by Nancy Davis Sachse of Hamden in 1982. Ms. Sachse, herself a long-time avid hiker of the hill, is now in the middle of an update of the book, which chronicles the history of the mountain. The trails were once game-hunting paths created by American Indians who called the giant Hobbomock or Evil Spirit, who, "angry at the neglect of his people, stamped a foot" -- at what is now Middletown -- "and changed the course of the Connecticut River to the east. Hobbomock was also the bogey by which Indian mothers frightened their children into obedience."
Her research of the state park took some doing but, she said, "everybody has a story to tell about the giant." At one time, the park was a resort with tiny houses dotting the giant's frame.
Ms. Sachse says it pleases her to see continued interest in the park, from younger generations who hike the hills or follow the stream or simply take a little solace looking down, once they've made it to the top. "It's a beautiful place," she said.
With a picnic basket brimming, some balls and bats or fishing poles packed, families have only to consult a map, gas up the car and head to some other part of the state and there'll be plenty to do.

HEADLINE: Some Schools Fear State Would Lower Standards

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
WITH the concern about American students being able to compete globally, a call from Albany for higher standards may be as much an article of faith as motherhood and apple pie.
As part of that refocusing on academic achievement, Education Commissioner Richard Mills has started an initiative to require all high school students to pass Regents examinations to receive diplomas. 
 The plan is to be phased in starting in September, and the goal is that students, in order to graduate in 2001 and after, will have to earn a grade of 65 or higher in four major subjects: English, mathematics, social studies and science.
Pupils now in the fourth grade will be the first required to meet the new requirement.
In 1994, according to the State Education Department, 59,900 of the 157,654 high school graduates earned Regents diplomas.
The call for higher standards is not limited to secondary education. Mr. Mills said he also wanted to raise standards for elementary students, and the Board of Regents is therefore developing more demanding requirements for them.
Under a national initiative, called Goals 2000: Educate America Act of 1994, the Federal Education Department has given money to the states to develop content and standards as well as develop ways to assess results.
"We want to look at state standards and our curriculum to set high standards for student achievement," the curriculum director in Ardsley, Dr. Florence Musiello, said. "The Regents exams are being totally revised to be a more authentic assessment. It's all part of the reform movement."
One aspect of the reform movement is a stronger partnership between business and schools. The National Education Summit in March, a partnership between governors and corporate executives, reflected a concern with improving performance and standards.
"At I.B.M. we believe we can't have a successful company without a successful community," the director for corporate social policy and programs, Robin Willner, said. "We have a $25 million initiative in 10 school districts to provide them with new applications of technology that will help them raise standards. With the Westchester Education Coalition we have a two-year project in professional development to develop new ways to use technology for the basics in the classroom.
"The bottom line is that we want to make sure that every child is prepared to reach the highest academic standards. Technology is a powerful tool to help."
The movement has affected school-to-work initiatives, an area that was the focus of a conference that the Westchester Education Coalition at Purchase College organized.
"One of the objectives of the conference is to break down the barriers between the academic and vocational tracks," said Dr. Thomas R. Bailey, director of the Institute on Education and the Economy at Teachers College at Columbia University. "We will be pairing up industry standards to academic standards. School-to-work has to be done in such a way that those Regents standards are achieved.
"But you can't have those same old multiple-choice tests to measure standards. When you're thinking about school-to-work you have to make sacrifices in the material that's covered. It's a different kind of experience. You don't expect to have one assessment that's going to tell that much."
Some districts have expressed concerns that higher standards would be difficult to attain because of limited resources and problems with students. Some stronger districts have said they are concerned that the Regents plan would, on the other hand, hinder their students' achievements.
"My concerns about the state are similar to what the concerns of most high-performing districts are," the Superintendent of the Byram Hills District in Armonk, Dr. Thomas F. Maguire, said. "With some kind of compulsory set of examinations we would have to provide a curriculum to pass those examinations -- and not provide the kind of challenge that we offer our students."
The executive director of the Westchester Education Coalition, Dr. Shirley L. Mow, said: "What's a high standard for one school is not a high standard for another. The average is sometimes misleading in Westchester. One concern is that more disadvantaged students will need more resources to get to that level, and closing the gap in performance and achievement in less affluent districts comes back to funding issues."
Some districts said they were hoping to apply for exemptions by offering more demanding tests like Advanced Placement examinations.
"It's fine Albany is dealing with standards," Superintendent Donald C. Parker of Chappaqua said. "But we feel that the program and standard of expectations that we have here are already higher than what Albany is proposing. We have courses that are not traditional Regents-type courses, and there are places that exceed what they are proposing.
"We don't give Regents diplomas now. Ninety-five percent of our seniors take A.P. physics. We have very challenging courses, and we don't want to be in a situation of putting in a testing program that will put us backward. We are sympathetic to the state, which has to do something to raise the bar for everyone. But we feel the bar is already raised here."
Prompted in part by Middle States Evaluations, several districts in the county and in Connecticut and New Jersey formed the Tristate Consortium to develop standards.
"We wanted an ongoing structure for improvement," Dr. Parker said. "We're developing world-class standards to continually challenge and improve ourselves. We don't want to be complacent."
At a recent Overcoming the Odds dinner to honor students who had surmounted substantial obstacles and succeeded in schools, former Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol said:
"We're in the midst of a standards-based reform movement. One of the premises is that if we are clear about what we want to teach our children and what we want them to learn and set those standards very high, we will have world-class students.
"So far as it goes, I very much agree with the movement. I think we ought to demand more of kids. They're capable of doing more than we're asking them currently."
At the dinner, sponsored by Student Advocacy Inc., Dr. Sobol, now a professor at Teachers College, added: "A problem is that the standards movement now under way cannot succeed unless students and teachers are given supports and motivation to jump the new, higher hurdles. Success depends on the right kind of follow-through.
"My concern is that the necessary follow-through and support that the standards-based movement depends on will not be forthcoming. Not all kids have access to resources like textbooks, good teachers and computer software. But all kids will be subject to those requirements. That's not fair, and it's not smart. The standards movement is a good thing and should be brought to completion."
At a meeting of the Westchester Education Coalition in Purchase on May 30, Commissioner Mills said: "The Board of Regents is really serious about high standards. To make it stick will require a set of connected links. We have to get instruction in line with the standards. Let's assemble materials that work and apply it to the standards. We need a high-performance curriculum in front of everyone so everyone is ready."

HEADLINE: THE BIRTH OF A REVOLUTIONARY CLASS

 BODY:
I take great exception to Thurow's essay. At 65, I am, as always, a productive, participating, contributing member of society. I pay taxes, spend money to support the economy and give generously to the less fortunate. I have worked outside of the home for all of my adult life, at the same time raising two moral and socially responsible children. 
 Thurow states that the elderly such as I threaten the nation's economic future. I say that without us and the strong work ethic we lived by and instilled in our children, America has no future.
 
LITA WOLFE
Scarsdale, N.Y.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
A State Tech Center to Help Emerging Companies

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: NORTH BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
GROUND has been broken here on a state-sponsored center intended to provide emerging high-technology and biotechnology companies with space at a reasonable price, allowing them to develop their products and grow. Supporters of the center say that in the process, it could have major implications for the state's economy.
Construction on a 60,000-square-foot building is to begin this summer, heralding the start of the proposed Technology Center of New Jersey, which ultimately will consist of 800,000 square feet of office, research and production space. 
 The $135-million project, which could take as long as 10 years to build, is the result of years of discussion among state, industry and academic leaders. The discussions took into account that without help such companies, hindered by high operating costs and the lack of credit, have left and could continue to leave the state.
The incentive to stay in the state comes not only from the low rents that would be provided, but also in financial assistance from the state to help companies design and build their spaces. The New Jersey Commission on Science and Technology will also provide technical support.
"We are looking to create a business climate that will encourage small high-tech companies to expand in New Jersey and build on the industry's ideas to achieve economic growth," said Gualberto Medina, commissioner of the state's Department of Commerce and Economic Development.
Based on a formula of two jobs for every 1,000 square feet of research and development space created, the state estimates the technology center will generate more than 1,600 jobs. The state's Economic Development Authority, using public and private funds, will develop the center on a 50-acre site it bought from Johnson & Johnson along a section of the Route 1 commercial artery known as the "research corridor."
The corridor extends for 14 miles from Princeton University north to Rutgers University in New Brunswick. Among other complexes on the corridor are the David Sarnoff Research Center, which conducts electronics research, and St. Peter's Hospital and the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, both in New Brunswick and noted for their medical research. Nearby are corporations like Johnson & Johnson and Bristol-Meyers Squibb.
The technology center is expected to forge links with its academic, research and corporate neighbors.
Apart from the building itself, the center's first phase, with an estimated cost of $25.6-million, involves making such improvements to the site as installing roads, utilities and telecommunication lines. Two of three existing buildings will be retained; a third will be partially demolished.
THE center is intended for companies working in biotechnology, telecommunications, computer applications and micro-electronics. Many have outgrown incubator space at state universities, but are not financially ready to move into fully finished space.
"There was no place for such companies to hang their hats," said Anthony R. Cosica chairman of the autonomous Economic Development Authority. He said his staff had visited several university-related parks to mold a concept that would work in North Brunswick.
There are 140 such centers nationwide, including two others in New Jersey, according to the Association of University Related Science Parks, a trade group in Tempe, Ariz. The two others in New Jersey are the 2,200-acre Princeton Forrestal Center in Plainsboro and South Brunswick and the 50-acre University Heights Science Park in Newark, which is linked to four institutions of higher education -- Rutgers University, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, the New Jersey Institute of Technology and the Essex County Community College. The North Brunswick center is the first initiated by the state.
A growing number of service industries are helping the state to recapture half of the 279,000 jobs lost during the recession of the early 90's, according to the state's Department of Commerce and Economic Development. But corporate restructurings and mergers continue and the state's manufacturing base continues to slip.
Still, New Jersey's pharmaceutical firms conduct 85 percent of the industry's research, a strong resource for young companies. The state is also already home to 100 biotechnology companies and more than 7,000 software and information technology concerns.
"Science and technology-related companies are the engine of growth for the state," said Jay J. Brandinger, executive director of the Commission on Science and Technology. "And the center is the next step that will allow them to move from research to production within New Jersey."
But Maxine Ballen, president of the New Jersey Technology Council, a Princeton-based nonprofit trade group, cautioned against being too optimistic. "The center is not a panacea," she said, adding that more must be done to remove government restrictions for companies to stay and blossom in the state.
The center is proceeding at a time when the 11-county northern and central New Jersey office market is improving, but still has a supply of space. But the center fills "a niche no one is serving, because private developers view building space for firms without sufficient credit as too risky," said Thomas P. Sullivan. He is a first vice president at the Iselin office of CB Commercial, which is marketing the project, designed by the Princeton-based architectural firm of CUH2A Inc.
To surmount the hurdle of financing, the Economic Development Authority will provide below-market-rate loans or guarantee loans secured from private lenders so companies can customize their space.
Moreover, said Mr. Sullivan, the center's "competitive edge" will be its rents -- 20 to 25 percent lower than the market rate for comparable space. For example, he said, lab space that normally rents for $24 to $26 a square foot would go for $21 and under.
Space in the new 60,000-square-foot building, to be completed by next summer, could be divided into areas as small as 6,000 square feet, said Mr. Sullivan. Construction of the rest of the space will be driven by the market and include build-to-suit deals for specific tenants.
"As developer and landowner the state can accept a lower profit, allowing rents to be kept low," said Mr. Coscia of the development authority. He noted that the agency bought the 50-acre Johnson & Johnson site for $9 million -- $4 million of which came from its own funds. The rest will be paid in two installments over 10 years. Improving the site and developing the first building will cost $16.6 million.
The Science and Technology Commission is providing a $2 million grant and the state is negotiating a joint-venture agreement with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Building Investment Trust Pension Fund to invest the remaining $14.6 million.
OF the existing buildings on the site, one with 26,000 square feet will remain the home of Advanced Care Products, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson that does research on new over-the-counter hygiene products. The authority will keep a second 20,000-square-foot building for offices.
The third, 200,000-square-foot building will be demolished except for 29,000 square feet, which Advance Realty of Bedminster has leased and in turn will re-lease 22,000 feet to Chubb Computer Services of Parsippany, a computer-training provider that is a subsidiary of the insurer.
Dan Goodman, Chubb's vice president of business development, described the space as "affordable." He added that 100 people would work at the site, the company's third in New Jersey. Advance Realty will retain the remaining 7,000 square feet for a conference center and cafeteria for the entire project.
"The project," said Mr. Coscia of the development authority, "is a reasonable risk balanced by the potential of creating jobs and retaining companies."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 4; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2995 words

HEADLINE: 80's Giant Dreams Facing 90's Economic Realities

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
BY the middle of 1990, the complex set of approvals to map the streets and run the electricity and dig the sewers and build the parks were in place for a 10,000-apartment development, and Arverne -- the name taken from the surrounding neighborhood -- was ready to rise on the waterfront of the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens.
But the recession hit, the developer backed out and for years, neighborhood residents assumed the 300-acre project was dead.
 Now plans for the development are alive again, although its scale will be vastly different, at least for now. With great caution, the city will shepherd the project through -- one block at a time. Instead of 10,000 condominiums, developers last week submitted bids to build 350. 
 In the raucously heady days of the mid to late 80's, when every fledgling developer had a dream and almost every big-time developer had a $100 million credit line, New York City real-estate watchers were treated to one "major announcement" after another, trumpeting the advent of one elaborate project after another.
In Manhattan, construction was said to be a few months away on a 60-story office building atop a new Staten Island Ferry terminal; on a $160 million multitower complex to be known as the West Side Yards, near the Javits Convention Center; on Riverwalk on the East River, and Riverside South on the Hudson. There was Bridgemarket, a three-level, $30 million international food market and restaurant under the Queensboro Bridge. The abandoned gray shed on Pier A in Battery Park, which once serviced city fireboats, was to be magnificently restored, with a new visitor's center and restaurants.
A few years later, when the old Staten Island Ferry terminal was ravaged by fire, the real estate market was beginning its downturn and thoughts of an office tower were already gone, a still-optimistic blue-ribbon panel chose an exuberant postmodern design that sported a 120-foot-high clock on its water-facing facade that seemed to shout, "Hurry Up, You're Almost in Manhattan -- Where Time Rules."
In the boroughs outside of Manhattan, developers say, there grew up a competitive spirit: If the banks were so flush, why shouldn't they get in on it, too? Long Island City was to have its own multitowered metropolis clustered around a rising new Citicorp tower; the Bronx was to have Bronxchester Plaza, a shopping center in the South Bronx, and Shorehaven, with a beach club and 1,000 condominium units; the Rockaways were to have Arverne.
With the spin-out in the real estate market at the beginning of this decade, many of these projects simply melted away, like cotton candy over a flame.
But now a substantial number of these projects are back, or are said to be coming back -- sometimes in totally different guises. In many cases, they have been shrunk, or in the word of several urban planners, "downsized." In several cases, private money has become public money; government officials have realized that without at least seed money developers and their banks don't want to play.
What happened?
"The 80's turned into the 90's," said Sam White, the architect whose $8 million design for an elegant restaurant next to the Harlem Meer boathouse at the north end of Central Park has evaporated in the mist. "In the 80's you could finance anything based on nothing; in the 90's you couldn't finance anything, even if it was secured with everything."
For Mr. White's project, banks were tried. Japanese investors were tried. Mr. White, who described the scene as "beautiful, little boys fishing, everything Winslow Homer would want," predicted the restaurant idea might resurface in about five years, "but probably restructured as a smaller restaurant," perhaps with construction financed by the Central Park Conservancy -- not a private developer.
Investors from Hong Kong did come to the rescue of Riverside South, a $3 billion project that had never been buried -- or even admitted to be stalled -- by its ebullient developer, Donald Trump. Last week Mr. Trump said that the $355 million construction of Phase One, the four rental towers designed by Philip Johnson between 64th and 69th Streets, would begin in "September or October."
Mr. Trump said that the towers had all their zoning approvals -- that a Court of Appeals case that challenged the zoning had been won -- and that the project was ready to go.
But at the foot of Manhattan, the 60-story office tower and ferry terminal is "deader than a doornail," one of its developers, William Lie Zeckendorf, said last week. That project, for which developers were chosen five years before the ferry terminal fire, was to have cost $400 million, and would have included a restoration of the now-crumbling landmark Battery Maritime Building as well as a new ferry terminal.
While that project has been written off, the idea for a new ferry terminal still lives -- although its design appears to be changing like quicksilver. The giant clock face, with its air of New York City in-your-face braggadocio, a design chosen in the post-fire 1992 competition won by Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates and Anderson/ Schwartz, has vanished, replaced by a glass-gridded box with an electronic news banner on the waterside. The budget has been slashed from $120 million to $73 million.
YET now, even that more conservative facade is gone -- the same architects have been directed to "go back to the drawing board," said Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, and "come up with a design that people on both islands will like." The re-redesign is expected shortly, he added.
Both the clock and the electronic news banner faced powerful opposition, led by Staten Island Borough President Guy V. Molinari, who several days ago suggested that both the clock and the banner be replaced by some type of seascape -- or by nothing.
"It could even be plain glass like the other side, but nothing garish," he said. "The people of Staten Island have been abused enough."
Politics, it seems, plays a big part in many of these projects. A substantial restoration of the Tweed Courthouse has been postponed, according to a city official involved, "because there was a feeling at City Hall that we didn't want to be funding something in our own backyard." Instead of a large-scale rehabilitation including grand new front stairs, probably only the more egregious problems -- like code violations -- will be addressed.
Where large-scale publicity and public-relations campaigns were a fixture of the real-estate development world in the late 80's, now there is often mystery.
At 99 Prince Street, the magnificent 1880's arched red brick building built for fur manufacturing by John Jacob Astor has been boarded up and covered with posters and graffiti for years. But plans for a boutique hotel, the Mercer, that were stalled in the real estate recession, may be back.
Suddenly there is light -- a worker's bare bulb glimpsed through a second-story window. On the first floor, there are newly glazed frosted glass windows that read: J. Crew, November 1996.
Nevertheless, the building's owner, Andre Balazs, who also owns the Chateau Marmont hotel in Hollywood, is mum. "This project has received enough attention already," he said, adding that he would rather wait until later to detail finances for his 75-room hotel and retail space, which ran into trouble in the early 1990's when financing problems involving a Japanese bank brought major work to a halt.
Another project, Bridgemarket, according to Hugh Hardy, the architect who has been involved in its planning, is definitely coming back but cannot be discussed, by order of Sheldon Gordon, the West Coast developer, who could not be reached for comment.
In the summer of 1987, the city's Public Development Corporation announced it had signed the lease agreement with the developer, "allowing construction to begin." That announcement added that "more than half of the market has already been leased" and that the 130,000-square-foot project under the Queensboro Bridge would be completed by late 1988.
There are persistent reports that the British home-furnishings entrepreneur Sir Terence Conran will return to America with a new incarnation of his Conran's/Habitats store and plans to build within Bridgemarket, but no one will confirm the plans for the record.
Secrecy can result in skepticism.
"If you're a developer, are you ever going to say your project is dead?" asked John Belle, a partner in the respected architectural firm of Beyer Blinder Belle, who saw one of the biggest projects of the boom years, West Side Yards, drop off the economic precipice. "Why would you want to reduce your property value? Why would you offend the Mayor or the Borough President or whatever the politics are? So projects are never labeled dead."
But there is evidence that efforts are being made to revive several of these projects, although frequently in different forms.
In the South Street Seaport neighborhood, 250 Water Street, a vacant site, with a long history of proposed office-building designs, was listed a few weeks ago by a high-ranking city official involved in permit approvals as one of those missing from the roster of active projects.
But two weeks ago, 250 Water Street resurfaced completely changed -- and bigger than ever, an exception to most 80's holdover projects.
Instead of a massive 11-story office building, its architects now envision the new structure as an $85 million residential tower -- 32 stories at its highest point.
The change reflects the economics of current downtown construction, according to Charles A. Platt of Platt Byard Dovell Architects. There are office buildings with high vacancy rates, and at the same time, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is offering financial incentives to build housing downtown, to move people into the concrete corridors that become bleak and foreboding after work hours. The developers, Paul and Seymour Milstein, are responding to that call for housing -- although 250 Water Street is not in the target area, and does not qualify for any of the incentives, Mr. Platt said.
THE project has already been attacked by the Seaport community, dozens of whom spent two hours loudly denouncing the design at a Landmarks Commission hearing on Tuesday.
"The community is fighting it," Mr. Platt said. "I'd say they're up in arms, as usual." The architect argued that the while the amount of floor space in the latest version is 36 percent greater than in his last version -- there were many other earlier versions, by different architects -- the volume is only 8 percent more because office buildings have much higher ceilings. New residential buildings, because of various light and air restrictions, end up being much shallower than office buildings, which are allowed to be very deep and have rooms without windows.
"If we couldn't build back on the site, there was nowhere to go but up," Mr. Platt said.
The proposed residential building does not need any special zoning or other changes or waivers. It is planned for market-rate rentals, the architect said, with perhaps some condominiums for sale in the tower. But because the proposed building would be in a historic district it requires approval by the city's landmarks commission, which will eventually vote on its appropriateness.
In the Bronx, William Procida, a veteran developer, is bringing back Shorehaven, a 47-acre site on a peninsula in Long Island Sound with the Whitestone and Throgs Neck bridges on one side and the East River and the nighttime lights of New York City on the other.
In an arrangement that is a paradigm for the mid-90's, Mr. Procida does not own the property -- the bank that took it over from the last development group does -- but he has been hired to build and market its redevelopment.
He is currently building 84 two- and three-bedroom units, which will sell for $129,000 to $162,000 each. When the last developer, a partnership of World Wide Properties and a group of other investors, including William Zeckendorf Jr. pulled out, they had built 150 out of the 170 homes scheduled for Phase I. Mr. Procida, criticizing these initial prefabricated units as poorly built, rehabilitated the existing units and completed the last 20 units. Now all 20 have been sold, for $135,000, he said, noting the original prices had ben $165,000 to $170,000.
The second phase, the group of 84 -- now half completed -- is being built of concrete blocks and wood planks, the developer said. Of the 84, he said, 69 have been sold and he is "about to build another 250 -- all of them three-bedroom units."
Mr. Procida said he was targeting the sales to black and Hispanic buyers who reflect the makeup of the community and are "the strongest middle market in the country."
"There's already enough developers chasing the white Yuppie market," he said.
The restoration of Pier A, which was launched when the city pulled its fireboats out of its large shed and sailed them over to the Brooklyn Navy Yard -- leaving an abandoned building at the tip of Manhattan with spectacular views of the harbor -- had also fallen victim to the city's economic downturn.
Although the 32,000-square-foot shed seemed a natural location for a visitor's center and restaurants -- there was virtually no opposition to the renovation and proposed uses -- the qualities that made it so popular made it more difficult to finance, according to its developers.
Anne E. Bliss, the design director for Wings Point Associates, the developers, said that although the state's Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation had pledged $4.2 million to develop and build a visitor's center to be run by the city's Department of Parks and Recreation, the banks they had tried in the past would have preferred an income-producing use for the 6,000 square feet, on the inshore end of the second floor. A catering facility is planned for the harbor side on the second floor, with an cafe and shops on the first floor.
"We spent seven years looking for private financing," said Ms. Bliss. "It was essentially impossible to find."
Now, however, the developers and city officials have come up with another solution: the Industrial Development Agency, which is part of the Economic Development Corporation, has made a preliminary commitment to issue $20 million of bonds to carry out the renovation.
Ms. Bliss said that the final details were being ironed out and that she expected the deal to close in July or August. Both Ms. Bliss and the preservation architect involved with the project, Roger Lang, praised the city for seeing its merits.
Mr. Millard, the development corporation's president, said he expected the project "to be in construction by the fall." The project "received a guarantee from HUD a couple of weeks ago," he said, "and that was the key to the puzzle."
The Pier A project, the city official said, was only one of the major projects that were finally moving ahead. If there was secrecy -- at least as far as projects involving the city -- it is because of Mayor Giuliani's insistence on "ribbon cuttings -- not announcements," he said.
Some of the city-sponsored projects have been reduced in size, he said -- the La Marqueta project to renovate the market in the El Barrio section of East Harlem has been scaled down from $5 million to $1.5 million, he said, but it's finally getting built.
ANOTHER example is Brooklyn's Renaissance Plaza, a grand hotel-and-office project first announced in 1984. "And while there are still no shovels in the ground," Mr. Millard said, "we're finalizing the financing."
Financing for the $220 million project, to be developed by Joshua Muss and the Carlyle Group, is now a combination of public and private funds, with the city contributing $20 million of the infrastructure, the E.D.C. president said.
"When the Mayor wants something done, he pushes us all," said Mr. Millard. "Deadlines are set."
In Arverne, the city Department of Housing Preservation and Development (H.P.D.) is moving to find developers for a vastly scaled-down version of what was envisioned by the master-plan architects, Ehrenkrantz & Eckstut, in one of a number of bold plans for the city-owned waterfront property over the years, as a sweeping 10,000-unit residential development, complete with parks and shopping.
Nine days ago, the city received "a strong response" to a request for proposals to build 7,500 square feet of commercial space and 350 housing units, as part of the first phase of the development, according to Deborah Boatright, an H.P.D. spokesperson.
To Mr. Belle, who as an architect has been involved in many large urban projects, such as the restoration and renovation of Grand Central Terminal and Ellis Island, the grander and more complicated a project is the harder it is to get it approved.
Which is why many of the true megaprojects of the 80's, including his own West Side Yards -- the site in the far west 30's that the city is currently exploring for a new Yankee Stadium -- are dead.
"It's nothing to do with building technology," he said, "but it takes forever to get all those approvals." The more complicated projects -- especially those waterfront projects that require building out into the water -- may be deemed too risky for banks to finance. (The plan for the grandiose residential and commercial development known as Riverwalk between 17th and 24th Streets has now been scaled down to a park on the East River, sponsored by the community -- with no construction at all, according to the City Planning Department.)
To Mr. Belle, at least, this downsizing and abandonment of fantastic schemes is a positive thing. He said he did not regret that "the megaprojects from the mid-80's didn't get built; they might have been a big mistake.
"We're coming back to the simpler way of doing things," he said. "And it just might be the salvation of our cities."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 6; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 948 words

HEADLINE: N.J. LAW;
Child-Support Payments Under Review, With Cuts Likely

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
New Jersey is updating its four-year-old guidelines for determining child-support payments, basing the changes on new estimates of how much it costs to raise a family. But if the State Supreme Court accepts the revisions, payments for thousands of children will actually drop.
The proposals, released by the court's Family Practice Committee this spring, would reduce child support paid by almost all non-custodial parents, with the largest cuts for those in high income brackets. They would also give non-custodial parents financial credit for visitation time. 
The 285,000 child-support orders already in effect in New Jersey would not change because the revisions would apply only to new cases. But parents who already pay support could request a reduction if their income or custody-agreement changed, said Daniel Phillips, a research analyst with the Administrative Office of the Courts.
The revisions are being discussed just as the State Legislature is overhauling New Jersey's 25-year-old divorce law, and some overlap with proposals being considered by lawmakers. But child-support guidelines come under the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court, and they are not subject to legislative approval.
Non-custodial parents have praised the proposals, saying that the extra money they spend on their children during visitation periods should be factored into their support payments. But some matrimonial lawyers have expressed concern, arguing that reduced payments could have a devastating effect on poor single-parent households.
"My biggest concern is the impact this will have on families living in poverty," said Nancy Goldhill, a senior lawyer for Legal Services of New Jersey. "When you start adding all of this up, the net effect is a dramatic reduction in payments."
Mr. Phillips said the revised payment schedule is based on new economic data suggesting that the basic cost of raising children is lower than New Jersey's courts had previously estimated. Several economists conducted studies to determine the new estimate, he said. Wealthy parents' payments will drop the most because the new guidelines assume that as income increases, child-rearing expenses do not increase at the same rate.
Although the poorest parents would also pay less under the new guidelines, the change could actually bring more of them into the system, according to the committee's report. Right now, non-custodial parents who earn $190 a week or less pay as much as $47 a week to support one child. But many simply cannot make the payments, so they slip into the cracks. The new guidelines would lower these parents' payments to $5 to $10 a week, regardless of how many children they have, to insure that they stay in the system.
Non-custodial parents are especially pleased that the new guidelines would account for the time they spend with their children. Until now, any money they spent on the children during visitation periods was in addition to their regular support payments. But a new shared-parenting credit would reduce payments for non-custodial parents who spend at least 28 percent of each week with their children. Parents who did not qualify for that credit could still have their payments reduced, although not as much.
"These guidelines are recognizing a significant change in the culture of divorce," said Patricia Barbarito, the chairwoman of the New Jersey Bar Association's family law section. "More and more, both parents are involved in raising the children, and you've got to give credit to the parent who doesn't live with them."
Ms. Barbarito said the proposal for visitation credit might urge some non-custodial parents to seek more visitation rights for the wrong reason -- more money -- but that judges would not be likely to grant such parents more time.
"It's a very valid concern," said Ms. Barbarito, a matrimonial lawyer in Denville. "But we've got to assume that judges are going to do what's in the children's best interest when they determine visitation time."
The proposed visitation credit might have been inspired by a well-publicized case last year in which the State Supreme Court ruled that James Pascale, a divorced father in Princeton, could not drastically reduce his support payments even though his three children spent a significant amount of time with him.
Mr. Pascale had said he was seeking not to pay less child support, but to have more control over how the money was spent, especially when the children were with him. Although the court did reduce Mr. Pascale's payments slightly, it ruled that his former wife, Debra Pascale, should maintain complete control over the $25,000 a year that both contributed to child-rearing.
Although parents like Mr. Pascale would automatically be eligible for reduced payments under the new guidelines, they still would not have a say in how their support payments were spent. Nor would they have the right to know exactly how the money was spent.
"It's disappointing because we feel custodial parents should have to show exactly how and where the money is spent," said Dominick Romano, the president of the New Jersey Council for Children's Rights, a non-custodial parents' group with 6,000 members.
While calling the new guidelines were "terrific," Mr. Romano said he suspected many family court judges would not follow them.
"There should be strict adherence to the guidelines," he said. "But in our experience, that is rarely the case."
Mr. Phillips said the Supreme Court would vote on the guidelines before its summer recess, and if approved, they will take effect in September. The public has until June 15 to submit written comments to the Administrative Office of the Courts.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 4; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 795 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Hyundai Elantra;
Rounding The Rough Edges

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON 

 BODY:
MY wife came through the door, frazzled from the day's work and a long commute by train, and the first words out of her mouth were these, "Whatever that is in the driveway, I'd never have such a car."
What? Hello? 
 "Hi," I said. "Have a good day? And what's wrong with the car?"
"No," she said. "Hello yourself. And it's the color. What color is that?"
Well, the color is strange, I'll grant that. But the car is not so bad. Hyundai calls the hue "pale violet/gray," and I'd already made some notes in which I scribbled that the Elantra is a purple-gray jellybean. It is also one whose brethren just might get snapped up by a lot of people looking for basic transportation.
For the South Korean company, that would be a pleasant change. Hyundai has taken its lumps in America, where the subcompact segment is jammed with competent competition. And there have already been rebates on the new Elantra sedans and wagons, which were introduced in March.
But shoppers will discover this car. And there are other colors.
The '96 Elantra is very rounded, very Chrysler Neon-like, very smooth. It can be had in two trim levels, base and GLS, and it is bigger than before, with an all-new engine that has 13 percent more power than its predecessor had. Hyundai says, too, that it has taken pains to eliminate problems with quality and with the buying experience, following Saturn's example to prove that small prices need not produce big headaches.
The plainest sedan has a price of $11,314, including a $415 delivery charge. The fancier GLS test car had a base sticker of $12,764, about $1,450 less than the GLS wagon, but options brought the price to $14,002.
A four-speed automatic transmission is optional on the GLS, as are anti-lock brakes, alloy wheels and, on the sedan, a rear-deck spoiler. But even without options, the GLS is surprisingly well equipped.
Among the standard features are a five-speed manual transmission, dual air bags and power front disk brakes. Power also works the windows, locks and side mirrors, and you get tinted glass, halogen headlights, intermittent wipers and a rear defroster.
Inside, the Elantra is all gray cloth and vinyl, and you are not likely to forget that this is an econobox. But the amenities are enough to make for a smug trip to the bank. This is a vehicle meant for the cities and the suburbs, for taking the children to soccer games, going to the movies and saving money on the way to where you make it.
There is a tilt wheel, and the driver's seat is six-way adjustable. There are dual air bags, of course, and adjustable mounts for the front seat belts. Twin cup holders slide out of the newly designed dash, which now has a larger instrument pod and a hugely optimistic 140-m.p.h. speedometer.
The seats, like the rest of the car, are molded into curves and covered in softly mottled cloth. Door panels are also smoothly molded and have cloth trim set into vinyl faces. Window switches are on the armrests, which is good, and the back windows go down all the way, proving what can be done with good design even in a small car.
In back, there is reasonable room for three adults, but none will be comfortable for long. The seat, which is split in a 60-40 proportion and folds down for hauling cargo, is flat and about as yielding as a park bench.
Noise isolation was supposedly one main main objective of the Elantra's redo, and the car is indeed tighter. The new 130-horsepower engine is also meant to be quiet, with 90 percent of torque coming at 2,300 r.p.m., the range at which most drivers need it. And when you open the hood, the first thing you see -- in large letters -- is the word "HOT" on a shield covering the engine. That may be a sly comment as well as a warning, and the car is warm in the classic sense, with performance that is snappy enough to be a surprise.
The engine, mounted sideways and driving the front wheels, is much lighter than before. Its maintenance-free aspect, widely noted in the company's ads, results from electronic ignition, self-adjustment of the 16 valves and fewer parts. And the output is impressive for just 1.8 liters, though the fuel economy (24 city, 32 highway) is about average for the small-car pack.
The new four-wheel independent suspension makes the car handle better, and there is less noticeable nose-dive under hard braking. Happily, too, the car is more maneuverable -- even with a two-inch-longer wheelbase and a generally larger size.
That counts for a lot in an around-town automobile whose mission is utility and economy. This is a little car with a pretty face and a likable personality. For some people, it might even work in purple-gray.

INSIDE TRACK: For getting to the show or to the train, the Elantra may be just the ticket.

HEADLINE: We'd Have School Reform If N.J.E.A. Would Cooperate

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Can Our Schools Be Merged?," your June 2 front-page article on regionalization, shed some light on the issue but omitted important unresolved problems. And it left the misleading impression that the State Legislature is a neutral, unbiased body looking for answers. It clearly has answers, but they are not the answers it would like. 
 It would be interesting to see how well and how efficiently New Jersey's schools could perform if they did not have to contend with restrictive, cumbersome and illogical laws -- many at the behest of the New Jersey Education Association, the statewide teachers' union. In a horrifyingly candid admission of the union's influence on the Legislature, John H. Ewing, chairman of the State Senate's Education Committee, recently told members of the New Jersey School Boards Association: "If you people came out and gave $5,000 to legislators, you might have a little more influence. There are a lot more N.J.E.A. members than there are you people."
The union's single sacred cow is tenure. New Jersey is one of just 16 states with this archaic leftover from the days of indiscriminate firings. Tenure is a major obstacle to schools' reacting to changing enrollment or financial needs.
For example, if a school had to eliminate its home economics program, it might expect to let the home economics teacher go. But if that teacher is licensed to teach English and has seniority, she has the right to bump a current English teacher out of a job -- even if she has never taught English.
At a time when corporate America is examining all areas for cost-effectiveness, medical benefits are a prime target. It is common for employees to contribute toward their own medical benefits and to have these benefits on the bargaining table at contract time. But thanks to special legislation passed at the N.J.E.A.'s behest, school boards that belong to the state's largest health carrier group, the State Health Benefits Program, are prohibited from asking for employee contributions and from negotiating any reduction in benefits.
I helped write legislation that allows school boards to join a self-insured fund to save money. My district alone will save $75,000 as a result, and other Bergen County districts will save a total of almost $10 million. Why did it take four years to pass? N.J.E.A. obstructionism.
No complex problem can be solved with a few quick fixes. But when the intent of the Legislature is to work at the problem only in a way that will not upset the teachers' union, then not only will the problem never be solved; in all likelihood it will get worse. At that time, the legislators and the Governor will stand up and say, "See, we told you so!"
 
ALAN R. GEISENHEIMER
Upper Saddle River
 
 The writer is a member of the Northern Highlands Regional High School Board of Education.

HEADLINE: Blue Blood and the Color of Money

BYLINE: By VICTORIA McKEE 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
WELL-HEELED tennis fans should be warming up for the Wimbledon battle in Britain this month. No, not the tennis matches at Wimbledon, but the battle for the title Lord of Wimbledon, which is one of about 30 titles to be auctioned on June 26 by the Manorial Society of Great Britain during the Wimbledon tennis championships.
The title from Wimbledon, home of the All England Lawn Tennis Club, is bound to be the big draw, and Robert Smith of the Manorial Society, which has provisionally valued it at around $75,000, is confident it will go for a sum well into six figures, even though it doesn't carry the rights to a seat at center court. Mr. Smith says he hopes the auction will attract the attention of the lords of tennis like Mark McCormack or John McEnroe. 
 "Since so many top tennis names are American, it has a good chance of going to an American purchaser," Mr. Smith said. "But then, about 30 percent of the titles we sell go to Americans anyway."
The owner of this title, which dates from the 13th century, is the Earl Spencer, the brother of the Princess of Wales. He would like to see it go "to Boris Becker or Mark McCormack," he said. "I'm selling it," said Lord Spencer, a part-time NBC commentator, "to raise the capital to replumb the house at Althorp, which is going to cost 200,000" -- about $300,000. He recently abandoned Althorp, where he and Diana grew up, for a modern house in South Africa.
"I'm also taking away a liability from my son when I die, because you have to pay the Government 40 percent of the value of these lordships anyway, even if you don't use them. So I have about a dozen others to sell, three -- the Lordship of Strixton, the Lordship of Upper Boddington and the Lordship of Newlane Squillers -- to be sold at this auction. Another 10 I wouldn't sell, because they are linked to land that's still in the family, like the Lordship of the Manor of Althorp. But these others, why not? I mean, frankly, there are so many that I'm not going to miss the ones that go."
Because aristocrats are realizing that there is an unmined resource in selling titles, and that it isn't as humiliating as selling the family silver or paintings (as Lord Spencer's stepmother, Raine, was criticized for doing), more and more are coming onto the market, their prices rising faster than house prices, the Manorial Society said.
Let the buyer beware, though. A scandal was uncovered recently, in which advertisements in The Wall Street Journal and The Economist were used to lure Americans into buying nonexistent titles that allegedly would guarantee "priority" on the social list of Queen Elizabeth II. None of the titles being auctioned will get you a seat in the House of Lords, but they might get you a better table in a restaurant.
While the majority of titles are being purchased by nouveau riche Britons, Americans make the largest number of purchasers from ouside Britain. A lordship of a manor can be acquired for as little as $7,000 or as much as $700,000. The feudal Earldom of Arran, the highest title ever sold at auction, went to John de Bruyne, head of Swaine Adeney, umbrella and riding-whip makers to royalty, for nearly that much in 1994.
But that deal fell through, and the title was sold to a Swiss national for about $360,000.
The feudal Earl of Arran must be distinguished from the Earl of Arran, a title held by the Duke of Hamilton. But Mr. de Bruyne said he hoped to use the title to help promote his upmarket British products abroad.
An American entrepreneur, Douglas Hall, who lives in the Eureka Mansion, a 75-acre estate just outside Cincinnati, had a similar motive when he purchased the lordships of Threshfield and Kirkby-on-the-Moor, Yorkshire, for $17,000 and $7,000 respectively, for himself and his business partner David Wecker.
"I'd like us to be able to make some money from endorsing products -- any products," said Mr. Hall, 37, who develops new products for companies as diverse as Nike, Lipton and Disney. "I'm looking at it as a business opportunity," said the new Lord of Threshfield, who bought the title when in London recently with his wife, Debbie, to celebrate their 15th wedding anniversary.
Mr. Hall said he had written into his will that the title should go to his only son Bradford, 5, in keeping with British principles of primogeniture, although "bought" titles can be deeded to anyone.
He said he also planned to start a Lord Threshfield's restaurant, serving his Brain Brew coffee and decorated with pictures of Threshfield, a place he has yet to visit.
Although Mr. Hall would like to call himself Lord Threshfield, that would not be proper by British standards. The "of" in his title, which Americans tend to drop, is vital because the Lord of Threshfield is a less grand title than that of Lord Threshfield, which goes to a hereditary peer entitled to a seat in the House of Lords.
Kathryn Falk, owner of Romantic Times Magazine and author of "How to Write a Romance and Get It Published" (Crown Books, 1983), is the Lady of Barrow, but insists on calling herself Lady Barrow.
"It's just an innocent mistake," said Mr. Smith of the Manorial Society. "We tell them not to, but you can't stop them."
"I now conduct Lady Barrow Tours of London," Miss Falk said, "where we have tea with people like Barbara Cartland and Lord and Lady Bath in their own homes, and I'm starting the Lady Barrow imprint of women's fiction." She is, she said, "in my 50's but in my heart I'm 18." She added, "I've never been married -- I'm too young!"
Few titles for sale come with land, but some have strange rights, which can be worth exploiting. Gerald Rand, an Englishman who bought the Lordship of Lynford title, is expert at extracting the last penny from the mineral rights included in his title, which allow him to claim a tithe from companies quarrying land within his "manor" in Norfolk. Mr. Rand, who bought the title to go with the manor house, Lynford Hall, his stately hotel, also collects for allowing gas, electricity and telephone lines to cross manorial land.
Some titles hold rights to hunt, fish or hold markets or fairs, and a few -- like the Lordship of Henley-in-Arden, bought by Joe Hardy, an American lumber baron, for about $120,000 in 1990, offer the right to preside over a medieval court leet, at which manor business is discussed and the villagers must ask the lord for permission to extend their hedges or erect new fences.
"I've got everything money could buy -- land, art, cars, companies," Mr. Hardy said at the time, "but this has bought me a chance to play with people's lives."
Contrary to his comment, Mr. Hardy has been a benevolent benefactor to the quaint market town near Stratford-upon-Avon, where he has set up a trust fund for the village, which finances village projects and pays for an an annual fireworks display and regatta.
Mr. Hardy, now 74, passed the title two years ago to his daughter Robin Freed-Hardy, who conducts the business of the title on her annual trip to Henley-in-Arden. She is also co-host with her father of a "royal reception" each Labor Day weekend at their Nemecolin Woodlands resort in Pennsylvania, which draws other notables like Prince Michael of Kent and officials from Henley-in-Arden like the high bailiff and town crier.
"We like mixing with other titled people," Robin Hardy said. "Although having the title hasn't changed me, what it has done is given me the opportunity to meet people I would never have met in my ordinary life, and it's an awful lot of fun!"
The Manoral Society is one of several houses like Sotheby's or Strutt & Parker's that auction royal titles. But the society, which provides social activities for its members, charges an annual fee of 20 (about $30) and offers a newsletter, guidance on designing a suitable coat of arms through the College of Arms and invitations to social gatherings like a Christmas carol service and dinner in London, or a Valentine's ball -- at which tiaras and manorial insignia may be worn.
Seena Davis, or the Lady of Barnham Broom, added, "I wear a tiara to all formal occasions."
Mrs. Davis is the wife of Arnold Davis, an art dealer and retired real estate executive, with homes in Manhattan and Scarsdale, N.Y. He bought the Lordship of Barnham Broom in Norfolk years ago for an undisclosed sum. But like Joe Hardy, he has put even more into it.
"We've given money for prizes at the local school and church, lent pictures for an exhibition and gave a big dinner party for everyone in Barnham Broom," said Mr. Davis, who travels regularly to Britain to buy paintings by the masters.
"We haven't got anything tangible out of the title," Mrs. Davis said, "but it has opened up all different avenues for us, and we've enjoyed most the friends we've made through it." The Davises would now like to buy titles for each of their two daughters and three grandchildren. Perhaps Wimbledon will be perfect for a budding tennis player.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Medicare Proposal Covers Costs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Medicare Argument" (editorial, June 4) suggests that a "serious, bipartisan effort" is needed to reform Medicare and that the Republican plan "was a move in the right direction." I strongly agree. 
 Since President Clinton vetoed Medicare reform as part of the balanced budget passed by Congress last year, this vital program will go bankrupt one year sooner than estimated just a year ago -- in 2001 rather than 2002.
In fact, Medicare is worse off by $114 billion today than it would have been had the President signed our legislation last year.
I would like to clarify one important point you make. Contrary to what you assert, the Congressional Budget Office has never stated that medical costs are increasing at a rate that exceeds spending under the Republican plan.
Here are the facts according to the Budget Office: Inflation accounts for 2.9 percent and increased enrollment accounts for 1.3 percent. Taken together these amount to a 4.2 percent growth rate. This is far less than the 7.2 percent growth rate of the Republican plan as included in the Balanced Budget Act of 1995.
The G.O.P. proposal more than covers inflation and the anticipated number of senior citizens enrolled in Medicare in 2002. Further, our program would have increased spending per person from $4,800 to $7,250 by the year 2002.
 
NEWT GINGRICH
Speaker of the House
Washington, June 6, 1996

HEADLINE: Tough or Lenient? It's a Question of Risk

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
WHERE companies stand on how the Government should deal with China -- whether to impose sanctions for pirating software and music, whether to renew China's most-favored-nation trade status -- is usually a direct function of how much they have at risk.
On sanctions, those urging the most conciliatory approach have the most to lose if China lashes out because of American pressure. Among them are the National Retail Federation. Its members -- Sears, Kmart and Toys "R" Us among them -- went to Washington last week to denounce the 100 percent tariffs that will be slapped on a range of made-in-China clothing if sanctions are invoked later this month. The federation has denounced the sanctions as "illegal" and "disastrous for consumers." 
 The nation's silk distributors, which depend on China for all of their supplies, warned that the Administration's action would "devastate hundreds of small American companies and thousands of workers."
The main proponent of the Administration's get-tough-on-pirates strategy, not surprisingly, is Hollywood. No one has pressed harder for sanctions than Jack Valenti, the lobbyist for the Motion Picture Association who has worked the capital since he was an aide to Lyndon B. Johnson. Mr. Valenti wants to make sure that the Administration's will does not weaken at the last minute, as it did in negotiations over market access to Europe in 1993. He has been backed up by record companies like Sony and video game makers like Nintendo of America -- both owned by Japanese parents that are pressing for American action because they know their own Government in Tokyo will not risk a confrontation with China.
Some industries, however, are deeply divided. General Motors has backed the Administration's strategy. But Ford, presumably fearful that China will block its efforts to open bigger joint ventures, has enraged many in the White House by denouncing the threat of unilateral sanctions as counterproductive.
"We saved their butts in the auto talks last year," one senior Administration official fumed the other day, referring to last year's showdown with Japan over automotive trade, "and in China they stiff-arm us."
And just as the Clinton Administration is divided on whether threatening sanctions can truly change China's behavior or merely stiffen its resistance, there is considerable dissent within many companies over what tactics to endorse.
In Washington, for example, Boeing and Microsoft have joined the chorus of praise for the Administration's hard line, contending that unless China is forced to live up to its agreement to protect intellectual property, it will not become a nation of laws where investors can operate without fear of exploitation.
But ask executives working for those same companies in Hong Kong or Shanghai, and their view is often far more pragmatic. Concerned about meeting their sales quotas for the quarter or the year, they dismiss as starry-eyed any hope that Washington's series of confrontations will fundamentally change the way China does business.
"Sanctions get you no place," a Microsoft official who frequently works on the company's China strategy said recently. China's plan, he said, "is to close down a few factories for a few months" to make American negotiators "shut up and go away."
Even the supporters of sanctions say the cycle of confrontation is undermining American credibility in China. As soon as the short-term argument over piracy is resolved, they argue, the only sensible long-term strategy is to end the annual debate over renewing China's most-favored-nation status, which despite the name simply gives China the low tariffs that almost every other trading partner enjoys. In short, they not only want to divorce most-favored-nation treatment from China's human rights record -- the step Mr. Clinton took two years ago -- they want to divorce it from every political dispute with China, whether the issue is missile proliferation or Taiwan.
"Do we really believe we can change overnight a culture that thinks in terms of dynasties?" asked John F. Smith Jr., chairman of General Motors, a company that, after years of neglect of Asia, now says the region is the key to expanding American exports. While America goes through its annual political ritual and flails China's behavior, he fumed in a recent speech, "our competitors from Japan and Europe sign new deals, which tie China closer to their economies." In fact, just days after the sanctions threat was issued, Toyota's president visited China to seal a deal for a major engine factory, on the heels of a Government-led trade mission from Britain.
But most-favored-nation status still has many opponents, from the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which fears jobs are being lost to China, to textile manufacturers. which say China has violated its agreements to limit textile exports and doesn't deserve the status.
Still, many China hands agree that the annual Congressional threat to revoke the trading privileges is doing more harm than good. "There is simply no historical precedent," Jeffrey E. Garten, the dean of the Yale School of Management and formerly a regular negotiator with China for the Administration, wrote recently, "for one powerful nation treating another with constant threats while still retaining a viable relationship."
