HEADLINE: POLITICS: NEW MEDIA;
Pete du Pont Set to Join On-Line Policy Debate

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
With varying degrees of skepticism, trepidation and excitement, print journalists and paperless cyber-scribes have been awaiting the ballyhooed debut this summer of Slate, the Microsoft-backed on-line magazine to be edited by Michael Kinsley, formerly of The New Republic and Crossfire.
Meanwhile, in relative obscurity, Pete du Pont, former Governor of Delaware and erstwhile Republican Presidential candidate, has been laboring here to start another public-policy journal in a raw medium where, he noted, "people aren't always polite." 
 Yet another politician leaping into the rapidly diversifying news media, Mr. du Pont, who will edit the journal, is clearly enjoying himself.
"Aren't these amazing machines!" he said this week, watching a mock version of the magazine scroll across a computer screen in its publisher's offices here. The first issue of the weekly -- whose name is IntellectualCapital.com -- is scheduled to appear on June 20.
Slipping into on-line patois, Mr. du Pont describes the journal as a "public-policy e-zine of opinion." He said it would stick out among the proliferating electronic publications -- a babel of biting commentary, researched articles and sophomoric maundering -- by offering meatier fare to appeal to viewers of "The News Hour with Jim Lehrer," readers of The New Republic and The National Review and students of government everywhere.
Mr. du Pont said that, in addition to his own conservative editorial, he would feature several columns from a stable of 26 regular contributors. He said their views would range from liberal to conservative. "It's a much more intellectually aggressive atmosphere," Mr. du Pont, already a syndicated columnist in the newsprint world, said of life on the World Wide Web. "And I think more fun."
It may not all be fun. Skeptics said that a magazine whose logo displays Rodin's "Thinker" superimposed on a CD-ROM disk may be ill-suited to the anarchy of the Web.
"It's not a top-down medium where gasbags dispense wisdom," said Jon Katz, a contributing editor to Wired magazine, who writes the "Media Rant" column for the Netizen, the politics and media Web site of the on-line publication HotWired. "It's much more individualistic. It's much more open."
But it is by drawing a highbrow crowd that the journal's publishers, A2S2 Digital Projects, hope to solve the critical problem for electronic journals -- by actually making money. Rather than charge for subscriptions, they want to draw large advertisers. So far, none have signed on.
"But we're talking to several," said Sam Sneed, managing director of A2S2 and what the magazine calls its "executive producer of interactive applications."
By contract, Mr. Kinsley has said he intends to charge readers of Slate a fee, as yet undisclosed, if they are not members of the Microsoft Network. He has also said he would sell advertising for his more ambitious magazine of opinion, politics and the arts, which is to go on line soon.
Mr. du Pont, in deference to the difficulty some people find reading on line, said his columns would be short, about 500 words, and rendered in large type. He plans to devote articles to a "hot issue" and to interesting ideas from think tanks, and to include a grab bag called "Quips, Quotes, and Quibbles."
The journal will hold an on-line forum once a week and solicit reader contributions.
Mr. du Pont said he had commitments from 20 of the 26 writers. He declined to name any but James K. Glassman, a television host and columnist with The Washington Post.
Mr. Glassman, who plans to write on politics and economics, said he was anxious to reach the on-line population. "I'm not really sure who's out there," he said. "We're obviously in a pioneering stage, and I'd like to be one of the pioneers."
While he acknowledged a lingering preference for newsprint, Mr. du Pont, who is 61, said that his children read their news on line. He expressed confidence that such computer devotees would sort through the on-line clutter of news and opinion to find a publication offering respected names engaged in informed debate.
"In the long run," Mr. du Pont said, "quality is what counts."

HEADLINE: First Lady Advocates Education Spending

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., June 8

 BODY:
Speaking to community college students and newspaper editors in Florida today, Hillary Rodham Clinton appealed for "renewed investment" in education by both government and individuals.
In the separate appearances in Orlando, before addressing a Democratic Party banquet, Mrs. Clinton stressed the theme that education is a key ingredient to the nation's economic progress and moral security. 
 In talking to students at Valencia Community College, Mrs. Clinton campaigned for her husband's proposal to create a scholarship plan to provide $1,500 in tax credits for each of two years of college.
At both events, Mrs. Clinton said that there was a gap between those who qualify for public assistance and loan programs to attend college and those who are ineligible because their grades fall short or whose parents make too much money.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE TAX ISSUE;
Dole and Clinton Refocus on Tax-Cut Plans as an Option

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL and DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
When President George Bush broke his "Read my lips, no new taxes" pledge in the spring of 1990, many Republicans lamented that he had handed away the Reagan legacy.
Two years later, Mr. Bush was defeated by Bill Clinton, a Democrat who ran on a platform that promised tax breaks -- a middle-class tax cut, he called it. But Mr. Clinton, too, turned around once in office, and put into place a deficit-reduction plan that included large new taxes. 
 Now, as the 1996 Presidential campaign moves into its final five months, both parties are once again homing in on tax cutting as a far more appealing economic theme than deficit reduction. President Clinton hopes to avoid the tax-and-spend label that Republicans like to pin on Democrats. And Republicans want to return to the theme that proved so successful for them under Ronald Reagan.
Aiming to unveil an economic plan around the time of the Republican convention, aides to Senator Bob Dole are drafting a tax plan they hope will be as bold and popular as Mr. Reagan's call in 1980 for an across-the-board tax cut. Their problem is to do so without making a mockery of Mr. Dole's long record of fighting doggedly for deficit reduction.
Meanwhile, launching a series of pre-emptive strikes, Mr. Clinton has thrown his support behind Republican proposals for a repeal of the gasoline tax increase he sponsored in 1993 and for a tax credit to help offset adoption expenses. He has also called for small businesses to receive a 10 percent income tax credit for employee education and training.
Last week, after a struggle inside his Administration, Mr. Clinton came out with a tax credit proposal designed to make the first two years of community college virtually free for those who maintain good grades.
Although neither side in the Presidential campaign has tipped its hand completely on tax policy, a clear policy choice seems to be emerging.
Mr. Clinton advocates limited tax breaks designed to assist the middle class and the working poor with special attention to child rearing, job training and education.
Mr. Dole has already proposed a $500-a-taxpayer credit for contributions to charities that help poor people. But, seeking to draw a sharp distinction with Mr. Clinton, he is also examining far more sweeping proposals: everything from an across-the-board income tax cut to some kind of tax system with fewer brackets and lower rates. He has said that the country should "scrap the current tax code and start again from scratch."
Both candidates' approaches raise doubts among many mainstream economists. In Mr. Clinton's case, the analysts say that tax breaks are an inefficient way to accomplish social goals like better education. In Mr. Dole's case, they worry that politically acceptable spending cuts could never be found to offset large tax cuts and that the consequence would be the reversal of progress that has been made in deficit reduction.
Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire, this week upbraided both men for their tax cut fever. "Take a poll, find out what you want to hear and tell you that and get elected and don't do it," he said.
But the political appeal of tax cutting is apparent.
"It's clear from polling that if you put a candidate who is for some kind of tax cut against a candidate who opposes any tax cut in the name of deficit reduction, the candidate who opposes the tax cut loses," said one Democratic consultant. "At a strategic level, it's very important not to fall into this tax trap."
From the Republican perspective, Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan, a close associate of Senator Dole's, said: "I want to have a tax debate. I think it will help focus the country on the differences between Bob Dole and Bill Clinton and where they would take the country."
 
The Dole Record
 
Longtime Supporter Of Deficit Reduction
For Mr. Dole, the stakes in this debate are enormous. He desperately needs to energize a Presidential campaign that polls show has failed to get a lift even from his decision to leave the Senate.
But Mr. Dole, the Kansas Senator, has long disdained the tax-cutting apostles of the Reagan wing of the Republican Party and their contention that tax cuts spur enough economic growth to pay for themselves. The "good news is that a bus full of supply-siders went over a cliff," he once said. "The bad news is that there were three empty seats."
As the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Dole loyally led the fight in the Senate for the 1981 Reagan tax cuts. But one year later he broke ranks with the supply-siders and pushed a tax increase to reduce the Federal deficits that had already begun to accumulate.
"In my view, constituents are at least a year ahead of us," he said in 1983. "They don't know why we cut taxes when we have deficits; they don't know why we spend more and more money when we have deficits."
But last year, when he announced his Presidential candidacy, Mr. Dole said: "We can cut taxes and balance the budget. Middle-class families are forced to send too much of their hard-earned money to Washington."
Mr. Dole has yet to tip his hand on the shape of his tax program beyond saying it will be "an economic growth package." His aides expect his proposal to encompass both a change in the tax structure toward a tax system with fewer brackets and a tax cut of perhaps 15 percent. This is far more sweeping than Mr. Clinton's approach, which the Dole camp derides as "these little pinprick, micro-tax-cut announcements."
After a group of conservative economists and senators met with Mr. Dole last month, John Taylor from Stanford University wrote a memorandum outlining "growth-oriented economic policies" that the Senator could propose.
Mr. Taylor, summarizing the ideas raised at the meeting, suggested that Mr. Dole would advocate that a completely new tax system be in place by the turn of the century.
In the meantime, Mr. Taylor wrote, the Senator should propose tax cuts that could cost tens of billions of dollars a year in lost revenue, including an across-the-board reduction in tax rates for all taxpayers, a lower capital gains tax and tax-free savings accounts that could be used for education expenses or to offset an unexpected loss of income.
In addition, the memorandum said Mr. Dole should balance the budget in four years, two years sooner than either President Clinton or Republicans in Congress are contemplating.
Mr. Taylor's memo did not address how Government spending should be reduced.
 
The Clinton Record
 
Rethinking Policy After a Tax Increase
Mr. Clinton is vulnerable in his own way. Running for President four years ago, he promised middle-income taxpayers a choice between a tax credit for each child and a reduction in their income-tax rate.
Instead, when Mr. Clinton came into office, he asserted that lowering the deficit had to be the nation's first economic priority. He pushed through Congress in 1993 a budget and tax package that passed without a single Republican vote.
Most of the higher taxes were placed on the wealthy. But the middle class bore the brunt of the gasoline-tax increase, and many Social Security beneficiaries ended up with higher income taxes.
Republicans have already gleefully aired one campaign commercial featuring footage of Mr. Clinton last autumn trying to disown his tax package. ("People in this room still get mad at me over the budget because you think I raised your taxes too much," he said at a Texas fundraising dinner. "It might surprise you to know I think I raised them too much, too.")
Should the President unveil a broad new tax proposal closer to Election Day, the Republicans say they have a commercial ready that showcases his unfulfilled 1992 pledge.
When the public repudiated Mr. Clinton's party in 1994, giving the Republicans control of Congress, the President responded almost immediately with a package of tax cuts he called the "Middle Class Bill of Rights."
The package included a $10,000 annual tax deduction for college or vocational education expenses, a $500 tax credit for each child under age 13, and expanded income limits and flexibility for individual retirement accounts. The package allowed Mr. Clinton to say he stood for tax cuts, but it became a casualty of the budget standoff between the President and Congress.
With Republicans examining tax cutting as a major theme of the Presidential race, Mr. Clinton took more pre-emptive steps in the past few weeks to inoculate himself, agreeing to several Republican tax reduction proposals.
But his decision to offer a new $1,500 tax credit for the first two years of higher education -- encouraged by his political adviser, Dick Morris -- met opposition from an economic team that thinks Mr. Clinton should count his reduction in the deficit as one of his proudest achievements.
Participants in the debate say that the President's chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, joined by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, Mr. Clinton's national economic adviser, and Alice M. Rivlin, the budget director, fought to scale back the original idea. They made sure it was accompanied by other tax increases and revenue-raising measures so that it would not increase the deficit.
 
Public Opinion
 
Economists Worry About 'Bidding War'
Politicians seem to be much more enthusiastic than the public, mainstream economists or the financial markets about the idea of cutting taxes.
The latest New York Times/CBS News poll found that only 2 percent of those questioned thought high taxes were the most serious problem facing the country. Other polls have consistently shown over the years that given the choice of balancing the budget or cutting taxes, the public opts for balancing the budget by a wide margin.
Economists disagree over the wisdom of lowering taxes. Conservatives generally support the idea, and liberals oppose it. But most economists, regardless of their ideology, accept these points:
*Continued reduction of the budget deficit would do more for the economy than either an across-the-board tax cut or tax breaks that encourage education and training.
*The Federal Reserve Board would use its authority over interest rates to dampen the effect of any short-term economic lift from a tax cut.
*The price of gasoline is determined mostly by the price of oil in world markets. Repealing the 4.3-cents-a- gallon additional gasoline tax that was enacted in 1993 would have little effect on what consumers pay at the pump.
*Tax breaks are an inefficient way of achieving social policy goals.
"There's a tremendous danger that bad ideas launched in an election year might have to be actually proposed by the next President," said Robert D. Reischauer, an economist who was director of the Congressional Budget Office when Democrats controlled Congress.
Many economists would endorse the idea of Senator Dole's advisers for a 15 percent reduction in all tax rates if they thought offsetting spending cuts would be adopted. But they are skeptical that would happen, and they worry about a repeat of the 1980's, when lower taxes without accompanying spending cuts led to a mushrooming deficit.
"If the bidding war in Washington continues to escalate," said David Hale, an economist at Zurich Kem per Investments in Chicago, "investors will become concerned about expansion of the Federal deficit."
The 15 percent reduction would cost the Treasury about $90 billion a year in lost revenue, according to Bruce Bartlett, an economist who is one of the idea's strongest proponents. Offsetting that would require spending cuts about 50 percent larger than those approved by Congress in its budget resolution this year.
The advocates of deep, across-the-board tax reductions hold that such a measure would lead the economy to grow faster than the 2 percent to 2.5 percent annual rate anticipated. Mr. Bartlett calculates that a 15 percent tax cut would increase growth by three-tenths of 1 percent. Senator Abraham suggests that it might lead to a full percentage-point increase.
The idea of an across-the-board tax reduction also creates a tension in Republican ranks between those who want to stimulate growth and those who favor direct assistance to families. The Contract With America, the platform on which Republicans ran for Congress two years ago, promised each family a $500 tax reduction for each child. Even the most ardent tax cutters doubt that both a large reduction in rates and a big break for families with children would be enacted.
Mr. Bartlett said: "I personally believe the contract was ill-conceived. A $500 child credit doesn't do anything for the economy."
But Gary Bauer, president of the Family Research Council, which takes a conservative approach to social issues, said that he and his associates would fight hard to maintain the tax cut for families. "The party misses the boat if it offers a purely economic package," he said.
President Clinton's proposal to give families a tax credit of up to $1,500 a year to help meet the cost of the first two years of college and Senator Dole's proposed tax credit for charitable contributions both violate a tenet held by most economists that tax policy should not be used to achieve social goals.
"If you're going to tie a tax credit to social policy, you ought to have a very strong case for doing that and not just spending the money directly," said C. Eugene Steuerle, who was a top tax policy official in the Reagan Administration.
The education credit, said Mr. Reischauer, would provide tax relief to many people who do not need it to afford college. If money is available, he said, it would be better spent on direct grants and loans to students.
Voters are skeptical they will ever see a tax cut, whatever happens during the campaign this year. In The New York Times/CBS News poll, 2 percent said they thought Mr. Clinton would reduce their taxes, and 10 percent said they thought Mr. Dole would do so.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 1282 words

HEADLINE: Many Fear Chad Election Won't End Its Misery

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: NDJAMENA, Chad, June 3

 BODY:
For more than 30 of its 36 years of independence from France, this vast, mostly desolate country - one of the world's poorest - has been gripped by civil wars.
 
 So when Chad held its first presidential election this week, the event offered a ray of hope for many voters, who withstood long lines and a rare downpour to choose from a field of 15 candidates.
 But many analysts of African affairs say that rather than to open a bright future for a distressed country, the election here - like several other recent votes across this continent - could simply underscore Chad's fragility.
 Life so many other countries carved out by foreign mapmakers in Europe's imperial scramble for Africa in the 19th country, Chad has been bedeviled ever since by their arbitrary choices, both geographic and ethnic, whose unforeseen but often tragic effects are still being played out.
 Inventing Chad, colonial masters in France randomly threw populations together that had been separated by everything from vast distances and historical enmities to religion and livelihood.
 As in Rwanda and Nigeria, two countries that have also suffered devastating civil wars, decisions on Chad by early colonizers about which groups to educate and which to maintain under traditional rule helped set the stage for hatred and bloodshed that persists to this day.
 Today, in this miserable country, where per capita income is about 50 cents a day, the recent discovery by an American oil company of huge reserves of oil might, like the election, stand out as a sign of hope.
 But in the volatile political jumble that ismodern Chad, this news, like most important developments here, can just as readily be seen as a source of renewed conflict.
 "It is hard to imagine what you would have had here if there was no Chad," said one Western diplomat. "But the ethnic fabric of the country we've ended up with its endlessly complicated. It is not just north-south division, it is east-west and all over the place."
 Many people doubt that the election will change this reality.
 When the incumbent President, a former guerrilla leader from the north named Idriss Deby, organized a referendum on a new Constitution in March, the measure passed with 65 percent of the vote, helped along by a bit of ballot fixing, diplomats say. But 95 percent of southern voters opposed the bill, which was seen as a northern creation.
 The presidential election, which will be decided in a runoff between the two leading candidates - whose names have not yet been announced - at the end of this month, is expected to be just as polarizing, and given raw hatreds between regions, potentially explosive.
 From the early colonial period at the start of this century, French administrators and missionaries concentrated their nation-building efforts on the territory's more densely populated, animist south.
 An army was assembled from the southern Sara ethnic group, and the few schools created for Chadians were in this fertile part of the country, which the French named "Le Tchad utile," or useful Chad.
 In the mainly Muslim, Arabic-speaking north, meanwhile, Paris made little attempt to change traditional structures. Colonial forts were established to stop raids by desert nomads, but little else was built in the north, and the population was largely left to its own devices.
 As independence in 1960 approached, these decisions by the French gave southerners a formidable advantage in determining who would run the new country. Before long, Chad's first leader, Francois (later changed to Ngarta) Tombalbaye, was lording it over northerners, who were resented in the south for their centuries - old practice of slave-trading raids.
 Mr. Tombalbaye was killed in a coup in 1975, but not before he had taken his regional vision to its logical extreme. As his grip on power grew more tenuous, Mr. Tombalbaye recruited a Haitian religious adviser and began a brutal "cultural revolution" in which he obliged people to abandon Christian names and forced Government workers and army officers of whatever origin to undergo traditional southern initiation rites. Those who refused were often buried alive or shot.
 In 1982, a northern-led guerrilla movement overthrew the southern elite, and northerners have ruled just as brutally over the south ever since.
 Today, Chad has become as fragmented a state as any in Africa. In a country that is two-and-a-half times the size of France but has only 200 miles of roads, the control of the central Government extends only to the capital, Ndjamena, and most of the other main provincial cities.
 Nearly every region of Chad is peppered with a bewildering variety of ethnically based guerrilla forces, which, even movement about the country perilous even for army troops. In the south, which is the only agriculturally viable region, violence between Government forces and local resistance groups often makes farming impossible.
 The core of the military itself is widely seen as little more than an ethnic militia recruited from President Deby's Zakhawa clan. Many Chadians see the army itself as the principal source of insecurity.
 A foreign visitor got a taste of this the other day, when soliders stopped the United Nations jeep in which he was riding at a roadblock 30 miles north of the capital and announced boldly: "Follow us to our headquarters. We need your vehicle."
 Only after lengthy discussions was the vehicle allowed to leave, but Chadians say that vehicles commandeered in this way are often sold in neighboring Sudan.
 Even as they voted last week, many Chadians said they feared that the legacy of ethnic and regional division here, compounded by a now-entrenched tradition of wielding power by force, meant that more violence lies ahead.
 "Every Chadian has a bit of the rebel in him; it suffices to put five or six of us together to bring it out," said one southern voter. "If these elections go badly, people here will certainly go on the warpath. If things go resonably well, maybe we will have a year or two of respite before trouble breaks out again."
 For many, a possible source of trouble is also the potential source of Chad's salvation: oil reserves estimated at more than one billion barrels found near the town of Doba in the south earlier this decade by Exxon. A consortium led by Exxon has plans to build a pipeline from the Doba fields to the coast of neighboring Cameroon to bring these reserves to market.
 Windfalls like these have fueled powerful centrifugal forces time and again in Africa, most notably in Nigeria. There, an army dominated since colonial times by people from the economically barren north has repeatedly resorted to force, from coups to widespread repression, to keep politicians from the better-educated and oil-rich south from either leading secession movements or wielding real political power.
 When a southener, Moshood K. Abiola, won Nigeria's last presidential election in 1993, northern officers threw him in prison for claiming his mandate and have ruled the country with a tight grip ever since.
 Already in Chad, where the oil income is still a few years off, apprehension is rising that a southern population that has felt put-upon for over 15 years will use any means, from secession to sabotage, to keep their historic enemies in the north from controlling this new wealth.
 "There is already great resentment of the presence of northerners throughout the south," said Robert Buytenhuys, a Dutch expert on Chadian politics who foresees growing separatist pressures. "In a way, it is a pity they've discovered oil. It makes the dream of a federal state in Chad that much more remote."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In the Islamic neighborhoods of Ndjamena, the capital, women lined up separately from men to cast their ballots in the election, which many observers fear will not do much to overcome Chad's violent history. (Robert Grossman for The New York Times); Map: Government control in Chad hardly extends beyond Ndjamena. (The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2752 words

HEADLINE: It's a Face-Lifted, Tummy-Tucked Jungle Out There

BYLINE: By AMY M. SPINDLER 

 BODY:
THE shrinkage of the great white-collar corporate institutions over the last five years has endangered a few institutions of another type: the C.E.O. belly, the wizened Walter Cronkite face of experience, the high forehead of a seasoned intellect, the furrowed brow of the thinking man.
Now, in this age of downsizing, success must feel slightly uncomfortable, a world away from the fat-cat executive style savored by the fathers of today's corporate men. Executives are taking their hard-earned salaries and applying them in a way that executive-placement firms are endorsing: measures to look younger, with smooth skin, a full head of hair and a taut stomach. Unlike Calvin Klein underwear models with washboard stomachs, executives looking for jobs (or trying to hold onto them) don't have three hours a day to devote to the gym. What they do have, if they're working in one of these leaner and meaner companies, is more responsibility and the physiques that go with that stress. They complain about bags under their eyes, wrinkles, graying and thinning hair, rolls in the midsection. 
 And so, as if to prove true the proverb "Where one door closes, another opens," downsizing seems to have helped spur a boom in another area: businesses that offer shortcuts for making men look young, healthy and fit. Call it an era of faux fitness.
So someone like Steven Friedman, 45, a management consultant in Potomac, Md., has plenty of companies willing to provide him products and services to help him look young and competitive, without wasting a lot of his time. His shaving cream has aloe to keep his skin moist and ward off wrinkles. He goes to a hair stylist instead of a barber to cut his hair long on top and short on the temples -- where the gray is.
And he is not ashamed a bit of caving in to the same sort of quick-fix cosmetic marketing ploys that women have faced for years as they have fought to look young.
"My wife makes fun of me," Mr. Friedman said. But "packaging is important."
Mr. Friedman needn't stop with a little aloe and a good shearing. He could buy the medicinally packaged Rogaine to thicken his hair.
He could invest in Bodyslimmers underwear for men, by the designer Nancy Ganz, with built-in support to suck in the waist. Or he could skip the aloe and go on to a more drastic measure, new to the male market: alpha-hydroxy products that slough off dead skin. Or he could rub on some belly- and thigh-shrinking creams, which even if ineffective offer a placebo-like comfort far less strenuous than the Nautilus AB/AD machine.
In fact, if even rubbing cream seems too strenuous, men today can just don an undershirt from Mountainville House, to "shape up and pull in loose stomachs and sagging chests," with a diamond-shaped insert at the gut for "extra control" ($19.95). Or buy a pair of Super Shaper Briefs, which for $24.95 round out a man's assets. They offer the added bonus of an "endowment pad," for $5, that can be slipped into the front.
In other words, this new youth movement is all window dressing, not the desire to sweat and burn of the fitness craze. And some see manipulation in all these faux fixes.
"Our parents weren't faced with all these studies by quasi-business experts with messages of how important youthful looks are today," said Michael Lafavore, executive editor of Men's Health magazine, which has reached a circulation of 1.3 million with its well-timed, quick-fix headlines like "5-Minute Muscle Builders," "Lose 9 Pounds Without Even Trying" and "After-Work Energizers."
"We buy into it, and we're being marketed to heavily," he said. "If anything, companies have discovered men are open to this message. And that opened the floodgates."
That flood has even brought profits to those who provide youth from under the knife.
Plastic surgery offers pectoral implants to make the chest appear more muscular, and calf muscle implants to give the leg a bodybuilder shape. There is liposuction to counter thickening middles and accumulating breast and fatty tissue in the chest. There are a half-dozen surgical methods for tightening skin and temporarily delaying the inevitable aged face.
"There was a time," said Richard Tyler, the men's clothing designer, "when all that men had to combat aging was Grecian Formula."
Mr. Tyler is part of a group of designers extending the new anti-aging arsenal beyond surgery and exotic products, to a staple of business: the suit.
"Because of downsizing, the 50-year-old is in competition with the 30-year-old," said J. Stanley Tucker, vice president and fashion director of Saks Fifth Avenue, who was recently asked to offer a conference on dressing after corporate downsizing for Lee Hecht Harrison, a job-search firm. His advice: look current, like young men do. "Customers are coming in wanting to look younger," he said. "They aren't coming in and buying replacement clothes, which is unusual. They really are buying clothes that make them look younger."
The industry is listening to these preferences, devising tricks to cover lumps and to help customers compete with younger men who have grown up with designer suits. Mr. Tyler even had a trunk show for his slim suits at Bergdorf Goodman, the sort of indulgence once reserved for society ladies. He said many men well over 40 were buying three of his slim suits at a time.
"Why they like our suit," he said, "is the cut makes you look like you take care of yourself more than you do."
Fear of younger rivals looms large for the age-aware working man. "It's a youth-dominated world," Mr. Friedman said. "The more youthful you look, the better the reception will be" in the workplace.
So while serious businessmen once felt that changing fashion was beneath their concern, an outdated suit now raises questions about the wearer's outdatedness in other areas.
WITH all the new camouflage available, James Kennedy, the publisher of Executive Recruiter News, has a new name for today's job seeker: the Bionic Executive.
"Does he or doesn't he?" Mr. Kennedy said. "From head to toe, today's male executive job seeker looks more and more like the Bionic Man. From the hairpiece or dye job through face lifts and mouth bridgework to tummy tuckers and elevator shoes, the executive in transition can look a dozen years younger. But what will we think of him in the morning before he's had a chance to put his makeup on?"
In fact, makeup is the only beauty product not yet making inroads for men.
For instance, sales of a Clairol product, Men's Choice hair coloring, have risen 30 percent in three years. The company financed a recent study that found 10 percent of the 45 million American men in their 40's and 50's were coloring their hair.
"At one time, a man in a salon was an odd commodity," said Louis Licari, a colorist who owns salons in Los Angeles and New York, and who is a consultant for Clairol. "But in New York, where men are more progressive, it's normal to look behind the newspaper and find a man in the chair."
That increase is solely because men want to hide gray hair, he said. Men don't go to the salon for the sort of fashion effects that women use, like highlights. "Women's hair can look colored because it's an acknowledged beauty accessory," he said. "Men come to combat the signs of aging."
Focusing on these fears helped the men's grooming industry rise from a rut that began in the 1970's, when Aramis introduced the first men's beauty products. When Aramis's offerings, like fake-suntan cream, didn't catch on, men could mostly find cologne at the cosmetics counter. By stressing anti-aging benefits, the new wave of products has made wide inroads. Department stores are expanding their men's grooming areas to make way for products like Polo Sport Face Fitness AHA Moisture Formula ("refining, moisturizing and protecting") and Aramis Lift Off ("provides the quickest, easiest way to moisturize skin and eliminate patches"). While sales of Lift Off have grown 20 to 30 percent a year since its debut four years ago, the harder-sell tactics of Ralph Lauren seem to work best.
Ralph Lauren's Face Fitness, introduced in 1995, became the No. 1 men's alpha-hydroxy product in the department store market with the help of lengthy informational advertising campaigns. Here's one cheerful thought that is bringing men to the cosmetic counter: "Your face just got a year older and by the end of this winter, that seven-layer cake you call skin could look like it's been freeze-dried." Ouch.
It seems more than coincidence that in 1994, when downsizing was rampant, Polo Ralph Lauren, Clinique and Aramis all created successful lines of men's skin-care products, for the first time suggesting that wrinkles weren't character lines but were worth paying to avoid. Chanel recently introduced a line called Technique Pour Homme, including an alpha-hydroxy lotion.
"I see the boom going back to 1988 when the downsizing really began," said Allan Mottus, editor of The Informationist, a cosmetics trade publication. "It's not just the men's skin-care products, but the men's hair-coloring products business is booming. People with seniority who expected to stay on to retirement were those being let go first, those in the 40's on up. Men need to be competitive not only with their peer group but with those 10 years younger than they are. There is a stress on appearance."
While people in the cosmetics industry may be smiling at that news, businessmen in other fields are dealing with another equation: youth equals success.
AND men who are not yet worried about that development will get their placidity zapped fast if they find themselves facing one of the biggest forces in this downsized era: the executive search firm. Saying appearances count more than ever, these firms strongly advise jobless executives to get on with fitness regimens, hair dye and sharper dress.
"Part of an executive's success is their ability to package themselves," said Dale Winston, president of Battalia Winston International. "It's like all package goods: you don't want to put your cereal in a gray box. Look at Bob Dole. Is he walking around with white hair? Go walk through the executive suite. You don't see many pouchy-looking people."
Executive placement firms stop short of telling men to get facial work. But men seem to be getting the idea on their own.
According to the American Academy of Cosmetic Surgery, men accounted for 10 percent of all plastic-surgery patients in 1980. But by 1994, they were 26 percent.
While 197,276 men in 1994 underwent hair transplants, the most common plastic surgery for men, there are many other procedures they can undergo. Liposuction was performed on 37,743 men that year, for instance, while 18,350 men had eyelid surgery. Other procedures include dermabrasion and face lifts (trickier for men, who don't always have hairlines to hide scars), as well as corrective work on the pronounced grooves between the eyebrows that give some men a constant stern look.
As for wrinkles, patients can try chemical peels or laser treatments.
"A youthful look gives the appearance of a more dynamic, charging individual who will go out and get the business," said Dr. Thomas Romo 3d, who runs the plastic surgery department at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. "The concepts downsized corporations are dealing with are lean and mean. They don't want guys who look fat and happy."
PRICES for these operations vary widely, according to statistics from the surgery group. Simple vein surgery costs $190, on average, while an eyelid operation goes for $1,504 and a pectoral implant is $4,000. Then there are combination procedures. At Dr. Romo's office in the Wall Street area -- where men account for 35 percent of the practice, compared with 10 to 15 percent five years ago -- men with aging, weakening chins can get liposuction and a chin implant for $3,500 to $4,500.
Plastic surgery was the answer for Joseph P. Toonen, a sales manager for Cox Cable in San Juan Capistrano, Calif. When colleagues repeatedly told him he looked tired when he in fact wasn't, he started feeling self-conscious about his baggy eyelids. He worried that they were affecting his superiors' perception of his abilities and performance. So, although he considers his job secure, he went ahead with an eye-lift operation in late April. It was a first step in protective career insurance; coloring his graying hair is next.
Mr. Toonen is typical of the new candidate for services, far from the youth-conscious realm of advertising or Hollywood. The change reflects the impact of the youth culture on every business. The computer industry, for example, used to be typified by the solid salesman in wing tips from I.B.M. Today, its personification is a whiz kid in cyber-gulch, wearing Converse sneakers and a Nirvana T-shirt.
Lee Canaan, vice president of Canaan Public Relations in New York City, had a more generalized aging complaint. "At a certain age, everything starts to sag," he said. So he had some facial surgery, including having a tip, or artificial bony implant, put in his nose. "A tip brings it up a tiny bit," he said. "It makes the face refreshed, not weather-beaten."
The increase in male plastic surgery is partly due to the loss of its former stigma, said Richard Dolsky, president of the American Academy of Cosmetic Surgery. Now, he said, "the mind-set is: 'It's available. It can be done. Why not do it for myself?' "
In fact, men are now talking openly about such beauty topics. Robert Blake, an actor who made a career of playing craggy macho guys, spoke at length to People magazine about his recent surgery. ("I told the doc, 'If you make me look like a lizard like everybody else, I'm going to kill you.' ")
Disguise does have its limits, though. All these quick fixes aren't, like exercise and a good diet, making men's skin better, their blood pressure lower or their hearts stronger. And it will not turn back the clock.
"You're not going to look like Paul Newman if you look like Harvey Keitel," Mr. Canaan said of plastic surgery. "They'll knock off some years, but it's still you that's going to be out there."
While Mr. Canaan, a public relations executive himself, would be the first to congratulate Ralph Lauren, Men's Health magazine, and others tapping into the fake-youth-quake, it isn't all just savvy marketing.
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the risk of job loss is rising for a group of men who are prime candidates for anti-aging products: 45- to 54-year-olds.
"They were less likely than the average person to be displaced during the early 80's," Jennifer Gardner, an economist with the agency, said of these middle-aged workers. "That's different now." In 1981-82, all workers had a 3.9 percent chance of dismissal annually, while men from 45 to 54 courted just a 3.1 percent risk. But by 1991-92, the latest period for which statistics are available, the risks had flipped. The whole work force faced a 3.8 percent annual danger of job loss, while for 45-to-54-year-old men the figure was 4.1 percent.
And worries about looking old extend beyond people who have already lost jobs, or who work for companies currently wielding the ax. In large numbers, those who are ostensibly secure in their jobs are fretting, too.
A 48-year-old realtor in the Cleveland area, who spoke on condition of anonymity, noticed recently that his company "seems to be attracting younger people." He is now on the verge of doing something he has been thinking about for a long time: getting collagen injections to remove wrinkles. He will pay $300 three times a year for the shots.
TO age-conscious men, younger guys may seem less of a threat than women, young and old, whom society expects to wear the latest fashions, to put on makeup to hide wrinkles and to stride about in high heels that give the appearance of muscle tone to legs.
"Most men are conscious of the fact that they are competing not only with younger competitors, but with women who know how to take care of themselves," said David Nap, vice president of marketing for Aramis.
Men, who are mostly responsible for marketing to women by making them loathe the effects of aging, are now the targets of the same methods. So there is a feeling of ambivalence to even the most triumphant of those pushing youthful dreams.
"It's not a friendly environment," said Mr. Mottus, of the cosmetics publication. "There's a degree of fear. And with that the men's business has finally begun to grow."

HEADLINE: Green Giant

BYLINE: By Mark Dowie; Mark Dowie's latest book is "Losing Ground: American Environmentalism at the Close of the 20th Century."

 BODY:

A NEW NAME FOR PEACE
International Environmentalism, Sustainable Development, and Democracy.
By Philip Shabecoff
Illustrated. 271 pp. Hanover, N.H.:
University Press of New England. $24.95.
 
DIVIDED PLANET
The Ecology of Rich and Poor.
By Tom Athanasiou.
385 pp. Boston:
Little, Brown. $24.95.
In his 900-page book "Diplomacy," Henry Kissinger mentions the environment only once. Along with communications, population, world economy and nuclear proliferation, it is listed amid issues that Mr. Kissinger believes may soon be globalizing international relations. But to our diplomat emeritus, diplomacy itself is still about Realpolitik, sovereign states pursuing national interests. Now come two books that say everything has to change, and fast. The catalyst for change? The environment. 
 In "A New Name for Peace," Philip Shabecoff, who covered the environmental beat for The New York Times for 25 years, sees in the rise of ecological diplomacy a "new Realpolitik" very different from the cold war dynamic of the Kissinger era. Complex environmental and economic issues will be addressed, he writes, "not by competition but by cooperation and not by unilateral exercise of sovereign power but by pooling that power." He foresees ecological matters affecting almost all international deliberations, even trade negotiations. Eventually, he says, GATT and other trade agreements will be subjected to a "green round."
Not only is diplomacy turning green, according to Mr. Shabecoff, it is also flirting with democracy. He cites recent rounds of the Montreal Protocol to the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer as examples of a "polycentric" decision-making process that involves -- along with diplomats -- scientists, corporate executives, environmentalists and other outside interests as integral participants.
Mr. Shabecoff's assertion that "global ecological stresses become global political issues" matches the realization arrived at by a few visionary diplomats in the early 1970's, which led to both the 1972 United Nations Conference on the Human Environment in Stockholm and the 1992 Earth Summit, held in Rio de Janeiro. Between Stockholm and Rio, 67 multilateral environmental treaties were concluded and signed, most notable among them the Law of the Sea Treaty and the Montreal Protocol. But the Earth Summit of 1992 was the defining moment of the new diplomacy, if not of a new world order.
"Rio was a doorway opening to a new post-cold war, postindustrial era," Tom Athanasiou writes in "Divided Planet," a trenchant but rambling essay on the state of international environmentalism. The new era he foresees is one of "more humane economics and benign technologies" combined with "greater concern for the vulnerability of Mother Earth and her creatures." And, he adds, "just possibly, the new laws, principles, promises, prescriptions and goals set forth in Rio laid the foundation for a second enlightenment -- a green enlightenment."
Mr. Athanasiou, a journalist and businessman, seems to agree with Mr. Shabecoff that environmentalism is globalizing and diplomacy is greening, and none too soon. But he cautions that a "growing inequity among nations and between generations" could spoil the party, and he confesses, "with caveats and reservations," to apocalyptic leanings. Warning of dire ecological consequences if northern, first world strategies of economic development are pursued -- with or without environmental diplomacy -- he says that the global ecosystem "cannot be saved while the poor people of the south are left to make their way along the paths of a haphazard and unjust development."
Green diplomacy has not only enlightened the world's foreign affairs ministers, according to both authors, it has changed greens as well. "Until recently, environmentalists seldom gave much thought to geopolitics," Mr. Athanasiou writes. But many northern environmentalists left Rio "with a new and not altogether comfortable sympathy for the view, common in the south, that saving the earth is less a matter of correcting isolated wrongs than of finding a route to fundamental social change."
Mr. Shabecoff's conclusions will be disheartening to greens who believe that the only route to a sustainable future is through less, not more, economic expansion. "Many environmentalists," he writes, "now accept that some form of continuing economic growth, if it is accompanied by a more equitable distribution of the wealth it creates, is imperative to correct the injustice that keeps one-fifth of the earth's inhabitants at the edge of survival while a minority live in comfort."
Mr. Athanasiou is not as sanguine about market-based growth and development as Mr. Shabecoff. In fact, he believes that "the market has been the principal device by which humanity has been divided into rich and poor," and he wonders if there is enough concern, enough political will in the north to make the requisite alterations. "Who really believes the world's executives will face the facts of ecological deterioration before events compel them to do so?"
Why limit the question to executives or, for that matter, to scientists, environmentalists, politicians or diplomats? We are dealing here with human nature, not business behavior, and the same events that compel executives to face ecological facts will challenge us all. As Mr. Shabecoff writes, "Homo sapiens will have to find some way to bid farewell to its own evolutionary childhood."
Both these books are disorganized, under-edited and unnecessarily difficult to read. Mr. Shabecoff intersperses dynamic and fascinating passages, spiced with the wisdom that made him such a good reporter, with ponderous sections written in the policy-wonk drone of the books and papers from which he drew much of his material. Mr. Athanasiou's work could have been cut by a third simply by eliminating quotations from the author's travel acquaintances. In most cases Mr. Athanasiou, a fine and ferocious writer, could have said what they say better himself.
Shortcomings aside, these two authors advance the notion dangled before us, then seemingly ignored, by Al Gore, who said that environmentalism must soon become "the central organizing principle of civilization." Mr. Gore should read both of these books.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 7, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A review on June 9 about "A New Name for Peace: International Environmentalism, Sustainable Development, and Democracy," by Philip Shabecoff, referred incorrectly to the author's career at The New York Times. He covered environmental issues for 14 years, not 25; earlier he was a foreign correspondent and a White House correspondent. His years at The Times totaled 32.

HEADLINE: The End of Germany's Economic Model

BYLINE: By Klaus Friedrich; Klaus Friedrich is chief economist of Dresdner Bank Group, Germany's second largest commercial bank.

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
For many years, Germany's economic model has earned the respect and envy of many countries, including the United States.
After all, this model, based on the idea of consensus, contributed decisively to our "economic miracle" of the 1950's and 1960's and to our high living standards since that time. 
 Instead of accepting conflict as inevitable in dealing with the appropriate distribution of wealth, Germans have traditionally settled this matter by forging agreement: Employers, unions and the Government sit around a table to discuss, for example, wages, benefits and working conditions. Then they resolve the issues in an evenhanded fashion by taking into account the concerns of all sides.
In this way, Germany has actually managed to lift all boats with the rising tide, to paraphrase the words of President John F. Kennedy.
The paradox is that at a time when influential voices in Washington are promoting concepts -- good corporate citizenship, for example -- that draw on the idea of consensus, the Germans themselves are running into severe problems with their much-praised system.
The pressures that the global economy imposes on all industrialized countries are enormous. Americans have already endured painful economic and social cutbacks.
At this critical stage, with Germany's high unemployment and with German investors moving their money outside the country, what we need most is not more agreement but a sharp increase in our willingness to disagree. In that sense, Germany needs to become a bit more like the United States.
That is why Chancellor Helmut Kohl's recently announced austerity package -- which includes reduced sick pay and fewer job guarantees for public and private employees -- is so important. It demonstrates that the Government is finally willing to deal with conflict, in the best democratic sense, and to abandon the need to make everyone happy.
Where did Germany go wrong? In the good old days under Ludwig Erhard, the postwar architect of our so-called social market economy, the goal was basically based on one notion: restraining wages. Corporate earnings were not quickly doled out to workers as raises and benefits but were reinvested. This produced Germany's economic miracle. High-paying jobs, topped off with enviable social peace, soon followed.
What Germans forgot at some point was that the success of their economy depended on everybody's willingness to put something into the system first. Instead, they began to make demands on the system from the start, and consensus came to mean avoiding any and all conflict. Whenever labor, industry and government found that they could not agree, they at least agreed to appear to agree. This usually translated into rising wages.
What can be done? Germans need to relearn the lesson that wages should be determined by productivity. The concept works, often with great success. In the United States, layoffs are painful but unemployment is 5.4 percent, compared with Germany's 10 percent.
German companies also need more flexibility. They must be able to set their own management policies, for example, rather than being legally tied to regionwide or sectorwide agreements that govern hiring, firing and wage policies. And archaic laws governing retail stores' hours must change. After 6:30 P.M. and on Sundays, costly inventories sit behind locked doors in high-rent downtown shops, as potential shoppers walk by.
Without flexibility, German companies will continue to be hamstrung in the global market. If Chancellor Kohl stays the course, he will not only help Germany address its fear of conflict, however democratic. He will also insure that Germans rediscover the roots of their past economic success. The welfare state needs to be adjusted to survive. Social peace and order may be worth a lot. But are they worth the price of stagnation?

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

HEADLINE: Tribal Casinos Catalyzed Gambling's Spread

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Gambling in the Senate," your June 3 editorial calling for a comprehensive study of the social costs of high-stakes casino gambling across the nation, overlooks the irony that an impending social catastrophe is a direct result of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act enacted by Congress eight years ago. 
 That legislation, intended to promote tribal economic self-sufficiency and strong tribal government, has backfired.
In 1988, Congress authorized Indian tribes to operate any forms of gambling on their reservations that were permitted for any purpose by state law, such as so-called Las Vegas charity nights. Although Congress did not intend the proliferation of high-stakes casino gambling both on and off Indian reservations, that is exactly what has happened.
In the past eight years state governments have watched helplessly as Indian casinos have diverted taxable income from their commercial economies to tribal treasuries. Since state governments cannot tax income generated by tribal gaming enterprises, many states have been forced to consider the legalization of commercial casino gambling to retain tax revenues.
The economic competition has spread into different geographic regions. Once casino gambling flourishes in one state, neighboring states are compelled to legalize commercial high-stakes gaming to prevent taxable revenue from flowing into casinos across states lines.
In the eight years since American Indians won the right to sponsor casino gambling on their reservations, the number of states where some form of casino gaming is available has jumped from 2 to 25. More Americans are now visiting casinos than are attending professional and college football games, arena and symphony concerts, and all Broadway and touring shows, combined.
It is unlikely that Congress anticipated such a profound social and economic fallout from its decision to encourage tribal gambling. Tribal gaming has played the unintended role of catalyzing the proliferation of casino gambling outside Nevada and Atlantic City.
An overwhelming majority of tribes with gaming report that their new-found revenues have allowed them to finance other nongambling ventures and improve their social, educational and health programs. The question that the Federal Government must now resolve is whether the objective of achieving tribal economic self-sufficiency takes priority over protecting the social fabric of the nation.
 
NICHOLAS GOLDIN
New York, June 4, 1996

HEADLINE: In Next Sequel, Let Scarlett, Like Atlanta, Personify New South

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Book Sequel Creates a New Civil War" (Business Day, June 3): 
 The problem with any sequel to Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind," which I read first in the fourth grade and many times since, lies in a misreading of the heroine's character and the book's main metaphor. Scarlett is not a love-driven heroine. She personifies the New South and specifically its archetypal city, Atlanta.
The nonbelievable Irish scenarios that Alexandra Ripley used in "Scarlett," the 1991 sequel, were a literary device to avoid dealing with economic issues and themes that the author acknowledged in an interview were central to postwar Atlanta but which she did not find understandable or interesting. These themes are equally central to Scarlett's character.
If I were representing St. Martin's Press or the Mitchell estate, I would pretend the first sequel never happened.
Contrary to your allusion in the article, Scarlett's prosperity insured that she could hold on to Tara -- a romantic symbol -- long before the conclusion of the original "Gone With the Wind." So what drives her?
Scarlett pays lip service to romance, but goes after money, power, dominance: She'll never be hungry -- or defeated -- again. That's her epic struggle. Scarlett's confusion comes from being a captive of romantic conventions. This creates the fundamental tension in her life, as it did in Mitchell's, for Mitchell was an early rebel who increasingly was controlled by her family and her husband (and now her heirs).
Unlike Mitchell, who may have grown to be classically depressed, Scarlett has the energy and bias for action. The true sequel would have Scarlett buying up the land of her less resilient neighbors around Jonesboro while building on her commercial success in Atlanta.
An underlying theme could include Mitchell's beloved Atlanta Journal and the New South editor Henry Grady as forces of change and commerce, played against the symbolic power but economic impotence of Tara, the past.
Atlanta, acknowledged by every city in the United States as the one to beat, has more than borne out the characterization imputed in Mitchell's portrait of this charming survivor. I can even visualize the fourth or fifth sequel chronicling the 1996 Olympics as a St. Martin's offering of 2010!
 
ESTHER T. SMITH
McLean, Va., June 5, 1996

HEADLINE: In the 2000 Census, Immigrants Will Lose

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a professional demographer, I too am distressed with the plans for the census in 2000 (news article, June 6) but for a different reason. 
 Asking the birthplace of one's parents, let alone one's grandparents, did not survive the politicized process that determines the questions to be included in the census. Until 1970 this question had been routine, as social planners, politicians and members of various nativity groups wanted to find out how their members and their offspring were faring.
After nearly a half-century of low immigration, the Census Bureau dropped this question -- just as the nation embarked upon its third great wave of newcomers. Now, in an era of Congressional false economy (each question costs money to ask and process), demographers cannot get this item restored.
No matter what one's interest in how the characteristics and behavior of immigrants change in the next generation, the 2000 census as currently drawn up will not satisfy it. Efforts to develop programs for immigrant groups will be hamstrung for the ensuing decade, at a minimum. Only Congress can move to restore these questions.
But be fair to the Census Bureau and increase financing accordingly.
 
B. MEREDITH BURKE
Palo Alto, Calif., June 6, 1996

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Lines of Communication Across Racial Divisions

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Derek McGinty returns to television tonight on PBS, at 10 on Channel 13 in New York, with the first of three episodes of "Straight Talk," this one on the inescapable subject "Black and White in America."
The straight-talking Mr. McGinty has a tactful knack for keeping other people's talk on track. His problem tonight is a format that includes a prime panel, a secondary mini-panel, studio participants selected with an eye toward diversity and some contributors on tape from Los Angeles. So a certain amount of hot air is inescapable, even though Johnnie L. Cochran does not have much to say. 
 The discussion, civil throughout, illuminates some of the often uncivil arguments about race these days. The main division here is between Clifford Alexander, a former Secretary of the Army, and Abigail Thernstrom of the Manhattan Institute, a conservative think tank. Mr. Alexander argues that racial inequities are still so great that race-targeted Government programs are essential. Ms. Thernstrom, an opponent of affirmative action, says that the continuing emphasis on race is poisoning American society.
Somewhere between them is Glenn Loury, a Boston University economist who reports he is put down as an Uncle Tom for emphasizing the responsibility of blacks for their own behavior. He notes what he calls a paradox: the continuing need for race-guided programs to forward the nation's movement toward the ideal of a color-blind society.
Coming up next week: "Money, Class and Politics," with Ralph Nader squaring off against Arianna Huffington. And after that, it's "The American Family," which promises an interview with Dan Quayle. Who can resist?
 
'America on Wheels'
PBS, tonight
(Channel 13, New York, at 9)
Tonight also brings the first hour of a peppy three-hour history of the automobile, fueled by high-octane newsreels. The opener, "Driving Force," focuses on Henry Ford's Model T and Model A, with side trips to assembly lines and bread lines, union busting and road building, the growth of the suburbs and the veerings of consumer tastes. There's even a glimpse of back-seat romance.
Next week's program, which features chrome, fins and the interstate highway system, carries us into the 1960's. And the final hour looks ahead, with attention to the economy and the environment. "America on Wheels" confirms that the motorcar is this century's ship of state.

HEADLINE: Media: PRESS;
Less is more as demands increase upon the publishers of stock and mutual fund tables.

BYLINE: By Edward Wyatt 

 BODY:
MAXIM of the newspaper business is: the smaller the type, the more loyal the readers. Publishers or editors who are skeptical of that rule need only to listen to the experience of The Day, a daily in New London, Conn.
In March, The Day cut its daily financial tables from two pages to one, eliminating hundreds of stocks and, said Anthony Cronin, deputy managing editor, eliciting "a massive amount of protest." 
 "We always considered the readers of stock tables to be a niche market, and the mantra of business journalists is that no one buys individual stocks anymore," Mr. Cronin said, alluding to the surge in mutual fund investments. "I don't know about the rest of the world, but in southeast Connecticut that's not true." Within a month, The Day restored about half of the tables it had cut.
Soaring newsprint prices, the rise of on-line sources of data and the growth of televised business news, complete with scrolling stock tickers, have left many publishers in a quandary. They must decide how to balance growing demand with the reality that newspapers are the last to deliver the data to investors.
"The pressure is on to add more information and at the same time to control the number of pages devoted to it," said Richard Rescigno, managing editor of Barron's, a financial weekly that devotes more than half of its roughly 172 pages to financial tables and market statistics. Later this year, Barron's, which is published by Dow Jones & Company, plans to review and possibly revamp its statistics section.
Vendors, too, have had cause for concern. Their customer base has shrunk as newspapers have closed and readers have abandoned print for other information sources.
While many newspapers have changed the type and amount of financial information they print, however, few have eliminated it. Randy Picht, assistant business editor for stock tables at The Associated Press, the biggest distributor of stock listings -- to about 550 newspapers -- said that when newsprint prices went through the roof more than a year ago, the expectation was that a lot more papers would drop financial tables.
"What we've seen instead is a little trimming and a lot of customization," in part because tables can now be easily formatted to meet a single newspaper's requests, Mr. Picht said. Few in the industry expect the trend to change now that newsprint prices have begun to fall.
Similarly, Barbara Needleman, vice president of data-base and advertising products at Tribune Media Services, part of the Tribune Company, and the only major competitor to The Associated Press in that field, said newspapers are "becoming much more economical about space."
Rather than eliminate financial listings, many publishers have reallocated space, from stock tables to mutual fund listings, for example, she said. Tribune's customer base has grown to 60 publications since the company began offering stock tables in 1990, she said.
Changes in technology have made both delivery of data and its presentation to readers more flexible. Among the requests for customization are: stock tables tailored to fit a certain space, regardless of how many companies are listed, and listings of specific stocks, usually local companies or big employers in a newspaper's circulation area.
The number of newspapers that run tables of all the stocks traded on the three major stock markets has fallen to a handful from several dozen at the beginning of the decade, Mr. Picht said.
At the same time, some smaller newspapers that had not previously run stock tables or that ran only limited lists have added to the data they provide. The Jonesboro Sun, for example, a daily paper in Jonesboro, Ark., last year beefed up its stock listings to a full page from less than one column of print.
"We were getting considerable demand for more stock listings," said John Troutt Jr., the publisher.
In other cases, changes in technology have allowed newspapers to undertake bold experiments. Last year, The Austin American-Statesman in Texas started to print a special 16-page weekend section, three-quarters of which is devoted to financial tables that summarize the week in financial markets.
What is unusual about the section is that it is delivered only to subscribers who request it, inserted in 24,000 copies of the publication's 200,000 Saturday papers. The section, which replaced the weekend financial tables that had run in all of the paper's 240,000 Sunday editions, is not available in copies sold on newsstands.
"We found a lot of money was being spent for a limited audience," said Richard A. Oppel, the newspaper's editor. Since last year, circulation of the weekly Business Review section has risen from about 15,000. Meanwhile, The American-Statesman, owned by Cox Enterprises Inc., has continued to run limited daily stock tables.
Mr. Oppel would not say whether the venture was profitable, but it clearly saved the company money on newsprint. "We didn't intend for it to rest strictly on the bottom line," he said. "But I think it is becoming increasingly attractive to advertisers" that want a targeted audience.
Mr. Picht of The Associated Press said some publications, after eliminating listings like stock options from the daily paper, began daily services to send tables by fax to readers who wanted them.
Others might, in a sense, join the competition. The New York Stock Exchange, which distributes most data on its stock listings through third parties, like The Associated Press, is considering new ways to expand direct sales, according to people at the top level of the exchange, who insisted on anonymity. Barron's, meanwhile, is readying an on-line version. "Maybe that is a place where statistics can grow unhampered," Mr. Rescigno said.

HEADLINE: Edward Bernstein, Economics Expert, Is Dead at 91

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Edward M. Bernstein, who, as a leading international economist helped negotiate the international monetary system at Bretton Woods, N.H., near the end of World War II, died on Saturday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 91 and lived in Washington.
Dr. Bernstein was born in Bayonne, N.J., grew up in Queens and was a copy boy for The New York World while attending De Witt Clinton High School. He received a bachelor's degree from the University of Chicago in 1927 and a doctorate in economics from Harvard in 1931. He went on to be a professor of economics at the University of North Carolina. 
 From 1940 to 1946, he was a Treasury Department official. In that role, in 1944, he was an adviser to the United States delegation to the Bretton Woods Conference, whose formal name was the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference. The conference resulted in the founding of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development -- known as the World Bank -- and the founding of the International Monetary Fund, with the mission of promoting international monetary cooperation.
One of Dr. Bernstein's feats was convincing the British economist and monetary expert John Maynard Keynes, who led the British delegation to Bretton Woods, that, contrary to the opinion then prevailing among American economists, there would not be a grave depression in the United States after World War II. His reasoning was that the United States had given up the gold standard in 1933 and would no longer allow gold reserves to regulate the money supply's growth.
Dr. Bernstein went on to be the first director of research at the International Monetary Fund, from 1946 to 1958, when he left to found EMB Ltd., a Washington economic consulting and research organization. He was its president until 1981, and his clients included large multinational companies and central banks of foreign countries. Later he was a guest scholar at the Brookings Institution for more than a decade.
His survivors include his wife of 60 years, the former Edith Lewis; three sons, Daniel L., of Bronxville, N.Y., Alan S., of Dallas, and George L., of New Orleans, and four grandchildren.
