SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 3981 words

HEADLINE: Life's Hubbub Returns to Oft-Shunned Hudson

SERIES: A RIVER RECLAIMED: Turning to the Water -- Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
On the waterfront of Beacon, N.Y., the city's environmental director, Shabazz Jackson, pointed to a brush-choked peninsula jutting into the glittering Hudson River. A year ago, the one-acre site overflowed with rusting cars. Soon it will be restored and turned into parkland. "We're taking it back," Mr. Jackson said.
In the lobby of the old McGraw-Hill Building on West 42d Street, volunteers with a group called "Floating the Apple" were building the sixth in a growing fleet of 25-foot wooden boats. Until the 1930's, anyone in Manhattan could stroll to a boathouse and go for a row in similar boats, said Michael Davis, an archeologist turned boatbuilder. Now plans were afoot for the first new public boathouse, on Pier 84 near the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum. "It's one thing to see the water," he said. "It's another to be out on it." 
 In the antique-filled parlor of a hilltop mansion overlooking the Hudson at Kingston, N.Y., Donald Casey served coffee to neighbors. Mr. Casey, a Manhattan emigre, had bought the house as a crumbling wreck four years ago and -- as part of Kingston's riverfront revival -- turned it into a luxurious bed and breakfast. "We saved this place from literally getting torn down," he said.
Up and down the Hudson, people who had for decades turned their backs on the sullied river are now rummaging through old wharfs, sagging buildings and fading memories to find new ways to link their lives and livelihoods to the water.
Riverfront cities and towns are realizing they can build a new economy around tourism and recreation. Many planners say the Hudson Valley -- with its fjord-like highlands, grand mansions, historic sites, and hills blanketed with orchards and vineyards -- could someday rival the Rhine or Loire valleys of Europe as a tourist destination. Tourism already directly employs 90,000 people in the region, a figure that has risen 38 percent in 20 years. By contrast, thousands of factory and high technology jobs along the river have disappeared in the last 30 years because of cutbacks at I.B.M. and other companies.
The Hudson Highlands, the mountains north of Peekskill which a century ago were being blasted into building blocks and 30 years ago were envisioned as a hollowed-out hydroelectric plant -- are now largely protected and a popular destination. In just one of many new initiatives, a ferry service began running on June 3 from the Metro-North train station in Peekskill past the eagle aeries of Bear Mountain up to the granite bastions of West Point. Other excursion ferries are also planned, harking back decades to when Day Line steamboats took city residents upriver on summer escapes.
With wildlife and many fish species abundant, so too are hikers, bird watchers, and anglers. This spring, so many striped bass have been caught that state environmental officials are considering introducing a fishing license for the lower Hudson. The income would pay for research on the fish. Swimmers, too, are drawn to the river, and after the Fourth of July -- for the first time in nearly a decade -- they will be able to bathe at Westchester County's only public Hudson River beach, in Croton Point Park.
"When I was growing up, we lived in Tarrytown, Hastings, Croton," said Barbara Muldoon, a resident of North Tarrytown, N.Y., who has swum in the river in bad times and good. "Now they're all Croton-on-Hudson, Hastings-on-Hudson. Some of us appreciated the river no matter what. Now all of a sudden everyone loves it."
But impediments to a strengthened bond between people and the Hudson still abound. From Manhattan to Albany, 60 percent of the river's banks, mainly on the eastern shore, are cut off by railroad tracks. Since 1917, some 42 percent of track crossings on that shore have been closed by state transportation officials, including many pedestrian overpasses that once allowed fishermen and picnickers casual access to the river. Many of the overpasses had deteriorated for lack of maintenance as communities turned away from the river.
Lingering traces of PCB's in striped bass and some other fish have imperiled one of the Hudson's most heralded features -- its commercial fishermen. A few dozen people still make a living at it, but for some of them, the only steady work now is setting nets for biologists trying to understand declines in sturgeon and shad.
And development pressure -- dormant after the market crash of October 1987 and the loss of thousands of I.B.M. jobs -- is once more on the rise, partly because the newly attractive river itself has drawn residents to the area.
New York State cities like Newburgh, Poughkeepsie and Kingston have seen new battles over long-forgotten tracts. At that renovated mansion in Kingston, Mr. Casey and his neighbors had gathered not just for coffee, but also to plot a legal challenge to a plan by the Mayor, T. R. Gallo, to level the top of a neighboring wooded knoll -- the city's last large patch of open land -- to build a 56-acre industrial park.
The Mayor said the industrial park was needed to keep a local manufacturer, Huck International, from moving. Huck's executives liked the plan, saying the picturesque hilltop would bolster Huck's image.
A few weeks later, the neighbors' lawsuits faltered and the city -- with more than $1.8 million in Federal aid -- began bulldozing trees and dynamiting the limestone ridge.
 
The Tension
Natural Wonder Or Economic Power?
For nearly two centuries, the relationship of people to the Hudson has been tugged between the poles seen in the struggle in Kingston: development and preservation.
Starting with the completion of the Erie Canal in 1825, industrialists saw the river as a shipping corridor for goods and quarry stone and as a place to build factories. Their efforts helped New York City become a major commercial center and seaport.
But over that same span, artists, writers and naturalists heralded the valley as a natural wonder. In the process, the valley became the focus of the first distinctively American school of art and literature, exemplified by the paintings of Thomas Cole and the stories of Washington Irving.
On both sides, "people's relationship to this river has always been intense," said Frances F. Dunwell, a historian who directs a state office that has just completed a 15-year management plan for the Hudson.
In 1846, quarrymen blasted the river's most famous attraction at the time: Turk's Face, a bluff south of Beacon that resembled a human profile. Tourists from as far away as Europe had regularly taken steamboats 45 miles up from Manhattan just to see the curiosity, and now it was rubble.
In Ms. Dunwell's book, "The Hudson River Highlands" (Columbia University Press, 1991), she describes how advocates for scenic preservation cheered shortly afterward when the man responsible, Deering Ayers, was himself blown up while checking an explosive charge on Staten Island.
Continued quarrying in the bluffs led several dozen influential New Yorkers in 1936 to form the Hudson River Conservation Society, the region's first organized environmental group. The society lobbied for the creation of a state commission that did the first survey of sources of Hudson River pollution.
Sewage and industrial waste were pouring into the river everywhere, but little was done about the problem. Mr. Jackson, Beacon's environmental director, recalled how in the 1950's he and other students riding a crosstown school bus would often pool lunch money before reaching the Fishkill Creek -- a Hudson tributary -- and make bets on the color of the water. A fabric-dyeing plant upstream kept them guessing.
Pollution shaped other childhood rites, as well, including summertime swims. To avoid dunking heads in tainted water, Mr. Jackson said, "kids in Beacon never learned to dive."
Other Hudson Valley residents recalled the dense pillows of white foam that would slowly drift by on the river -- effluent from factories. Children would compete to see who could get a tossed stone to perch on the fluff.
 
The Tide Turns
A Drought Reveals A River's Agony
Not until the 1960's did the perception that something was terribly wrong with the Hudson gain real force. By then the banks around each factory were strewn with evidence, said John Cronin, who investigates river pollution for the Hudson Riverkeeper Fund, a private group. "If you went to Diamond Candle Company in Newburgh, wax was everywhere," he said. "Around Tuck Tape, adhesive was everywhere."
Just as people were getting fed up with the foul water, a parallel battle intensified over protection of the scenery around the river. In 1963, the Consolidated Edison Company proposed to hollow out the face of Storm King -- a mountain directly across the river from where Turk's Face once jutted -- to create a hydroelectric power plant.
As the legal challenges to the Storm King project intensified, so too did a record drought. From 1962 to 1966, so little rain and snow fell that the natural flow of the Hudson shriveled, concentrating the river's burden of human and industrial wastes. The result was a literal stinking mess.
With Rachel Carson's seminal environmental book, "Silent Spring," a recent best seller and public concern about pollution rising, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller campaigned in 1965 for a $1 billion Pure Waters Bond Act to build sewage plants. The bond act passed by more than a 3-to-1 ratio, one year before similar Federal legislation forced the rest of the country to begin catching up.
Quickly thereafter, momentum for a clean river built as a tenacious assortment of fishermen, naturalists, folk singers, property owners and activists formed private groups with names like Riverkeeper and Clearwater. Ever since, communities up and down the river have thwarted a host of projects, including nuclear power plants and a pet project of Mr. Rockefeller's: the Hudson River Expressway, which would have cut a 47-mile swath of pavement along the river's eastern shore from the North Bronx to Beacon and which was abandoned in 1971.
Environmental groups were unwittingly aided by large economic shifts, according to a variety of river watchers. As early as the 1950's, many polluting industries -- through consolidation and a quest for cheaper labor and lower costs -- were abandoning New York, said Nicholas A. Robinson, a law professor at Pace University and the founder of the school's environmental law program.
"That trend saved the Hudson from the fate of many Midwestern rivers," Mr. Robinson said. "Unlike the Cuyahoga" -- the oil-stained river that runs through Cleveland -- "the Hudson never caught fire."
More lawsuits and laws in the 1980's forced the closing of the landfills that for decades smothered Hudson River marshes and leaked toxic chemicals. According to state environmental officials, only 2 of the 32 licensed dumps within a mile of the river in the 1980's still operate. And those two are to close by the end of the decade.
In recent years, environmental activism was again abetted by a shift in the economy: plans for thousands of units of riverfront housing died with the stock market crash of 1987 and the shrinkage of I.B.M. Now, the cleaner river that resulted in part from economic downturns is seen as the source of economic salvation for the Hudson Valley.
 
New Uses
Water to Drink, Fish to Catch
Everywhere along the Hudson, people are finding new opportunities. In some spots, the water itself has become a resource.
Where 20 years ago the river around Albany was so ripe with sewage that fish would suffocate, the water is now so clean that the Albany suburb of Bethlehem began pumping some of its drinking water last winter from an aquifer fed by the river.
Half a dozen communities along cleaner stretches of the river have always drunk filtered river water, but for Bethlehem, just five miles south of the capital, access to clean river water is akin to breathing fresh air after decades of smog. "For us, that water means growth and jobs," said Bruce H. Secor, Bethlehem's commissioner of public works.
From Manhattan to Troy, entrepreneurs are creating dozens of river-oriented businesses. There is serious talk of reviving the oyster beds of the Tappan Zee, which supplied Manhattan taverns with oysters before pollution from rail yards, sewers and factories tainted the water.
John Cutten, a Hudson Valley native, had lived in Miami for many years, working on all manner of boats. But when he decided to start his own charter-cruise business in 1993, he came back to the Hudson. As he slapped a new coat of paint on his restored 70-foot motor yacht, the Teal, Mr. Cutten recalled how, with I.B.M. gone from Kingston and the local economy reeling, "My friends said I was crazy." But business is growing 10 percent a year, he said: "People are falling in love with this river again."
At a new sports complex on Manhattan's Chelsea piers, which a few years ago were a ramshackle mass of warehouses, roller skaters play hockey and golfers now watch Albany-bound tankers as they tee off on a driving range facing New Jersey, their shots trapped by a fine net.
One misty Saturday morning, a swarm of 60 hikers passed the driving range and surged north, weaving around concrete barriers and potholes like a determined school of migratory shad. This was the "Great Saunter," an annual daylong trek around Manhattan's 32-mile perimeter, organized by a group called Shore Walkers. Since the first saunter in 1984, impediments like barbed wire and junk piles have been getting rarer, said the Shore Walkers' founder, Cyrus A. Adler.
Mr. Adler called out to see where his fellow hikers hailed from; the answers -- California, Florida, Ontario, Utah -- were a sign that the riverfront -- albeit a work in progress -- was now an attractive place.
 
The New Shoreline
Towns Again Face A River of Life
Upstate New York communities like Haverstraw, Newburgh and Beacon -- blighted by decay and chronic unemployment after industry abandoned the Hudson -- are now staking their futures on using the river for tourism and recreation. They -- along with seven other riverfront towns, from Albany to Ossining -- are model communities in a state program intended to unify the Hudson Valley.
Created in 1991, the Hudson River Valley Greenway, a state agency, is providing small grants to spur tourism, agriculture, regional planning and urban renewal in the area and helping local governments negotiate the daunting maze of state and county agencies that regulate activities along the river.
The Greenway's small staff is also meant to serve as a go-between, fostering communication among state agencies that rarely talk to each other. For example, some efforts to revitalize waterfronts are run from the New York Secretary of State's office, while much state-owned riverfront property is managed by the Office of General Services.
Another aim, said David Sampson, executive director of one arm of the Greenway office, is to develop new transportation links among Hudson River towns, including trolleys, ferries, and trails. The goal is to make it easy for a hiker from New York City to, say, take a Metro-North train to Beacon, take a trolley up the town's Main Street to the foot of Mount Beacon, then hike along the crags of the Hudson Highlands to Cold Spring, returning home by rail.
 
The Money
Public Gap Filled By Private Largess
With state budgets continuing to shrink, a critical issue these days is money. Last year, cost cutters in the administration of Gov. George E. Pataki came close to eliminating the greenway program altogether. But a public outcry spurred the Governor -- who as a legislator pushed for the creation of the program -- to restore funding.
Mr. Pataki, who grew up along the river and is fond of canoeing with his children in Constitution Marsh, one mile from his Garrison home, said protecting the river and reviving its communities remained a top priority. He recently backed a $40 million plan to increase research on the river and spur sensible economic development, but none of the money is allocated in this year's budget.
Where public money has been lacking, the Hudson Valley -- to an extent unmatched anywhere else, according to a variety of land preservation experts -- has benefited from private philanthropy. In 1983, the founders of Reader's Digest bequeathed part of their fortune to support the Hudson Valley, specifically the Highlands. Acting as an endowment for the river, the Lila Acheson and DeWitt Wallace Fund for the Hudson Highlands annually dispenses some $16 million to buy or protect land. The money is funneled through two groups, Scenic Hudson and the Open Space Institute. Close to 30,000 acres have been set aside.
Although the Hudson has benefited from huge bequests, it has also been improved by a sprinkling of tiny grants and the sweat of hundreds of unpaid river lovers.
Since 1986, the Hudson River Improvement Fund -- created with a $1.5 million settlement paid after tankers flushed oil into the river -- has paid for dozens of projects, including community boat ramps, boat clubs, even a ceramic mural of river life. From Yonkers to Beacon, residents patrol shores for junk and pollution, run educational shad festivals and stage summertime "weed wallows" to rip out channel-clogging mats of imported European water chestnut.
One of the most devoted groups of volunteers, the Beacon Sloop Club, operates out of a tiny shack on that city's waterfront that was built around a living spruce tree. On a recent Friday evening, the folk singer Pete Seeger swept the floor before the club's monthly meeting and laid out a plan to insure that people continue to love the Hudson. Mr. Seeger, 77, a pioneer in the struggle for a cleaner river, wants to increase the river's constituency by immersing people in it, even in the many towns that lack beaches.
"The answer is floating swimming pools," he said. A century ago, Mr. Seeger said, such pools -- porous enclosures surrounded by platforms -- were common around New York City, allowing safe swimming even in deep spots with strong currents. "Once you've got people swimming in it," he said, "they'll never allow it to get dirty again."
 
Getting There
Beautiful, Yes, But How to Reach It?
All is not harmony on the Hudson. Last month, two dozen environmental groups staged a rally in Fishkill, a few miles from the crumbled spot where Turk's Face once stood, to protest a planned quarry that would blast 50 million tons of rock over the next 140 years.
Efforts to revitalize waterfronts from Hoboken to Kingston have increasingly been stalled as developers and environmental groups fight to balance private projects, open space, and public access. Most troubling to many communities is the realization that although the Hudson is cleaner, it is now far harder to get to than ever before.
Guy Hoffman discovered this in 1993, when he hiked across the railroad tracks near Peekskill to reach Roa Hook, a fabled fishing spot for striped bass. He was charged with trespassing by Metro-North police officers.
As he cast a baited hook into the Hudson at the same spot on a recent rainy day, Mr. Hoffman recalled: "I was laid off at the time. I told them, 'This fish plus a box of macaroni and cheese is dinner.' " But the ticket was written nonetheless.
The railroad later dropped the charge for lack of evidence, but Mr. Hoffman's case caused an inquiry into the effect of the railroads on access to the water. Matthew R. Atkinson, a lawyer at Pace University's Environmental Law Clinic, is completing a study that questions the railroads' right to deny access to the river and lists nearly 100 track crossings that have been closed by state officials over the last 80 years.
Many were track-level crossings that, with rising train speeds, posed a hazard, Mr. Atkinson said. But dozens were overpasses, including 18 pedestrian walkways. "People fought for 30 years to clean up the river," he said. "They should have the right to enjoy the fruits of that labor."
The Transportation Department is beginning to take into account the issue of waterfront access, Greenway officials said. But many Hudson Valley residents fear that planners are focusing too much on cars, not pedestrians. "We're losing casual access to places to go fish or have a picnic or just sit quietly," Mr. Atkinson said. "If that continues, we may end up with the Hudson becoming 'Jones Beach North.' "
Mr. Hoffman and the other six anglers casting for bass along Roa Hook recently said that, one way or the other, people will not be denied their river.
They stood on a shoreline that was itself a sign of the cycle of renewal along the Hudson. Not long ago, the forested hill behind them was a dump. Donald Bernstein, fishing with two of his five sons, said he had been coming to this spot every spring for 12 years. "This is my last student," he said of his youngest son, James, who at 10 years old had just caught his first striped bass. A few minutes later, James's rod twitched. He yelled, "Got one!" and hauled in his line, this time landing a squirming green eel.
As an Amtrak train flashed toward Manhattan behind him, Mr. Hoffman sent his line zinging over the milky Hudson, whose waters were beginning to shift as the ebb tide gained force. "Forget about trying to keep people away," he said. "It'd be like trying to stop this water flowing to the ocean."
 
Resurgence Brings Peril Of Its Own
With pollution on the wane, a governor who was raised on the riverbank, and dozens of towns embracing their waterfronts, it might appear that the resurgent Hudson is safe from future degradation. But many longtime observers of the river see signs that a shift for the worse looms.
The renewed love affair between New Yorkers and the Hudson may threaten the very qualities that are drawing people to the river again: its serenity and clean water.
"In some ways, tourism may be the greatest danger that faces the river valley," said John Cronin, who patrols the river for the Hudson Riverkeeper Fund, adding that tourism's effects will not be easy to predict. "It's not like studying the effects of power plants or PCB's," he said. "It's like trying to grab Jell-O."
Increased recreation could shatter the Hudson's tranquillity. Eight boat ramps to be built by the state in the next three years will allow many more New Yorkers to get out on the river. But rising speedboat traffic could stain the water with oil, and the shrill buzz of jet skis could increasingly echo from the bluffs of the Hudson Highlands.
As the Hudson Valley economy recovers, the dormant housing market is stirring, creating a new threat to shoreline marshes and potential sources of pollution.
Subtler problems could hamper the river's recovery. Although efforts are under way to foster regional planning, a long tradition of home rule still holds sway, with many of the river's local governments pressing ahead with independent development projects. Without regional agreement on how to deal with environmental problems, cleanups have been delayed.
In an era of tight budgets, few people studying the Hudson say they believe that any proposal for a large-scale initiative, like Nelson A. Rockefeller's short-lived Hudson River Valley Commission of the 1960's, stands a chance.
Indeed, while ambitious projects of all sorts -- be they river commissions, sewage plants or nuclear power plants -- were emblematic of the river's past, they are unlikely to be a part of its future. In two recent announcements, Gov. George E. Pataki revealed a $40 million management plan for the river, with $25 million coming from his $1.5 billion environmental bond act. But as recently as Friday, the state's Hudson River office did not know if there was money to pay for programs for 1997.

NEW YORK
 
For Some Parents, Lawyers Fail
For the parents, almost all of them poor, whose children have been removed from their households by child-welfare authorities, the legal system can be daunting. Their court-appointed lawyers are overburdened and ill equipped, according to parents, lawyers and judges. With the merits of the city's case unresolved, a child can remain in foster care for months, sometimes more than a year, before a judge makes a permanent decision on his or her future. And once children have been placed in foster care, parents trying to get them back have no right to a court-appointed lawyer. [Page A1.]
 
Prayers for an Attack Victim
Prayers for the victim of the vicious assault in Central Park were offered in solemn services at Armenian Orthodox churches across the metropolitan area as the police intensified the hunt for the assailant and a grieving family kept a round-the-clock hospital vigil for the comatose woman. At the behest of the victim's mother, hundreds of worshipers at Armenian Orthodox rites on Manhattan's East and West Sides, in Queens and on Long Island prayed amid flickering candles and medieval liturgical music for a woman whose victimization seemed to strike at the roots of the city's psyche. [B1.]
 
The Police Department's Crime Stoppers Unit has been fielding calls from hundreds of people who believe they have information that might lead to an arrest in the attack in Central Park. [B3.]
 
Keeping Peace in Far Rockaway
In Far Rockaway, Queens, a booming middle class Orthodox community and black and Hispanic residents maintain a neighborly, though not warm, relationship. There is strain just beneath the surface, projected in a language of suspicion, stereotype and self-interest by people on both sides. But through a combination of physical separation, political savvy and pragmatic cooperation, there is also an effort to keep Far Rockaway from becoming Crown Heights, where just last month hackles rose again when the police said members of a Hasidic patrol beat a black man with their walkie-talkies. [B1.]
 
A Club Owner Speaks Out
Town officials in Westhampton Beach, L.I., have portrayed a beating at Club Marakesh as an accident waiting to happen. They say the club has been a spawning ground for trouble, and they have petitioned the State Liquor Authority to revoke its liquor license. But Edward J. Dougherty, the club's founder and owner, called the situation one fraught with irony: the day after the beating over the Memorial Day weekend, he said, he was to transfer the club's management to another entity. "It was my intention to get out," said Mr. Dougherty, a real estate agent and entrepreneur, in his first public comments since the incident. [B1.]
 
In his first words since a near-fatal beating Memorial Day weekend, Shane L. Daniels, 21, asked for his mother. [B5.]
 
A Nod to What's Missing
Next time you're traveling on any of the highways in New York City, notice what is missing. Notice the absence of filth. Garbage, so long a permanent fixture of the city's roads that the sloppiness was a national embarrassment, has done a disappearing act. Not everywhere; some roadways remain as dirty as ever, especially because of illegal dumping. But there has been a noticeable change in just a year. The reason is an experiment in privatization called the Adopt-a-Highway program. A California-based company brought it to New York City, and it has, with the encouragement of the Giuliani administration, grown. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [B1.]
 
Church Rivalry Ends in Death
They are two simple storefront churches, on the ground floor of two-story row houses on a modest block in Brownsville, Brooklyn. But since one opened a door away from the other about eight years ago, investigators said, the neighbors have fought bitterly, each accusing the other of slashed tires and hang-up phone calls, each hurling slurs questioning the other church's legitimacy. The feud came to a violent end when the three sons of the pastor of the Prince of Peace Disciples Church took out guns and fired at the parishioners from the other church, killing one, the police said. [B2.]
 
Puerto Ricans Celebrate
Tens of thousands of Puerto Ricans turned a hazy stretch of Fifth Avenue red, white and blue with a sea of miniature national flags, lining the street to cheer their heritage -- and many also to jeer Mayor Giuliani -- during the 39th annual Puerto Rican Day parade. For the second year in a row, Mr. Giuliani met with a chorus of boos and catcalls as he marched at the head of the parade, publicly underscoring a recent poll that shows his popularity among Hispanic voters remains much lower than when he was elected. [B3.]
 
Al Poulin, Poetry Editor, Dies
Al Poulin, a French-Canadian New England mill hand's son who had such an appetite for language that he managed to live the life of a poet in a world that sometimes seems to value typesetters more, died at a hospital in Brockport, N.Y., the Erie Canal town he had made a center of contemporary American poetry. He was 58 and the founding editor of BOA Editions, one of the nation's premier poetry publishers. [B12.]
 
REGION
 
Hubbub Returns to the Hudson
Up and down the Hudson, people who for decades had turned their backs on the sullied river are now rummaging through old wharfs, sagging buildings and fading memories to find new ways to link their lives and livelihoods to the water. Riverfront cities and towns are realizing they can build a new economy around tourism and recreation. Many planners say the Hudson Valley -- with its fjord-like highlands, grand mansions, historic sites, and hills blanketed with orchards and vineyards -- could someday rival the Rhine or Loire valleys of Europe as a tourist destination. With wildlife and many fish species abundant, so too are hikers, birders, and anglers. [A1.]
 
With pollution on the wane, it might appear that the Hudson is safe from future degradation. But many longtime observers of the river see signs that a shift for the worse looms. [B6.]

HEADLINE: White House Says Provision Endangers Health Bill

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today threatened to veto a health insurance bill if Republicans insist on including a large-scale program of medical savings accounts, and Representative Dick Armey, the House Republican floor leader, dared the President to do it.
Others in each party said they still hoped a compromise could be worked out, but neither Administration nor Congressional aides involved with the issue said any progress had been made over the weekend. Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader and likely Republican Presidential nominee, has frequently said he would like to see a bill passed before he leaves the Senate on Tuesday. 
 The underlying measure to make health-insurance coverage portable from job to job has almost universal support on Capitol Hill. Sponsored by Senators Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, it passed the Senate 100 to 0.
But House Republicans, supported by Mr. Dole, want to include a program of tax-free savings accounts to pay basic health care costs for individuals, who would also buy insurance policies with high deductibles to cover catastrophic illnesses.
The Republicans contend such a plan would slow medical inflation and increase patients' choices. But Democrats argue, as Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said today, "the most healthy and the most affluent are likely to go into that program," raising insurance costs for everyone else.
With Congress and Mr. Clinton out of town, today's skirmishing took place on television interview programs. Mr. Rubin, appearing on ABC News's "This Week," said the President would veto the bill if it reached him with medical savings accounts attached. Mr. Clinton had previously described the provision as a "poison pill," but no explicit veto threat had been made by the Administration.
Mr. Armey, who ranks second to Speaker Newt Gingrich among House Republicans, appeared on the same broadcast and said, "I will not give up" on the savings accounts. Asked what would happen if that provoked a veto, he replied, "Then the President will have to deal with the American people when he has vetoed one of the most popular things before the American people."
The temperature was a little cooler on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," where Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said, "If there is anything I hope Senator Dole can deliver on before he leaves the Senate, it is the Kennedy-Kassebaum bill."
Mr. Panetta said that while the accounts "do not belong" in the Kassebaum-Kennedy bill, the Administration was willing to accept a demonstration project to see how they worked in practice. "The Republicans on the House side have said, 'No, no, we want this thing all or nothing,' " he said.
As passed by the House, the bill would have made the accounts immediately available to almost everyone covered by private insurance. House Republicans have agreed to scale it back to about two-thirds of those with private insurance, as a first step, with everyone else being eligible after three years.
The House negotiators in the informal, all-Republican negotiations have also agreed to drop provisions in their bill for limits on damages in medical malpractice suits and for the creation of small business insurance purchasing groups that would be free of state regulation.
Another House Republican, also appearing on "Meet the Press," took a softer line than Mr. Armey's. Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, chairman of the Budget Committee, said that even though he strongly favored medical savings accounts, he did not want to see the savings provision kill a bill making coverage portable and curtailing the ability of insurance companies to deny coverage to new clients for existing medical conditions.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

British Air and American: Hands Across the Water
American Airlines and British Airways are expected to announce tomorrow that they will join forces as marketing partners, selling seats on each other's flights and linking frequent-flier programs. A deal would mean that American's chairman, Robert L. Crandall, was dropping his opposition to code-sharing, a powerful shortcut in the computerized booking of space on an airline partner's flights.
While other carriers have made similar deals, an American-British Airways partnership is considered the most important yet because of the vast reach of the two carriers' route networks. [Page D2.]
 
Big Bill for Debt Relief
The cost of reducing the debts of the poorest nations so that they may increase economic growth rates and attract more investment could be $5.6 billion to $7.7 billion over six years, a study by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund estimated. [D2.]
 
Affirmative Action in Atlanta
In contrast with a large number of American cities, Atlanta's political establishment continues to embrace affirmative action. The private corporation that is staging the summer Olympics has awarded almost a third of its $387 million in construction and vending contracts to companies primarily owned by blacks. [A1.]
 
Stock Tables in Flux
Although newspapers are becoming more economical with space and investors can get their hands on financial data in any number of ways, stock tables are not disappearing. Instead, the tables are being trimmed a bit and customized a great deal. Press. [D9.]

Human Development on the Web
The World Wide Web is serving as a hospitable environment for memes. Memes? The word is what an evolutionary biologist at Oxford University came up with in 1969 to denote ideas that alter the ways in which we think. The biologist said that memes would, like genes, replicate themselves, affecting the course of human development. Edward Rothstein: Technology. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Life After General Motors: Day 1 at E.D.S.

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: PLANO, Tex., June 7

 BODY:
Electronic Data Systems begins trading Monday on the New York Stock Exchange as a separate company, free after a dozen years of ownership by the General Motors Corporation. But E.D.S., the nation's largest independent computer-services provider, has been revving its engine, trying even to line up business from General Motors' rivals, for more than a year.
At the company's Virtual Reality Center in Detroit, open since April 1995, E.D.S. has courted executives who had shied away from G.M. Visitors to the center saw how to build and test virtual products in virtual factories, even walking virtual assembly lines to make sure that every employee and robot was productively placed. 
 "Last year all the automobile companies came into the center, and I mean all of them," said Bob Voiers, the center's director. A top E.D.S. executive said the company had already reached agreements to provide services to several Asian, European and American auto makers.
With its own stock and no need for laborious review by General Motors, E.D.S. will have much greater freedom to pursue partners, allies and customers of all sorts.
"There's no question that it's going to give them additional economies and flexibility," said Dennie M. Welsh, general manager of I.B.M. Global Services, the consulting, maintenance and computer-services unit that is a chief rival of Electronic Data.
E.D.S. unbound is unlikely, however, to become E.D.S. unstoppable. In the hot, high-growth computer services business, International Business Machines' $12.7 billion in sales last year surpassed E.D.S.'s $12.4 billion, according to the Gartner Group, a research firm in Stamford, Conn. (E.D.S. calls the I.B.M. revenue figure suspect.)
To prosper, E.D.S., which is based in Plano, Tex., just north of Dallas, must show clients how far it has come from its origins under Ross Perot, as a regiment of computer specialists with management skills borrowed from the military.
Although Mr. Perot sold the company to General Motors in 1984, as recently as last summer, at Mr. Perot's midterm political convention in Dallas, the House minority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, referred to "E.D.S., Ross's company." E.D.S. executives shuddered.
"For the first time in our history we're not under the shadow of either Perot or G.M.," Lester M. Alberthal Jr., the company's chief executive, said in an interview this week, with a contented grin. "Our challenge is to carve out either an image or a brand."
If E.D.S. is looking for a more human face, it won't be his. "C.E.O.'s aren't going to buy business because they see my face on television," said Mr. Alberthal, the shy, guarded antithesis of a modern computer baron.
E.D.S. has been looking for ways to let people know how often it sets up everything from automated bank teller and airline reservations systems to World Wide Web pages. Late last year, with the split with G.M. pending, E.D.S. hired Bates Worldwide as its first major, global advertising agency.
Its ultimate audience consists of chief executives. Rivals like Andersen Consulting have had greater success in advising chief executives how technology can transform their companies and then carrying out these plans.
E.D.S. hoped to buy its way into the thick of management consulting with its $600 million purchase last year of A. T. Kearney. But analysts say that E.D.S. employees are still learning how to present themselves as canny corporate advisers "instead of how people know them, which is with the Ross Perot 'take the beach' mentality," as Bonnie Digrius, a Gartner Group vice president, put it.
E.D.S. executives complain that their reputation have lagged behind their evolution. "Nobody who has met me can say that E.D.S. is a highly regimented bunch of robots," said Gary J. Fernandes, the company's vice chairman. (He may have been an Army first lieutenant from a military family, but he collects rare first editions of Bertrand Russell, the philosopher and pacifist.)
Because the split with G.M. was announced in August, analysts foresee no great surprises in the stock market on Monday.
Under G.M.'s ownership. E.D.S. was listed as General Motors class E stock. "E.D.S. has traded as if it were an independent company for an awful long time," said Bill Rabin of J. P. Morgan Securities. Some new buyers might show up, he said, especially among institutional investors forbidden from owning special stock issues like G.M. class E. The company's expected inclusion in the Standard & Poor's 500 index will also produce demand.
Independence is also likely to help E.D.S. with acquisitions. Because the class E shares had no direct ownership or transaction value, E.D.S. had to pay cash. Now it can use its new stock, although Federal regulations require it to wait two years to begin realizing the full financial advantages.
Don't expect any mega-deals, however.
"We haven't gone through what we've gone through to become independent only to throw that independence away," Mr. Alberthal said. E.D.S. will instead hunt for smaller, niche and foreign acquisitions. Major alliances with communications or computer-hardware companies are also possible, he added, noting that E.D.S. and Sprint were already doing much more business together.
Mr. Fernandes, the company's chief deal maker, said that while G.M.'s ownership provided expertise in manufacturing and in running a vast, global computer web, it also killed a planned merger with Sprint as well as several other deals.
Mr. Alberthal observed that his telephone conference negotiations with General Motors were often shared by more than 30 lawyers.
G.M. plans to gradually seek other bidders for computer services.
E.D.S. faces the delicate task of marketing talents gained from its work for G.M., which reached nearly $4 billion last year, without having its former parent or its rivals suspect E.D.S. of trafficking in trade secrets.
E.D.S. executives describe their initial assignments for other auto companies -- in areas like consulting and systems integration, or linking computer equipment from different makers -- as modest. But these give E.D.S. its first inroads into the broader, $36 billion information technology market among auto makers other than G.M.
The separation will open other new fields as well, E.D.S. says. A few years ago, a company executive approached John C. Malone, chief executive of Tele-Communications Inc., the cable television giant, about a partnership. His response was curt. "No way would we ever do a deal with someone trying to put us out of business," he said, alluding to the satellite-television plans of G.M.'s Hughes Electronics unit.
"We're not trying to put you out of business," the E.D.S. executive responded.
"But you're a fellow traveler," Mr. Malone shot back.
Now that E.D.S. is a fellow traveler no more, its executives hope that Hughes rivals in aerospace, military contracting and electronics, and competitors of G.M.'s finance unit, will emerge as potential customers.
Rival auto makers in particular, Mr. Voiers, said, have awakened to the new virtual reality. Since last year, he said, their attitude has changed from, "Gee, I wonder how we can do business with these guys who are owned by G.M." to "Gee, I wonder how they can help us."

HEADLINE: As Trade Booms, Little Fear of a Communist

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, June 5

 BODY:
Surrounded by beaver coats, ermine jackets and fox trim hats, Perry Green happily remembered the recent morning here when 13 Russian women walked into his store empty-handed -- and walked out with 15 mink coats.
But conversation in his chilly fur vault heated up when the rotund Alaskan furrier looked at the coming presidential elections on the far side of the Bering Strait. Noting that only a year ago he opened another store, at Anchorage's airport, to cater to Russian tourists who come for the variety, quality and low prices they do not find at home, he said: "I don't think the Communists will win. Even if they do, once you have tasted freedom, you can't shut it off." 
 Five years ago this week, with the advent of regularly scheduled air service by Aeroflot and Alaska Airlines after the collapse of the Soviet Union, the decades-old "ice curtain" effectively melted between the Russian Far East and the American Northwest.
While Russian-American trade has grown by about $1 billion a year since 1992, some of the fastest growth has been registered in sales from Alaska, Oregon and Washington. With container ships now leaving Tacoma, Wash., each week for the Russian Far East, exports from the Pacific Northwest now total about half a billion dollars a year, giving the region a healthy trade surplus with the Far East, in contrast to the United States' overall trade deficit with Russia.
After opening a trade office in Vladivostok, the largest city of the Russian Far East, Washington State now sells apples, computers and Boeing jets to Russia. Seattle entrepreneurs have exported a microbrewery to Vladivostok and are lining up bands for a grunge rock concert this fall: Vladirockstok.
Russia opened a consulate in Seattle in 1993, its first new one in the United States in 20 years. Today, frost-free Seattle is fast becoming a Miami for the Russian Far East, with about 45,000 Russians in residence. Some of these are affluent Russian businessmen who have bought houses and apartments there, and, fleeing the gangland violence of Russia's "wild East," have moved their families over.
Here in Alaska, Russia's stamp is as ancient as the colonial place names: Nikolai, Tolstoi Point, and Glory of Russia Cape.
Today, Anchorage is virtually equidistant by jet from Los Angeles and Vladivostok. As trans-Bering interchanges intensify, 14 Alaskan cities and towns have signed sister city agreements with Russian Far East municipalities. Regular flights now link Anchorage to cities of Russia's Pacific Rim. From Fairbanks, Jack Randolph, a regional director for Rotary International, last month chartered six new Rotary Clubs across the Russian Far East.
After five years of soaring business and cultural ties, many Alaskans and Washingtonians are now closely following Russia's June 16 presidential elections, in which President Boris N. Yeltsin is facing a strong challenge from a Communist candidate, Gennadi A. Zyuganov.
Here, in the shadow of the onion domes and robin's-egg blue trim of the new Russian Orthodox Cathedral, Father E. Nicholas Harris warned darkly of the threat posed by Mr. Zyuganov, saying, "We are very leery that the Communists would come back and take over again."
"We Americans forget very, very fast," said the priest, whose church is part of an archipelago of 88 Russian Orthodox communities along Alaska's southern coastline. "There were 70 years of Communism -- and, after five years of business, we put it out of our minds."
In recent weeks, by signing a peace treaty with Chechnya, abolishing the draft and stressing previous economic failures under Communism, Mr. Yeltsin appears to have gained an edge with the electorate. But even if he were to lose, many Alaska business people cannot imagine that a new Russian government would try to turn back the clock.
At an office near the port here, with electronic mail from Russia glowing on the computer screens of the Alaska Russia Company, David A. Heatwole asked oratorically: "What happens if Yeltsin loses? Nothing.
"What people don't realize is that changes in Russia are driven by the people," said Mr. Heatwole, president of the company, which exports food and earth-moving equipment to Magadan, a gold mining city close to the Arctic Circle built by Stalin 60 years ago as a gateway to the gulag. "Politicians are politicians -- to remain in power they have to provide economic growth," he said.
At an Anchorage Wal-Mart, four Russian businesswomen were inspecting cosmetics on Tuesday, talking contentedly in Russian about "the little prices, the little prices." They were from Sakhalin, a vast island, much of which was occupied by the Japanese in the first half of this century. The entire island was off-limits to foreigners until the early part of this decade.
A hometown booster, Nadezhda A. Snezhkina, pressed on a curious American a full-color, bilingual Russian-English tourist brochure, prepared by the Mayor of her city, Kholmsk.
"No one seriously thinks that we could return to history -- maybe there will be some limitations," reflected Mrs. Snezhkina, who directs a municipal trading company.
A similar view came from Charles B. Neff, director of the American Business Center, an organization that is financed by the United States Government and has given small business training to 7,000 Russians in the last three years.
"We are past the point of going back to Brezhnev," said Mr. Neff, whose organization, based in Anchorage, concentrates on the Russian Far East. "Most people think that if Zyuganov comes and tries some things in the old style, he will eventually have to try the way of the market."
In what would be a major commitment to the market, the Marathon Oil Company is expected to announce within two weeks that the international consortium it leads, the Sakhalin Energy Investment Company, will go ahead with a multibillion-dollar oil and gas investment for the island.
Alaska is expected to be the staging area for many of the companies in the project.
"Everyone is just holding out and waiting for the big oil development in Sakhalin," said Anne Sudkamp, editor of Russian Far East News, a business monthly published by the University of Alaska. Reflecting growing business interest, a rival monthly, Russian Far East Update, is published in Seattle.
Determined to win a major share of the oil service business, Alaska has signed a sister state accord with Sakhalin. Alaska Airlines is studying expanding service to the provincial capital, Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk. In 1991, this airline made a cautious foray into Russia, with summer service to two cities. Now, it has year-round service to four cities: Khabarovsk, Magadan, Petropavlovsk and Vladivostok.
As stores here continue to stock 220-volt appliances for visiting Russian tourists, many Alaskan business executives predict that trade will grow with the Russian Far East -- in part because of the region's traditional autonomy from far-off Moscow, and in part because of its heavy reliance on imports.
Last year, after supplies failed to arrive from Moscow, one Russian Far East province turned to the Tesoro Alaska Petroleum Company for imports of jet fuel and gasoline. Now the oil company is looking for a Russian partner to open a chain of gasoline stations in Vladivostok.
The Russian Far East, an area about two-thirds the size of the lower 48 states, imports about 75 percent of its food. Few traders here believe that a Communist president would risk closing off food imports from the United States, a natural supplier.
"Even if the Communists do come back, they won't be able to switch everything back," said Michael J. Francis, food purchasing manager for Slava Export, an Anchorage trading company that on any given day has about five food containers on ships shuttling from Tacoma to the Russian Far East.
As Mr. Francis talked here on Tuesday, Slava's president, Steve Zelner, was in Khabarovsk signing leases on apartments that he planned to renovate and sublet to visiting American businessmen this fall.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2056 words

HEADLINE: ATLANTA LEADERS SEE RACIAL GOALS AS OLYMPIC IDEAL

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 9

 BODY:
All across America, affirmative action has been chased into retreat by lawmakers and judges. But here in Atlanta, the private corporation that is staging this summer's Olympic Games has awarded almost a third of its $387 million in construction and vending contracts to companies owned primarily by minorities and women.
Experts on affirmative action say such numbers are unheard-of in the private sector. But to city leaders, the commitment to minority participation is a reflection of a political reality so entrenched that it has come to be known as "the Atlanta way." 
Twenty-two years ago, after Atlantans elected Maynard H. Jackson Jr. as their first black Mayor, the city pioneered the practice of encouraging joint ventures between white-owned companies and those with minority or female owners. Two decades later, even as such programs elsewhere are being attacked as reverse discrimination, Atlanta's political establishment still embraces affirmative action with enthusiasm.
"Everybody who is a person of color in this country has benefited from affirmative action," said Mayor Bill Campbell, the third black to lead a city that is now 67 percent black. "There's not been anybody who's gotten into a college on their own, nobody who's gotten a job on their own, no one who's prospered as a businessman or businesswoman on their own without affirmative action.
"The sad truth in this country, the sad truth even in the city of Atlanta, is that without our affirmative-action programs, our minority businesses would wither."
In 1973, the year Mr. Jackson was first elected, a tenth of a percent of the city's contract dollars went to companies with minority and female owners. Last year, the figure was 40 percent, exceeding the goal of 36 percent the city had set by statute. And these companies tend to have far more minority employees than do white-owned companies. (Black-owned companies here get far more business than do those owned by women or other minorities.)
When bidding to be host of the 1996 Olympic Games, leaders here used Atlanta's history as the birthplace of the civil rights movement to sell the city to the International Olympic Committee, particularly members from third-world countries. Now they say they have used the Olympics to demonstrate how the political victories won in the civil rights era can produce economic benefits, too.
Under pressure from Atlanta's black leaders, the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, the private corporation established by city officials to run the event, made it clear to businesses seeking contracts that it expected them to have significant partnerships with companies owned by minority members and women. While the committee never adopted formal quotas or goals, it used the city's 36 percent goal as a benchmark.
Companies that submitted bids with insufficient minority participation did so at their peril. Those that said they could not find qualified minority partners were provided with lists of names compiled by the Olympic committee. "People soon realized that the team with the greatest minority participation was usually the team that won the contract if all things were equal," said former Mayor Andrew J. Young, a co-chairman of the committee.
As a result, virtually every new site for the Summer Games, which begin on July 19, was built with significant minority participation. Almost every purchasing and vending contract signed by the Olympic committee includes a minority partner.
As of March, 32 percent of the committee's $387 million in procurement contracts had been granted to minority companies, including 35 percent of the $297 million spent on design and construction.
Olympic officials like Shirley C. Franklin, who oversees the committee's equal economic opportunity program, said it would leave a lasting legacy of biracial business relationships.
"The whole idea of the Games is to bring people together in peaceful competition," Mr. Young said, "and we did that in our contracts and services as well as on the playing fields."
The beneficiaries vary from Herman J. Russell, whose company, the H.J. Russell Company, the nation's largest black contractor, won a 29 percent share of the $207 million spent to build the Centennial Olympic Stadium, the Games' main arena, to Thomas L. Harris Jr., a black landscaper who was hired to help install the stadium's track.
Six years ago, Mr. Harris founded a lawn care service, earning $8,000 in his first year by toting a mower around town in the trunk of his car. Last year, his company collected revenues of $525,000, most of it from his Olympic joint venture contracts, and he had as many as 35 employees.
His partnership with Mondo S.P.A., the Italian company hired to make and install the stadium's vulcanized rubber track, began several years ago when Mr. Harris peered out his office window and noticed a man with a tripod surveying the site that was to become a warm-up track for Olympic athletes.
Mr. Harris said he wandered out to chat with the surveyor, a Mondo official, and extended a standing offer to the man to use his office as a refuge from the Atlanta sun. His Southern hospitality paid off months later when the surveyor called Mr. Harris to ask whether he was interested in becoming the company's minority partner.
"I said, 'Sure but I don't have any experience with tracks,' " Mr. Harris said. "He said, 'No problem; we plan to train you.' "

A Divisive Scramble, Then Acceptance
Getting to this point has not always been easy. As Marva Jones Brooks, a former city attorney, said, "One of the most incendiary, combustible mixes in public life is race and money."City leaders past and present said it took some tough persuasion by Mr. Jackson, who was Mayor in the early 1990's, to persuade Billy Payne, the Olympic committee's chief executive officer, that he should have an affirmative-action plan.
"It was the last clearly divisive moment for the Olympics," said Michael L. Lomax, the former chairman of the Fulton County Commission in Atlanta. "Everybody was scrambling to get their piece of the pie and it was ugly."
It was not the first time Mr. Jackson had fought this battle. When he first took office, in 1974, he infuriated the white business community by holding up the construction of Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport until contractors took on minority partners. "I still have the scars on my back to prove that the resistance was brutal," he said.
But for two decades, the city's commitment to affirmative action has not wavered. Since 1989, when the Supreme Court ruled that public contracts could be set aside for female- and minority-owned companies only if governments could demonstrate current effects of past discrimination, dozens of cities and states, from New York City to Louisiana, have moved to dismantle their programs. Atlanta, by contrast, responded to the ruling by commissioning a study that documented past discrimination, and its program has not been successfully challenged.
Like states and cities elsewhere, Atlanta has had problems over the years with fraudulent joint ventures, in which minority contractors are hired by white-owned companies to provide the necessary racial balance but do little actual work.
"There were not that many qualified people around, so you had shams," said Marvin M. Black, a prominent white contractor based in Norcross, an Atlanta suburb. "Businessmen have a way of accomplishing these things. That's called good old American ingenuity."
Atlanta's program has also been criticized for adding costs to some public works projects, for temporarily supporting minority businesses that later failed, and for disproportionately helping a few minority companies win big contracts.
"I think it's worked to put money in the hands of a few politically powerful blacks," said Robert J. Proctor, a white lawyer who has filed a reverse-discrimination lawsuit against the Atlanta Board of Education. "It's used as a cover for political patronage."

While Some Benefit, Others Feel Blocked
The defenders of joint venture programs acknowledge the problems, but contend that they have eased over time with the help of rigorous contract reviews. And grumbling has been minimal during Olympic preparations, largely because Atlanta's economy is so strong that work has been plentiful.
Some white Atlantans, of course, oppose affirmative action on principle or because they feel locked out by the joint venture system. "I don't believe I should be denied a contract that I'm the lowest responsible bidder on just because I'm white," Mr. Black said. "If that's not discrimination, I don't know what is."
The system in Atlanta can be particularly difficult for small, white-owned businesses squeezed out when minority companies are linked with large white-owned companies that have plenty of capital.
Paul Muldawer, a white architect and longtime political ally of Mr. Young, is deeply embittered that he failed to win a piece of an Olympic contract for designing a promenade linking the campuses of the Atlanta University Center. Mr. Muldawer said he was excluded even though he did 470 hours of preliminary studies of the project for the Olympic committee at no charge.
"When it came time to bid, I wasn't even short-listed, even though they used my plan as the basis for bidding for architectural selection," he said. Mr. Young said, "There was some serious injustice there."
Like many of his white competitors, Mr. Black says he rarely bids on public works projects now because of the difficulty in finding minority partners and the increased paperwork required of joint ventures.

Will the Jobs Last Beyond the Games?
But other white contractors say they overcame their early resistance to joint ventures and eventually came to accept it as the only way to win public contracts in Atlanta.
Robert M. Holder Jr., chairman of a large construction company and a co-chairman of the Olympic committee, formed a lasting and lucrative relationship with Mr. Russell that has brought the two companies nearly $1 billion in contracts over the last 20 years. "Originally, we had huge concerns about competence and all of our prejudices were solidly in place," Mr. Holder said. "But we've learned more than we knew then, and there's been a high degree of growth in the competence of the minority infrastructure."
Yet many established black contractors, architects and engineers still find it difficult to win private-sector business, making them heavily dependent on government joint ventures. "I've been in business here for 20 years and a lot of people know I exist," said Oscar L. Harris Jr., a leading black architect. "But I don't get a lot of phone calls."
Even Mr. Russell, whose company has 1,500 employees and revenue of $179 million, says the playing field remains tilted. "You have to prove yourself much harder than your white counterparts," he said. "It's just taken for granted when people look at the color of your skin that you don't have your act together."
 Despite the success of Atlanta's affirmative-action programs, much of the city remains impoverished. The city grew blacker and poorer in the last 25 years as white residents fled to the suburbs.
While the percentage of black residents in managerial and professional jobs has increased slightly, the percentage of black families living in poverty has grown from 25 percent in 1970 to 32 percent in 1990, according to the Census. In 1990, the average black family's income was 26 percent of the average white family's, down from 52 percent in 1970.
Many civic leaders worry that post-Olympic Atlanta may face deepening racial and economic problems, particularly if the private sector does not join local governments in providing opportunities for minority businesses.
"What will happen to the class of African-Americans who have been so successful over the last 20 years?" asked Mr. Lomax, the former chairman of the Fulton County Commission. "Is this city going to embrace them with the same kind of opportunities their experience warrants or is there going to be a glass ceiling for them?
"Los Angeles ended the 1984 Olympics with this tremendous aura of success. And a decade later it was a city in flames because there was still this deep divide between the haves and have-nots."

HEADLINE: Corrections

 BODY:
An article in Business Day on May 20 about the job prospects of recent college graduates with journalism degrees misattributed an estimate of where the graduates are seeking work. The statement that three-quarters of journalism graduates will seek jobs in print, radio, television and Internet journalism was based on interviews with educators, placement directors and professionals around the country. It was not a finding of a survey of graduates by Professor Lee Becker of Ohio State University.

HEADLINE: Federal Reserve Board Has Too Much Power

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I'm one of many who disagree with your strong endorsement (editorial, June 8) of Alan Greenspan's record as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. 
 Thousands of jobs and billions of dollars' worth of useful work have been sacrificed in the name of a threat of inflation that was faint to nonexistent.
Unjustified interest rate increases have imposed burdens on home buyers, small business, consumers and others whose borrowing costs were raised.
But the central issue is far more important than who should head the Fed. It is the legitimacy of an institution that combines enormous power with virtually no accountability to the public or its elected representatives.
Conceived early in this century as a rational solution to real problems, the Federal Reserve Board has become master instead of the servant it was designed to be.
Mr. Greenspan supports legislation that would strike from the 1978 Full Employment and Balanced Growth Act, known as Humphrey-Hawkins, the Federal Reserve Board's responsibility to encourage full employment as well as to guard against inflation.
With fiscal policy essentially neutered by a bipartisan compact, this would eliminate the only mandate, weak though it is, that preserves the original vision of the drafters and their predecessors who understood that public policy is the only bulwark against the renewal of large-scale, continuing unemployment.
Mr. Greenspan's decisions are eloquent evidence that an economy whose level of employment relies primarily on decisions and policies of the Federal Reserve will continue to impose high levels of unemployment and underemployment, stagnant real earnings and widespread economic insecurity.
We need a national discussion about our central bank's power and accountability. Without it, it will matter little whether Mr. Greenspan or someone else wields power that no one should have.
 
SUMNER M. ROSEN
New York, June 9, 1996
 
The writer is professor emeritus of social policy at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: Crashes of Asteroids Shed Tiny Diamonds In Glittering Trillions

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
SPEEDING rocks from space that have slammed into Earth periodically over the ages are usually seen as agents of destruction and death, begetting global palls of dust that block sunlight, disrupt the climate and do in creatures like the dinosaurs.
But it turns out that the same upheavals that blast craters in solid granite and spew tons of incandescent rock into the sky also tend to produce diamonds, trillions of them, more than any thief ever dreamed of. 
 Alas for gem lovers and investment bankers, most of the impact diamonds are microscopic. But some are larger -- the size of match heads or peanuts -- and are considered good enough for industrial use, if not jewelry.
But over all, experts say, the discovery is likely to be more of a boon for understanding Earth's cataclysmic past than for commercial diamond mining. That history is important because periodic strikes from space are thought to have repeatedly shaped life's evolution, killing off some species and making room for others. Yet such violent episodes tend to be surrounded by mystery and debate.
Scientists have now found diamonds in more than a half-dozen impact zones around the globe and are hunting for other places where the enormous heats and pressures of cosmic collisions have turned plain old carbon into the hardest substance known to humans. To date, it appears that no crater examined for diamonds has failed to reveal them.
"The question is whether diamond is going to be a ubiquitous phase in the ejecta," Dr. Peter S. Fiske, a planetary scientist at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California, said in an interview. "It's just a question of going to look at these other craters."
The American Geophysical Union, the world's largest professional group devoted to earth studies, based in Washington, recently held its first meeting on impact diamonds and mineralogy, which Dr. Fiske helped organize.
The rocks of old craters, experts say, probably hide thousands and perhaps millions of tons of diamonds. The rub is getting them. Candidate rocks can be very deep, buried over the eons by such geological processes as erosion and sedimentation.
And even when in hand, raw rocks have to sit for weeks and months in caustic baths that slowly eat away softer rock with deadly cocktails of nitric, hydrochloric, perchloric and sulfuric acids, among other nasty substances. But the residue is pure diamond.
Western experts say that the Russians have investigated mining impact craters for diamonds in remote parts of Siberia and that Western companies are quietly conducting similar studies.
"It may be that a lot of craters have diamonds," Dr. Richard A. F. Grieve, a geophysicist at the Geological Survey of Canada who is a leading crater-identification expert, said in an interview. "You never know, in the right place they might be commercial grade."
One company, Dr. Grieve added, is now looking for gemstones in a North American crater. "They don't think it's commercial, but they don't want to get caught with their pants down," he said, adding that he was not allowed to disclose the company's name.
The world's largest known crater, named Sudbury after a nearby town, is a giant scar some 155 miles across in Ontario, Canada.
Earth's face is marred by 150 or so authenticated impact craters. More are added at the rate of up to five a year as geologists find new evidence of collision fury. But some candidates repeatedly fail to make the list. The problem is knowing how to distinguish the scars of cosmic impacts from those made by volcanoes and earthquakes and gentler processes like sedimentation and glacial action.
Diamonds are seen as a likely new way to identify eroded impact craters and to investigate the planet's violent past. The durability of diamonds, experts say, may shed light on extremely old impact scars that have lost their other characteristic features.
"There's no reason they can't to go back to the Cambrian," Robert M. Hough, a diamond-crater expert at the Open University in England, said in an interview of impact diamonds from the geological age 600 million years ago when marine creatures ruled the earth.
"Diamond is very interesting," agreed Dr. Virgil L. Sharpton, a crater expert at the Lunar and Planetary Institute in Houston. "It helps distinguish features produced by these very high-pressure impacts from all the other things they can be confused with. That's a tremendous tool."
Scientists estimate Earth's surface has been struck by perhaps hundreds of thousand asteroids and comets big enough to carve out craters more than a half-mile wide. Most of those craters have vanished without a trace in the past few billion years, often carried deep into Earth's interior through geologic action.
Dr. Sharpton said new signposts like diamonds might eventually quadruple the number of known craters, raising the total from 150 to 600 or more. "There are plenty out there to be discovered," he said.
Diamonds are traditionally thought of as travelers from Earth's deep interior, from depths of roughly 100 miles and perhaps as deep as 300 miles. How they form there is well known. Crushing pressures and blistering heats work in unison to squeeze carbon into stones of unrivaled hardness.
Some of the deep carbon may be elemental graphite, the same greasy-feeling, black stuff used in lead pencils. Another source may be carbonate rocks like limestone, which are driven into the planet's interior by the slow, continuous motion of Earth's tectonic plates. Diamond is simply carbon in which the atoms are packed closer together than in graphite.
The tidy picture of diamond production began to blur as scientists found that meteorites were often riddled with tiny diamonds. They were believed to have formed by the shock of collision between solar-system bodies, like asteroids, as well as by distant stellar explosions billions of years ago. Some of these extra-solar diamonds, whose discovery was announced in 1987, were smaller than viruses and their tiny widths measured in numbers of atoms.
Scientists have known for decades that earthen scars from cosmic collisions display all kinds of alchemy from shock waves made of enormously high heats and pressures -- a process known as shock metamorphism, which causes irreversible changes in rocks. The effects include melting, conical fractures known as shatter cones, microscopic distortions in minerals and various glasses and high-pressure minerals.
It was the Russians, however, who discovered that shock metamorphism can transform the carbon of bedrock into diamonds. Not only that, the diamonds are often much larger than the ones found in meteorites and sometimes easy to see with the naked eye.
Western experts say the discovery was made in the early 1970's and was kept a state secret for nearly two decades. With the collapse of the Soviet Union, much information began to leak out, including the fact that the Russians had investigated mining impact craters for diamonds.
A main exploratory site is the Popigai crater in the wilds of northern Siberia. About 60 miles in diameter, it was formed 35 million years ago. Viktor L. Masaitis of the Karpinsky Geological Institute in Leningrad reported on its diamond content at the recent geophysical union meeting, saying the shock metamorphism had occurred in bedrock graphite. He also showed photographs of the resulting diamonds.
"Some are peanut-sized," said Dr. Fiske of the Livermore laboratory. "They're really impressive."
Dr. Grieve of the Geological Survey of Canada said that Russians had drilled about 500 bore holes into Popigai to map its diamond distribution in three dimensions. "We eventually realized it was to look at economic potential," he said, adding that the unfinished work had now collapsed with Russia's lack of research money.
In Europe, the trail of diamond evidence was picked up by a team of scientists from the Open University, Oxford University, Cambridge University and University College in London. In southern Germany they probed the Ries Crater, the 15-mile wide hole dug by a colliding asteroid 15 million years ago.
They found billions of tiny diamonds embedded in the melted rock of a characteristic local stone, named suevite. The largest diamond was the size of a pinhead.
"They'd make good engagement rings for an ant," Dr. Iain Gilmour of the Open University told reporters, "but Liz Taylor won't be very impressed." He added that the same kind of diamond-laden rock was used to build the church and the town hall in the medieval town of Nordlingen, which lies in the Ries crater.
Atomic evidence suggested the diamonds came not from the exploding asteroid, whose load of diamonds, if any, probably vaporized during the fireball, but from condensation of vaporized bedrock. And the condensation apparently occurred in midair in the hot fireball, where pressures were lower than in the ground and shock waves less powerful. Thus, the diamonds were smaller.
The main clue to the midair formation was that most of the diamonds formed in combination with silicon carbide, a union also seen in a common industrial process for the production of diamonds known a chemical vapor deposition.
The team announced its results last Nov. 2 in Nature, the weekly British journal. Dr. Christian Koeberl, a geochemist at the University of Vienna in Austria, writing in Nature, hailed the discovery.
"Never before have such composites of diamond and silicon carbide been found in nature," he said.
The British team is now hunting for diamonds in rocks from the 14-mile Rochechouart crater in France and the six-mile Mien crater in Sweden.
A final aspect of the new discoveries about diamonds concerns tiny diamonds created and thrown hundreds and even thousands miles by one of the biggest known collisions of all, the one that 65 million years ago probably helped do in the dinosaurs and definitely dug a crater 105 miles wide, the remnants of which lie below the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico. The crater is known as Chicxulub, for a town near its heart.
That asteroid kicked up iridium-rich dust that has been discovered around the globe.
Beginning in 1991, scientists began finding billions of tiny diamonds, which were often mixed with iridium. Both occurred in the rocks of geological boundary between the Cretaceous and Tertiary periods 65 million years ago. And no diamonds were found in sediments immediately above or below that layer.
The first such diamonds were found in Alberta, Canada, then in Colorado, New Mexico and Mexico, with the diamonds getting progressively larger the closer they came to the Chicxulub impact crater.
"It represents a very important discovery," said Dr. Hough of the Open University, who reported on the Mexican find at the geophysical union meeting. "The diamonds that we found there are larger than ones in the Western United States."
He added that the British team was broadening its hunt for Cretaceous-Tertiary diamonds to Italy and New Zealand.
Dr. Sharpton of the Lunar and Planetary Institute said that the diamond signature of the Cretaceous-Tertiary impact in time might surpass that of iridium in importance. "In many cases there is no iridium anomaly" in the global rocks of the period, he said. "So it's very handy."
The suspicion among scientists is that the bigger the impact, the bigger the diamonds.
This logic would make Sudbury in Canada and Chicxulub in Mexico prime targets for diamond investigation.
With a laugh, Dr. Sharpton, an expert on the Chicxulub crater, noted that its eroded remnants were so deep beneath the land's surface than they were impossible to retrieve except with long drills, which are too small for a mining operation.
Many scientists say reward enough is the new understanding of the planet's dim past that the diamond finds promise to deliver.
"It's a time-consuming process," Dr. Sharpton said of the months of acid baths often needed to extract the impact diamonds. "But it's something from which we can get important results."

Killer asteroids produce enough heat and pressure in their fireballs to make trillions of diamonds, a form of carbon in which atoms are packed in a tight lattice.
 
"A Trail of Glitter"
The relatively low pressures at the edge of the fireball apparently make smaller diamonds; meanwhile, higher pressures in the bedrock below produce larger ones.
