HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Color Them White

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Think of it: 34 white-congregation churches, synagogues or mosques are burned down in one part of the country, 23 in the last 17 months.
Would it take the President a year to talk to the American people about it? Or Republican Presidential candidates? Would the public be satisfied when the Federal law enforcement establishment -- Attorney General, F.B.I. and Federal attorneys -- said they had not been able to break the case but had not run across any evidence of conspiracy? 
 Would much of the press and TV wait until we got to number 20 or so before deciding it was a big story?
And how about ordinary, non-press, non-official Americans? When would they wake up to it? Would it take 30 and counting before supposedly alert and involved Americans would say, as a few did at a lunch this weekend -- "Say, how long has this been going on? I just heard about it."
Would every major Christian and Jewish organization across the country come up with money to rebuild the houses of worship or would that be left to a few, the rest sitting on their pews and purses?
We know what would happen and what would not, don't we -- no use pounding the point. But there is use, if only for the soul's sake, in saying that the reaction to the burning of black churches, now climbing to epidemic, is not disgraceful -- it is disgusting. Little political commotion, late press attention, relief efforts ranging from zero to mingy. If I were a black man I would say it is because the churches are black, not white. As a white man I say exactly the same thing.
We do not know if there is one conspiracy or several or if there are just so many race-sick people around to copy each other. But we do know that the same law enforcement establishment was unable to track down the Unabomber for 17 years until his brother turned him in. It failed to enforce warrants issued against the "Freemen" of Montana -- free of everything but their own hatreds -- until they were able to use their children as hostages. So the police have had to sit around for months while the haters inside make a clown of the law.
The figures in the first paragraph are conservative. They come from Morris Dees, founder of the Southern Poverty Law Center, who has done as much as anybody to alert law enforcement agencies to the lethal dangers of organized hatred. The National Council of Churches said last month that 53 churches had been burned since 1990, including 23 so far in 1996.
Whatever the correct figures, I believe the fires came from the hatreds of segregation -- either its embers or the beginning of a new blaze. Segregation is usually preached by extremists, white and black. They feed and live by it. But although they denounce the thought it can also come from liberals who have decided that integration has failed and are ready to give up on it.
In his new book about integration, "Tragic Failure," Tom Wicker says the mainstream parties appear to have neither the will nor leadership to bring about economic advances for most African-Americans and the "social leveling" that would accompany it. His remedy is for blacks to form a new party "dedicated to economic growth for black and white."
Mr. Wicker never says what would happen to blacks running for public office if all blacks split off into a new party, what cracks would widen to chasms in American society, what utter joy it would give to white and black supremacists to see blacks march off to a political ghetto. He does not fill in the idea. He just puts it forward two or three times and his publisher blurbs it up good. Like Wernher von Braun, he fires the missile and lets it land where it may. I think it is a dud but I want to do my bit to water it out.
Mr. Wicker is peeved at writers, including me, who urged more blacks to come out against Louis Farrakhan.
Whether the church fires are an actual conspiracy or several, or a copycat conspiracy of the mind, the worst thing that could happen to America would be more of the ghettoization, mental and physical, that is the fuel of race hatred.
As in the case of Louis Farrakhan I think it is the job of white and black, both, to renounce and turn away from ghettoization -- yesterday, today and forever.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls on Profit Taking And German Rates Outlook

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against the German mark and Japanese yen yesterday, weakened by profit taking and by speculation that Germany might delay further cuts in interest rates.
The dollar has been bolstered recently by signs of robust economic growth in the United States, suggesting that the Federal Reserve will be prompted to raise short-term interest rates. Higher rates typically make the dollar more attractive by increasing the returns on United States deposits. 
 On Friday, unexpected strength in the May employment report confirmed currency traders' expectations that rates would rise, and the dollar surged against the yen to its highest level in more than two years.
But traders sold dollars yesterday after remarks by Hans Tietmeyer, president of the Bundesbank, were interpreted to mean that the central bank might defer action on interest rates until it had more data on Germany's broadest measure of its money supply, known as M-3. Those data are due in a few weeks.
"The emphasis on the M-3 number may have stymied the market," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the Bank Leumi Trust Company.
Speculation has persisted that Germany must lower rates further to stimulate its anemic economy. The prospect of lower rates has put pressure on the mark and strengthened the dollar, so any suggestion that rates will remain constant in Germany can weaken the dollar.
Further hurting the dollar yesterday was selling whenever the dollar neared 110 yen.
In late trading in New York, the dollar fell to 109 yen, from 109.23 yen on Friday. The dollar also traded at 1.5350 marks, down from 1.5366 marks. The British pound slipped to $1.5345 from $1.5380.
Both Mr. Tietmeyer and his chief economist, Otmar Issing, said they foresaw a decline in the growth of M-3, which German monetary officials watch closely because they consider it a barometer of inflation. But traders said that any public discussion of M-3 by these officials was enough to suggest that there would be no Bundesbank action on rates until the information was released.
"I think it allows us to assume that a rate cut is sidelined at this point," Mr. Waxman said.
The dollar's weakness against the yen came despite a Japanese Government report that Japan's trade surplus shrank by 45 percent in April. Such news has tended to strengthen the dollar in the past.

HEADLINE: Images of Revolutions Old and New

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 10

 BODY:
Starting his career as a photographer in the early 1950's, Marc Riboud was lucky enough to have the founders of the Magnum photo agency as friends and advisers. While Henri Cartier-Bresson tried to broaden the young Frenchman's education, telling him what to read and what museums to visit, Robert Capa encouraged him to learn English and even arranged his first professional assignment.
Yet despite the help of these role models, Mr. Riboud said he always felt uncomfortable among photographers. "They had their own jargon, they knew how to push, they were tough," he recalled. "I was very shy. I had trouble looking people in the face. Eventually I thought, I have to go somewhere else." 
 So in 1956, he bought a second-hand Land Rover from George Rodger, another Magnum founder, and drove from London to Calcutta. For almost a year, working and traveling alone, he took photographs throughout India. But he wanted to go still farther East. And finally, on Dec. 31, 1956, after months of waiting for a visa, he crossed from Hong Kong into China and boarded a train for Beijing.
It was a major coup for him to become one of the first Western photographers to enter China since the Communist takeover of 1949. But more relevantly, he was allowed to return at regular intervals over the next four decades and witness China's transformation from a backward peasant land dominated by Mao Zedong to a money-driven society that seems ready to forget its ancient culture and customs in the name of profit.
Now white-haired but still full of energy at 72, Mr. Riboud is presenting his record of this astonishing metamorphosis at the Centre National de la Photographie in Paris through July 29. The show, "Marc Riboud: 40 Years of Photography in China," will go to Beijing in the fall and to the International Center of Photography in New York in the summer of 1997. A book with 134 black-and-white photographs from the exhibition is to be published next year by Harry N. Abrams.
Mr. Riboud insists that he is no expert China watcher. And he notes that he was not in China at many crucial political moments, including the height of the Cultural Revolution in the late 1960's, the deaths of Chairman Mao and Zhou Enlai in 1976 and the killing of pro-democracy students in Tiananmen Square in 1989. "I am not an analyst," he said in an interview at his Paris home. "I just collect impressions." But he was nonetheless a rare Western witness to both past and present of China, and his photographs serve as a memory.
On his first four-month trip, he was able to photograph Mao and Zhou at a banquet for a visiting Polish Prime Minister. But authorized to travel the country, he found he was more interested in the day-to-day lives of ordinary Chinese workers, peasants and students. Wandering the streets of Beijing, which he remembers as still having the atmosphere of a village, he found circus performers, puppeteers and peddlers. A few years later, they were no longer to be seen.
Visits to factories and universities were more complicated, Mr. Riboud recalled, because he was invariably accompanied by "a guardian angel," as he nicknamed his official guides. "I was shown students, but not those who were learning English," he said. "It was tricky. I would try to 'get lost,' but I couldn't make the guide feel I had done it on purpose or else he would lose face and the next day I would have nothing."
Still, in 1957, after only eight years under Communism, China was more relaxed than when he returned for another four-month visit in 1965. "By then the regime was consolidated," he said. "Huge Stalinist buildings were going up everywhere. People talked even less to foreigners. Street life was disappearing. Everyone was being made equal, and they all seemed equally poor." One photograph from that visit shows grim-faced children undergoing military training with wooden rifles.
At the time, though, Mr. Riboud felt sympathy for the Chinese revolution. "Coming from India, I could see a big difference," he said. "There was less misery than in India. One had the impression of a bit more dignity. In the West, we had understood that the Soviet Union was a complete failure. But I was tempted to believe that China could be the answer to societies where the rich become richer and the poor become poorer."
Only later did disillusionment set in. "The big disappointment was the total failure of the Great Leap Forward in the early 1960's, which led to millions of people dying of starvation," he said. "But in 1965, we didn't know that. I wanted to visit the Huang Shan Mountains in 1965 and was told it was not possible. I later learned that 1.5 million people died of famine in the region. Girls were fed less than boys, so girls died first."
This disaster was followed by the Cultural Revolution, when Westerners were decidedly unwelcome. Mr. Riboud was able to return in 1971, but he was refused a visa to cover Mao's funeral in 1976. "They told me, 'We know you're a friend of China, but our house is in disorder,' " he said.
After 1983, when he was finally allowed to travel to Huang Shan, Mr. Riboud returned to China often. Even then it was only in the late 1980's that he began to see China change before his eyes. Since 1992, he has traveled there 10 times. "When I crossed into Shenzhen for the first time 40 years ago, it was a fishermen's village," he said. "Today, it has three million people and rivals Hong Kong."
In the exhibition, the magnitude of China's economic revolution is startlingly evident in photographs that show the old and the new side by side: the uniformly drab Mao suits and the latest Western fashions, streets crowded with bicycles and today's traffic jams, traditional Chinese homes and glass-covered skyscrapers. But the two faces of China also coexist: a street scene in Shenzhen photographed in 1993 shows an impoverished man walking past posters of a pinup girl and of a baby.
Mr. Riboud finds the pace of change disturbing. "It's a bit like someone who becomes a millionaire in one week," he said. "If it's not good for an individual, I can't believe it's good for a country. Today money is suddenly the only value. No one speaks about politics, no one speaks about Tiananmen Square, no one speaks about Confucius. It's as if the Mao period were one big dramatic parenthesis, and now the Chinese have gone back to being tradesmen."
What worries him is the threat this poses to traditional Chinese culture. "The poetry, opera and painting that were part of the Chinese identity for a thousand years have gone," he said. "Bookstores are closing. All the music comes from Hong Kong. They're selling all their antiquities abroad. Everything in the West is being imitated. But their pride is still Chinese. They're all convinced that China will become the most important country in the world."

C17); Top left, children on a back street of Beijing in 1957; above, a couple being photographed with a backdrop of the Forbidden City in Beijing in 1957; top right, Young Pioneers training with wooden rifles in Shenyang, Liaoning Province, in 1965. HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rate Fears Push Prices Down Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The bond market continued to slide yesterday as prices remained under heavy pressure from investors who increasingly expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates next month.
The 30-year Treasury bond, a benchmark for the market, plunged 1 5/32, to 86 5/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, rose 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.12 percent, its highest level in more than a year. Between Friday and yesterday, bondholders have lost about $25 for each $1,000 invested. 
 Traders and analysts attributed yesterday's negative sentiment to carry-over selling from the drop of nearly one and a half points on Friday, the response to a stronger-than-expected labor report. The 30-year bond's yield has not been so high since May 4, 1995, when it was 7.16 percent.
John Burgess, managing director at Bankers Trust Investment Management, said he was not surprised by the market's behavior yesterday.
"On Thursday the market was coming to grips with the fact that the Fed might raise rates," he said. "so that Friday's report was a shock for the fixed-income market and today is a continuation of that trade."
"We think the Fed will tighten by August,' Mr. Burgess added, "but the market has yet to price that in, including upcoming supply."
Mr. Burgess predicted that rates would reach 6.5 percent on a two-year note and 7.25 percent on the long bond before the selling was through. "We have not seen any weak numbers thus far," he said. "One can't make an argument of weakness in the second half of the year."
Prices for commodity futures also rose yesterday, a reminder that inflation could accelerate if the economy was to continue to show signs of heating up. That would hurt bond investors by eroding the value of their investments. So far this year the flash points have been the volatile sectors of food and energy costs but now market participants are worried that wages may see an inflationary rise.
Bond prices eroded even further because the market was concerned with this week's inflation reports that could also show stronger-than-expected increases.
Commenting on possible Fed action, Greg Jones, an economist with MMS International in San Francisco, said: "While a tightening appears to be likely, it is not inevitable. Evidence of strong growth is plentiful, evidence of rising inflationary pressures is not."
Today, the Government will issue the Producer Price Index for May, with a view of price pressures at the manufacturing level. Tomorrow, it will report on prices at the consumer level. Expectations by economists polled by Bloomberg Business News are that producer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month, compared with four-tenths of 1 percent in April, while consumer prices climbed three-tenths of 1 percent, down from four-tenths of 1 percent in April.
"The fear of tighter monetary policy is gripping the Treasury market," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. But he added that a tightening at the July or August meeting of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, which sets rate policy, was not a foregone conclusion.
"Another hike in interest rates as part of a series of tightening moves is one thing," he said. "Reversing the course of monetary policy from easing to tightening is something else."
At the Treasury's weekly bills auction, interest rates were up and the results were a bit below average.
Traders said the average rates were 5.16 percent and 5.34 percent, for a three-month and six-month bill, respectively. The disappointing results, they said, are likely because of the increased size of the auction and weak bidding.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three and six-month bills:

SECTION: Section D; Page 7; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 735 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A White House Gaffe Puts Clinton in China's Corner

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration heads into the last week of a showdown with China over its failure to live up to a major trade agreement, an oversight by the White House is putting President Clinton in the politically delicate position of having to assert that China is opening markets and lowering its barriers to American companies.
The assurance would come in the form of a certification that is ordinarily part of routine renewal of the basic trade agreement that underlies all American trade ties with China. 
 On Friday, after a bipartisan group of Congressional opponents of renewing Beijing's preferential trade status declared that Mr. Clinton had failed to sign the certification last year, the White House said they were wrong. Senior officials in the United States trade representative's office said they were certain Mr. Clinton had signed the renewal more than a year ago and had simply failed to publish the notification in the Federal Register.
But today the White House and the trade office retracted that, saying that after a weekend check of the files, no one could find any evidence that the President had actually made a determination that China had "satisfactorily reciprocated" to a lowering of barriers by the United States. They also said there was no evidence that he had not signed it.
"This is an administrative error and we have taken steps to correct it," said Jay Ziegler, spokesman for Charlene Barshefsky, the trade representative, adding that a copy of the certification was being sent to Mr. Clinton for signature this week. "It has no legal significance."
The legal ramifications of the oversight probably are insignificant. By making his determination now, Mr. Clinton can assure that Congress goes ahead with its debate over extending most-favored-status treatment to China, which gives Beijing the benefit of the lowest tariffs and best trading arrangements the United States offers.
Congress has 60 days to review the President's decision to renew that preferred status. While the debate is expected to be heated, in the end China's trading status seems likely to be renewed, though perhaps under conditions Beijing may find onerous.
The political ramifications of the White House error, though, are harder to predict. The opponents of renewing trade preference -- who include liberals angry about China's human rights record and conservatives angry about its harassment of Taiwan -- are looking for any way they can to declare Mr. Clinton's strategy of "comprehensive engagement" with China a failure.
By discovering the White House's mistake and forcing the President to sign the determination this week, they put him in the potentially embarrassing position of declaring that China is making progress at the same time he is threatening sanctions because the Chinese have kept out American products and produced counterfeits of American goods.
Trade officials insisted today that there was nothing inconsistent in that stance. The sanctions threat, they said, was narrowly aimed at solving a specific problem: the illegal production in China of roughly 200 million compact disks and CD-ROM's a year. In contrast, most-favored nation status was critical to a sustained economic relationship.
Ms. Barshefsky is expected to make that argument at hearings on Tuesday by the House Ways and Means Committee on China's trade status. She is likely to run into considerable opposition from lawmakers who want to turn the debate into a referendum on Chinese behavior.
Five House members wrote to Mr. Clinton on Friday, asking why he had failed to certify that China was making progress in trade. They quoted the Administration's own report on trade barriers, which said, "China still maintains a large number of nontariff administrative controls to implement its trade and industrial policies." It cited curbs on the types of companies that could engage in foreign trade, curbs on imports and "prohibitively high" tariffs.
Administration officials also said today that China was showing signs it wanted a solution to the standoff over intellectual-property rights before sanctions went into effect next Monday. Over the weekend, four plants were reported raided by the Chinese authorities, who seized illegally produced CD's. It was unclear whether the crackdown was largely to avoid sanctions or whether the factories had been closed for good.

HEADLINE: Stocks Are Down, With Dow Falling 9.24

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The stock market pared its early losses yesterday to close moderately lower, withstanding another weak day in the bond market as interest rates continued to climb.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.24, to 5,687.87, after being down more than 30 points several times during the session. On Friday, the Dow ended up nearly 30 points, shrugging off an early 85-point slide spurred by inflation worries after a surprisingly strong employment report. Other broader market indexes also fell, although the Nasdaq composite index ended with a modest gain. 
 Trading was quiet as investors moved to the sidelines in advance of this week's reports on inflation at the producer and consumer levels during May.
"You didn't see any major selling," said A. Marshall Acuff Jr., a market strategist at Smith Barney. "There was no rush to take action one way or the other" before today's report on producer prices report and tomorrow's on consumer prices.
"It was more like the buyers were on strike -- legitimately so after the volatility on Friday," he said.
In the bond market, investors remained worried about inflationary pressures and the possibility that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates.
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark used to determine the interest rate charged on many types of loans -- rose to 7.12 percent, from 7.02 percent late Friday and 6.89 percent late Thursday.
Some analysts said stock investors remained hopeful that the economic strength indicated by recent employment reports would translate into rapid earnings growth, outweighing the risks of higher interest rates.
Declining issues outnumbered advancers by a margin of almost 12 to 11 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled just 337.2 million shares as of 4 P.M., down sharply from Friday's 445.7 million.
The Big Board's composite index fell 0.44, to 360.17, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.15, to 672.16. But the Nasdaq composite index rose 0.28, to 1,230.04, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index rose 0.17, to 599.48.
Westinghouse Electric, up 7/8, to 19 5/8, gave the Dow a boost after announcing it may split the conglomerate into separate industrial and broadcasting concerns.
J. P. Morgan, down 1 3/8, at 85 5/8, was among the weakest issues in the Dow industrials, reflecting the worsening interest rate environment. Higher interest rates mean a smaller profit margin on loans by financial institutions. The Dow also was weighed down by economically sensitive issues. Du Pont fell 1 1/8, to 79 7/8, and United Technologies lost 1, to 113 3/8.
Despite a return to the more cautious tone that preceded the May employment report, analysts were not as leery of this week's inflation numbers.
The Consumer Price Index and the Producer Price Index "have been relatively favorable for some months, so there's no precedent for people to be as anxious," Mr. Acuff said.
Among other issues, Kellogg fell 2 7/8, to 72, after it announced price cuts averaging 19 percent on 16 cereal brands.
Community Health Systems jumped 8 1/2, to 51 7/8, after Forstmann Little agreed to acquire the company for $52 a share.
Storage Technology rose 4 1/2, to 39 1/2, after I.B.M. agreed to resell the company's storage subsystems. Iomega surged 6, to 43 7/8, after I.B.M. said it would include Iomega's popular high-density Zip drives in a new model of its Aptiva personal computer. I.B.M., meanwhile, rose 7/8, to 102 5/8.
Chiron rose 2 1/2, to 99 1/2, and Cephalon added 1/8, to 23 1/4 after an advisory panel of the Food and Drug Administration voted to allow early access to their Myotrophin drug for Lou Gehrig's disease.

HEADLINE: $1 Billion in Borrowing Is Sought for School Work

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 10

 BODY:
Assembly Speaker Jack Collins proposed a 25-cents-a-pack increase in the state's cigarette tax today to pay for a $1 billion bond issue that would in turn help pay for the state's most ambitious school-construction program in decades.
With many school districts facing increasing enrollments and some urban areas struggling to educate children in crumbling buildings, Mr. Collins, a Republican from Salem County, said the bond act would help districts without burdening property owners with higher taxes. 
 Mr. Collins said his four-year school construction program would complement Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's new school-financing plan aimed at ending a 25-year dispute over the disparity in spending between the state's richest and poorest school districts. The Governor's plan would give more money to help school districts comply with new curriculum standards, but it does not suggest how to pay for major construction projects.
This is the first major initiative announced by Mr. Collins since he was elected Speaker in January. He said the bond issue would give school districts, particularly needy ones, the resources to improve schools and build new ones to meet the new curriculum standards -- paying for new laboratories to meet the science requirements, for example.
"The funding formula will provide financial parity," Mr. Collins said. "The core curriculum will provide program parity. But if the learning environment is not conducive to success, then our objective of providing a thorough and efficient education for all students, especially those in urban areas and financially struggling communities, will not and can not be achieved."
The plan was welcomed by education groups who have long complained that New Jersey has failed to meet its obligation to help districts improve and add buildings. Many districts have postponed construction projects because they have been reluctant to burden taxpayers. Other districts are now being forced to pay for projects without the state assistance that they had anticipated.
"This is the most ambitious undertaking that has been proposed to date," said Dr. Robert E. Boose, executive director of the New Jersey School Boards Association.
Mr. Collins outlined his plan to Governor Whitman and the Senate president, Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Republican of Scotch Plains, who both promised to review it.
Governor Whitman had recommended a 25-cent increase in the cigarette tax late last year to help pay for the state program that reimburses hospitals for providing free medical treatment to the uninsured. But Mrs. Whitman was unable to win support for the tax increase in the Legislature, primarily because Democrats refused to go along with any rise in taxes, and Republicans insisted that they would support only a bipartisan measure.
At the time, Mr. Collins was reluctant to go along with a cigarette tax increase to pay for charity care. But he said he believes such an increase is entirely appropriate to help pay for a school construction program, and he expects Democratic support for the measure.
"But it will be up to the voters to decide," Mr. Collins said.
Under the plan, voters would need to approve a constitutional amendment in November authorizing the state to increase the cigarette tax and dedicate that revenue for the bond act. A traditional bond issue requires voter approval and is repaid from state general revenues, but in this case, the state's Economic Development Authority would issue the bonds and pay the debt service with proceeds from the cigarette tax increase.
Dale Florio, a lobbyist who represents Philip Morris, the tobacco company, said that he expected that efforts to raise the tax in New Jersey would drive down sales and reduce overall cigarette tax revenues.
Although the state projects some loss in cigarette tax revenues because of an expected increase in bootlegging and lost sales to neighboring states, New Jersey budget officials estimate a 25-cent increase would generate $135 million a year in new revenues. The increase would raise the state cigarette tax to 65 cents, the highest in the region, from 40 cents, increasing the average cost of a pack to $2.60, from $2.35. The state cigarette tax in New York is 56 cents; it is 31 cents in Pennsylvania and 24 cents in Delaware.
Of the $135 million in annual proceeds, Mr. Collins said that $75 million would be used to pay debt service on a $1 billion bond sale. The remaining $60 million would be used to pay for the state's share of local debt service on existing capital construction programs.
The state now covers only 58 percent of what it is supposed to pay for those local debt service costs.
"Our plan would provide immediate relief and put this wrong to right," Mr. Collins said.
Mr. Collins said half of the money from the $1 billion bond act would be used to help fix schools or build new ones within 113 school districts that have been designated by the state as the most financially needy. The other $500 million would be available to the remaining 480 districts.
David Sciarra, executive director of the Education Law Center, a not-for-profit public interest group which brought the lawsuit against New Jersey demanding parity between the wealthiest and poorest districts, said that the plan still depends too heavily on property taxes.
To appear on the ballot in November, the proposed amendment to the state constitution would have to be approved by three-fifths of each house by August.
The measure would not need the Governor's signature to get on the ballot, but certainly Mrs. Whitman's support would be critical to the bond issue's survival.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
The Trouble Selling Kodak in Japan, Land of Fuji

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 10

 BODY:
In the small town of Odaicho on Japan's east coast, Isamu Yoshida says he would love to carry Kodak film in his little photo shop.
But the Fuji film salesmen visit regularly, and provide posters and advertising as well as twice-a-day film pickup and delivery of photos. In contrast, Mr. Yoshida says that he has never met a Kodak salesman and that Kodak offers no film pickup in his area. 
 "I don't think Kodak is making enough effort," said Mr. Yoshida, a photo buff who likes the color tones of Kodak products. "You can't just sell film and think that's the end of it. People want to bring it back for developing."
Mr. Yoshida's harsh verdict -- that Kodak Japan Ltd., a unit of the Eastman Kodak Company, is not trying hard enough in this country -- may be less merited in the future. Kodak is working to build up its network of retailers and labs in Japan -- and it is also trying a short cut, by bringing United States Government pressure, to raise its market share in this $10 billion business.
This week, the United States trade representative's office is expected to file a suit on behalf of Kodak with the World Trade Organization. It would be the first major case that the United States initiates at the W.T.O. against Japan, and a test of trade policy in both countries.
The world's two largest and most competitive photo film companies, Kodak and Fuji, have been locked in an ugly battle for the snapshot memories of Japan, hurling pointed salvos back and forth and virtually calling each other liars. In many ways, it is emblematic of the fight for market access that has dogged many American companies coming to Japan: Kodak says that after decades of effort, it still feels itself running up against an invisible wall.
Kodak's frustrations arise partly because it is fairly clear that the Fuji Photo Film Company's dominance of the Japanese market derives in great measure from Japanese Government policy in the past. Government favoritism may have ended, but its effects linger: Tokyo's effort helped build Fuji's market share to 70 percent today, compared with 10 percent for Kodak.
"The whole buildup of the market, which was bolstered by the Government, has made it so hard for foreign competitors to come in," said Jiro Tamura, a professor of anti-monopoly law at Keio University. "But if the Government wants Kodak to get access to the market and sell to the retailers, the answer will only come from the consumer. It's hard for the Government to provide any kind of affirmative action for Kodak."
Still, Kodak says that when it tries to break into Japan's small film shops, like Mr. Yoshida's in Odaicho, it cannot because the film market is clubby, secretive and discriminatory. Kodak also says that the Japanese Government should enforce monopoly laws against Fuji, but it is hampered a bit in making this argument because similar complaints are made in the United States about the dominance of Kodak there.
So Kodak has an uphill battle. Yet conversations with two dozen film retailers around Japan suggest that while Fuji's dominance may in itself be a source of pressure and influence, overwhelming retailers, the main problems that Kodak faces may be partly of its own making.
For example, Kodak offers minimal discounts, of about 10 percent, it says, which may not be enough to get customers to switch from Fuji; its advertising does not seem to make much of an impression; it seems hesitant to build a sales and distribution network that would rival Fuji's; it does not have nearly as many laboratories to process film as Fuji.
Naturally, Fuji has the home-court advantage, as Kodak does in the United States, where market-share proportions for the two are the reverse of what they are in Japan. But some scholars and business executives say that Kodak has not clearly demonstrated that it understands the Japanese market, for it has stumbled in its business judgment in the past.
A main problem for Kodak lies in the perception of consumers. Retailers say many consumers believe that Fuji film is superior. Several retailers said that even with a roll of Kodak film selling at 20 percent less than Fuji, consumers choose Fuji. When prices are the same, the task of selling Kodak becomes more challenging yet.
"I try to sell Kodak film, but if I don't say anything, people buy Fuji," said a manager who runs a photo lab tied to Kodak in Sanjo, a small city of 86,000 in Niigata prefecture, about 150 miles north of Tokyo. Fuji, the manager added, outsells Kodak by a margin of 2 to 1.
Kodak will not disclose details, but says it has talked to some retailers who say that they have been pressed by Fuji into not letting Kodak film upstage its own. Most retailers denied this, including Mr. Yoshida in Odaicho.
Indeed his shop still has an old Kodak sign, from the days when he did sell Kodak film before demand dried up, and now in addition to Fuji, he carries Konica and Polaroid film, as well as an obscure Korean brand.
In a country town in Mie prefecture, Akihisa Kashiwagi runs a small convenience store, where film is only a tiny part of overall sales. Until two months ago, he carried Kodak film. But sales did not go well, so his main headquarters stopped sending Kodak to his store, and now he carries only Fuji.
On Friday, he said, a Kodak salesman visited him for the first time -- offering to sell the company's film and processing for essentially the same price as Fuji, with one exception. He said that Kodak's print costs would be one-fifth the price of Fuji's per picture, though the company would not comment on this. This would save money for his customers but mean a smaller commission for the shopkeeper.
Mr. Kashiwagi says he was delighted by the visit but will probably not take Kodak on. His store is in a small, lightly trafficked town, and he says he is skeptical that the lower prices will bring in more customers, so that he could end up with a smaller profit on the processing of pictures.
Mr. Kashiwagi says he has never been strong-armed by Fuji. But to a small retailer Fuji looms large, and when asked whether taking on Kodak's deal might bring him pressure or other problems from Fuji, he replied slowly: "It is possible."
In another sign of Fuji's weight in the market, distributors may also be wary of helping Kodak. Heisaburo Okawara, a senior managing director at the Omiya Photo Supply Company, one of Fuji's four main channels, said that his company was highly dependent on Fuji and that he was unlikely to carry Kodak products. He called Kodak's marketing strategy incompatible with his company.
Kodak argues that some redress is necessary, although it has not clearly articulated exactly what it wants. It says it is impractical for it to replicate a distribution network like Fuji's.
But some scholars say that the film industry is changing rapidly and Kodak has a few good opportunities, if it works fast. More and more film is being sold through discounters, convenience-store chains and even vending machines, and Fuji is already moving aggressively on those fronts. Traveling around Japan, one frequently sees Fuji film and disposable cameras being sold in vending machines, but not Kodak.
"Small labs and convenience stores are very independent from Fuji's film companies, and there may be room for newcomers like Kodak to construct new types of distribution channels," said Kyoichi Ikeo, a marketing professor at Keio University. "Now the situation is changing, so that a new strategy could be very effective for Kodak."

HEADLINE: Negotiations Begin on Auto Industry Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., June 10

 BODY:
Officials from the United Automobile Workers union and the Ford Motor Company were carrying baseball bats when they showed up here today for the ritual of opening negotiations on a three-year labor contract, but their meeting was cordial and largely ceremonial.
Stephen P. Yokich, the president of the U.A.W., and his aides brought two baseball bats given to them by activists who urged them to "go to bat" to stop auto makers from buying more parts from outside companies. Warned how Mr. Yokich had armed himself for the talks, Alexander J. Trotman, Ford's chairman and chief executive, picked up his own bat to show that he could play ball with the union. 
 But while the baseball bats may have evoked images of the 1930's, when Ford security officials sometimes beat up union organizers, auto industry labor negotiations have long since settled down to a series of rituals with a lot of theater. Today was no exception, and similar ceremonies scheduled at the Chrysler Corporation on Tuesday and at the General Motors Corporation on Wednesday are likely to be the same.
Mr. Yokich and Mr. Trotman made brief presentations to the two sides' negotiating teams during a meeting here this morning that lasted a little over an hour. But the serious bargaining may not come until Aug. 22, when the union will choose one of the Big Three auto makers as its primary target for negotiating a contract that the union will then try to impose on the others.
Ernest Lofton, the U.A.W. vice president in charge of relations with Ford, said this afternoon that the union would not even make its opening offer to the company until early next week. While the U.A.W. adopted broad goals for its negotiating strategy at a bargaining convention here in April, the union has had to work out the details of its specific demands to each company.
In addition to reducing the purchase of outside parts, the union wants the auto makers to reduce overtime by hiring more workers, and would like to hold on to past gains in wages and pension benefits. The auto makers all want to hold down overall labor costs, but have varying positions on issues like health care costs, pension benefits and the parts purchases. Ford officials said they would discuss the possibility of a contract lasting more than three years, but Mr. Yokich professed little enthusiasm.
At news conferences this afternoon, union and company officials alike played down the possibility of a strike this autumn. The U.A.W.'s current three-year contracts with G.M., Ford and Chrysler are scheduled to expire on Sept. 14.
"We never go into these negotiations with a strike in mind, we go into these negotiations with a tentative settlement in mind," Mr. Lofton said.
But for all the expressions of harmony, basic disagreements were apparent in the negotiators' remarks this afternoon. And those differences are even sharper at G.M. and Chrysler, which have cooler relationships with the union than Ford does.
Mr. Yokich complained that the Big Three, including Ford, had relied too heavily on forcing existing workers to put in many hours of overtime, instead of hiring new workers. Workers putting in six- and seven-day weeks have suffered needless injuries while fatigued, Mr. Yokich said. The U.A.W. wants to expand its dues-paying base of workers during the current economic expansion, but the auto makers have been slow to do so.
But Ford officials were equally firm in expressing their reluctance to hire more workers. Thomas M. Brown, Ford's executive director of labor affairs, said the company needed the flexibility of overtime to deal with variations in demand for cars and trucks, and did not want to hire workers during prosperous times only to lay them off during economic downturns.

HEADLINE: In Naming a New Executive, G.M. Tightens Reins at Saab

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 10

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation took tighter hold of the reins at Saab Automobile A.B. today by naming an executive close to G.M.'s chairman, John F. Smith Jr., to run the Swedish auto maker.
Robert W. Hendry, a G.M. vice president and group executive, will become president and chief executive of Saab in August. Saab is a joint venture between General Motors and Investor A.B., the Swedish holding company controlled by the Wallenberg family. 
 The appointment of Mr. Hendry, who is 51, along with other recent executive moves, signals that General Motors is redoubling its efforts to make Saab consistently profitable. Just last week, Saab announced that Joel K. Manby, an executive at G.M.'s much-admired Saturn small- car subsidiary, would become president and chief executive of Saab Cars USA Inc., Saab's American marketing arm. Moving to Saab with Mr. Manby is Saturn's director of consumer marketing, John J. Orth, who today was named vice president for sales at Saab Cars.
Mr. Hendry replaces Keith Butler-Wheelhouse, who is leaving after four years to join Smiths Industries, the British conglomerate, as an executive director and board member. Mr. Hendry will retain his high post at G.M. while he runs Saab. Mr. Butler-Wheelhouse, who worked for the Ford Motor Company for two decades before joining Saab, is not an officer of General Motors, signaling that Mr. Hendry's link with the parent company will be stronger.
General Motors paid $500 million for a half interest in Saab in 1990, and has invested another $500 million since. During that time, Saab cut its work force in half and adopted many streamlined manufacturing techniques.
Saab's goal is to sell 150,000 cars a year worldwide by the year 2000, up from 98,700 last year. It also wants to raise its annual United States sales from 25,595 last year to about 40,000. Saab plans to start selling a new sedan and station wagon next year. The sedan, referred to as project 640, will be more luxurious than Saab's 9000 hatchback, and will be sold in a station-wagon version -- informally called project 641 -- starting in 1999, said Karl Olof Axelson, Saab Automobile's vice president for communications.
Mr. Hendry's mandate to finish turning Saab around comes after he helped Mr. Smith and other executives stanch the hemorrhaging at G.M. in 1992. Serving as chief financial officer for G.M.'s North American operations, Mr. Hendry had authority over every major capital spending proposal. "He was on the front lines during the stop-the-bleeding years," said Scott F. Merlis, president of Merlis Automotive International, an independent automotive research firm in Westport, Conn.
Mr. Hendry also led G.M.'s New United Motor Manufacturing Inc., a California joint venture with the Toyota Motor Corporation in which G.M. learned Japanese lean-production techniques while building Toyota Corollas and Geo Prizms.
Indeed, the new team at Saab could be preparing to link the G.M. subsidiary more closely with the company's Saturn division. "There has been a lot of talk about a Saturn/ Saab alignment," said Lincoln C. Merrihew, an auto analyst for DRI/ McGraw-Hill, an economic forecasting company in Lexington, Mass. "There is sort of a similarity in the psychological makeup of Saab and Saturn buyers," he said, since both customer bases are famously loyal. Saab and Saturn products do not compete against each other because Saturn's small cars fill the lower end of the market, Mr. Merrihew said.
Mr. Butler-Wheelhouse told The Financial Times of London last week that some Saturn dealers might eventually sell Saab cars, too, and that the two would cooperate more behind the scenes.
Mr. Hendry was not available for comment. But Mr. Axelson of Saab acknowledged that the auto maker hoped to make its buyers happier by adopting some of Saturn's ways.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Employers' Rights Upheld In Early-Retirement Plans
In a closely watched labor case involving Lockheed Martin, the Supreme Court unanimously ruled that employers can require workers to give up various legal claims against a company as the price of receiving an early-retirement buyout with enhanced pension benefits.
The court overturned a finding by a Federal appeals court that Lockheed had violated Federal pension law when it made a new early-retirement program available only to employees who were willing to waive any claims against Lockheed based on violations of labor laws. [Page A1.]
 
Kellogg Cuts Many Cereal Prices
Kellogg cut prices by an average of 19 percent on Frosted Flakes, Raisin Bran and 14 other brands of cereal that represent two-thirds of its domestic sales. Supermarket scanner data had warned the company that its industry-leading market share was rapidly eroding in the face of across-the-board 20 percent price cuts announced earlier in the spring by Post and Nabisco cereals. [D4.]

Forstmann to Buy Hospital Chain
Making its first purchase in health care, Forstmann Little, the New York investment firm, said it would buy Community Health Systems Inc., a Nashville-based chain of 38 hospitals, which are mainly in the Southeast and Southwest, for $1.1 billion. [D4.]

Exxon Wins an Insurance Trial
A Texas jury awarded Exxon $250 million from Lloyd's of London and other insurers that sold policies to protect it from liabilities incurred in the Exxon Valdez oil spill. [D8.]
 
Exxon reached an agreement with Russia that clears the way for its consortium to begin work on oil and gas fields off Sakhalin Island. [D8.]
 
Bond Prices Keep Skidding
Bonds continued to slide as prices remained under heavy pressure from investors who expect the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates next month. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.12 percent, the highest level in more than a year. [D17.]
 
Stocks rebounded from early losses to close moderately lower. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.24 points to 5,687.87. [D10.]
 
White House Trade Gaffe
Even as the Clinton Administration heads into a showdown with China over its failure to abide by a key trade agreement, an oversight at the White House has put President Clinton in the awkward position of having to assert that China is opening markets and lowering barriers to American companies. [D7.]
 
U.A.W. and Ford Start to Talk
Officials from the United Automobile Workers union and Ford Motor carried baseball bats when they showed up for the ritual of opening negotiations on a new three-year labor contract, but their meeting was cordial and largely ceremonial. Similar labor talks begin at Chrysler today and General Motors tomorrow. [D2.]

G.M. Names New Chief at Saab
General Motors, which holds a 50 percent stake in Saab Automobile A.B., took tighter hold of the Swedish auto maker by naming an executive close to the G.M. chairman, John F. Smith Jr., to run it. [D2.]

Phone Giants Embrace the Internet
Projecting that the volume of computer-based communications traffic would soon surpass that for voice communications, MCI and British Telecom said they planned to merge their international high-speed data networks and to significantly expand their Internet capacity. [D5.]

Russian Bank Tightens Credit
Struggling to limit the damage from President Boris N. Yeltsin's costly campaign promises, Russia's central bank imposed a series of measures to keep inflation down. [A6.]
 
No Games, Just Recaps
ESPN plans a third channel, ESPNEWS, a 24-hour all-sports-news network. [B19.]

HEADLINE: Closing Long Chapter, Dole Looks Ahead

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
Hours before leaving the Senate, Senator Bob Dole declared that he had "no illusions about the difficulties ahead of us," but he told supporters at a black-tie Republican fund-raiser here that they should not despair about the next chapter in his political life: his campaign for President.
"I want all of you always to remember this moment," Mr. Dole said, his voice echoing across a cavernous hall filled with more than 4,000 Republican supporters who had each paid $1,000 for the political dinner. "I want you to remember when the media dismissed our chances. I want you to remember when the White House was not just confident, but overconfident, to the point of arrogance. I want you to remember that our belief was still strong." 
Mr. Dole made his remarks at a fund-raiser for the National Republican Congressional Committee and the National Republican Senatorial Committee. Although none of the money will go to his Presidential campaign, the sponsors -- who reported raising $8 million tonight -- framed the evening around Mr. Dole, since it coincided with Mr. Dole's last night as a United States Senator.
Mr. Dole was in good humor. "It's good to see all the faces that match the names on the White House enemies list," he said, glancing at his audience.
He said that as he prepared to leave the Senate, his "biggest disappointment" was not passing a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution. He was referring to the amendment's defeat by three votes last week. Mr. Dole knew the measure would fail when he brought it up, but he calculated that a loss would allow him to leave the Senate with an issue he could use against President Clinton.
Mr. Dole said his main campaign focus would be on the economy, and he chastised the news media for questioning his central economic precept: that he can cut taxes and balance the budget.
"We can make the economy grow and balance the budget and cut taxes at the same time," he said. "Don't let the media fool you. It can be done, and we will do it."
Mr. Dole shared the evening with Speaker Newt Gingrich, whose unpopularity, in the view of some of Mr. Dole's political advisers, accounts for some of the Senator's political problems. But while Mr. Dole and Mr. Gingrich were on the same program, they were separated by about half a football field across the Washington Convention Center. There were three stages in the room, and the two men traded compliments from opposite sides of the hall.

HEADLINE: CORPORATION WINS IN PENSION RULING

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
The Supreme Court ruled in a closely watched labor case today that an employer could require employees to give up various legal claims against a company as the price of receiving an early-retirement buyout with enhanced pension benefits.
The Court ruled unanimously in favor of the Lockheed Martin Corporation. A Federal appeals court found last year that the company had violated the basic Federal pension law, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, when it made a new early-retirement program available only to employees who were willing to waive any claims against Lockheed based on violations of labor laws. 
 On a second question in the case, the Court split 7 to 2 in ruling that the members of Lockheed's retirement committee, who administered the pension plan, could not be sued because the Federal law, known as Erisa, does not forbid a quid pro quo under which employees gain a benefit if they meet a particular condition set by the employer.
The section of Erisa at issue in the case "simply does not address what an employer can and cannot ask an employee to do in return for benefits," Justice Clarence Thomas wrote in a majority opinion that encompassed both of the questions that were before the Court.
Early-retirement options are a popular management technique in an era of corporate downsizing, and this case, framed by the highly technical provisions of the Erisa law, posed the basic question of whether there are legal limits on what an employer can demand while offering a lifeline to workers who might otherwise face involuntary layoffs.
Unsurprisingly, the Court did not answer all the questions that can come up in such situations -- for example, whether there are certain legal rights, like the right to collect workers' compensation for injuries, that employees cannot be asked to waive under any circumstances. At issue in this case was credit for earlier years of employment that had not been counted in a pension plan.
The case was brought by Paul L. Spink, an aerospace engineer who retired from a Lockheed plant in Burbank, Calif., in 1990 at age 72. He took a pension of less than $100 a month rather than waive his right to sue for his retroactive pension credit. He was recruited to Lockheed in 1979, when he was 61 years old and ineligible for the pension plan under a company policy that barred participation by employees who were over age 60 when they were hired.
Congress passed a law in 1986 that made such age-related exclusions from pension plans illegal. Lockheed then gave Mr. Spink pension credit beginning in 1988, refusing to credit him retroactively. In a separate portion of the ruling today, the Court found that Lockheed was correct and that Congress had not intended the provision to have retroactive effect.
One of Mr. Spink's lawyers, Bert Voorhees, said in an interview today that the case would proceed on various legal theories that were not before the Supreme Court, including whether Lockheed should be held to promises it made to Mr. Spink that it would provide him with a pension.
Mr. Spink sued Lockheed in 1992 under a provision of Erisa, Section 406, that makes illegal certain transfers of pension plan assets or the use of the assets to benefit the company. He contended that the company and the pension plan's administrators were harming the overall health of the pension plan by diverting tens of millions of dollars to employees who were willing to retire with enhanced pensions in return for giving up their legal rights.
He lost in Federal District Court in Los Angeles before winning last year in the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco. The appeals court ruled that the company was illegally using the pension plan for its own benefit.
The ruling alarmed many employer groups, which urged the Supreme Court to review the case. For example, the United States Chamber of Commerce told the Justices that "employee benefit plans simply could not function" under the Ninth Circuit's approach. "In a free-market economy, an employer always provides employee benefits in return for valuable benefits from the employee," the chamber's brief said.
In the decision today, Lockheed v. Spink, No. 95-809, the Court found two grounds for overturning the Ninth Circuit's opinion. First, Justice Thomas said, while Lockheed sponsored the pension plan and the amendment that made the buyout available, the company did not have fiduciary responsibility for running the plan. Under the section of Erisa at issue, "a plaintiff must show that a fiduciary caused the plan to engage in the allegedly unlawful transaction," so, the section does not apply to Lockheed at all, Justice Thomas said. The Court was unanimous on that point.
While the plan's administrators did act as fiduciaries, their behavior was not illegal because "the payment of benefits is in fact not a 'transaction' in the sense that Congress used that term in Section 406," Justice Thomas said.
He said Congress meant to prohibit "commercial bargains that present a special risk of plan underfunding because they are struck with plan insiders, presumably not at arm-length" and that therefore have the potential to harm the plan. "The payment of benefits conditioned on performance by plan participants cannot reasonably be said to share that characteristic," he said.
Justices Stephen G. Breyer and David H. Souter dissented from this portion of the decision. They said the question of plan administrators' liability under these circumstances was a "difficult one" that would "benefit from further development in the lower courts" before being resolved at the Supreme Court level.

HEADLINE: Mayor and Council Leaders Agree on $32.8 Billion Budget

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and leaders of the City Council reached a tentative agreement early this morning on a $32.8 billion budget that would make sharp cuts in spending on municipal services but include a plan to borrow $1.4 billion for repairs to New York City's public schools over the next four years.
The agreement -- the third under Mr. Giuliani, a Republican who pledged to cure the city's fiscal ills -- reflected the grim realities of the city's sluggish economy and the ever-rising costs of municipal expenses, like interest on the city's debt and health benefits for unionized employees. 
 With the city facing a projected shortfall of $2.7 billion, the Mayor and the Council's leaders agreed to postpone almost all of the $428 million in tax cuts that Mr. Giuliani had originally proposed.
They agreed to extend the city's temporary 12.5 percent surcharge on the personal income tax that was to have expired in December -- a move that the Mayor's senior aides derided as a tax increase only a few months ago -- to keep the budget balanced.
The Mayor and the Council leaders finished negotiations just before 1 this morning after a last, protracted day and night of wrangling between the two sides. The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, signaled the deal after emerging from the Mayor's office, and strode through the lobby of City Hall, still crowded with anxious lobbyists. An announcement of an agreement was delayed when the Mayor left City Hall abruptly just before 11 P.M. to visit a police officer who was shot and wounded in East New York.
The agreement would leave in place most of the fiscal and political priorities contained in the Mayor's executive budget a month ago. It included more than $1.1 billion in cuts in spending to the city's myriad agencies that would affect municipal services used by most New Yorkers.
At a news conference at City Hall early this morning, the Mayor praised the Council's Democrats for making what he called significant changes, but ones that remained within the parameters of his original proposal.
"This is a budget that is fiscally sound," Mr. Giuliani said. "At the same time, I think some historic things have been done."
The Council's leaders declared a major victory, pointing to the Mayor's acceptance of a plan to provide an infusion of cash for school repairs. The proposal would pay for much-needed work -- from minor patchwork to new windows and roofs -- for the city's aging, overcrowded schools, although the Council has not yet released a list of specific projects.
But the Council's proposal has undergone significant changes since Mr. Vallone announced it in January and made it his top priority in this spring's budget battle. Moreover, the financing for the version Mr. Giuliani has accepted remains unresolved after the first year, and the total package could end up costing the city billions more in interest and strain its ability to borrow money.
The Council dropped its initial proposal to pay for the repairs with $1.4 billion in revenues from an extension of the personal income tax surcharge over four years. Instead it accepted the Mayor's demand to raise the same amount by issuing new bonds that will be repaid with interest over the next 30 years.
The problem, however, is that the city already faces a state constitutional limit on its debt. The prospect that the city would reach the limit in 1998 forced Mr. Giuliani to propose cutting capital spending by $1 billion over the next four years when he unveiled his budget last month.
With an agreement to spend $1.4 billion in schools, the city will again bump against the debt limit.
To sidestep the limit, the Mayor also proposed the creation of a new public authority to issue bonds for schools, bridges and mass transit. The Council has yet to agree to that proposal, which has already raised concerns among legislators in Albany, who would have to approve it or any changes in the limit.
The Council officials acknowledged the uncertainty surrounding the money for schools, considering the legislative logjams that often leave the city empty-handed. But they said they were confident that the State Legislature would ultimately go along.
The agreement still requires the approval of the entire Council, but that is a mere formality, if the past is any guide, since the Speaker holds tight reins over the Democratic majority.
In addition to the school repairs, the Council focused much of its efforts on blocking some of the Mayor's budget cuts from taking effect. The tentative agreement early this morning restored about $115 million in spending for a variety of programs, like the city's libraries, its museums and treatment for alcoholics and the mentally ill.
The Council's black and Latino caucus -- representing 22 of the Council's 51 members -- insisted on restoring at least part of the city's subsidy to the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which the Mayor had proposed cutting by $110 million, to only $37 million. The agreement put back $20 million.
Mr. Giuliani has maintained all along that his budget cutting has had little or no effect on municipal services. Other elected officials, however, have disputed his claims, including Public Advocate Mark J. Green and Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, whose offices each released reports in the last week detailing eroding services, from street cleaning to youth programs.
"Anybody who thinks we're going to get through this budget without pain is living an illusion," said Councilman Herbert E. Berman, a Democrat from Brooklyn and the chairman of the Council's Finance Committee.
Last night's tentative agreement ended an unusual budget process that began in January with the Mayor's preliminary budget proposal and over the next few months experienced radical changes midstream.
The Mayor's preliminary plan proposed $691 million in spending cuts, and Mr. Giuliani vowed to press ahead with his campaign pledges to reduce taxes. But he also softened his message of fiscal austerity.
He promised to protect the city's most vulnerable citizens -- children, the elderly. To do so, he relied heavily on risky assumptions of help from Albany and financial maneuvers that provided immediate infusions of cash but that raised the concerns of fiscal monitors and bond raters.
By the time Mr. Giuliani submitted his formal budget proposal to the City Council last month, much of that preliminary plan had changed. Prompted by the warnings from the monitors and raters, the Mayor eliminated some of the overly optimistic assumptions, including a plan to sell the city's parking meters for $150 million to $300 million.

HEADLINE: Federal Reserve Board Has Too Much Power;
Ask Mr. Greenspan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your June 8 editorial "The Unfair War on Alan Greenspan" rightly asks the Senate promptly to confirm Alan Greenspan's reappointment by the President as Federal Reserve chairman. To delay confirmation to permit a "great debate" on Mr. Greenspan's economic policies ignores that Mr. Greenspan would not be there to present his side of the debate. 
 Fortunately, a true great debate can take place next month when Mr. Greenspan appears before the Congressional banking committees for their semiannual review of monetary policy. Some questions that might be put to Mr. Greenspan:
* If the Fed discerns inflationary signs in particular sectors -- say, rapidly increasing overtime in labor markets or capacity shortages in the trucking industry -- why not consult with the President and Congress to explore whether there aren't specific solutions for these problems that make it unnecessary to raise interest rates across the board?
* Before moving to raise interest rates generally, which would restrain not only consumer spending but also inflation-fighting business investment in plant and equipment, why not recommend that Congress repeal the income tax deduction for interest on home-equity loans of up to $100,000, a perverse incentive to spend the tax savings on consumer goods, both domestic and imported?
* At a time when many are calling the stock market inflated, and when a blow-off could destabilize the entire economy, why isn't the Fed using its statutory power to order a modest increase in stock margin requirements?
 
HENRY S. REUSS
Belvedere, Calif., June 9, 1996
 
The writer, a former Representative from Wisconsin, headed the House Banking Committee from 1975 to 1981.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
ALCOA ANNOUNCES CLOSING OF SAN DIEGO PACKAGING PLANT

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it had closed its Alcoa Electronic Packaging plant after failing to find a buyer for the subsidiary, which makes ceramic packages for microprocessors. Alcoa, based in Pittsburgh, has been winding down operations at the San Diego plant since the beginning of the year after its principal customer, the Intel Corporation, said it would not be placing any new orders. In March, Alcoa laid off virtually all of the plant's roughly 600 regular employees. Alcoa said closing the plant would reduce its second-quarter earnings by $40 million after taxes. The charge is related to the expected loss from the sale of equipment and inventories. In the second quarter last year, Alcoa earned $219.4 million.
