HEADLINE: After Newark Takeover, Hopes Fade for Quick Fix of Schools

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 9

 BODY:
The state government promised to end the rampant failure of Newark's students when it evicted the top administrators and the elected board from New Jersey's largest school district 12 months ago.
There would be a new emphasis on classroom instruction, they said, and no tolerance for abuses of the past, when board members kept cars and restaurant accounts while students lacked basic amenities like bathroom partitions and toilet paper. But the new administration was circumspect about when the system would alter its course, and as the academic year ends, there are few tangible signs of change. 
 The old board has been banished, and all 82 school buildings that were crumbling and covered inside and out with often-obscene graffiti were given an $8 million face lift last summer. But aside from the remodeling, the administration says the year was mostly dedicated to hiring a host of consultants. Their tasks included evaluating 182 principals and vice principals and studying the food service, the central administration, previous contracts for possible abuse and the way schools are policed.
Their reports, due later this year, are supposed to point the way toward revitalizing an urban school system in which only about a quarter of the high school students pass the standardized tests needed for graduation and few students perform at grade level. But in making improved student performance the No. 1 priority on their list, the imported administration raised expectations that the takeover would quickly improve classroom instruction. For many parents, teachers and students, the sense that the school system is still not focusing on its students is tarnishing those expectations.
Dr. Beverly L. Hall, a former deputy chancellor in New York City whom the state hired as Newark Superintendent for four years, acknowledges that some problems, like poor attendance, have actually worsened. She knows Newark residents would prefer action to waiting for yet another round of expert reports.
"This is a hard concept to explain to the public, who wants to see the same kind of change they saw in the physical appearance of the buildings after eight weeks," Dr. Hall said.
Changes are in the offing. She has vowed to make significant layoffs, especially at central headquarters and among cafeteria or maintenance workers, to shift money to the classrooms. Forty kindergarten classes, include 14 new ones, will move to all-day programs in the fall. Barringer Preparatory School, a school consisting only of ninth graders, and one of the city's most violent, with 61 violent incidents reported this year, will close its doors at the end of school on June 26. The recently formed school planning teams will help develop rough reform plans by that time.
But even the few plans actually enunciated have created considerable friction, especially with the Newark Teachers Union, which represents 4,400 teachers and aides. The tug-of-war with the union over the school teams delayed their start for several months, and the group is now considering pickets for June 20 as well as a lawsuit to stop what it calls ebbing conflict-of-interest questions. Both the union and parents say they fear that privatization of some instruction and services will mean fewer jobs for local people.
Perhaps one of the most significant hurdles is the resentment born of the fact that seven top managers and several consulting firms were imported from New York City. Locals grumble about carpetbaggers from another decayed system and have taken to referring to their own town as "Newark, New York" when out of earshot of the new management. Dr. Hall bridles at the comparison.
"There are lots of pockets of excellence in New York," she said. "When it comes to the scores you can't compare New York to Newark. We should only get to where New York is. That is not the ideal, but at least you are on the move."
In Newark, reading and math scores, for example, are coming out later this month. But officials say they anticipate little change in the scores because there were no curriculum changes this school year.
Of about 20 states that have passed legislation allowing takeovers for failed academic standards, New Jersey has been among the most aggressive in intervening. Its three largest districts are in state hands. The lurking fear in Newark is that as in earlier takeovers in Jersey City in 1989 and Paterson in 1991, the state will fail to improve academic achievement within the five years mandated by state law and either extend its stay or leave without a successful overhaul.
"That old school board is sitting back and waiting just like the Devil," Sabriyyah Muslima-Boyd said during a recent raucous public meeting of the state-appointed board.
 
Hopes Were High, Maybe Too High
Everyone acknowledges that expectations may have been too high when the state concluded a decadelong review of the Newark public schools and announced that a takeover was warranted by extended student failure on standardized tests and widespread incompetence. All the top administrators and the elected school board were removed last July.
"I assumed that it would get better now that we have experienced people heading our schools," said Stephanie Foard, a 14-year-old at University High who complained that her classrooms were still packed and her course options too limited. "It seems as though after the state took over, we got metal detectors and a coat of paint."
Dr. Hall pointed out in an interview that the main reason for the lack of change is that only the top layer of 30 managers was replaced. "The reality is the principals are still there, so the ones who are competent continue to do their job and the ones who are not continue to not be competent, that hasn't changed," she said. "It will be some time before we begin to see a change in the delivery of instruction."
Active principals are considered the linchpin in successfully remaking any school, with some of the stagnation in Jersey City and Paterson attributed to the state's being too timid in making such personnel changes. Principals and vice principals in Newark deemed incompetent could lose their jobs later this year, Dr. Hall said. Officials at the 360-member City Association of Supervisors and Administrators, the union representing principals, said that at least 40 principals and vice principals were rated unsatisfactory in the first of three evaluation rounds.
"I will not deny that there may be some that need strengthening, but we abhor the 'I gotcha' mentality," said one union member, speaking on condition of anonymity for fear of losing his job.
Those being rated hint darkly that there is a hit list downtown, and union officials attribute one man's mild stroke and the sick leaves taken by five other administrators to the stress caused by being summoned to headquarters to hear an unsatisfactory rating. They also complain that administrators are judged for tasks that they were not assigned, that there is no formal means to rebut low scores and that the quality of the evaluators is uneven.
"Here's a guy putting my 35 years of education on the line in five hours and he falls asleep in a staff meeting," said John D. Petrozzino, the principal at Barringer Prep. "His head went down, his head went back and the guy was out."
Dr. Hall will not specify how many employees she plans to let go, but charged that the previous administration treated the school system like a job agency for friends and relatives. Joseph Del Grosso, the president of the teachers' union, said threatened reductions include up to 350 teaching positions, including a heavy reduction in elementary art and music courses to save money. Dr. Hall said principals were asked to make some budget reductions, but said the teachers would probably be reassigned within the system.
With its annual budget of $550 million, Newark's cost per pupil was more than $10,000, one of the highest in the state. Dr. Hall said too much was eaten up by administrative costs, and said she planned to find at least $4 million in the budget to shift from headquarters to the classrooms. The system also faces a $30.5 million cut in state aid in 1997 because its enrollment dropped to 45,805 this year from 47,500 in 1991. State aid had been frozen at 1991 levels.
 
New Boss Warns Teacher Union
Dr. Hall warned in a June 4 letter to the unions that without some concessions on job sharing and furloughs, "the reorganization will result in significant layoffs for economy and efficiency." As an example, Dr. Hall said in an interview that many cities manage to gain extra money from the Federal food subsidies for poor children, but Newark's cafeteria staff is so costly that the district has to supplement the program with $16 million a year.
Critics of the state-run administration resent that in tandem with threatened cuts, the state-run board has invested at least $1.65 million in eight outside consulting contracts, including $450 a day to Leonard Hellenbrand, a former budget director with the New York City Board of Education, hired to revise the Newark budget.
"They certainly made it a jobs program for people they like," said Houston Stevens, the head of the Parent-Teacher Organization at University High. "They are bringing in consultants, they are bringing in people from New York and people from the suburbs. But they are attacking the wage and benefits package for people who live in Newark and need these jobs."
Both parents and the union also fear creeping privatization. The administration signed a $1.25 million contract through June 1997 with Sylvan Learning Systems of Columbia, Md., for remedial reading classes, starting with three high schools this spring.
The company painted and carpeted and put air-conditioning in classrooms. Three students were assigned per teacher per hourlong session. Attendance fell markedly after the High School Proficiency Test in April. Dr. Hall said their results would be reviewed to determine if the contract should be extended.
William H. Harris 3d, who runs the program at Barringer, said many of the students read at an elementary level. Getting students to attend is largely a question of attitude. "It's an issue of pride: 'Hey, I'm in the 11th grade. Why do I have to work on short vowel sounds?' " he said.
To help overcome that, Sylvan issues a series of chits for classroom shops, which students can exchange for things including raspberry shower gel and sunglasses.
Newark teachers resent that Sylvan did not choose from their ranks for instructors and that developing a similar homegrown program was never broached. "They were allowed to rebuild their classroom as this plush temple of learning," said one Barringer teacher, speaking on condition of anonymity, "while we get 35 students to a class."
The school planning teams were supposed to be elected in February and have three months to develop reform programs for each school. The changes were to be paid for with $300 per pupil under a state program. But the union objected to its employees working on the planning without pay. So a wage scale of $30 per hour, with a cap of $900, was worked out, with parents subsequently awarded a $25 stipend per meeting.
The wrangling added at least $700,000 to the cost of the program and created a brooding resentment on all sides, especially since the elections were hastily called in April and the teams are only beginning to work at year's end.
"It shouldn't be a money issue, it was supposed to be for the children," said Miriam Bey, a vocal parent. "Dr. Hall probably needs more time to do what she needs to do, but it is almost a year now and you don't really see that much of a difference."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Producer Prices Fell in May, Easing Threat of Inflation
Prices at the producer level fell unexpectedly in May, the Government said, offering fresh evidence that inflation remains tame despite Wall Street's fears. Tumbling energy prices and stable food costs helped push the Producer Price Index down one-tenth of 1 percent in May, the Labor Department said. Excluding volatile food and energy costs, the core rate was unchanged after rising one-tenth of 1 percent in each of the three prior months.
Economists had expected the overall and the core rates to increase by two-tenths of 1 percent in May. [Page D2.]

Conflict Over China Trade
A top State Department official accused Japan and the European Union of criticizing America's efforts to force China to respect trade accords, while seeking to cash in on its growing market. [A1.]
 
Airline Alliance Raises Questions
Officials of American Airlines and British Airways formally announced their plans for a broad marketing alliance, setting off criticism from rivals and raising questions about the likelihood of their partnership winning approval from Government officials in both countries. [D4.]

Orange County Files Lawsuits
Orange County, Calif., filed lawsuits that seek more than $2 billion in damages against brokerage firms, lawyers and a rating agency that the county contends could have warned it of an impending financial crisis. The lawsuits were filed on the eve of the county's emergence from bankruptcy. [D5.]
 
Conoco and Phillips Break Off Talks
Conoco and Phillips Petroleum said they had been unable to reach an agreement to merge their refining and marketing businesses and had broken off talks. [D3.]

NatWest to Buy Greenwich Capital
The NatWest Group agreed to pay $590 million in cash to acquire Greenwich Capital Holdings, a bond-trading business, from the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan. [D3.]

Indicator Shows Rebound for Chips
The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rebounded slightly in May, though it still pointed to weak demand. [D4.]

Stocks Fall After Rally
Stocks ended lower as enthusiasm about an encouraging inflation report proved fleeting. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.21 points, to 5,668.66, retreating from an early advance of nearly 41 points. [D10.]
 
An early bond market rally fizzled on profit taking, leaving the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond at 7.12 percent. [D20.]

Lexmark Missing Technology Boom
Even in the robust market for new technology stocks, some initial public offerings have stalled. That is the case with Lexmark International, a maker of computer printers. Market Place. [D10.]
 
A Union Decision at Hoover
Union workers at a Hoover vacuum cleaner plant in Ohio faced a painful choice -- approve a company offer to lower wages for starting workers or watch jobs leave to a nonunion plant. They voted against the plan. [A16.]
 
G.M. Cuts Indonesian Investments
General Motors has suspended plans for further investments in Indonesia in a trade dispute. [D21.]

Cathay Pacific Makes Itself Heard
It is difficult to be heard in the din of advertising in New York, but it is hard to miss the news that Cathay Pacific Airways will begin flights to Hong Kong from Kennedy International Airport. Advertising. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Damages Sought in Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
On the eve of its emergence from bankruptcy, Orange County, Calif., filed five lawsuits yesterday -- seeking more than $2 billion in damages -- against a number of brokerage firms, lawyers and a rating agency that it contended were in a position to warn of an impending financial crisis at the county, but did not.
 "These lawsuits reveal a pervasive and systemic failure of the county's former municipal finance professionals to perform services with independence and regard for the laws," said Jan M. Mittermeier, the county's chief executive. "Each of these defendants had a clear opportunity and professional responsibility to prevent serious damage." 

 Lawsuits were filed against Morgan Stanley & Company, for selling the county "risky and exotic" securities that the county contends violated California law; against the law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Green & MacRae for failing to disclose risks in the county's investment pool and against a financial adviser, Rauscher Pierce & Refsnes of Dallas, for also failing to warn of risks in a county investment pool that lost $1.6 billion.
 The county also sued Standard & Poor's Rating Group, a unit of McGraw-Hill, for an "erroneous evaluation." The county, in a statement, said the rating group "played a pivotal role in falsely assuring taxpayers, county officials, the press and the financial community" that the county's investment strategy was safe. Michael Dorfman, a spokesman, said the ratings group would not comment.
 And the county sued the Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, for what it called a secret kickback arrangement with Merrill Lynch & Company, the county's former broker, to disguise compensation paid to Merrill. The county already has a $2 billion lawsuit pending against Merrill, accusing it of securities fraud. Sallie Mae issued $913 million in securities to the county's investment pool.
 Gisela Vallandigham, a Sallie Mae spokeswoman, said, "We find it inconceivable that any liability would be attached to the Sallie Mae debt obligation that ultimately wound up in the Orange County investment portfolio." Merrill said, "This is an old allegation with no merit."
 Also yesterday, the county negotiated the return of $62 million in collateral held by CS First Boston since the county filed for bankruptcy in December 1994, as well as undisclosed sums from other brokers.
 CS First Boston had been named as a potential defendant by the county, along with Normura Securities International, Dean Witter Reynolds, Paine Webber and Bear, Stearns, in an earlier disclosure statement. But the county and these potential defendants agreed to hold off on any case pending the outcome of the Morgan Stanley litigation.
 Each of the defendants in the suits filed yesterday is being sued for $500 million, except for Sallie Mae, which is being sued for around $100 million.
 "These defendants are representative of other parts of the story behind the financial crisis of December 1994," said Bruce Bennett, the county's lawyer. "It is an integrated story of an overall failure by professionals. Had any of these professionals done the job imposed on them by the law, at least some of these losses would have been avoided."
 Perhaps the most unusual charges are those leveled against Standard & Poor's. Mr. Bennett said that in May 1994, an S.& P. official received a presentation from the county detailing the risks of the investment pool. Yet, when John Moorlach, the county's treasurer, was running for office in 1994 and warned that the investment pool was excessively dangerous, the same S.& P. official stated that the investment pool was safe.
 "The Moorlach criticism was drowned out by a major institution that had unquestioned credibility in this field," Mr. Bennett said. "The effect of this cannot be understated."
 The county also has a lawsuit pending against KPMG Peat Marwick, the county's former auditor. Any proceeds from that litigation will be used to pay off some $800 million to Orange County municipalities that had put money in the county's investment pool but agreed to hold off on their claims.
 Orange County, which filed for bankruptcy on Dec. 6, 1994, after losing $1.69 billion on the risky investments, will emerge from bankruptcy today.

HEADLINE: In Era of Smaller Schools, One County Finds Improvement From Consolidating

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

DATELINE: GREENSBORO, N.C.

 BODY:
Just a few years ago, the 93 public schools in Guilford County, a rolling expanse of cities and towns nestled between the Blue Ridge Mountains and Carolina coastal plains, needed help.
 Test scores and dropout rates varied widely among schools. Classrooms were crumbling, and some students graduated barely able to read. So, Guilford County voters reluctantly agreed to an overhaul. 

 While the trend around the country has been for big school districts to break into smaller units, the three districts in Guilford County decided to merge.
 The result has been marked improvements in most areas, better morale among most teachers, parents and students and a recognition of Guilford as a national model of how to succeed despite the crowding and budget freezes that have chewed away at similar efforts.
 "If you can pull three faculties into one system and show improvement at the same time, I'd say that's pretty significant," said John N. Dornan, executive director of Public School Forum, a nonprofit public policy center based in Raleigh, N.C.
 John F. Jennings, director of the Center on National Education Policy in Washington, says the new 57,000-student system, one of the nation's 65 largest, as an example of a district doing something right.
 "Guilford has been an interesting case study in whether a school system can get its own house in order," he said. "They are facing the dilemma of regaining public confidence in schools, and they are doing it by making difficult decisions on administrative matters, holding the line on taxes and trying to improve quality, all at the same time."
 By most accounts, Guilford has succeeded in marrying the economies of merger with the virtues of small-district administration, like redirecting savings into classrooms, focusing on core subjects and strong-arming principals and teachers into more accountability. But the price of change -- program cuts, heightened anxieties and a rising dropout rate -- has not gone unnoticed.
 For much of this century, local schools, eager to share resources or seeking an antidote to segregation, formed unified districts with their neighbors. But in recent years, many districts have found that bigger systems often create new problems, like inpenetrable bureaucracies, rather than saving money and desegregating. Consequently, across the country, behemoth systems have been breaking up.
 In Guilford County, the 1993 merger of two city districts -- Greensboro and High Point -- with the county district, was born of the need to cut costs, equalize resources, bolster achievement and curb the suburban flight of white families and businesses.
 "The key to making it work has been to rebuild the system," said Jerry D. Weast, who was recruited from the Sioux Falls, S.D., public schools to be superintendent of the newly merged system and who has since been called both a visionary reformer and a power-hungry Robespierre. "But you don't just change the organization. You have to change it's caliber."
 Unlike many superintendents, Dr. Weast has had the full support of a newly elected board of education, which undertook the merger with the slogan "achievement up, costs down." And because a state right-to-work law, Dr. Weast did not face unions, only teacher tenure laws.
 His first step was a careful audit. Looking at figures for the year before the merger, he discovered, spending in each of the former districts was well above the state average of $4,517 per student. Still, science and computer labs were under-equipped, and students were being crowded into mobile classrooms.
 In addition, while parents complained about poor teachers and achievement scores ranked Guilford students last or near last among North Carolina's large urban districts, principals had given all but a few teachers high evaluations.
 "It was Lake Wobegon here," Dr. Weast said. "Everyone was above average." Some principals had become lax in their reviews, he said. Others did not know how to give poor evaluations without inviting legal problems.
 But changes required money, and without new resources, Dr. Weast had to find the financing within his existing budget and staff.
 To lower costs, he cut the combined central office staff of 590 by 73 positions, saving $3 million.
 Another $2.36 million came from trimming district programs, including peer and college counseling, school based administrators and elementary foreign languages. And $1 million a year has been saved by using the district's maintenance staff instead of private vendors for most grounds keeping and repair.
 Other changes were made as well. In place of summer school, for example, tutors now offer after-school help to keep students from falling hopelessly behind. Two magnet programs and several undersubscribed high school electives have been eliminated as well -- changes that continue to raise objections.
 One mother, Carol Groover, was disappointed that her son's science and technology magnet program at Washington Elementary School was being dismantled. "This school's program has served a population that really needs it," she said.
 To improve teaching, the administration gave principals training in navigating a tenure system that protects incompetent as well as competent teachers and asking them to identify, improve or remove failing teachers. Principals, told they would be judged on their evaluation skills, submitted the names of 111 tenured and 19 nontenured teachers as needing help. By the end of last year, half were no longer in the system. Most others had been given "improved" status.
 Using money saved from program cuts, teachers and administrators have also been offered extra training, from computer and technology seminars to diversity counseling.
 But improving student performance, Dr. Weast said, has been his ultimate goal. Focusing intently on early intervention to improve reading, Dr. Weast quickly set up six new pre-school classrooms and pooled Federal school aid to send elementary school teachers to Ohio State University for training in a reading program.
 At a recent school board meeting Tommy McNulty, a kindergarten teacher of 30 years, said she had planned to resign from the Fairview School, one of the county's poorest, until she saw the students' benefits from the program. "I'm amazed at the difference it has made," she said. "Now I have to stick around and see how these children do in first and second grade."
 Extra teachers have also been assigned to help with reading and discipline problems.
 Trying to whip Guilford's 14 high schools into shape has been more difficult. Before the merger, many of the courses offered to the estimated 75 percent of students who would not attend or complete four-year colleges provided what Dr. Weast called "a second-rate education."
 Now, all students must take beginning algebra and a new work-preparedness program. And local businesses have joined an ambitious apprenticeship program.
 Despite such efforts, the merger report card is not all good news.
 High school test scores have shown less improvement than those for the lower grades. The mobile classroom count has doubled to about 300. The drop-out rate has gone up, from 2.7 percent of students in 1993-94 to 3.26 percent last year, in part because of higher standards, teachers say. And teachers and principals said that while schools now have better lab equipment and improved access to the Internet, they must coordinate programs and needs across a sea of schools and bureaucrats.
 Still, even Hannah H. Turner, president of the Guilford County P.T.A.'s who led opposition to merger three years ago, said while she was wary about the district's large size, its schools were better and safer now.
 She and others cite the slight, but welcome, rise in reading and math scores and improved S.A.T. scores. "The schools are never up to where the public thinks they ought to be," she said. "But a lot of schools, especially low-achieving ones, have made great strides since merger. There has really been a marked difference."

HEADLINE: Economic Data Sending Conflicting Signals

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
A new round of statistics released yesterday were but the latest in a recent series of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde economic numbers. Pleasant, optimistic statistics alternate with scary ones, leaving economists, Government officials, politicians and ordinary people wondering what's ahead in this election year.
 Yesterday's scary Mr. Hyde number reported that Americans, in increasing numbers, are failing to pay their credit card debts on time. But if that sounds like a downer for the economy, just four days earlier, the Labor Department released a hugely optimistic employment report for May, featuring the creation of hundreds of thousands of new jobs. 

 Just in the last month, Government data and private-sector surveys have bristled with puzzling contradictions. The overall economy expanded briskly in the first quarter, but manufacturing weakened. Home construction was strong, but consumer confidence edged down. Interest rates are rising in apparent expectation of inflation, but the Producer Price Index for May, released by the Labor Department yesterday, declined by one-tenth of 1 percent. [Page D2.]
 Perhaps most puzzling of all, retail sales and consumer demand are reported to be strong, but debt is a problem. Not only are credit card payments increasingly delinquent by 30 days or more, but bankruptcies are also up -- personal and corporate -- and some mortgage payments are late. No one really knows how to reconcile these contradictions, but two possible explanations are offered.
 One holds that consumers, pressed for cash, will soon cut back, pulling down the economy in the process. That is a minority view among economists. The more widely held view portrays the population as divided between the better-off and the not so well-off. The former, 40 percent or so of the total population, have benefited from rising wealth conferred mainly by a booming stock market, and their buying lifts the economy. The latter belong to households with $30,000 or less in annual income and little saved, and they are now stretched.
 The latter had not qualified for credit cards until the early 1990's. But with more than 6,000 banks and other institutions competing to issue credit cards, the less affluent were finally offered cards, and the rise in delinquencies is apparently mostly among them.
 "Normally, I would say yes, this could be the beginning of a consumer slowdown, but now I would hesitate to make that argument," said David S. Levy of the Levy Institute, an economic forecasting company. "The delinquencies could suggest that while lower-income Americans are suffering, the economy is thriving on the spending of wealthier people."
 Some 3.34 percent of all holders of credit cards issued by banks were behind in payments by 30 days or more in the first quarter, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday. That is the highest level since 1981, a recession year, when the rate hit 3.58 percent.
 "There has been a tremendous democratization of credit card use," said Alicia Munnell, a member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. "When you push cards on a broader population, it is not startling that there are more delinquencies."
 Delinquency rates for other forms of consumer debt have not risen, the Bankers Association said yesterday. Still, Americans took on new consumer debt at a slower pace in April than in any previous month this year, with total debt rising by 7 percent, to $1.14 trillion, compared with rises of 10 percent or more in the previous three months, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.
 But if credit card delinquencies were centered on a narrow group, other data suggest that a larger number of Americans might be strained financially. Installment payments are at unusually high levels as a percentage of available income. Mortgage payment delinquencies have risen, particularly in cases where the down payment on a home was relatively small, suggesting that buyers stretched themselves to afford their new homes, according to several groups that gather these data.
 Personal bankruptcies in the first quarter reached 253,000, or 1.01 million at an annual rate, a record level if the first-quarter pace continues through the year, and 15 percent above last year's level. And corporate bankruptcies are inching up, Dun & Bradstreet reports, having reached 32,164 for the year through May, or 4.9 percent above last year's level for the corresponding period.
 "The delinquency rates, bankruptcies and debt service levels suggest that we are not at the edge of some new consumer boom," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers. Despite this obstacle, Mr. Lipsky, like many other economists, argues that the economy will thrive as long as new jobs continue to be created at the current rapid pace, and a rising stock market adds to the wealth of millions of Americans.
 The trouble would come if the economy stumbles, perhaps because of some unexpected event, like a war or the bankruptcy of a huge corporation. "Then the debt burden would accelerate a slowdown," said Henry Kaufman, an economist and money manager. "But we are not at the stage when the economy begins to top out."

HEADLINE: When Lifetime Jobs Die Prematurely;
Downsizing Comes to Japan, Fraying Old Workplace Ties

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 11

 BODY:
When a major Japanese tire-and-rubber company asked a 53-year-old senior researcher to retire early last year, he refused.
 So the company moved him to a bare desk in the corner of a factory and told him that every two weeks, he would have to turn in a report on the same topic: "My Second Life." For six months, he stubbornly stuck it out, writing about himself until he had nothing left to say. In desperation, he turned to a friend, Kiyotsugu Shitara, who gave him two books on insects and animals, which turned out to be his salvation. 

 "He said, 'I can read about the lives of butterflies and animals and then I can write thousands of reports,' " said Mr. Shitara, who runs a union for managers. "He is still writing."
 His friend's predicament may not seem so bleak, in light of the armies of unemployed white-collar workers in Europe and the United States. After all, he still has a job.
 But his plight is one of numerous signs that after five years of economic troubles, the tight link between Japan's companies and its workers -- symbolized by the concept of lifetime employment -- is starting to come undone.
 The changes are modest and evolutionary in most cases, but together they may add up to a revolution that would have far-reaching reverberations for Japan and for competing economies in the United States and elsewhere.
 Seniority is losing out to performance in raising pay. Young and ambitious recruits are quitting to start their own companies. Employees are spurning their employers -- if only by occasionally quitting work a few hours earlier -- to indulge in family life.
 But the backdrop is the harsh new reality that the guarantee of a lifelong job, declared on the way out before but still a staple of many of the country's biggest companies, is finally beginning to break down. Mr. Shitara's friend may be hanging on, but Japan Inc. has succeeded in ridiculing, ostracizing and bullying other idle workers off the payroll.
 The traditional Japanese system that bound loyal workers and paternalistic employers to each other, in good times and bad, produced a level of commitment and a lack of labor unrest that were unknown in the West -- factors that helped make Japan a world economic power.
 But one cost was a bloated work force, particularly in the white-collar sector, which proved to be a painful drag that prolonged the economic troubles. While the recovery is now finally under way, Japan's maturing economy is bringing slower growth than before the troubles began -- and pressure is building for action aimed at greater productivity, including downsizing. That could mean American-style chronic unemployment as well as a redefinition of the concepts of loyalty, team dynamics and security.
 If Japan emerges stronger from the process -- more open, flexible, efficient and entrepreneurial, as in the Western economic model -- then American companies will have a new challenge on their hands. But if Japan has trouble adapting, then its workers and companies may find themselves adrift, without the familiar anchor of the past, and increasingly at odds with each other.
 For now, the only thing certain is that a shift has begun.
 "The long-term-employment system is crumbling gradually, even in the large corporations," said Kazunori Morishita, president of the Pasona Bright Career Company, a job placement agency for managers in Tokyo.
 In a nod to the continuing power of corporate identity, people here still sometimes introduce themselves with their company name, before offering their own.
 But polls of workers are now reflecting a spreading sentiment that the notion of a one-company career may no longer be ideal. When asked in 1987, in a survey by the Labor Ministry, to choose between keeping a frustrating job or switching to a more satisfying one, only 42.3 percent said they would dare move. Last year, those willing to jump rose to 63.4 percent.
 Indeed, while the shift away from security is highly painful for some, like Mr. Shitara's friend, for others it is liberating, auguring a period of greater job-hopping. This new spirit offers both a release from a single-minded devotion to work and a chance to pursue greater job satisfaction. It also means Japanese companies will not have the kind of control over their workers that they used to enjoy.
 To be sure, the promise of lifetime employment has never been a universal one in Japan, generally applying only to male employees working for big companies. Over all, only about one in five workers in recent years have been offered "jobs for life." And it has long been the case that the promise did not prevent employers from "encouraging" some older workers to retire.
 That happened to Yoshio Atsuda, a 63-year-old graduate of Kyoto University, a decade ago. His bosses at Nippon Steel suddenly told him one day that he was being transferred from his engineering post to a headhunting job, which he regarded as an extreme insult.
 "In Japan, someone with a good education can't do such a low-class task, where usually 9 out of 10 people are going to refuse your telephone call," Mr. Atsuda said. "Within a week, the telephone began to feel heavier and heavier, and I no longer wanted to make phone calls."
 He added, "The aim of Nippon Steel was to put people like us into such places so we would become unable to tolerate it and would quit."
 Mr. Atsuda endured for a while, but his life was miserable, with nightmares and marital problems. After six months, he jumped to a job at a patent office.
 Now, however, that office is revamping, and Mr. Atsuda fears he will lose his job again. "These days, there's a feeling that employers can do restructuring anywhere in Japan," he said.
 While statistics on such harsh treatment are hard to come by, anecdotal evidence indicates that more people are now being pushed toward the door -- enough so that Mr. Shitara operated a call-in service last week to offer advice and consolation to people like his friend.
 Nonetheless, some economists say that pronouncements about the decline of the lifetime-employment system are overdone. The system is still a basic tenet of the business ethos and philosophy of Japan, they say, adding that while the tectonic plates of Japanese industry may be shifting in fundamental ways, the process of change is proceeding at a geological pace akin to an inch a year.
 Layoffs remain minuscule, these experts say, even after the long economic downturn, which has included real estate and stock market crashes and a banking crisis.
 Remarkably, they note, Japan's unemployment rate is still only 3.4 percent, compared with 5.6 percent in the United States and more than 10 percent in much of Europe. But other data show that productivity in Japan lags behind both the United States and most other Western economies.
 So now, many economists say that Japan would be better off with a harsher approach.
 "A faster pace of layoffs in inefficient industries probably would have been a net benefit to companies and shareholders as a whole," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at the Tokyo branch of Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd. "Without more layoffs and a sense that they have to change their ways, they won't prepare for the future in the long run."
 About one-third of Japanese companies are now trying to cut employment, according to a survey conducted recently by the Labor Ministry. But the gingerly methods that some are still using tend to take a great deal of time, further dampening productivity.
 When the NKK Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel manufacturer, wanted to cut 1,500 white-collar employees a couple of years ago, department managers were involved in the search to find new places for some of their unlucky subordinates.
 "We have overemployment but we have to secure jobs for our employees," said Fumikatsu Ito, a personnel manager at NKK.
 Many companies have been proceeding cautiously for fear of depressing morale or being caught short-handed when the economy rebounds. Moreover, sagging birth rates mean that the size of the labor force is likely to decline after the year 2000, and so companies want to insure that they have adequate staffing for the future.
 Yet while many companies may be struggling to find the right mix, it is increasingly likely that the promise of lifetime employment will not be held out to many new hires.
 "College students are now in permanent oversupply and there is no reason why lifetime employment should be valid for all of them," said Takashi Kiuchi, head economist at the LTCB Research Institute, a private research center in Tokyo.
 Eventually, economists say, if companies want to remain competitive, they will have to become more cold-hearted in evicting longtime workers who are not needed.
 "If unemployment is not tolerated in the long run, this will erode business," said Haruo Shimada, a labor economist at Keio University. "It will be the slow death of the Japanese economy."
 That means, Mr. Kiuchi said, that Japanese companies "are moving much more toward the direction of U.S. companies," where labor mobility is a given -- and not necessarily a bad thing.
 Some managers, like Kazuhiko Tashiro, have already gotten the message.
 In 1991, when Mr. Tashiro did not like the managerial post he was given, he asked for a transfer. His company, the Sumitomo Corporation, one of the nation's most prestigious, sent him to the Okura Yusoki Company, a midsized manufacturer of conveyors that had a distant relationship with Sumitomo.
 Okura paid a fee to Sumitomo, and Sumitomo paid Mr. Tashiro's salary. But four years later, when Mr. Tashiro, an energetic 58-year-old with a degree from Tokyo University, wanted to return to Sumitomo, his bosses explained that there was no job for him at headquarters and he should stay at Okura.
 Mr. Tashiro refused. So, last November, after 33 years at Sumitomo, he took early retirement. Now, he works at Sugiyama Shoji, a small apparel company, where he travels door to door, drumming up sales of men's socks and T-shirts.
 "It is fun," he said cheerfully, "to go about doing work yourself."

HEADLINE: A Union Standing Fast Now Stands to Lose

SERIES: AN AMERICAN PLACE: Management and labor at odds.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

DATELINE: NORTH CANTON, Ohio, June 11

 BODY:
It was one of those awful moments when people can feel the future of their community shift and they tremble a little inside. At 4:25 on Monday afternoon, Raymond Eldreth, one of 1,490 union workers for the Hoover vacuum cleaner company who had crowded into the downtown civic center for the big vote, rushed out shouting, "They voted it down!"
 "Down big time!" shouted Bill Black, a 24-year veteran of Hoover, following him out the door. 

 The management at the Hoover Company, which has been manufacturing vacuum cleaners here since 1907, had given its workers one of those dreaded marketplace choices of the 1990's: Either accept a lower tier of wages for new hires (a $7.50-an-hour average, versus a current average of $14.50), or Hoover would build its new model of vacuum at a nonunion plant in El Paso.
 Hoover has long been considered here to be a benevolent employer. But the workers' rage was plain, and there was nothing ambiguous about their response. They voted by 1,300 to 188 to reject the lower tier of wages, even if that meant losing jobs to Texas.
 "If you take a yes vote, you might as well work in a sweatshop," said Debra Martin, a group leader on a motor line who has spent 17 years at Hoover. "It's just a damn shame this has got to happen in Ohio."
 Said Terry King, a 27-year Hoover veteran: "We made so many concessions in the 1980's, when this company was having trouble. And now that they're making big money, they turn around and cut our throats."
 Since W. H. (Boss) Hoover set up shop here at the turn of the century, Hoover has been the largest employer in North Canton, a prosperous, conservative Canton suburb of 15,000 people. Everything major in this city, from the library to City Hall to the Fire Department's hook and ladder to the Little League fields, has been financed with donations from the company and the Hoover family.
 But in 1986 Hoover was sold to a Chicago holding company, and in 1989 it was sold again, to the Maytag Corporation of Newton, Iowa. And even though Hoover has been a top earner for Maytag, there has been an edginess here about the corporation's commitment to North Canton.
 How many jobs will be lost to Texas is unclear, but as Daryl Revoldt, a City Councilman, said today, "No one can find anything hopeful in this."
 Company officials say that none of the 2,000 union workers here in Stark County will be affected for the present and that 200 new jobs will be created in Texas. But if the new upright product is as successful as the company hopes, union officials say, between 600 and 1,500 jobs could be lost here in coming years. There are already people in North Canton who fear that this could be the beginning of the end for Hoover here.
 "This will suck a lot of jobs down there," said Dan Mareno, chief steward for the union, a local of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.
 Lynne Dragomier, a Hoover vice president, said company officials were disappointed and surprised by the vote and had given the union a choice because Hoover had hoped to put the new jobs in North Canton. The vacuum cleaner field is highly competitive, she said, and Hoover has to keep prices down. "There is a market-share battle under way that is very critical for the Hoover Company and its employees," she said.
 If the people of North Canton want to see what could lie in store, they can look to Hoover's closest competitor, the Eureka Company, owned by Electrolux of Sweden. In the early 1980's, just before Eureka opened a new plant in El Paso, it had all 1,200 of its manufacturing jobs in Bloomington, Ill. Today there are 400 jobs in Bloomington, 878 in El Paso. Last month the company announced that it was planning 390 new jobs in El Paso, raising the work force there to 1,268. Those new Eureka jobs will pay $7.25 an hour.
 The dilemma for Hoover's workers offers another example of the mixed state of the national economy. Unemployment here is about 5 percent, a big improvement on the 8 percent rate of four years ago. Everywhere there are "now hiring" signs. But that oft-repeated workers' lament is also true here: "There are plenty of jobs -- I've got three of them."
 In a poll taken by The New York Times in Stark County last month, 28 percent of respondents said someone in their household had taken on an extra job in the last three years; 19 percent said someone in their home had lost a job to downsizing in the last five years.
 When asked whom they blamed for such job losses nationally, 52 percent placed "a lot" of blame on corporations; 19 percent blamed unions a lot.
 Stark is a county that tends to vote as the nation does in Presidential elections, and, although a lot of workers here deserted the Democrats in the 1980's, they returned in 1992 to help Bill Clinton carry the county. As the Hoover workers waited for the union ballots to be tabulated on Monday, there were not many who had nice things to say about corporations or Republicans.
 Roger Davis, a 23-year Hoover veteran, said the experience made him more likely to vote for President Clinton. "This tier-wage system," he said, "is exactly how Republicans think life should be."
 Many were angered that this was happening at so profitable a company. Maytag had record profits as recently as 1994, and Susan Gallagher, an analyst for Natwest Securities, said 1996 should be another "very strong year."
 "It's like they want to eliminate the middle class," said Bob Black, a 25-year Hoover veteran. "It's pretty typical of Republicans. I haven't seen management say they'll take a 10 percent cut across the board."
 The new proposal by Hoover would actually have created a third tier of wages. In 1988, during a company reorganization, the union agreed to 250 layoffs, a three-year wage freeze and a two-tier system. As a result, there are now 1,600 Hoover workers earning $15.50 an hour and 400, in the second tier, earning $9.50. Wages in the third tier, rejected on Monday, would have ranged from $6.50 to $8 an hour.
 Denise Foster, a 20-year Hoover veteran, said: "People lost their jobs in 1988, their homes, marriages broke up -- it was terrible, terrible. We gave these concessions, and this is what we get. What's the point?"
 In April, when Jim Repace, president of the union local, was asked by a reporter how he felt about Hoover as an employer, he was effusive, saying, "People have it nice here, they really do."
 But the month since Hoover gave him the third-tier alternative has been miserable, he says. At the Monday meeting, he made no recommendation to his members. After the vote, when the civic center was empty and quiet, a reporter asked how he felt about Hoover now. Mr. Repace looked shaken, and in a quiet voice he spoke words like "disappointed" and "betrayed."
 
Throughout the Presidential election year, articles in this series will examine Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County, a political bellwether for decades

HEADLINE: What to Give The Newlyweds? Just Be Practical

BYLINE: By SUZANNE HAMLIN

 BODY:
AS the 1996 wedding season unofficially opens, many of this year's 2.5 million nuptial couples have some requests. Please, no more lava lamps, knitted pillowcases, temple bells from Thailand, electric forks, plastic trays laminated with sequins, monthly bagel shipments or cheese boards with chain-attached knives.
 Instead, when selecting a gift, consider something that the couple have actually said they want. 

 An eminently practical present, like top-quality kitchen equipment or appliances, is high on this year's list of newlywed must-haves. Something notably luxurious but still functional, like beautiful bed linens, will not be scorned, either. And when in doubt, don't hesitate to give money, "an absolutely acceptable gift -- I love it myself," said Martha Stewart, America's home and entertainment mentor.
 Along with several other contemporary arbiters of tasteful giving and getting, Ms. Stewart was asked what she thought of a cash gift, the No. 1 choice in two wedding-gift surveys. One was a 1994 random sample survey of 218 newlyweds, commissioned by American Express, and it found that money was spent on trips, household items, bills and mortgage payments.
 Money was also popular in a large sampling compiled by Modern Bride magazine in November and December 1995. In the magazine's mail survey of about-to-be brides, 512 completed extensive questionnaires; 88 percent said they would prefer cash to other gifts.
 No matter what their economic circumstances, most couples said they were hesitant to ask for money directly for fear that they would appear crass. But Cele Lalli, editor in chief of Modern Bride, said, "Money is a fine gift, and in some cultures it's standard."
 It appears, though, that old-fashioned gift-giving has not disappeared, even if the gifts have changed from formal to practical. And the brides and grooms of 1996, many of whom have already established households, know exactly what they want.
 In another Modern Bride survey, in June 1995, 87 percent of 500 newlyweds, whose average wedding cost $14,900, reported that they had registered at one or several places for wedding presents, and more than half said they were as happy to have received household items as money.
 More affluent than the American Express group, whose income average was $38,170 a couple, the Modern Bride respondents, who with their spouses had an average income of $54,507, asked for small kitchen appliances, cookware and bakeware, followed by crystal stemware, bath linens, china, cutlery and bed linens.
 Sally Fischer, whose wedding date is June 23, is not being coy when she says she prefers gifts to money. "By giving us things for a household, people are recognizing that Elliott and I are really establishing a life together," said Ms. Fischer, 40, who owns a public relations business in Manhattan. She is marrying Elliott Upton, 49, a widower who is a staff developer for schools in the South Bronx. It will be her first marriage, "an event I've been planning since I was born," she said.
 In Mill Valley, Calif., Audrey Sadler, 30, said that she, too, preferred presents to cash. "It's very touching when people give you something for your home," said Ms. Sadler, a graphic designer who is marrying Ron Martinez, 43, the chief executive of Postlinear Entertainment, an interactive media company, on June 22. "Your friends and family become a real part of your everyday life."
 Ms. Fischer and Ms. Sadler signed up with their fiances at bridal registries, listing specific gift choices, from modest to extravagant. Ms. Fischer registered at Bergdorf Goodman, ABC Carpet and Home, Bloomingdale's and Crate and Barrel; Ms. Sadler at Macy's and Williams-Sonoma. They are part of the $32 billion-a-year wedding business, a large part of which takes place in the second half of the year. (August is the most popular month for weddings, followed by June and July.)
 "The bridal registry solves all kinds of problems," Mrs. Lalli said. "It's easy to find out where a couple has registered by asking them or their family.
 "The couple can list inexpensive as well as big-ticket items, and people get what they really want. They don't -- or shouldn't if the computer system works properly -- get duplications. The registry knows where to send the gifts. And anyone can call those 800 numbers, tell the store how much they want to spend, and order from anywhere in the world."
 For Modern Bride readers, the most popular department store registries nationwide are J. C. Penny, Dillard's and Macy's; for mail-order catalogues, Service Merchandise; for housewares, Crate and Barrel.
 Kathy Paddor, the director of marketing at Crate and Barrel headquarters in Chicago, said that bridal registration in the chain's 62 nationwide stores "now accounts for a huge part of our business."
 Four years ago, Crate and Barrel, which sells everything from bathmats to sofas, changed its "bridal registry" to just plain "gift registry" to accommodate a wide spectrum of recipients. "We now list people as registrant and co-registrant instead of bride and groom, which makes everyone comfortable, including gay couples," said Tammy Dorward, the furniture manager at Manhattan Crate and Barrel, at Madison and 59th Street.
 For those who have everything, don't want money and have failed to register, there are still some magnanimous possibilities. A case of wine produced in the year of the wedding. Or a pre-arranged grand restaurant dinner, beginning with Champagne. Or anything from Tiffany's.
 Marjabelle Young Stewart, who lives in Kewanee, Ill., and is the author of 15 books, including "Your Complete Wedding Planner" (St. Martin's Press, 1989, $14.95), said her standard wedding gift for years has been Tiffany's crystal candlesticks. "You just can't have too many of them," she said.
 "Who cares if you get duplicates?" said Anne Teshima of Manhattan, who testified that Tiffany graciously accommodates returns. A commercial real estate agent who was married in December to Steven Martin Cohen, a toy inventor and novelist, Ms. Teshima added that she much preferred her four identical Tiffany vases to the present sent by her husband's former girlfriend: coffee mugs laminated with photos of Mr. Cohen in the throes of a severe case of adult chicken pox.
 Martha Stewart, who wrote "Martha Stewart Weddings" (Clarkson N. Potter, 1987, $70), suggests giving the most luxurious version you can afford of the most practical gift. Her own favorites are "the very, very finest down comforter, or a bouquet a month for a year from a favorite florist, or a library of books, such as Random House's Everyman's Library."
 Of course, "if the couple has a house I give them a great lawn mower, or if they're real gardeners, the very best shovels," said Ms. Stewart, who added that she thought "a gift is a little bit better than money, even if it's the same amount of money."
 To those who still prefer cash, which some people feel uncomfortable giving, gift-givers have dress-up options. American Express suggests its gift checks, which can be used like traveler's checks. And several enterprising travel agents are suggesting cash through a "honeymoon fund," set up to finance a trip the couple have chosen.
 Those who do give gifts should send them ahead, not bring them to the ceremony. "The worst thing to do," said one recent bride, who bemoaned last-minute arrivals. "One gift got stolen, several cards were lost, and my brother got stuck with packing everything up and storing it for us until we got home from our honeymoon."
 The amount spent on a present should not be contingent on the lavishness of the ceremony, or lack thereof, Mrs. Lalli said. "What you give should be based on two things: what you can afford, and what your relationship is to the couple," she added, estimating that the cost of gifts nationwide was $50 to $100, and often much more in urban areas.
 "Don't forget sharing, either," she said. "It's perfectly fine to get together with some friends and give the couple one very good thing."
 For recipients, unbreakable rules of weddings are that if the wedding is canceled, the gifts must be returned to the givers, no exceptions. And as for those thank-you notes, get busy.
 In a perfect world run by mothers and wedding consultants, thank-you notes would be written the day the gift is received. In less controlled circumstances, up to three months is considered acceptable for hand-written expressions of gratitude. (In the case of a large wedding, a printed card acknowledging receipt of the gift is fine as long as it is followed shortly by a personal note.)
 And the multimarried should be assured that they have all the rights and privileges of the first time out.
 Marjabelle Stewart, the wedding adviser, is adamant about this. "Every time Elizabeth Taylor gets married again, people call me and ask if they should send a gift," she said, sounding incredulous that anyone would even ask. "Of course she should get gifts. Every marriage is a new beginning, not a number."

HEADLINE: Economy Poor, Germans Yield On Store Hours

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BERLIN, June 11

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl's governing party agreed today to allow stores to stay open longer in the hopes of increasing employment and stimulating the sluggish German economy.
 The long-debated change has been opposed by many trade unions as anti-family but supported by harried shoppers. It would allow stores to stay open until 8 P.M. during the week and until 4 P.M. on Saturdays. 

 Currently, most stores are required to close by 6:30 P.M. on weekdays and 2 P.M. on Saturdays, with only occasional exceptions.
 The compromise would also lift a law in force since before World War II that even forbids bakeries from baking bread on Sundays. The strict rules are often a source of frustration to Germans rushing to buy groceries after work and to tourists.
 Although Germans have debated this major shift for years, support for longer store hours has grown as the economy weakens. Unemployment is currently about 10 percent and growth is stagnant.
 A Government-commissioned study last year estimated that longer shop hours would mean an additional $13 billion in the economy.
 The Christian Democrats, led by Mr. Kohl, and its sister party, the Christian Social Union, approved the changes today, putting all three coalition partners in agreement.
 The liberal Free Democrats, the smallest member of the governing coalition, had called on the other partners at its party meeting on Friday to reach a compromise.
 The staunchly conservative Christian Social Union had held out on agreeing to the changes, especially the Saturday extensions, arguing that longer hours would cut into family time for store employees.
 Wolfgang Schaeuble, parliamentary leader for the parties, said the new regulations would be passed and in effect no later than Jan. 1.
 At a news conference on Monday, Mr. Kohl mentioned his recent trip to Washington, noting with approval how stores in the Georgetown section were open at midnight. He said it was getting harder and harder to explain to foreigners why such all-night groceries were illegal here.

HEADLINE: Phillips and Conoco End Talks About Merging Operations

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 11

 BODY:
Conoco Inc. and the Phillips Petroleum Company said today that they had been unable to reach a final agreement to merge their refining and marketing businesses and had broken off talks.
 Executives familiar with the discussions said the companies could not agree on the value of the businesses to be merged -- in particular, the value of the refineries -- and on how much cash each company was to have received in the deal. 

 The companies had announced plans on May 14 to form a 50-50 joint venture that was to be the first of its kind between major oil companies in the United States. Phillips said today that it would look for other partners, but Conoco, which is owned by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said it would not.
 Conoco apparently believed that its refineries were worth more than those of Phillips. Though Archie W. Dunham, Conoco's chief executive, declined to comment on the talks, he said that Conoco's refineries deserved some sort of premium. "It's critical that the shareholders receive full value for those assets because it's taken tremendous amounts of precious cash to build them," he said in an interview tonight.
 The Mobil Corporation and British Petroleum P.L.C. agreed in February to combine their European refining and marketing. In the United States, refiners and distributors trying to cut costs have reduced their inventories, contributing to the recent rises in gasoline prices. Conoco and Exxon agreed several weeks to turn their separate refineries in Karlsruhe, Germany, into one.
 The partnership between Conoco and Phillips would have sold gasoline through more than 12,000 stations and drawn $13.6 billion in annual sales. The companies, citing confidentiality agreements, offered only a brief explanation of why the talks ended, saying they could not agree on "significant commercial issues."
 Analysts elaborated on that, saying questions of valuation had been crucial. "They couldn't come to an agreement on what their assets were worth," said John D. Hervey of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "That's the bottom line."
 Conoco, which is based in Houston, and Phillips, which is based in Bartlesville, Okla., wanted to combine refineries, gas stations and transportation systems into a new company. That company was to borrow on its own behalf to pay the partners for the operations. Though Phillips planned to contribute $2.6 billion in assets and Conoco $2.4 billion, those are just accounting values. In practice, the companies could not agree on the initial payouts each would get.
 The incentives for a merger arise from especially tight margins in the refining and selling of gasoline. Oil companies have been cutting their staffs and costs. But combined, large refiners could achieve further economies by measures like closing gas stations in overlapping markets.
 Phillips and Conoco had agreed on many questions of the management and direction of the venture, one person with knowledge of the talks said. And though the rise in gasoline prices has prompted several Federal investigations of the industry, both companies said no regulatory obstacles had blocked their deal.
 In the statement, Wayne W. Allen, the chief executive of Phillips, said he would keep looking for "creative ways to enhance the value of our assets -- including joint venture opportunities." But Rob Phillips, a company spokesman, said he knew of no talks with other companies.
 The two companies disclosed the end of the talks as the stock market closed. Phillips shares closed down 75 cents, at $40.75, on the New York Stock Exchange; those of Du Pont fell 62.5 cents, to $79.25.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Plunges on Worries Of Possible Big Sales in Japan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Copper prices tumbled yesterday as a market already nervous about supply was roiled by speculation that a management change at a big Japanese trading company could lead to a selloff of its copper holdings.
 Traders said that rumors that Yasuo Hamanaka, the chief copper trader at the Sumitomo Corporation, had resigned sent copper prices plunging. Traders were betting that the company would sell its copper positions, said Wolfgang Becker, a trader at Iceni Commodities Brokerage in Hamburg, Germany. 

 The selling in copper spilled over into precious metals, which were also weakened by data showing moderate inflation in the United States.
 Mr. Hamanaka has been a focus of attention in the copper market since last month, when his title was changed from general manager of nonferrous metals to assistant to the general manager. Mr. Hamanaka had been in charge of copper trading at Sumitomo, which traders believe controls about 70 percent of the copper stockpiles held in the London Metal Exchange warehouse in Long Beach, Calif. That warehouse holds 23 percent of the exchange's worldwide stockpile.
 Copper traders have been speculating about the meaning of Mr. Hamanka's change in title, and the rumor yesterday was that he had left the company, suggesting to some traders that Sumitomo intended to sell off its copper, flooding the market at a time when rising production has begun to outstrip demand.
 Sumitomo officials in New York denied that Mr. Hamanaka had left, calling the job shift "part of a normal policy of rotating managers."
 But copper prices, which fell sharply on the London Metal Exchange, continued to drop in New York. Copper for July delivery fell 6.65 cents, or 6 percent, to $1.013 a pound on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, its lowest since June 1, 1994.
 Gold prices were also lower on the Comex. Investment demand for gold cooled in response to a Labor Department report showing a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in producer prices in May.
 Gold for August delivery fell $1.60, to $386.90 an ounce -- its lowest closing price since Nov. 22, 1995.

HEADLINE: Fall in Producer Prices Signals That Inflation Remains Tame

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
Prices at the producer level fell unexpectedly in May, the Government said today, offering fresh evidence that inflation remains tame despite Wall Street's worries that the economy's strength will unleash a pickup in prices.
 Tumbling energy prices and stable food costs helped push the Producer Price Index down one-tenth of 1 percent in May after a four-tenths of 1 percent increase in April, the Labor Department said. 

 Excluding volatile food and energy costs, the closely watched core rate of the Producer Price Index was unchanged last month after rising a mere one-tenth of 1 percent in each of the three prior months.
 Economists had expected both the overall and the core rates of the Producer Price Index to increase by two-tenths of 1 percent in May.
 "What more can you ask for?" asked Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation. "Healthy economic growth and low inflation -- this is economic heaven."
 The Government is scheduled on Wednesday to report on consumer prices for May, and economists have been expecting a three-tenths of 1 percent increase, down from April's rise of four-tenths of 1 percent.
 Economists said the drop in the overall Producer Price Index took some pressure off the Federal Reserve to push up interest rates to keep inflation in check.
 "I don't see anything that demands them to do anything immediately," said Robert Dederick, Northern Trust Corporation economist.
 On Friday, a stronger-than-expected employment report shook the financial markets and raised expectations that the Fed's policy makers were more likely to increase interest rates at their meeting in early July.
 The report on producer prices initially cheered the financial markets today, and stock and bond prices rallied as interest rates slipped. But both markets later gave up their gains. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 19.21 points, at 5,668.66, while the yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond ended the day unchanged at 7.12 percent.
 The report showed that energy prices slid six-tenths of 1 percent in May after surging more than 2 percent in each of the two prior months because of tight petroleum supplies.
 Heating oil prices fell 7.3 percent -- the biggest drop in more than one and a half years -- while gasoline was unchanged after soaring 6.1 percent in April and 7.1 percent in March.
 Economists expect energy prices will remain under pressure in the months ahead as suppliesease.
 Food prices were unchanged in May after falling three-tenths of 1 percent. Vegetable costs fell 19.5 percent, the largest decline in 16 months. Pork prices jumped 8.6 percent, the largest rise in nearly seven and a half years. Fruit prices rose.
 Tobacco prices, meanwhile, jumped 3.2 percent, the largest rise in nearly two and a half years.
 Economists said bargain-hungry consumers, fierce competition among retailers and global competition among producers were combining to keep a lid on prices.
 "The markets out there are still highly competitive," said Cynthia Latta of DRI/McGraw-Hill Inc.
 While economists were mostly pleased with the report and said it showed inflation was under control, some cautioned that the threat of higher prices was not entirely removed. They pointed to recent rises in labor costs and other factors.
 Prices of intermediate goods -- those that require further processing such as flour, synthetic fibers and leather -- rose five-tenths of 1 percent after rising three-tenths of 1 percent in April. Prices of raw materials climbed 1.3 percent in May after rising 5.3 percent in April.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Producer Prices" tracks index of finished goods prices, seasonally adjusted, from December 1994 through May 1996. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: Bond Firm Being Sold To NatWest

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL

 BODY:
The NatWest Group, which is trying to build a substantial global investment bank, agreed yesterday to pay $590 million in cash to acquire Greenwich Capital Holdings Inc. from the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan. The acquisition, which was negotiated over the last several months, had been widely expected.
 Greenwich, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., is a bond-trading business with more than 400 employees. It focuses on United States Treasury securities, mortgage- and asset-backed securities as well as the government debt of the world's biggest economies. In the Treasury market, it is one of the 37 primary dealers that deal directly with the Federal Reserve. 

 "This is a recognition by NatWest that we are absolutely determined to become a premier-league global investment bank," Peter Hall, deputy chief executive of NatWest Markets, the company's investment banking unit, said in an interview yesterday. "It's not easy to define precisely what that means, but we want to be seen by institutional clients as one of their top providers of investment banking services."
 NatWest recently sold NatWest Bancorp, its North American branch-banking network, to Fleet Financial Group for $3.5 billion, saying it wanted to focus on building an international investment bank.
 NatWest, with its National Westminster Bank, is one of Britain's biggest banks. It is not alone in trying to buy its way into New York's investment banking business. Large European banks, like Deutsche Bank A.G. of Germany, Union Bank of Switzerland and Swiss Bank, are also spending heavily to set up New York operations. They are just the latest wave of foreigners with big ambitions in the world's biggest, and most competitive, financial market.
 Many New York financial experts are skeptical about the chances for success of these ventures. But the European banks insist that they have to build big investment banks in New York if they are to survive and prosper, because international financial markets are now so closely integrated that their biggest and most important customers require them to have a presence on Wall Street.
 As part of the Greenwich transaction, Gary F. Holloway and Konrad R. Kruger, who are co-chief executives of Greenwich Capital, will head Greenwich NatWest, the new name for the global bond business of NatWest Markets, which now has about 7,000 employees.
 Including subordinated debt, Greenwich had capital of $465 million, with net assets of $243 million on Dec. 31, 1995, a year in which it made profits of $75 million before taxes. It became a primary dealer in Treasury securities in 1984 and now ranks among the 10 most active primary dealers. Long Term Credit Bank of Japan acquired Greenwich for about $145 million in 1988.
 Mr. Hall said that Greenwich would also complement the existing North American businesses of NatWest Markets. He said that NatWest already had a significant equities business after its November 1995 purchase of Gleacher & Company, a merger-and-acquisition advisory business that Natwest bought for $135 million.
 Analysts were not surprised by the purchase. "In general, since NatWest made the decision to sell off their consumer and small-business banking it was pretty clear they were going to concentrate on investment banking," said Charles N. Cranmer, an analyst at M. A. Schapiro & Company. "Whether it works out, time will tell."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against the Yen, But Is Mixed in Other Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen yesterday on growing expectations that Japanese interest rates would stay low, but it ended mixed against other major currencies.
 Officials at the Japanese Ministry of Finance announced yesterday that it planned to resume direct purchases of Government bonds this week for the first time in three years. Currency traders said the purchases would help keep rates from rising. Demand for the bonds would tend to bolster prices, which move in the opposite direction from yields. 

 "That indicates Japan is not going to be raising official interest rates any time soon, and on that a short-term trader should buy dollars against yen," said Robert Nelson, managing director of foreign exchange sales at Westdeutsche Landesbank.
 In addition, Japan's sluggish economy is likely to need low interest rates for some time to stimulate growth, traders said.
 The dollar rallied almost one yen after the comments by the ministry officials, hitting a fresh 28-month high of 109.70 yen before slipping a bit on profit taking, traders said.
 "The dollar was bid all day against the yen," Mr. Nelson said.
 In late trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 109.43 Japanese yen, up from 109 yen on Monday. The dollar fell to 1.5347 German marks from 1.5350 marks. The British pound rose to $1.5350 from $1.5345.
 As the dollar approached the psychological barrier of 110 yen, Japanese trust banks and United States investment funds started selling, capping the currency's rally, traders said.
 But the outlook remains good for the dollar, based on the strength of the United States economy compared with those in Europe and Japan and more attractive investment returns promised by American stocks and bonds, dealers said.
 "Any time we see a selloff it seems to be met with buying interest," said James Kemp, chief spot dealer at Citibank. "There are plenty of reasons to buy the dollar."
 The Labor Department's report that prices at the producer level fell last month bolstered the bond market and the dollar. A Federal Reserve governor, Edward W. Kelley Jr., told an audience in Basel, Switzerland, that he was encouraged by the apparent lack of inflation pressures in the United States economy, which also helped the dollar.
 "People generally want to buy dollars and if there's no extraneous noise in the market, that's the way they will go," Mr. Kemp said.

HEADLINE: Slight Rebound In Indicator of Chip Demand

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11

 BODY:
The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rebounded slightly in May, although it still pointed to weak demand, providing a first sign that the five-month-old slump might be nearing an end, a trade group said today.
 The report came after the close of the stock market, but analysts said it was likely to bolster semiconductor stocks, many of which are trading at historic lows. A protracted glut of memory chips has caused a free fall in prices, prompting several large manufacturers to cut back production plans. 

 The Semiconductor Industry Association, which is based in San Jose, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 0.84 for the three-month period ending in May, up from a revised figure of 0.81 for the April period. The April book-to-bill ratio was revised upward from 0.78. The association said the most recent period marked a significant pickup in new orders for the first time in 1996.
 The book-to-bill compares orders with shipments. Thus, a book-to-bill of 0.84 means that for every $100 worth of product shipped, $84 worth was ordered, which would normally indicate declining demand. But since the ratio is measured in dollars, not units, a steep decline in the price of memory chips has served to push the ratio lower than actual unit demand might indicate.
 "These are very positive developments. They suggest that the industry's first-quarter doldrums are truly over," said Doug Andrey, director of information systems and finance for the association.
 "We're still seeing a slight decline in billings, but that's a leftover from the weak bookings of the first quarter," he said. "Together, these figures appear to show that the industry has stabilized."
 New chip orders in May totaled about $3.20 billion, a three-tenths of 1 percent increase from the $3.19 billion worth of bookings recorded in April, but 24.2 percent lower than the $4.22 billion in bookings in the comparable period a year ago, when the overall book-to-bill ratio reached 1.18.
 Shipments for May reached $3.79 billion, a decline of 3.3 percent from April's billings of $3.92 billion, but a 5.9 percent increase over the May 1995 billings total of $3.58 billion.
 "Orders are still decelerating slightly, and that's partly due to some pretty tough comparisons; it was just about this time last year that memory prices hit their peaks," said Jonathan Joseph, an analyst with Montgomery Securities.
