HEADLINE: U.S. BLAMES ALLIES FOR UNDERCUTTING ITS CHINA POLICY

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
The State Department's top official for Asian affairs said today that the Administration's efforts to force China to respect trade accords and halt the spread of weapons were being exploited by Europe and Japan, which he said were happy to "hold our coats" while they "gobble up our contracts."
 The unusually blunt assessment by the official, Winston Lord, in testimony before the House Ways and Means Committee, came a day after Prime Minister Li Peng explicitly warned that he would use China's growing economic power to send more business to non-American companies unless Washington dropped its efforts to force China to change its ways. 

 Mr. Li, in an interview with The Financial Times, praised European leaders because "they do not attach political strings to cooperation with China, unlike the Americans who arbitrarily resort to the threat of sanctions or the use of sanctions."
 Mr. Lord, a former Ambassador to China who is now Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia and the Pacific, and other Clinton Administration officials have privately expressed their frustration in recent months that Japan and the European Union have criticized America's tactics with China -- while turning the tensions to their own benefit.
 They have noted, for example, that among the biggest beneficiaries of America's crackdown on the piracy of music and video recordings in China are the Sony Corporation of Japan and Bertelsmann A. G. of Germany.
 Through industry associations in Washington, the companies have lobbied the Administration heavily to take a tough line against China on behalf of their American subsidiaries.
 But in Japan and Germany, the same companies and their Governments have stayed on the sidelines.
 European nations, along with Canada and Mexico, have their own complaints about the Administration's mix of trade and politics. In recent months the European Union has expressed outrage over Mr. Clinton's decision to impose sanctions on companies around the world who do business with Cuba. Last week the State Department sent letters to the top executives of companies doing business in Havana warning that they may be barred from entering the United States.
 Europe has also objected to legislation now making its way through Congress that would penalize companies, particularly in France and Germany, that are striking billions of dollars in oil deals with Iran. On Wednesday, Jacques Santer, the new president of the European Commission, is scheduled to meet President Clinton, amid suggestions from Europe that American companies will be subject to retaliation if their business in the United States is hurt.
 In his testimony today, which focused on the Administration's efforts to renew China's "most favored nation" trade status, Mr. Lord was trying to make the case that the best way to deal with China was to remain fully engaged with Beijing, but to threaten specific sanctions for specific offenses -- from trade violations to the shipping of nuclear weapons to rogue states.
 He quickly acknowledged, however, that the sanctions are only truly effective when China's other major trading partners join in. "One of our biggest problems in China is that our friends in Europe and Japan hold our coats while we take on the Chinese, and they gobble up the contracts," he said.
 "And I've said it directly to our friends," he added. "If we could get more European and Japanese support of intellectual property rights, for example -- where they have a clear interest -- on nonproliferation, on human rights, whatever we did, targeted or not, would be much more effective. It's one of our biggest problems. We're working on it, but we need more help from our friends around the world."
 After his testimony, Mr. Lord said in an interview that he did not believe that Europe and Japan were always seeking to profit from differences between China and the United States. "Sometimes there are real policy differences over China, and we have to respect that," he said. "There are times when they genuinely disagree on the most effective approach or tactics."
 But he was clearly disturbed by Mr. Li's comments on Monday, the baldest statement by China yet that American companies will be punished for the pressure placed upon Beijing by Washington.
 In April, China gave a $1.2 billion aircraft order to Airbus Industrie that had been expected to go to the Boeing Company, and Japanese auto makers have used the recent tensions between Washington and Beijing to win approval for new plants in China. A number of American companies with large or potential investments in China have urged Washington to calm the waters, declaring that they are being held hostage.
 European business executives are unapologetic for their efforts to get into the Chinese market at America's expense.
 "Don't ask too much from the Europeans," Klaus Friedrich, the chief economist of Dresdner Bank Group, Germany's second-largest commercial bank, said today. "It's too early. We can't play world cop." If the United States was unhappy with Europe's failure to back the threats of unilateral sanctions, he advised, "then don't do what you're doing."
 By explicitly raising the possibility of sending more business to Europe, Mr. Li and other Chinese leaders appear to be betting that they can further fracture the United States business community about the wisdom of confronting China.
 Whether that tactic pays off may become clearer by Monday, the Administration's deadline for imposing roughly $2 billion in sanctions unless Beijing agrees to enforce a 15-month-old agreement to protect foreign-produced compact disks and programs contained on CD-ROM's.
 In the last several days China has begun a last-minute crackdown on the plants, raiding several of them and closing their doors. "There's action under way," Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States Trade Representative, said today.
 But while their body language suggests a deal is in the works to avert sanctions, Administration officials say China has yet to do enough to get the United States to drop its threats. That could be a negotiating ploy, or it could be a reflection of the odd set of negotiations now under way -- talks in which the American side is uncertain who in the Chinese leadership is actually making the decisions.

HEADLINE: Bradley, Retiring Senator, Pondering His Next Shot;
He Hasn't Decided What His Role Will Be

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Twelve pounds heavier from nights of burgers and room service, Bill Bradley returned recently from a trip around the country to promote the book he wrote that made him realize he no longer wished to be a United States Senator.
 His head was overfull with the issues he wants to tackle, now that he will soon be free of elective office as he stews, maybe for the last time, over whether he could, or even should, try to become President. 

 "And that raises my wife's question," Mr. Bradley said in his office here the other day. "Which is, O.K., what's your job?"
 The answer is, less than six months before he is to retire, the senior Senator from New Jersey says he has no earthly idea of what comes next. The general job title he is thinking about -- a sort of public intellectual -- has few models. In fact, as Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts, and Mario M. Cuomo, the former Governor of New York, have learned, the public cares little when a former politician speaks out unless it thinks he has ambitions for higher office, especially the highest.
 The risks of irrelevance or perceived sanctimony seem not to concern Mr. Bradley at the moment. He is clearly laying the groundwork for something, even if he is not sure exactly what it is. At 52, he has begun to take computer lessons, working at the machine only recently installed at his office. (He is interested in learning how grass-roots organizations can use the Internet.)
 His unusual book, "Time Present, Time Past," written not with a computer keyboard but with a No. 2 pencil, can be read as either a valedictory summing up or a verbal launching pad for the Presidency in four years. The book has sold 125,000 copies and spent eight weeks on the best-seller lists.
 The reception has pleased Mr. Bradley, who chatted at his desk recently over his usual Washington lunch, a green salad with one cherry tomato, two cans of apple-cranberry drink and several saltines, which he likes to swab in the residue dressing and eat with a plastic fork.
 Speaking of his book and his travels to promote it, he said: "I would remark on various points of the tour that, if I walked out of the radio station today and somebody hit me with a car and it's over, well, there it is. That's what I think. It's great to reach a point where you say: There it is, it's O.K."
 His professed contentment aside, the book more than hints that there may be another chapter in Mr. Bradley's life in elective office -- that he will finally answer the question that has dogged him since high school in Crystal City, Mo. These days, with Bill Clinton doing well in the polls, Mr. Bradley has stopped hinting about an independent run for President this year, telling people that he would run only a race he thought he could win.
 But that only underscores what has become a central feature of his political persona: that of a talented, articulate, at times difficult Democrat who is good at saying what is wrong but has not stepped forward himself to fix it.
 Democrats, many disappointed that Mr. Bradley announced he was leaving Congress when the going for Democrats looked rough, are watching closely. Will his next move be aimed at a run in 2000? Or will he follow the path of another talented, articulate and difficult Democrat, Mr. Cuomo, who is the host of a radio show and misses public service? Or, will he shuck the party entirely and run as an independent?
 Mr. Bradley, a combination of substance and outright coyness, will not commit himself.
 "You know, that used to be a question that used to give me a lot of trouble," he said of whether he will run for President. "But it is no longer that much of a problem for me to deal with."
 He recounted how since 1992, when he decided not to run, his wife, Ernestine Schlant, developed breast cancer (now in remission), both his parents died, two colleagues were killed in plane crashes and a friend committed suicide.
 "For me, it was a time when I realized nothing is forever and that catastrophe overtakes the best-laid plans," Mr. Bradley said. "The only way to operate is to live life a year at a time, go out and serve as best you can.
 "I mean, would I want to do it? In the right circumstances, yes. But life is too fragile. And I also think that we need to try to find a different way of doing things, so that what comes forward is not so much process but the substance of dealing with the underlying issues that I think are out there."
 Mr. Bradley is clear about several things. One is that his immediate reason for leaving the Senate was not that he feared a repeat of the 1990 race, when he barely won re-election against a little-known Christine Todd Whitman. He said he could not tend to his constituents and devote full time to speaking out on the three issues that most matter to him: campaign finance reform, the changing economic life of the middle class and race.
 He is typically thoughtful on all three issues, perhaps on race particularly -- a problem he has faced since his days in an integrated high school and in his first career as a forward with the New York Knicks.
 "In the last year, what has the focus been on?" he asked. "It's been on three African-American males: O. J. Simpson, Louis Farrakhan and Colin Powell. One was ridiculed, one was demonized and one was idealized.
 "Well, that isn't the way that true racial harmony occurs. It occurs only when you put yourself on the line in a candid expression of your own views, about yourself, your values and what you perceive to be the other person's circumstances, problems, attitudes."
 The framework for his thinking these days is based on what he calls "public power," which steers a middle course between the Democrats' expansive view of government and the Republicans' narrower one. The idea is for government to make a difference without overburdening citizens or business with yet more government across the board.
 An example, one of several he sketches in his book, is to require companies to provide health insurance for one year to employees who are laid off.
 "How is that going to happen?" he asked. "It's going to happen with public power. That's all. It's not some giant bureaucracy delivering a program. It's simply saying: Look, these are the rules of the game."
 Still, summoning the voice of his more practical wife: What will he do? And will anyone listen to Bill Bradley, private citizen?
 "That's a good question," he said. "I mean, I like to think that, if you are saying something that is clear, that is on a subject that most of the American people care about or wonder about and you are saying something fresh, that you are going to be able to get an audience."
 "There is no slot" for his current ambition, he acknowledged. But still, he hints. When asked about his concept of leadership, he talks about the need for both a big idea pushed by a national figure as well as strength from the grass roots. He sounds as if a high-minded United We Stand would be perfect, with himself as a cerebral and stretched-out Ross Perot.
 He waved off several suggestions as unknowable: president of a college, head of a foundation, founder of a new political party or movement. Would he rule anything out?
 "I'm sure there are certain things that if you mentioned I would rule out," he said. "But I can't go out and say everything I've excluded from my mind."
 Would he rule out, oh, say, wing walking?
 "Yeah," he said. "I'm too heavy." He did have another idea, however: "Designated foul shooter?"

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Lose Early Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
A report showing an unexpected decline in producer prices sent Treasury prices surging yesterday, but profit taking in the afternoon erased the gains.
 Bond prices have been under pressure since Friday, when the May employment report showed surprising strength, suggesting that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates next month. In two sessions, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- which moves in the opposite direction from the bond's price -- rose to 7.12 percent -- its highest level in more than a year. 

 But the Labor Department's report on producer prices indicated that inflation was remaining stable, despite other signs of robust growth, thus leaving the Federal Reserve room to leave interest rates unchanged next month.
 The Labor Department said the Producer Price Index fell one-tenth of 1 percent in May. Many economists had been expecting an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent. The so-called core rate of the index, which excludes the volatile categories of food and energy, was unchanged last month.
 "The P.P.I. statistics for May are another indication of there being no inflation in the pipeline," said Elliott Platt, director of research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities.
 Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a market research and analysis firm, said, "Despite the acceleration in the pace of economic growth and the recent increases in grain and energy prices, the overall rate of inflation remains subdued." Still, ahead of today's report on consumer prices, Mr. Platt said, the "market improvement is probably more a relief rather than a bona fide rally."
 
 The morning rally soon ran out of steam as market participants used the uptick in bond prices as an opportunity to sell.
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond ended up 2/32, to 86 7/32, leaving its yield unchanged at 7.12 percent. Shorter-term maturies ended slightly higher, with the yield on the two-year note dropping to 6.36 percent, from 6.39 percent on Monday.
 The enthusiasm of the market was also muted yesterday because it needed to see confirmation of moderate inflation in today's report on consumer prices.
 Mr. Platt of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities said that despite the decline in producer prices he was still expecting a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
President Clinton's proposal to increase the international departure tax raises some hackles.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:
AIRLINES and the travel industry have usually supported taxes earmarked for improvements in aviation or infrastructure. But President Clinton's recent proposal to raise the tax on international departures from $6 a passenger to $16, with the money used to help offset the cost of attending college, has gone over with the business travel community like the proverbial lead balloon.
 The Air Transport Association termed the proposed increase "an absolute outrage to air travelers who already pay a long list of taxes and fees totaling more than $6 billion annually." Carol Hallett, the association president, said the proposal would cost an additional $500 million a year, "and not a dime will be used to fund runways, radar systems, or anything else that benefits aviation safety or overall system capacity." She added that the tax would lead to a new round of bankruptcies and layoffs by aircraft makers. 

 The Travel Industry Association of America said travelers "should not have to shoulder a disproportionate part" of the President's initiative.
 And the National Business Travel Association, which represents more than 1,650 corporations, vowed to fight the measure in Congress. In a letter to President Clinton, the association's executive director, Norman R. Sherlock, wrote: "Raising the departure tax would substantially increase the financial burden on business travelers and would impact the operative balances of many corporations who operate in the global arena. This type of measure is counterproductive since the overriding policy of the United States should be to promote business enterprise and travel because of the enormous benefits this generates for the economy."
 In a separate statement, Judie Shyman, the executive director of the National Business Travel Association, declared, "Washington must learn that business travel is a national asset, not a gold mine of last resort."
 
Sheraton Expands in China
 
 The ITT Corporation said yesterday that its Sheraton subsidiary had signed agreements to manage seven new hotels in China, all of which will be operational "in the near term." The seven include the Beijing International Club, in which Sheraton has acquired a 31 percent interest, valued at $54 million. Together with the five hotels it already manages in China, Sheraton will have more than 5,000 rooms in the country.
 
Hotel of the Future
 
 While hotel occupancy and room rates are steadily rising, a recent survey by Arthur Andersen and New York University's Center for Hospitality, Tourism and Travel Administration found that the hotel of the future would increase profits more from new services and products sold to guests rather than from traditional room sales. According to Roger Cline, worldwide director of hospitality consulting services for Arthur Andersen, these services and products could range from computer links to gain access to stock prices and brokers to shopping in the hotel's electronic store or ordering books from the hotel's affiliate bookstore.
 
Turning Back the Clock
 
 While the Waterfront Center Hotel in Vancouver, British Columbia, is as modern as they come, the five-year-old hotel -- recently rated one of the world's top 10 business hotels by a leading Canadian business magazine -- has resorted to a centuries-old tradition: it employs a page. That's right, the same kind of hotel messenger who served in medieval inns, and who last served in a Canadian Pacific hotel in 1981. (Waterfront Center is one of 26 Canadian Pacific hotels, as is Quebec's Chateau Frontenac.)
 The best known page in this country was Albert (Johnny) Altieri, who worked at the Stratfield Hotel in Bridgeport, Conn., and was hired by Philip Morris in 1935. For the next 25 years his trademark "Call for Philip Morris" was one of the best-known commercials on radio and television.
 Waterfront Center's page, Claude Dery, is on duty Monday through Friday from 10 A.M. to 6:30 P.M., decked out in a pill box hat, white gloves and silver tray. His duties include paging guests in the lobby, assisting at the elevator and delivering faxes and messages. He has proved so popular in his two weeks on the job that a spokeswoman said yesterday that the 489-room hotel was thinking of hiring another page for weekends.
 
Coffee, Tea or Cuffs?
 
 Whatever happened to the friendly skies? The current Frequent Flyer magazine has an article titled "At the Zoo," about the increasing number of bizarre and sometimes violent incidents aboard airplanes. As if to underscore that trend, Travel Management Newsletter reported this week that some British charter airlines "plan to have handcuffs on board this summer to restrain disruptive passengers."

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Retreat, with Dow off by 19.21

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stocks ended lower yesterday as enthusiasm about an encouraging inflation report proved fleeting and a morning rally in the bond market faded.
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.21 points, to 5,668.66, retreating from an early advance of nearly 41 points. A series of computer-guided "sell" orders exacerbated the decline, subtracting 33 points from the Dow industrials, according to Birinyi Associates Inc., a research firm that tracks computer-guided trading. 

 Many broader measures also turned negative as bonds shed early gains that were prompted by an unexpected decline in producer prices in May. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.19 points, to 670.97,
 But the Nasdaq composite index edged up 0.72 point, to 1,230.76, as several industry bellwethers posted gains. Intel gained 1 1/8, to 75 1/4, and Microsoft rose 1 1/2, to 122 1/8.
 Stocks initially followed bonds higher after the Labor Department reported that producer prices -- the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers -- fell one-tenth of 1 percent in May.
 The report muted concerns generated by Friday's report on May employment that robust growth would cause inflation to accelerate and prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
 Higher rates would increase increase borrowing costs for companies and draw investors away from stocks.
 But by midafternoon, bonds began to slide on profit taking, sending the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for corporate and consumer interest rates -- back up to Monday's level of 7.12 percent, the highest the yield has been in more than a year.
 Analysts said that a further rise in rates would hamper stocks.
 "The bond market is very close to its May reaction low," said Ralph Bloch, chief market analyst at Raymond James & Associates of St. Petersburg, Fla. "If that low is taken out, I think the bond market will fall sharply.
 "Stocks can't take much more competition from the bond market." He added that if the yield ran to 7 1/4 percent, stocks were going to get hurt.
 Declining issues outnumbered advancers by a slim margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 405.4 million shares, up sharply from Monday's anemic pace before the report on producer prices.
 Among the Dow industrials' biggest decliners, Boeing fell 1 1/2, to 84 7/8; General Electric fell 1 3/8, to 84 5/8, and Sears fell 1 1/4, to 51 3/4.
 Gold stocks fell as the price of gold declined on commodity markets. Gold is traditionally a hedge against inflation, and the producer prices report helped ease inflation concerns. Gold for August delivery fell $1.60, to $386.90 an ounce -- its lowest closing price since Nov. 22, 1995.
 Newmont Gold fell 1 1/8, to 52 3/4, and Battle Mountain Gold slipped 1/8, to 8 1/8.
 Shares of Kellogg fell 1 7/8, to 70 1/8, a day after the company said it would cut prices on some of its top cereal brands
 Storage Technology rose for a second day after I.B.M. announced a deal to sell Storage Technology's computer-disk storage systems under the I.B.M. brand name. And yesterday Lehman Brothers raised its rating on the stock, which rose 3 3/8, to 42 7/8.
 Several new stocks posted strong gains on their Wall Street debut.
 McLeod Inc., which provides local and long-distance telecommunications services to small and medium-sized businesses, soared 5 1/8, to 25 1/8.
 Verilink surged 7, to 23. The company makes integrated access products for telecommunications. And Infoseek, an Internet search services company, rose 2, to 14.
 Shares of Tower Semiconductor tumbled 3 1/8, to 10 7/8. The Israeli chip maker and Hewlett-Packard terminated their relationship. Shares of Data Systems and Software, which owns about 25 percent of Tower, fell 1 1/4, to 6 3/4. It derives a significant portion of its profits from Tower.
 AMR, the parent of American Airlines, fell 5/8, to 93 3/8, while American depository receipts -- with each A.D.R. representing 10 ordinary shares -- rose 2 1/8, to 86 3/4.

HEADLINE: Why Commercial Off Broadway Is All but Wiped Out, for Now

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS

 BODY:
Daryl Roth, a veteran theater producer, had just about given up hope. For months, her efforts to find an Off Broadway house in which to bring back "Old Wicked Songs," a critically acclaimed play that had a successful limited run last fall, had come to naught: the commercial playhouses of Off Broadway were booked solid with new productions and established hits.
 Then, about six weeks ago, the logjam broke suddenly. Play after Off Broadway play closed. Several new productions flopped and several established hits fizzled. Theater owners who had been offering Ms. Roth places on their waiting lists suddenly wanted to offer her something else: their places. 

 "It was amazing," said Ms. Roth, whose production of "Old Wicked Songs" is to begin performances on Aug. 16 in the Promenade Theater on the Upper West Side, one of the premier Off Broadway spaces. "I was lucky I heard from the Promenade, because I love the theater," she said. "But it seemed like as soon as I got that call, other theaters started opening up, too."
 The reversal of fortune that benefited Ms. Roth spelled trouble for other Off Broadway producers. This spring, virtually the entire lineup of shows in commercial Off Broadway theaters faded, folded, or decided to hit the road in search of new audiences.
 In quick succession, eight of the most expensive and highest-profile Off Broadway shows closed or announced they would this month: "Zombie Prom," "After-Play," "Below the Belt," "Nixon's Nixon," "I Do! I Do!" "The Food Chain," "Picasso at the Lapin Agile" and "Mrs. Klein." Among recent openings at major commercial houses, only three remain: the well-received "Cowgirls," a musical; "Curtains," a dark comedy, and "Papa," a one-man show about Ernest Hemingway.
 "It was a big wipeout," said Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, one of the producers of "Nixon's Nixon," a play that closed at the Westside Theater on West 43d Street last month after a surprisingly brief and anemic run. "Despite excellent notices, 'Nixon's Nixon' never was able to attract an audience, for reasons which I cannot understand."
 The question echoes through suddenly vacant playhouses all over town: What killed the artistically rich Off Broadway season? Was it competition from an unexpectedly robust Broadway? Was it the rising cost of an Off Broadway ticket (top price: $45) or a shrinking audience for serious theater? Had the life of each production simply run its course, or were some shows yanked before their time by producers fearful of the summer doldrums?
 In the complex marketplace of New York theater, the answer, it seems, is all of the above. Some Off Broadway producers and theater executives say the season's collapse reflects the very nature of Off Broadway, where small houses and narrow profit margins make the life of a production especially precarious. Others, however, say that a combination of factors peculiar to this season conspired to do Off Broadway in. In particular, an extraordinary number of Broadway plays and musicals opened to strong reviews in March and April.
 "There is only so much theater dollar, and there was so much competition," said Robert Straus, one of the producers of "The Food Chain," Nicky Silver's comedy of manners and appetites, which closed Sunday after a 10-month run. "I did better in the depths of winter than I did in the springtime, when I thought I would break out and do wonderfully."
 Mr. Straus said he thought "The Food Chain" could have survived a couple of strong plays on Broadway, but at best became the fourth or fifth choice for playgoers who were opting at the season's end for Broadway plays like "A Delicate Balance," "Master Class," "Buried Child," "An Ideal Husband" and "Seven Guitars." Complicating the struggle to survive, all of the Broadway plays were competing with "The Food Chain" at the Theater Development Fund's half-price TKTS booth in Duffy Square.
 "The economics of the business are that you do live off the booth," Mr. Straus said. "And when every show except one or two are at the booth, where in the pecking order does the smaller play fit in?"
 Not everyone is convinced that Broadway's gains were Off Broadway's losses. "How about the play just ran out of gas and closed?" Ben Sprecher, an owner and manager of several commercial Off Broadway houses, including the Promenade, said, referring to several of the plays that were shut. Still, Mr. Sprecher was upset about two of the longer-running plays that are abruptly closing in two of his theaters, "Mrs. Klein" and "Picasso." He said in those cases, producers were leaving before they had to.
 "I really don't understand," Mr. Sprecher said. "Their grosses were terrific. I think they were closed prematurely."
 The producers of both shows -- two of the few to earn back their investments this season -- said they had decided to close to pursue opportunities elsewhere. (In an unusual confluence of events, both plays are reopening in San Francisco this summer with their New York casts.) But declining popularity also played a part. Joan Stein, a producer of "Picasso," said market research indicated the play had faced an increasingly uphill battle to fill seats in the coming months.
 Off Broadway, Manhattan theaters with 100 to 499 seats, encompasses two theater worlds: nonprofit companies like the Manhattan Theater Club, the New York Shakespeare Festival and the New York Theater Workshop and independent commercial houses, like the Minetta Lane in Greenwich Village, the Variety Arts on the Lower East Side and the Westside Theater in midtown. Together, they have become the creative engine that drives New York theater.
 In each of the last three years, for example, the Pulitzer Prize for drama has been given to a production that began Off Broadway. And while Off Broadway has long been regarded as the home of the serious play, this year, two of the biggest musical hits on Broadway, "Rent" and "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk," also originated Off Broadway.
 It is the commercial part of Off Broadway, which lacks the subscriber-based audiences of many of the nonprofit institutions, that suffered most at the end of the season, a predicament that may be a reflection of the limited popularity of playgoing rather than the quality of any individual production.
 "Some of those shows, like 'Picasso,' have already had healthy runs," said George Wachtel, president of Audience Research and Analysis. He said they might have gone through the supply of traditional theatergoers and simply could not appeal to tourists, a group that has long proved resistant to Off Broadway.
 "I don't think any of these shows crossed over to the out-of-town audience, where the Broadway crossover would have had an impact," Mr. Wachtel said.
 In the end, however, the death of so many plays at once may just have been an inevitable fact of the cycle of life both Off Broadway and on. "There is a huge glut of plays looking for houses right now," said Mr. Sprecher, who owns the theater in which Ms. Roth's play will be presented. "I can name 10 plays that are financed and ready to go, and want a theater."
 Another fact: for producers like Ms. Roth, who is bringing in "Old Wicked Songs" at a cost of $425,000, hope springs eternal.

HEADLINE: State Approves Bronx Paper-Recycling Mill

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
A plan for a $485 million paper-recycling mill in the South Bronx -- which officials say would be the largest private-sector manufacturing plant built in the city since World War II -- has cleared two major hurdles, receiving approval from state officials for an environmental permit and for low-cost financing.
 While the developers must still complete detailed engineering studies and round up the rest of the financing, they say the state's decision removes some of the biggest obstacles to the project. The state approvals are expected to be announced today. 

 The mill would produce newsprint from waste paper collected by the city's Department of Sanitation and private sources. It would provide 600 permanent jobs and 2,200 temporary construction jobs in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx, one of the poorest neighborhoods in the city. Related community projects are expected to add another 350 jobs.
 Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that the state had agreed to use its power to sell tax-free bonds to secure $75 million in low-cost financing for the project, and he pledged to help push it to completion. The 33-acre plant would be built on the site of the old Harlem River rail yard, which has been abandoned for more than 25 years.
 "If we are successful, this project would create more than 2,800 jobs, encourage recycling and reduce the waste stream," Mr. Pataki said in a statement. "As we move to close the Fresh Kills landfill by the end of 2001, this plant could represent an important piece of the New York City waste disposal solution."
 The plant is being developed by the Natural Resources Defense Council, a major environmental group, and the Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association, a civic group in the Bronx. The two nonprofit groups will then turn it over to a for-profit corporation, NYC Paper Mill, which is obtaining additional financing for the plan from private investors.
 The site is within a state economic development zone and the newly created Federal Empowerment Zone, which will qualify the development for Federal and state benefits intended to encourage projects in poor areas.
 The newsprint mill is the successor to a plan to produce de-inked paper pulp on the site, which was abandoned last year when two international paper companies withdrew after a delay caused by a lawsuit. The newsprint would be used by newspapers in the region, and several newspaper publishers, including Advance Publications, the Gannett Company, News Corporation and The New York Times Company, have said they would each be willing to buy part of the plant's output.
 Most newsprint mills have been built in rural areas, where trees are abundant and costs are low. But the developers of the Bronx mill are seeking to take advantage of the vast amounts of paper discarded in the city every day. Because the mill would be situated within a few miles of its raw material, savings of about $60 a ton on transportation costs are expected to help offset the higher costs for labor and utilities.
 The project would also break new environmental ground by using partly treated sewage water from the city's water treatment plant on Ward's Island. Paper processing consumes large amounts of water, about three million gallons a day in this case, but by using waste water the plant would reduce its water costs and not be a burden for the city's supply of fresh water.
 Allen Hershkowitz, a senior scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, said that the group was sponsoring the project because of its environmental benefits and to reduce some of the bureaucratic and social obstacles that discourage private investors from building factories in older urban locations.
 "Our role here was to insure the environmental integrity of the project while reducing the costly and complicated entry risks that have to date prevented the private sector from building a manufacturing plant in New York we could support," he said.
 Mr. Hershkowitz said he expected environmental groups increasingly to attempt to foster environmentally beneficial development projects rather than concentrate on stopping harmful ones, as they have done. But he said the resources council would have no role in operating the plant and would receive no fees for its development role.
 NYC Paper Mill has raised $20 million in equity capital from paper industry investors. The company's president, Niilo Hakkarainen, said the group hoped "to complete equity raising and other financing before the fall of this year, and begin construction immediately thereafter."
 The plant would provide a local market for paper collected by the city and private trash haulers. An agreement calls for the mill to pay the city for delivering the waste paper; currently the city must pay to have recyclable paper processed and shipped to mills outside the region.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Newbury Street in Boston is changing from boutiques to chains, including a Niketown.

BYLINE: By Susan Diesenhouse

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
OF the delight of some and the dismay of others, the largest retail project in 70 years is now under construction on Newbury Street in the historic Back Bay neighborhood of Boston.
 For years the street has been known for its high-priced, one-of-a-kind retail shops. They occupy the first or second floors of the Victorian-era red-brick row houses that dominate the eight blocks of Newbury Street, from the Public Gardens to Massachusetts Avenue. 

 Now, on the site of a former parking lot, a $14.5 million, four-story, 42,000-square-foot masonry and glass building with parking for 69 cars is being developed by the 200 Newbury Street Corporation, an affiliate of the Boston-based Sawyer Enterprises.
 Sawyer, an owner of four parking lots downtown, will occupy the top floor of the new building, which is on the corner of Exeter Street. The remaining three stories, with 30,000 square feet of space, will be occupied by a Niketown store.
 Nike Inc. has opened four Niketown stores since 1991: in Portland, Ore.; Chicago; Costa Mesa, Calif., and Atlanta. This year, it will open stores in Seattle, Los Angeles and Manhattan. The Manhattan store, with 85,000 square feet of space, will be the largest. In Boston, Nike has taken a long-term lease on undisclosed terms from the developer. Construction of the store, at 200 Newbury Street, began last November, and the opening is expected in the spring. The architect is Childs Bertman Tseckares Inc. of Boston.
 The building is one of the few new retail buildings to be developed in the city since the collapse of the commercial real estate market in 1990. It also represents a change in Newbury Street's traditional character.
 "Newbury street is hot and the whole flavor is changing from small, local boutiques to large chains that can offer landlords more money," said Deanna M. Caron, vice president of the Hunneman Real Estate Corporation. "These companies have long wanted to be here, but the neighborhood association blocked them."
 Soon, another national chain, which she declined to name, will lease an existing four-story building there, she said.
 Chain retailers have moved onto Newbury Street since the late 1980's but have not had the commanding presence that the Niketown store will have. As a relatively large building that will primarily be occupied by one store, it represents a departure and has attracted criticism.
 Susan Park, president of the Boston Preservation Alliance, said that while the architect tried to make the building sympathetic with its context, it was too big, with too much glass and illumination.
 "Most of the retail stores on Newbury Street are small one-of-a-kind stores that occupy 1,000 square feet," Ms. Park said. "This is too big. It's like putting the QE2 on the corner."
 Also voicing concern was Susan D. Prindle of the Neighborhood Association of the Back Bay. "We're concerned that in the long term, the large national retailers who can pay more rent will drive out the smaller merchants," she said, "and Newbury will become a street of restaurants, bars and chain stores."
 The architect, Richard J. Bertman, said the building was somewhat smaller than the zoning allowed, and, in terms of lighting, would respect whatever guidelines the neighborhood established.
 Newbury Street and the entire Back Bay neighborhood were developed for residences in the late 19th century as the tidal flats that surrounded the original city were filled in, said William S. Young, a preservation planner for the city.
 Of the district's four east-west streets -- Beacon Street with its views of the Charles River, Marlborough Street and Commonwealth Avenue, a wide boulevard -- Newbury was the least fashionable, with residential hotels and apartments.
 During World War I, retail uses began to appear on Newbury Street. By 1927 with the completion of the Ritz Hotel on Newbury and Arlington Streets facing the Public Garden, a rash of retail shops opened in converted residential space to cater to the hotel's guests, Mr. Young said.
 During the real estate boom of the 1980's, rents rose, national and international retailers arrived, and the street acquired a cachet as a tourist attraction. In the 1990 recession, rents fell by 25 to 50 percent, depending on the location, to a range of $20 to $50 a square foot.
 Now the street has about 600,000 square feet of retail space. Over the last year, the amount of space available has fallen to 2.6 percent from 4 percent while the average asking rent has risen to $59.64, Ms. Caron of Hunneman said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Lexmark makes money but does not excite investors.

BYLINE: By Laurence Zuckerman

 BODY:
WITH a robust market for new technology stocks, it is easy to forget that there have been some initial public offerings that have stalled -- even offerings from technology companies with actual profits. That is the case with Lexmark International Group, a maker of laser and inkjet printers for computers.
 Since going public at $20 a share in November, Lexmark shares have traded as low as $15.50 and as high as $23.25. Yesterday, the shares fell 12.5 cents, to $21.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. 

 That is a pretty feeble performance compared with Internet stars like Netscape Communications or Yahoo, which both soared after going public despite meager earnings.
 While Lexmark may lack those companies' Internet cachet, it did have more than $2 billion in revenue last year and earned $32.4 million. It is also selling its products into a hot market: corporations are hooking laser printers to their networks and consumers are snapping up low-priced color inkjet printers to create their own greeting cards and drawings or to print out pages from the Internet's colorful World Wide Web.
 Once the printing division of I.B.M., Lexmark was spun off in a leveraged buyout financed by the firm Clayton Dubilier & Rice in 1991. Since then it has managed to cut its debt to $176 million from $940 million and is growing at a healthy pace.
 For the most recent quarter ending in March, the company, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., saw its earnings jump 88 percent, to $21.6 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with $11.4 million, or 15 cents a share, for the corresponding period a year earlier.
 "I call Lexmark the Rodney Dangerfield of printer companies," said Steve Milunovich, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, which co-managed the company's November offering. "It doesn't get the respect it deserves."
 One reason, it seems, is that Lexmark lives in the shadow of the Hewlett-Packard Company, which holds about a 70 percent share of the market for laser printers and more than 50 percent of the market for inkjet printers.
 "H.P. is a tough competitor," said Charles LeCompte, editor and publisher of The Hard Copy Observer, a newsletter in Newton, Mass. "It has raised the standard for the industry. Lexmark has to play its hand perfectly every time."
 And the competition is about to get tougher. In March, a five-year agreement between Lexmark and I.B.M. not to compete against each other expired. Later this month, I.B.M. is expected to announce that it will introduce network laser printers that will compete directly with Lexmark's products.
 So far, though, Lexmark has more than held its own against Hewlett Packard and Canon, the other big maker of laser and inkjet printers. Lexmark estimated that its share of the network laser-printer market grew 40 percent last year and that it now had 6.5 percent of the inkjet-printer market after entering the business just 15 months ago.
 "Our strategy is to gain share and we are optimistic about our ability to do that," Marvin Mann, Lexmark's chairman and chief executive, said.
 Volume is important because, in one respect, the inkjet-printer business is just like the razor business: replacement cartridges are more lucrative than the printers themselves. Those sales, which average two to three cartridges for each printer, also provide a stable stream of earnings.
 A report by a Goldman, Sachs analyst, Richard C. Schutte, estimated that printer supplies accounted for 17 percent of sales last year for Lexmark but 29 percent of gross profit; that should rise, he said, to 40 percent of revenue and 57 percent of gross profit by 1999.
 On the strength of that business, Mr. Schutte said Lexmark's stock should hit $28, or 15 times 1997 estimated earnings, by the end of the year.
 But the company may hit some bumps before then. Lexmark's recent departure from the low-margin business of manufacturing keyboards for I.B.M. and a new, less profitable, licensing agreement with Big Blue will hurt revenues in the next few quarters, Mr. Mann said. He also warned that intense price competition among inkjet-printer makers could also compound the problem.
 As a result, technology investors -- who have for the most part avoided Lexmark to date -- have little reason to buy the stock. As Dick Goers, chief technology strategist at Zurich Kemper Investments in Chicago, put it: "I heard about the economics of the replacement cartridges and felt great about owning H.P."

HEADLINE: Not All the Comfort Is Being Left Behind

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
When Bob Dole announced on May 15 that he was resigning from the Senate, he said he would be leaving behind "all the trappings of power, all comfort, all security," and was off to seek the Presidency "with nothing to fall back on but the judgment of the people."
 But Mr. Dole will not be in financial free fall. 

 Quite apart from his other assets -- he reported a total asset value ranging from $758,000 to $1.97 million on his 1994 financial disclosure form -- his retirement from the Senate today makes him eligible for as much as $107,000 in annual pension payments starting in August, as estimated by David Keating of the National Taxpayers Union, a fiscal watchdog group.
 Unlike most private-sector pensions, Federal pensions are adjusted for inflation. Assuming annual inflation of 4 percent, Mr. Dole's yearly benefits would rise to about $178,000 by the time he reached the age of 86, which is the life expectancy of a man now 72, as he is.
 Not all of that benefit will come from the taxpayers. During his 35 years in Congress, Mr. Dole has contributed as much as 8 percent of his own salary toward his pension.
 In any event, he has said that he is considering giving all his pension benefits to charity. "I'm trying to get another job," he told USA Today last week. "I haven't decided whether I'm going to take it or not. I might give it away."
 Nor has Mr. Dole been receiving Social Security benefits, even though he could have been collecting about $17,000 a year. An aide said the Senator had simply never applied for Social Security benefits, because he was still working.
 As Senate majority leader, Mr. Dole has been receiving an annual salary of $148,400. He also receives a veteran's disability payment of $17,700 a year, and that will not change with his retirement. But if he is elected to the Presidency, which pays an annual salary of $200,000, he must defer his Senate pension until he leaves office.
 Mr. Dole's 59-year-old wife, Elizabeth -- who was a Cabinet officer in the Reagan and Bush Administrations, spent 28 years in government and in 1994 reported an asset range of $2.38 million to $6.16 million, less liabilities of $300,00 to $600,000 in loans -- will be eligible in three years for a Federal pension whose benefits to her could total $1,947,000 by the time she reaches 86, her own life expectancy.
 Given the couple's two pensions, plus her survivor benefits in the event of Mr. Dole's death (assuming he has opted for a spousal survivor benefit), they could collect more than $6 million, Mr. Keating said, by the time she turns 86.
 Mrs. Dole is on leave from the presidency of the American Red Cross and has said that if her husband is elected President, she will return to that post, whose yearly salary is $200,000.

HEADLINE: Pension Agency Recommends An Increase in Benefit Limit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
The Government agency insuring workers' pensions urged Congress today to increase benefit limits on its multi-employer plan to make up for 16 years of inflation.
 Multi-employer plans are collectively bargained pension programs to which more than one employer is required to contribute, such as in the construction, trucking and retail-food industries. 

 When a multi-employer plan becomes insolvent, the agency, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, provides financial assistance to pay benefits at the guaranteed level from premium revenues received from insurance plans.
 In a report to Congress, the agency said that the plan, which insures 8.7 million people in 1,963 programs, was financially sound.
 But, it added, the benefit guarantee has not been changed since 1980. Since then, wage inflation has cut the real value of the guarantee by more than half. As a result, fewer than 1 percent of all workers and retirees would get their promised benefits if their plans ran out of money. The agency recommended changes that would extend full coverage to 75 percent of participants.
 If enacted, the proposal would more than double the maximum guarantee for a retiree with 30 years of service, to $12,870 a month from $5,850. The increase would not require any change in the annual premium of $2.60 a participant.
 The new guarantee would equal the participant's years of service multiplied by 100 percent of the first $11 of monthly benefit plus 75 percent of the next $33. The limit now is 100 percent of the first $5 of monthly benefit and 75 percent of the next $15.
 President Clinton first proposed the rise when he outlined his Retirement Savings and Security Act in April. Legislation is pending in both houses of Congress.
 The agency said that the multi-employer plan, which had a $8.5 million deficit in 1980, has had a surplus for the last 14 years. The current surplus is $192 million.

HEADLINE: Singapore Journal;
Youth's Flogging Exposes 'the Importance of Skin'

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE

 BODY:
"No culture shock! Zilch!" the American cries happily. "I felt right at home the minute I came here."
It is all downhill from there in Singapore's most popular recent play, a rollicking and dead serious exploration of the East-West divide that ends with the characters spitting racial insults at one another. 
 "You yellow bastard!" the American snarls, after a Singaporean co-worker taunts him for his unconscious assumption of superiority.
The catalyst in the play -- as it was two years ago in a real-world episode of international culture shock -- is the flogging of Michael Fay, an American teen-ager who confessed to spray-painting graffiti on cars.
The flogging shredded cultural skin, the play suggests, as painfully for Singaporeans as for the teen-ager.
The leitmotif of the play is a series of quotations from 19th- and early 20th-century Western travelers who set the tone of cultural superiority, dismissing the natives as "half-barbarous people" and "a pack of lunatics."
There is no flogging scene, and the name of Mr. Fay is never pronounced in the one-act play, "Six of the Best," by Tan Tarn How, who is the Beijing bureau chief for The Straits Times.
And the play, which recently ended its run, does not try to explore the merits of corporal punishment, though it presents the contrasting views of its characters.
But the details of the incident remain as vivid to people here as they are to the characters -- an American, a Briton and four Singaporeans working together in a local advertising agency.
In May 1994, despite a plea for clemency by President Clinton, Mr. Fay, then 18, received four lashes with a rattan cane (reduced from a sentence of six lashes) after signing and then recanting an admission to a 10-day spree of spray painting and egg-throwing.
Some people here remember him as "that nasty little vandal," some as "the poor American boy." But whether he is recalled with contempt or sympathy, the furor still troubles Singaporeans -- a moment when many in the West turned a cold eye toward them and branded them bullies.
Singapore is indeed the most Westernized of Asian nations, where most people speak English and where the pristine cityscape looks like the schematic drawing of a southern California property developer.
It is easy for an American, like the character in the play, to feel right at home. But as the play suggests, many of these similarities are only skin deep, and many of the snubs from colonial days still sting.
"It is strange to see them at their grub, with their little basins close to their mouths in one hand and their chopsticks, which they so daintily and cleverly use, in the other," a traveler named Hugh Wilkinson wrote in 1883, in an account quoted in the play. "They are all cast in the same mold, and are consequently exactly alike."
Or: "What thinks she, I wonder -- if she thinks at all -- of the pale European."
Such colonial-era disdain is the backdrop for today's attitudes, said the play's director, Ong Keng Sen, as Singapore asserts itself as a model of economic development and social order. And it is the backdrop, he asserted, for America's dudgeon over the caning of Mr. Fay and for Singapore's stubborn response.
"Western media interpretation of the events and American 'intervention' raised the old hackles," Mr. Ong said. " 'Don't tell us what to do. We are a sovereign nation. Leave us to our ways. Let us govern ourselves.' "
But along with the legacy of hurt, the colonial era has also left an evident desire to be embraced by the West.
Despite lectures by Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew on the superiority of "Asian values," Singaporeans still yearn to meet Western standards as well. Just as the angriest of the Singaporean characters in the play nevertheless seeks career advancement by working for an American-run company, it is sometimes said here that an American or British university degree has the cachet of a designer fashion label.
"At first we thought, wow, six strokes, that much," said a Singaporean journalist who was in the audience the other night. "We were feeling sorry for the poor American boy. But then we were branded uncivilized brutes who will torture this child."
Like the American character in the play who thought he was just like everybody else here, the journalist said, Singaporeans themselves had begun to forget about their differences from the West.
"It didn't help when William Safire started saying all those things and urging an economic boycott," said the journalist, who asked that his name not be printed. "Ouch, that hurts. It was one ridiculous thing after another. Maybe we execute people by having an elephant walk on their head. We thought we got along with the rich world, and all of a sudden these huge chasms were showing up."
In the play, the cultural rifts emerge as the characters discuss the flogging of "that boy." The rising tension is broken periodically by surreal tableaux that include the apparition of a uniformed flogger who parades an outsized cane.
"Let me discourse on the importance of skin," the flogger says in the play's coda. "The skin is a covering, but my job is to remove it, opening up the skin to discover the human in us, to reach for the primal scream, the primal hurt. The skin is mere covering, but the skin is all-important. To find what's underneath, what's inside, to see if it's mere shell, or flesh, or feeling, or life -- that's my job."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cast members of the Singapore production of "Six of the Best" act out one of the play's more emotional confrontations. The play was inspired by the caning of an American teen-ager, Michael Fay, in 1994. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Medical savings accounts: a solution without a problem?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IF legislation giving workers the right to keep their health insurance when they change jobs breathes its last, the cause of death will almost certainly be a political stalemate over medical savings accounts. But is this idea, so loved by House Republicans and so detested by the White House, really worth the fuss?
Not according to researchers at the Rand Corporation led by Emmett Keeler, whose report in the Journal of the American Medical Association last week suggested that the tax-sheltered accounts created by the House bill would have little effect on either total outlays for health care by people under age 65 or on accessibility of insurance for the very sick. And not according to Joe Newhouse at the Kennedy School of Government, who argues that the politicians are fighting over ways to improve a health care delivery system -- fee for service -- that is rapidly fading. "This debate is largely symbolic," he concludes. 
 When bread is very cheap, Mikhail S. Gorbachev discovered, farmers feed it to their livestock. Similarly, a landmark experiment completed by Rand in the early 1980's showed that Americans were inclined to waste medical care when the price to the patient was far less than the actual cost in economic resources. Those with first-dollar insurance coverage used 25 to 30 percent more health care than their counterparts facing hefty co-payments. Even so, the penny pinchers apparently spent enough. Co-payments had "little or no adverse effect on health for the average person," Mr. Newhouse, the senior author of the study, writes.
To some, the practical lesson here is that the health establishment can be squeezed without making patients squeal. Hence the push for managed care and state regulations limiting the numbers of hospital beds and MRI scanners. But true believers in free markets came away with a very different conclusion: Americans buy too much coverage because employer-paid insurance premiums are sheltered from taxation.
What to do about it? Discouraging belt-and-suspenders coverage by eliminating tax breaks for health insurance seems a political nonstarter. That largely explains why some conservative economists, notably John Goodman, the head of the National Center for Policy Analysis in Dallas, opted for the carrot rather than the stick.
Under the House Republican bill passed in April, those who bought only catastrophic coverage -- a minimum $3,000 deductible a family at the time of passage -- would also be permitted to deduct deposits to medical savings accounts. Withdrawals from the accounts to pay medical bills would not be taxed. Savings accumulated in the accounts and withdrawn after age 59 1/2 would be taxed as ordinary income.
Supporters look to the old Rand experiment and envisage cost savings in the hundreds of billions of dollars. But the just-released Rand study, a simulation intended to project consumer behavior if medical savings accounts are made available, concludes that the incentives of a $3,000 deductible would reduce total health care spending by, at most, 2 percent. Expenditures may even rise, the researchers found, if enough very sick people switched to catastrophic insurance that required no cost sharing on outlays above $3,000.
Limiting insurance coverage to expenses over $5,000 would, by contrast, suck a lot of healthy people out of traditional insurance and inhibit use of health care by 7 to 13 percent. Indeed, the number may even be larger if the migration of healthy people from community-rated insurance plans make it impossible for those who remain to foot the bill for high-quality coverage. But Uwe Reinhardt of Princeton University is certain that employers would not voluntarily opt for such bare-bones catastrophic policies. "Corporate America prefers a more socialized system in which healthy employees subsidize the care of the sick ones," he argues.
Perhaps the most striking aspect of the political debate is its near irrelevance. Republicans are still focused on the flawed market incentives for health care and looking for clever fixes. But health care is rapidly moving away from a world in which people have much choice about the amount of service they get and toward one in which doctors must please insurers as well as patients, state regulators keep a lock on investments in hospitals and costly equipment and access to expensive procedures is guarded by insurance company "gatekeepers."
The battle over medical savings accounts seems like an exercise in ideology -- much like the battle over raising the minimum wage from a pittance to a near pittance. "Medical savings accounts are like earrings for men," muses Mark Pauly at the Wharton School. "I wouldn't have one for myself, but I don't think they should be discouraged by public policy."

HEADLINE: Bangladeshis Vote in Big Numbers on a Calm, Even Festive, Day

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: DHAKA, Bangladesh, June 12

 BODY:
Voters turned out in record numbers today for a general election that many people here hope will put an end to political turmoil that has stunted economic growth and even raised fears of a new military takeover.
Voter turnout in many of the 300 parliamentary districts was reported as high as 70 percent, considerably higher than in the last national election in 1991. 
 As important for hopes that the election results will eventually be accepted by the country's feuding political parties, the voting appeared to have been conducted impartially in most areas and to have been largely free of the violence that has been a hallmark of politics in Bangladesh.
"It's been the dream of our people, casting a free ballot," the chief election commissioner, Muhammed Abu Hena, said as accounts came in from across the country of long lines and a festive atmosphere at many of the 26,000 polling stations.
Independent monitoring organizations, including some from Europe and the United States, offered preliminary endorsements of the election, saying the voting arrangements seemed to have assured a mostly fair poll. The Bangladesh Army, which ruled for 15 of the 25 years of the nation's existence, made no visible attempt to influence the outcome.
Partial returns late tonight pointed toward a neck-and-neck contest between the two principal contenders, the Awami League and the Bangladesh National Party, with a strong showing by a third group, the Jatiya Party, that could end up holding the balance of power.
With about half the vote counted in 220 districts that had reported returns to the election commission, the Awami League and the Bangladesh National Party were each leading in about 90 districts, with the Jatiya Party leading in 30 other districts. Other groups, including the Muslim fundamentalist Jamaat-i-Islami, were leading in 10 other seats.
A few violent incidents were reported today, one of them a shootout between rival political groups in the port city of Chittagong that left two men dead.
Final results are not expected until Thursday. But if the trend holds up, the country could be confronted with a situation that many here fear could lead to further instability, with neither of the main parties emerging as a clear winner and both inclined to claim that outright victory was snatched from them by election fraud.
Before the vote, the women who lead both parties, Hasina Wazed of the Awami League and Khaleda Zia of the Bangladesh National Party, laid the ground for challenges to the election outcome by asserting that election arrangements had been rigged. Both parties are committed to free-enterprise policies, but their leaders are personal rivals whose family histories have suffered from the political assassinations that have afflicted Bangladesh.
Further complicating the situation was the fact that the leader of the Jatiya Party, the possible kingmaker if the election produces a hung Parliament, is the imprisoned former military leader, Gen. Hussein Muhammed Ershad, who has indicated that the price he would exact for supporting a new government would be his release from jail.
One voter here, Zennur Hussein, a 39-year-old coal trader, said: "At least today, we are the ones who count. But what matters is what happens tomorrow -- whether the political parties will accept the result, or start the fighting again. Once it starts, it will be hard to stop."

HEADLINE: President Of Colombia Is Absolved In Drug Case

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, June 12

 BODY:
Nearly a year after President Ernesto Samper became the target of an unprecedented inquiry into allegations that his election was financed by Cali drug lords, the Congress here voted late tonight to drop all charges against him.
The 111-to-43 vote, which had been expected, officially ends the legal tribulations of the 45-year-old President, but leaves him vulnerable to continued political opposition across the spectrum of business, religious and civic groups that have called for his resignation. 
 Mr. Samper, who made no immediate statement, has consistently denied the allegations.
The President is expected to make overtures to heal rifts with the business sector, which blames the case for a deepening economic downturn, and to name a new cabinet.
Supporters of Mr. Samper who were interviewed after the vote said they hoped a new troubled chapter would begin tonight. Others predicted serious consequences, domestically and internationally.
"From the beginning, nobody believed in this process," said a Conservative Representative, Roberto Camacho. "It is not just that this trial is a farce, but that it's a farce to call it a trial."
In a meeting this afternoon, the Conservative party pledged systematic opposition in the Congress, and a group of industrialists announced that a new cabinet would not end their discontent. The country also faces a further worsening of relations with the United States.
The vote came after 14 days of frequently windy debate, with many of the 76 deputies who took the floor speaking for several hours. Because the House was charged simply with determining whether there was cause to send the charges onto the Senate, rather than ruling on the President's guilt or innocence, the debate did not include testimony by any witnesses, prosecutors or the President's defense attorney.
The investigation and interview of witnesses was handled solely by the chairman of the Accusations Committee, Heyne Mogollon, who offered a six-hour speech spanning two days that proved to be the President's most avid defense. Mr. Samper had been indicted on four charges, including illicit enrichment, falsification of documents, fraud and obstruction of justice.
Mr. Mogollon, who recommended dropping the charges, came under investigation by the Supreme Court for "neglect of duty" after he dropped a related charge against the President last December. Doubts have been raised about the authenticity of transcripts of his interrogation of the President, which lack any of the legally required observations about the defendant's reactions to questions, equivocations or hesitations.
With many people inside and outside Colombia predicting that the largely Liberal Congress would drop the charges, the debates appeared almost like waltzes without music, adhering to the formal procedures while largely disregarding serious evidence against the President and contradictions in testimony.
Mr. Samper's supporters argued, for example, that the President could not be accused of "illicit enrichment" because the drug traffickers who reportedly financed his campaign had yet to be sentenced. The House, however, generated a firestorm of protest after it threw out a bill to this effect in December after it had passed the Senate.
His supporters also argued that even if drug money had found its way into his campaign, there was no "reigning proof" that Mr. Samper knew of it, a conclusion -- given the evidence -- that appeared to be a confession by the President. Mr. Samper's defenders contended that the charges were nothing more than barbs thrown by political enemies and the hyperactive media.
Mr. Samper's presumed ties to the Cali underworld haunted him even before he was elected. In November 1993, Robert S. Gelbard, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs, said he put Mr. Samper on notice that American officials "knew" his campaign had accepted "a couple of million dollars" from drug traffickers.
At the time, Mr. Samper strongly denied that drug money could have entered his campaign, Mr. Gelbard said. He said he warned Mr. Samper that if the practice continued and he won the election, the two countries would face an "extremely bad relationship."
Publicly, Mr. Samper denied the meeting ever took place, but days after his election two years ago, the first explosive recordings of drug exporters discussing contributions to Mr. Samper's campaign surfaced. The issue has crippled Mr. Samper's presidency, and his country, ever since.

HEADLINE: Public Cost of Teen-Age Pregnancy Is Put at $7 Billion This Year

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
In the most comprehensive study to date on the effects of teen-age pregnancy, a group of scholars has calculated that taxpayers this year will spend nearly $7 billion to deal with social problems resulting from recent births by girls under the age of 18.
The study, sponsored by the Robin Hood Foundation, a New York City charity, is the first that tries to isolate the costs of adolescent pregnancy. It is to be made public on Thursday at the White House, where President Clinton is expected cite it in highlighting a $30 million program in his 1997 budget for prevention of teen-age pregnancy. 
 In the past, studies of teen-age pregnancy have compared the lives of women who gave birth to their first child during their teen years with women who did not. As a result, such studies often compare young girls of wildly different economic, educational and social backgrounds.
In contrast, the study looks at the consequences for teen-age mothers, their children and the fathers of the babies, compared with people from the same social background when pregnancy was delayed until the woman was 20 or 21.
To determine the costs of such pregnancies, the researchers looked at the differences over the last 13 years between welfare payments to teen-age mothers and the other mothers, as well as at the use of publicly financed health care, abuse and neglect cases that resulted in a child being placed in foster care, and prison incarceration rates for the children born to teen-age girls.
The study found that teen-age child bearing cost the country an additional $2.2 billion annually in welfare and food stamp benefits, $1.5 billion in medical care costs, $900 million in increased foster care expenses and $1 billion for additional prison construction. In addition, the study concluded that governments lose about $1.3 billion a year in tax revenue from the reduced productivity of women who bear children as teens.
"That's $7 billion a year that's going right out the window," said Rebecca Maynard, professor of Education and Social Policy at the University of Pennsylvania who was the chief editor of the study. "We could spend $7 billion to fix this problem and end up no worse or better off financially."
Sociologists who conducted the study say its calculations are conservative since they only looked at the result of childbirth for girls under 18. As a group, they give birth to 175,000 children each year. All told, about 500,000 children a year are born to girls 15 to 19, 72 percent of them unmarried.
To the surprise of social workers, however, the study found that teenagers gained no economic advantage by delaying childbirth until they were 20 or 21. Indeed, from the age of 19 to 30, those who have their first child as a young teen average higher incomes from welfare benefits, child support payments from fathers and earnings, than girls who put off having a baby until they are 20 or 21.
"Certainly that wasn't the thought when the study was commissioned," Ms. Maynard said. "We had hoped to have a bigger number to flash in front of teens."
In rewriting their legislation to overhaul welfare, Republicans in Congress are again considering requiring teen-age mothers to live at home with their parents or risk loss of cash benefits. President Clinton has twice vetoed the legislation, saying it was too harsh.
Two years ago, the Administration proposed spending $400 million over five years on an effort to cut the teen-age birth rate. The proposal was part of Mr. Clinton's welfare plan, which made little headway in a Democrat-controlled Congress.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Down Against Mark And Yen in Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar finished lower against the Japanese yen and German mark yesterday after spending most of day in narrow ranges in quiet trading.
The dollar slipped to fresh lows late in the day as speculators took advantage of the thin market volume to push the currency lower. 
 "Some people got tired of doing nothing so they tried to push through some support," said Jack Griffin, manager of corporate foreign exchange at the Fuji Bank. "We were unable to break higher earlier, so they decided to try the lows."
The dollar was also dragged down by a late afternoon selloff in the United States Treasury market.
But the recent slump in bonds has been driven by concerns over robust economic growth and interest rate increases that are likely to come as a result: factors that should ultimately bolster the dollar, traders said.
"The dollar is showing good resistance to weakness in the bond market, which implies the dollar is being supported by the strength of the U.S. economy," said Chris Widness, international economist at Chase Securities.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar fell to 109.05 yen from 109.43 yen on Tuesday. The dollar also traded at 1.5325 marks, down from 1.5347 marks. The British pound rose to $1.5355 from $1.5350.
Earlier in Asian trading, the dollar received a mild boost from the governor of the Bank of Japan, Yasuo Matsushita, who told reporters in Tokyo that Japan would keep interest rates at current historically low levels. But the brief rally faded quickly.
"That news from Japan should have been bullish for the dollar, but the market shrugged it off," said Bill Marr, foreign exchange manager at Credit Commerciale de France.
During trading in New York, the dollar weathered a warning about the dollar's strength against the yen by a United States auto maker.
A further rise in the dollar against the yen "will put a serious drag" on American manufacturing, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, Robert J. Eaton, said in a statement after he and other auto industry executives met with Clinton Administration officials.
Other auto officials have warned that a rally above 110 yen will damage their competitive position in export markets.
"The market will be watching for any change in rhetoric out of the Administration," Mr. Marr said. "They have been very clearly in favor of a higher dollar and if they say anything to the contrary, the dollar will get hit hard."
