HEADLINE: U.S. Mediator Survives Political Crossfire in Ulster

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY 

DATELINE: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 12

 BODY:
When former Senator George J. Mitchell was formally installed early this morning as chairman of the new broad-based Ulster peace talks, he had just survived his first personal lesson in the emotional, often vicious, sectarianism that has riven this British province for decades.
After being appointed chairman by the British and Irish Governments, he quietly endured two days of vilification by hard-line leaders of the Protestant unionist parties. They want the province to remain British, and they see Mr. Mitchell as an agent of change who will give the Roman Catholic minority more political power, cement closer links between Ulster and the Irish Republic and pave the way for an eventual British surrender of control. 
 Unionist leaders resent American involvement because Northern Ireland Catholics have long felt that only the White House could press Britain into serious peace talks. And Mr. Mitchell, with his close ties to the White House, is the target of their anger and fear.
The attacks characterized him as an Irish-American Catholic who would be prejudiced against the Protestant majority in the North.
"You simply accept it as part of the process; I didn't take it personally," Mr. Mitchell, 62, said in an interview at the Europa Hotel (which used to call itself the most bombed hotel in Europe because of attacks by the Irish Republican Army).
"In one respect, this is a new experience for me," he added. "In 30 years in American politics, no one ever asked what my religion is or where my parents were from.
"Last night, after it was all over, I joked that they had gone a long way to make me feel back in the Senate: talking all day, voting late at night."
The attack that delayed his installation was led by the Rev. Ian Paisley, the flamboyant leader of the hard-line Democratic Unionist Party. Mr. Paisley was once ejected from the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, in 1988 for heckling Pope John Paul II.
After the Ulster Unionist Party, the largest Protestant group, agreed late Tuesday to install Mr. Mitchell, Mr. Paisley and members of another unionist group stalked out of the Castle Buildings. They said they would take part in sessions selectively, but would not attend full sessions at which Mr. Mitchell is chairman.
Part of Mr. Paisley's attack is involved with his need to siphon votes away from the Ulster Unionist Party of David Trimble in the next British parliamentary election, which could be held this fall. Mr. Trimble is also under pressure from dissidents in his own party.
The Paisley unionists promised to keep up the harassment they had aimed at Mr. Mitchell, a Maine Democrat, a former Senate majority leader and a close adviser to President Clinton. Mr. Mitchell never responded directly to the attacks, but issued a statement today that he would be fair and impartial.
Mr. Paisley, who does not deal in understatement, had said Mr. Mitchell wanted to be "pope" of the talks. He said Mr. Mitchell was Mr. Clinton's agent, bent on winning Irish-American votes for the President. He said Mr. Mitchell was "a crony of Gerry Adams," the president of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A.
Ulster Protestant leaders are infuriated with President Clinton because he has allowed Mr. Adams to travel and raise money in the United States. Mr. Adams has welcomed the appointment of Mr. Mitchell.
Sinn Fein has been excluded from the talks until the I.R.A. renews the 17-month cease-fire that it ended in February with bombings in London. Mr. Paisley has said that if Sinn Fein is admitted to the talks, he will not talk to its representatives.
Mr. Paisley's son, Ian Paisley Jr., an aide to his father, matched his invective. Told that Mr. Mitchell had international credentials, he said, "Well, Mickey Mouse has international credentials."
Mr. Mitchell declined to discuss specifics of the talks. But he said he had never thought much about Ireland or his Irish heritage until President Clinton asked him to be his economic adviser on Ireland in 1994.
"I am not an Irish-American," he said, referring to his paternal grandparents' roots. "I am not a Lebanese-American," referring to his mother's birthplace.
"I am not a hypenated American. My father and mother would speak Arabic to each other, but all the emphasis was on America, on being American. I can't remember my father ever mentioning Ireland. He was a janitor; she worked nights in the textile factory."
Mr. Mitchell, who can still speak some Arabic, said he has never been to Lebanon and had been to Ireland only once before he became officially involved.
His father, Joseph Kilroy, was an orphan adopted by a Lebanese family whose Arabic name had been anglicized to Mitchell, and Mr. Mitchell was raised a Maronite Catholic by his Lebanese mother.
Mr. Mitchell said he was interrupting his Washington law practice for the unpaid job of chairman of the peace talks. He is also a director of the Walt Disney Company, Federal Express and Xerox.
After declining Mr. Clinton's offer in 1994 to appoint him to the Supreme Court, Mr. Mitchell agreed to be the President's economic adviser for Ireland. That led to his appointment late last year as chairman of an international commission on the disarmament of the I.R.A. and Protestant paramilitary groups. The commission's report provided grounds for the compromise that produced the talks that began on Monday.
His appointment by the British and Irish Governments marked the end of Britain's historical policy of refusing to allow foreigners to become involved in what London considered internal security problems. Ireland has been an ardent supporter of Mr. Mitchell's involvement and, with the White House, persuaded Britain that he should be chairman.
Under the compromise reached this morning, his chairmanship will be reviewed by all the parties, with the possibility of altering some of the powers the Irish and British Government proposed. But drastic reduction of his power is not expected, and officials who know how he worked as Senate majority leader say he does not rely on strict adherence to procedures but on gaining the confidence of those he is trying to move.
Under the Government-proposed rules, Mr. Mitchell may cut off filibusters; resolve issues by unanimous agreement or, failing that, with majority approval by Catholic and Protestant parties, and decide whether groups with paramilitary links, like Sinn Fein and smaller Protestant loyalist parties, fulfill requirements that they unequivocally renounce violence and agree to peaceful acceptance of whatever the majority decides. He may order the talks to continue even if one party, like Mr. Paisley's, walks out.
But Mr. Paisley said this afternoon: "The battle is not over. We'll be coming back to haunt them."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Post Sharp Drop

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended sharply lower yesterday despite a report that showed inflation remaining moderate.
The report said consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in May, providing little evidence of inflationary pressures. But the numbers only matched the market's expectations and were not weak enough to shake fears that inflation could still begin to accelerate. 
 Indeed, the nervousness and uncertainty has made the market vulnerable to rumors about selling by large funds and about the Federal Reserve's next move.
Bond prices bounced off morning lows, but ended the session down lower as buyers position themselves ahead of the next important economic report, today's data on retail sales.
"Thursday's retail sales data should set the tone in the bond market for the next couple of days," said Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data of Boston.
"The Street presumes that consumers came out of their cave in May and spent furiously," he said. If this assumption is true, the bearish tone that pervaded the market for the past several months will find a new set of fans."
The price of the 30-year bond ended down 24/32 , to 8515/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the bond's prices, rose to 7.19 percent, from 7.12 percent on Tuesday. The yield is currently at its highest level since May 3, 1995, when it was 7.24 percent.
Shorter-term maturities fared a little better, with the yield on the two-year note rising to 6.39 percent from 6.36 percent and the yield on the 10-year note rising to 7.06 percent from 6.98 percent.
Yesterday's report on consumer prices confirmed indications that inflation remains contained. Excluding the volatile categories of food and energy, the so-called core rate of the Consumer Price Index edged up only two-tenths of 1 percent, with a year-to-year gain of 2.7 percent.
The two price reports are consistent with a view -- albeit a minority opinion in the market -- that the Federal Reserve will leave short-term interest rates unchanged when Fed policy makers meet on July 2 and 3, said Bruce Steinberg, an econmist with Merrill Lynch & Company.
"Many worry that even though inflation is currently subdued the economy is currently growing too fast, which will lead to inflation problems down the road," Mr. Steinberg said. "That concern is understandable, but there are two reasons we believe it will not materialize. First we think that the economy's growth potential is higher than the pathetic 2.2 percent that many believe it to be.
"Second, interest rate developments so far this year are likely to slow the economy sharply during the next six months, short-circuiting any budding inflation problem."
But the market was busy yesterday pricing in a strong retail sales number expected today. Still, additional signs of strength will likely lead to more selling and a retesting of the market's lows.
The May report is expected to show a gain of 1 percent, and excluding autos, a gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent.
In the corporate market, Chase Manhattan Bank sold $2 billion in asset-backed securities in two parts through a Chase Manhattan Credit Card Trust.
The banking company joins companies like Chrysler, Advanta and the Providian Corporation that have repackaged about $65 billion of credit card, auto, home equity and other loans and sold them as bonds so far this year.
The Chase securities, which are backed by credit card receiveables, are equally divided between an expected maturity date of 1999, that is priced to yield 6.831 percent, or about 28-hundredths of a percentage point more than a comparable Treasury issue, and one with an expected maturity date of 2001 that is priced to yield 7.147 percent, or about 37-hundredths of a percentage point more than a comparable Treasury.

HEADLINE: A Billion-Dollar Dam Scam

BYLINE: By Thomas E. Petri; Thomas E. Petri is a Republican Representative from Wisconsin.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Congress is again being asked to approve the most expensive dam in United States history -- the Auburn Dam on California's beautiful American River. Its stated purpose is to protect Sacramento from floods that even the dam's proponents admit would occur about once every five centuries, although it is designed to last only one century.
The dam would destroy up to 50 miles of deep, richly forested canyons that provide habitat for wildlife and support recreation for 500,000 people a year. Taxpayers around the nation -- many of whom live with far more serious flood threats than the American River poses -- would pay 75 percent of its nearly $1 billion cost. 
 The project has a long, troubled history. First authorized as a $425 million irrigation project in 1965, it was scrapped after engineers raised doubts about earthquake safety. Revived in 1992, the dam was rejected by the House of Representatives by a bipartisan vote of 273 to 140.
The plan looks all the more ridiculous in 1996 as Congress struggles to cut spending. Both Republicans and Democrats should agree on that.
Dam proponents argue that this billion-dollar "investment" would save $16 billion in future flood damage costs. But they conveniently ignore the time value of money. If we invested the $1 billion in government bonds instead at 3 1/2 percent real interest, by the expected average date of the epic flood 250 years from now, we'd have over a trillion inflation-adjusted dollars with which to cover the $16 billion in damages. That investment would be 60 times better than building a dam. Even this understates the comparison, because the epic flood is nothing but an absurd extrapolation of a mathematical formula.
Why then the big push for the dam? Critics say the real game plan is to turn it into a water supply project for areas near the dam, although that water could be obtained in other ways. State Assemblyman Phil Isenberg, who represents flood-prone areas of Sacramento but nevertheless opposes the dam, says the drive behind the project "is to get people in Florida, Maine, Texas and Los Angeles, San Diego and San Francisco to pay huge costs for a dam that will benefit primarily land developers."
According to the Army Corps of Engineers and many local officials, improving the existing flood control dam and reservoir, and strengthening levees can protect Sacramento from the worst floods reasonably imaginable, at far less cost. It is no wonder that the Army is not recommending the dam. The Environmental Protection Agency and the Fish and Wildlife Service actively oppose it.
Finally, the Auburn Dam would still be built on a fault-riddled section of the Sierra Nevada foothills. Its failure in an earthquake could send a 40-foot wave of water cresting against the State Capitol. (Now, that would be an epic flood!) Earlier this year, a report from the United States Geological Survey reinforced earlier questions about seismic safety.
Clearly this pork-barrel monster should be killed again, this time for good.

HEADLINE: As Russian Vote Nears, Investors Are Anxious

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
Having endured crime, a chaotic financial system and an economy that promises better days but has yet to deliver, American and other foreign companies that do business in Russia do not rattle easily.
But despite public displays of bravado and a small flurry of new deals in the last few months, big corporations and other international investors have clearly been shaken by the possibility of a Communist victory in Russia's upcoming Presidential elections. 
 Analysts and executives at some companies said they have to take at face value the platform supported by the Communist candidate, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, which calls for increased government control over key industries, curtailing the International Monetary Fund's economic stabilization program, erecting trade barriers and limiting foreign influences.
So although President Boris N. Yeltsin's rebound in the polls has made them more optimistic about the outcome, many companies are holding back on investment decisions until after the elections.
Just last week, for example, Unilever N.V., the Anglo-Dutch consumer products company, said it would like to expand in Russia, but that it would only do so if Mr. Yeltsin won.
"In general terms, for foreign investors any thoughts of future commitments are definitely on hold," said Z. Blake Marshall, vice president of the U.S.-Russia Business Council, which promotes the interests of American companies operating in Russia.
There have been exceptions. The Exxon Corporation said on Monday that it had reached an agreement to begin work on a new oil field in the Russian Far East. The General Electric Company just reached a deal to build jet engines in Russia. Citicorp opened an office in St. Petersburg a few months ago to complement its operation in Moscow. Pepsico Inc. and two American partners unveiled a plan in April to spend $550 million expanding soft-drink production across Russia.
"We think we can survive and prosper whatever the regime is going to be there," said F. David Jones, Pepsi-Cola's president for eastern Europe. "Whatever happens, we don't think any government is going to turn back the clock on consumers and deny them modern, Western brands."
Mr. Jones added, however, that Pepsi and its partners plan to invest their $550 million over five years, and that if the political situation changes dramatically during that period, they can always pull back.
It is unclear what economic policies the Communists would pursue if they won the Presidency, and Mr. Zyuganov has repeatedly promised that there would be no confiscation of private property. But there would undoubtedly be strong pressures within the party for the government to exert greater control over some of the industries, like energy and telecommunications, that have attracted much of the foreign investment -- if not to renationalize them. Mr. Yeltsin's plan to sell to foreign investors nine percent of Gazprom, the Russian natural gas company, would almost certainly be canceled if the Communists won.
American companies said they are not taking any specific actions to prepare for the possibility of a Communist government. U S West, the telecommunications company that is two-thirds owner of a joint venture to improve phone service in Russia, believes that new business opportunities could "slow down initially" if the Communists win, said Bruce Amundsen, a spokesman for the company. "But we don't think there will be any drastic change, at least not affecting us."
The Atlantic Richfield Company, which invested $330 million over the last year to acquire an 8.8 percent stake in Lukoil, Russia's largest oil company, is "going ahead with business as usual," said Albert Greenstein, a spokesman for Arco.
Business as usual in Russia, though, is a relative term. Most companies have kept their investments small, saying they will decide on making a bigger commitment only after the situation becomes more clear. Arco, for example, plans to spend an additional $3 billion on joint ventures with Lukoil -- but has not yet committed itself to investing a single penny of it.
Avon Products Inc. ships its products into the country from Western Europe rather than building factories in Russia, and to minimize currency risk it converts its rubles into dollars each day and transfers the funds out of the country.
The political uncertainty is only exacerbating what some analysts consider to be one of the country's biggest problems: that despite the presence of many big-name American and other foreign companies, Russia has been attracting an extremely low level of foreign investment and needs much more to modernize its economy.
Although estimates vary, Russia is believed to have attracted about $2 billion last year in foreign direct investment -- the purchase by foreign companies of existing factories plus their spending on building new businesses. Russia received an estimated $4 billion last year in all types of foreign investment, including money flowing into the Russian stock market.
By contrast, China received $38 billion in foreign direct investment alone last year, according to preliminary estimates from the United Nations Council on Trade and Development. Poland, with a population roughly a quarter that of Russia's, received $2.5 billion in foreign direct investment last year.
David A. Lipton, the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, cited statistics in a recent speech showing that between 1989 and 1994, Hungary received foreign direct investment equal to $671 per capita, compared to $11 per capita for Russia during the same period.
"It's a pathetic trickle of foreign investment into the Russian economy," said Mr. Marshall.
That trickle is unlikely to become a flood even if Mr. Yeltsin wins the election and reaffirms his sometimes wavering support for a free market economy. Many of the impediments to foreign investment are a result of problems like a confusing and often arbitrary tax system and a lack of legislation to protect investors, Western executives say.
American and other foreign oil companies, for example, are ready to commit billions of dollars to helping their Russian counterparts develop oil and gas fields. But almost none of the deals has gone through because the Russian Parliament has failed to clarify a host of tax, legal and regulatory issues involving joint ventures, access to pipelines and exports.
"Russia must treat its early investors fairly if it wishes to attract more investors," Mr. Lipton said.
In the meantime, investment has been largely limited to consumer products companies that want to establish their brand names and grab share in a market where consumer loyalties are up for grabs. Avon, for one, is not at all reluctant to continue its aggressive marketing and sales effort there despite the political uncertainty.
"We don't know who will be in power or what kind of attitude they will have," said Susan J. Kroph, Avon's president for central and eastern Europe. Ms. Kroph said, "but I think, maybe with some naivete, once Russian women get a taste of this they cannot stop it."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
May, too, was rich for mutual funds -- a year in five months.

BYLINE: By Edward Wyatt 

 BODY:
CASH flows into mutual funds that invest in stocks slowed a bit in May from April's level, but demand remained strong, with aggressive growth funds continuing to attract the largest portion of assets, an industry group estimated yesterday.
Mutual funds that invest primarily in stocks took in an estimated $22.5 billion in net new cash in May, down from April's total of $26.4 billion but still the third-highest monthly total on record, according to the Investment Company Institute of Washington. Bond funds added about $500 million in new cash, roughly equal to their growth in April, the group estimated. 
 Over all, Americans have added $130.6 billion to stock and bond mutual funds in the first five months of this year -- more than the net amount flowing into stock and bond funds in all of 1995.
Last year, $123.4 billion in net new cash flowed into stock and bond mutual funds, though that total represented $128.1 billion of cash going into stock funds and $4.7 billion flowing out of bond funds. So far in 1996, stock funds have taken in $121.6 billion, still slightly below the full-year total for 1995 and the record $129.6 billion in 1993.
Still, several large fund companies have already seen this year's equity cash flows exceed last year's; among them, the Vanguard Group, T. Rowe Price Associates, State Street Research and the Scudder Funds, a unit of Scudder, Stevens & Clark, have all taken in more in the first five months of 1996 than in the 12 months of 1995.
That is not the case for every fund, however. the country's largest mutual fund, Fidelity Magellan, a property of the FMR Corporation, suffered net outflows close to $1 billion in May, according to data released yesterday by Fidelity.
Assets in the Magellan fund fell to $55.2 billion at the end of May from $56 billion at the end of April, even though the value of the fund's investments grew nearly one-half of 1 percent in May.
Long a top-selling fund at Fidelity, Magellan has suffered this year as its performance lagged. The poor performance and attendant negative publicity stemmed from decisions beginning late last year by Jeffrey N. Vinik, the fund's former manager, to place as much as 20 percent of its assets in bonds and an additional 15 percent in cash. Mr. Vinik resigned at the beginning of this month.
In May, net cash flows into aggressive growth funds, which are intended to offer investors the highest potential reward but also carry the most risk of sharp, short-term losses, "appeared to be on a pace with April's strong levels," said John Rea, chief economist at the Investment Company Institute. In April, aggressive growth funds took in $7.5 billion of the $26.3 billion that flowed into stock funds.
While total cash flows into bond funds were estimated to be about even with those the previous month, funds that invest in municipal bonds continued to have outflows, the institute said. Since January 1994, municipal bond funds have had such outflows in 23 of 29 months.
The estimates released yesterday are based on a survey of funds that account for about 97 percent of industry assets. Final cash-flow totals, along with a breakdown of net flows into specific categories of funds, will be reported at the end of the month.
Nearly any way the Investment Company Institute's figures are viewed, this year has been a banner one for mutual fund companies. May marked the fifth straight month in which stock fund inflows exceeded $20 billion, for instance; before this year, neither stock nor bond funds had taken in more than $20 billion in a single month.
But with the size of the mutual fund industry growing so rapidly, the dollar amount of inflows "isn't of record magnitude relative to assets," Mr. Rea said. Just as a 50-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average is not as big a deal as it used to be, with the Dow at record levels, so too should the dollar amounts flowing into funds be viewed in perspective, he said.
So far in 1996, net inflows as a percentage of stock fund assets have averaged about 1.75 percent a month, with the highest percentage, 2.27, coming in January. At the end of May, according to the institute's estimates, stock fund assets totaled $1.49 trillion, up from $1.27 trillion at the end of 1995 and $866 billion at the end of 1994.
But for periods of several months each in the early 1990's and in the mid-1980's, stock fund inflows were at higher percentages. For instance, in the first half of 1983, fund inflows for several months ran above 2 percent of assets. Similar periods occurred in 1986, 1987 and 1993. And in August 1984, fund inflows were 4.22 percent of assets.
These typically surge in the first four months of a year, as investors make annual payments into profit-sharing and retirement plans before the April 15 tax deadline.
While current inflows are below record levels, however, they are not far below. And for more than 50 years, each time a six-month moving average of fund inflows has exceeded 2 percent of assets, the trend has reversed course. While still below record levels, Mr. Rea said, "we are currently in the upper range of our experience."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1130 words

HEADLINE: Orange County: Hard Lesson in Safety of Municipal Debt

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
When Orange County, Calif., emerged from bankruptcy yesterday, ending an 18-month cliffhanger over the fate of this wealthy enclave south of Los Angeles, there was a Hollywood ending: Worried bondholders got paid in full, taxpayers did not have to raise a dime to pay off a $1.6 billion loss and the municipal market, after being burned once by the county, eagerly lent it $800 million more.
But the neat resolution to the crisis, the largest municipal bankruptcy in United States history, could not hide the fact that the most fundamental tenet of municipal finance had been shaken -- the once ironclad belief that municipalities always pay their debts. 
 This shared value, the underpinning of the $1.5 trillion market, ultimately prevailed in Orange County. Yet many worry that the market could well be lulled into complacency when it should instead be concerned about the red flags raised by Orange County since it filed for bankruptcy in December 1994.
"Things that were once unthinkable are now being thought of," said Joe Mysak, editor of Grant's Municipal Bond Observer, a trade publication. "This wasn't like nothing happened. This was a big deal. Yet I don't think people appreciate the risks that this crisis revealed, because they haven't been touched by them yet. There's just a lot less security in municipal finance. This is a seismic event. Yet it will take a while to measure the reverberations."
Unlike the corporate bond markets, in which risk is scrutinized from a variety of angles and security holders know that they could lose most of their money, the municipal markets have always been viewed as sleepier and less risky. There has been less scrutiny of the underlying risk of municipal deals, of the creditworthiness of municipalities and the risk of default, because investors have always been assured that municipalities would raise taxes to pay off their borrowings -- and if they did not, the state would step in to help. That, in fact, is how financial crises in New York, Philadelphia and Cleveland were resolved.
In Orange County, not only did the county do the unthinkable -- make its creditors fight it out with the county in bankruptcy court -- but it did not raise taxes to cover its debts. And the State of California made it clear that it would not step in to help.
"The municipal system did receive some interesting tests," said Paul S. Maco, head of the Securities and Exchange Commission's office of municipal securities. "The edges of the envelope were tested."
In the end, the crisis was resolved when Orange County engineered an elaborate plan, dubbed Project Robin Hood, to divert funds coming into some of the county's agencies and use them instead to repay bondholders. In addition, some Orange County municipalities agreed to accept only 80 cents on the dollar for claims they had against the county from the losses in the county's investment pool, with the rest to be made up from any proceeds of litigation filed by the county against its former financial advisers.
"Investors will interpret the resolution of Orange County as an affirmation that there is no risk in municipal debt," said Chris Varelas, an adviser to the county at Salomon Brothers. "But Orange County proves that the safeguards to investors may not be there. We've recalculated risk. What does 'full faith and credit' mean when you have no ability to raise taxes and you have a community with high antitax sentiment. Does it mean you will be paid in full?"
He added: "The risk was always there. But people's perception of risk was not calibrated with the actuality of it."
Orange County exposes the risks inherent in municipal finance: that municipalities can file for bankruptcy, that their elected officials may not be responsible or right-thinking, that default is possible and that financially pressed municipalities may have neither the resources nor the willingness to always honor their obligations. Especially in an era of taxpayer revolt and the shifting of the burden for costly health and welfare services from the Federal Government to cash-short local governments, these issues are expected to come into play even more in the future, experts say.
"Orange County gave us a fundamental lesson that wasn't there before," said Jeremy Ragus, a municipal portfolio manager for Scudder, Stevens & Clark, a mutual fund company. "Before, the willingness of any major voting group to pay was never in question. There are now limits of what you can do with taxes -- you just can't raise them."
In addition, Orange County's bankruptcy was the catalyst for several other trends. There is some debate about whether the apparently successful resolution will encourage more municipalities to seek bankruptcy protection.
Some argue that it has given the S.E.C. a broad platform to make its case for greater financial accountability by public officials and more prudence in the investment of public funds. And there may well be a shift in the type of borrowing used by municipalities -- more toward project finance, with limited protection given to borrowers, and away from general obligation bonds and their unlimited promise to repay investors.
At least two groups are thinking about proposing amendments to the Federal Bankruptcy Code to make it more difficult for municipalities to seek bankruptcy protection. As this goes on, some say that Orange County has moved municipal bankruptcy from the unthinkable to a possible financial tool. Others say that the pain and disruption that resulted in Orange County show how costly a tool this is.
Bankruptcy, after all, does not reduce the payment of obligations, it only slows it down. In Orange County's case, the county has $800 million more in long-term debt than when it filed for bankruptcy, and services to many of its citizens, mainly the poor, are being drastically cut.
With some Orange County officials facing civil and criminal charges over their roles in the county's $1.6 billion loss, a warning shot has been fired against poor public oversight. "There's a great level of fear and concern among local officials over the S.E.C. enforcement actions," said Robert Dean Pope, a bond attorney with Hunton & Williams, a Richmond firm.
James Spiotto, a lawyer with Chapman & Cutler in Chicago, added: "It won't be amateur hour any more. The professionals and the officials will be required by the S.E.C. and by the market to know and stand by their product."
One market analyst, who insisted that he not be named, said: "Orange County was a near miss. Every time this happens, all bets are off. Before, the market got used to municipalities doing what they promised for bondholders and then more. Now municipalities may well just do what they promised -- and no more."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
There's Gold in Spain That the Romans Left

BYLINE: By AL GOODMAN 

DATELINE: BELMONTE DE MIRANDA, Spain

 BODY:
The old Roman gold-mining pit cuts across this secluded valley, where the trained eye can still identify zigzag lines that were canals carrying water down from the hills to wash away soil and expose the treasure.
Using slaves and the best hydraulic technology known 2,000 years ago, the Roman Empire fed its gold appetite from this gash in northwestern Spain. Now, Rio Narcea Gold Mines Ltd. of Denver is preparing to dig a little deeper and take what the Romans left behind. 
 Based on extensive test drilling, Rio Narcea executives say that the valley will be the focal point of Western Europe's largest gold mine, in an area with minimum gold reserves of 1.8 million ounces. They expect to produce 100,000 ounces annually.
"They say if you go down 900 feet, you'll find gold; I don't know about that," said Zoilo Llano, 78, who reluctantly sold his dairy farm for $315,000 as part of Rio Narcea's $3 million buyout of his neighbors in the valley.
The company hopes that banks and investors will be less skeptical when asked to provide $40 million in fresh capital so that a gold-processing plant can be built near here and drilling started by late next year.
Rio Narcea is paying $1 million for a feasibility study of its own rosy predictions. The independent report is expected early in July, and banks will decide whether to back the mine based on its findings.
"It looks as if we've got a pretty sweet project," said Chris von Christierson, Rio Narcea's 48-year-old chairman, a South African who formerly worked for Gold Fields mining company of Johannesburg. "I'd be surprised if we weren't in a position to take a production decision."
Mr. von Christierson said the company's owners, including two Spanish coal-mining concerns and a Denver nuclear-fuel trader, Oren Benton, had spent nearly $20 million so far on drilling, property rights and development.
Europe's largest gold reserve, over all, is in Bulgaria, where Navan Resources of Dublin is mining an area containing 3.6 million ounces of gold, compared with Rio Narcea's estimated reserves of 1.8 million ounces, according to a London mining analyst, Jim Taylor of Yorkton Securities.
Spain accounts for just over 1 percent of world gold deposits. South Africa is the leader with 40 percent, and the United States has moved into second place with 10 percent, largely due to mining and assaying techniques developed in the last two decades. This technology permits the location, digging and processing of tiny gold flecks dispersed in rock as deep as 950 feet.
Rio Narcea is applying similar technology in northern Spain. Mr. von Christierson said that Anglo American of South Africa, the huge mining-based conglomerate, had spent $20 million drilling for gold in Spain, starting in the 1980's, without grasping the full potential of what the Romans had left over.
Mr. Benton's Concord group, a Spanish coal company and Anglo American formed a joint venture in 1992, but Anglo American pulled out because it saw only limited potential, said Mr. von Christierson, who once worked for Concord. Rio Narcea started in 1994, with his participation, as a publicly traded company on the Toronto Stock Exchange, and the Roman gold pits were studied more thoroughly.
"Essentially, the districts which the Romans exploited, most of the 60 big pits, we have under control," said Eugene Spiering, Rio Narcea's vice president for exploration.
Mr. Taylor, the London analyst, said "the potential is enormous."
Investors have seconded that notion this year. Rio Narcea shares, after languishing just over $2 (Canadian) for 18 months, have more than doubled this year. [On Wednesday, they closed in Toronto at $4.85.]
Rio Narcea's studies show a high grade, or concentration, of gold per ton of rock that is churned up by the noisy mechanical diggers. With less rock to process before getting to the gold, Rio Narcea aims for production costs of $180 to $200 an ounce, compared with the global average of $240 an ounce, Mr. Taylor said. The current price of gold is $384.30 an ounce.
The company would also cut costs by building a $25 million processing plant to make gold bars in the valley, not far from Mr. Llano's old dairy barn. Mr. Spiering envisions an armored truck climbing the narrow, winding highway every so often to pick up a shipment.
He said Rio Narcea might ask officials to authorize a new, straighter road for easier access. Getting permission may not be difficult, given the official support the company has already secured in the Asturias region of Spain, which is suffering from 20 percent unemployment.
The regional government has agreed to offset 15 percent of the operating costs of the project for as long as it lasts, and recently paid nearly $2 million. The Spanish Government offers additional subsidies and, Mr. von Christierson said, has demanded no royalty payments.
"We all want this project to go forward," said Inigo Alvarez, an Asturias government spokesman. "But there's not gold fever. Here we are very cautious. We prefer prudence."
One man who senses advantage is the Mayor of this community of 2,500, Roberto Perez, a Socialist. The Mayor keeps a handwritten wish list on his desk that he wants to discuss before issuing more operating permits. He would like Rio Narcea to open an office in Belmonte de Miranda and hire local workers. The company's operations so far have been based in a rival town nearby, Salas.
Environmentalists, who are skeptical about Rio Narcea's pledge to use cyanide sparingly to leach gold from the rock, and to fully restore the spent mining areas, concede that it is difficult to fight city hall when gold is at stake. "It's impossible to stop the project when it enjoys the full support of government," said Carlos Lastra, a University of Oviedo biology professor, who has helped lead unsuccessful campaigns seeking to block the project.

HEADLINE: Signs Emerge Of China Deal On Sanctions

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
China invited United States trade officials today to fly to Beijing immediately as new signs emerged that a last-minute Government crackdown on factories pirating American software, music and videos might persuade Washington not to impose $2 billion in sanctions on Chinese imports.
The acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said she planned to leave for Beijing on Thursday. Still, she met this afternoon with China's Ambassador to Washington, Li Daoyu, telling him that "while plenty of progress has been made, it is insufficient," according to American officials familiar with the discussion. 
 In another significant dispute with an Asian trade partner, American officials said they would announce on Thursday that after a yearlong investigation into charges by the Eastman Kodak Company that the Japanese Government had colluded with private industry to exclude foreign-made film in Japan, they would begin steps to take the case to the World Trade Organization. That is a disappointment to Kodak, which wanted Washington to threaten sanctions. But it puts a contentious trade issue off until after the Presidential election in November.
In the China case, Ms. Barshefsky renewed her threat that sanctions would go into effect on Monday unless China took more steps. Those steps include enacting a long-term mechanism for monitoring plants to insure that once closed they do not reopen unless they negotiate licenses with foreign companies to produce their goods legally.
Despite the tough stance, American officials said they were growing optimistic that a deal was in the making. "There is no question they got the message," one senior American official said. "They clearly want to get out of this situation."
Ms. Barshefsky said in a statement that "we have confirmed that the Chinese are engaged in efforts to close pirate CD factories," though she has declined to say how many. For the first time, representatives of the recording industry, who are already in Beijing with Ms. Barshefsky's deputies, suggested that they had seen a change of attitude among Chinese officials, who until recently dismissed demands for a crackdown.
Clearly, both sides are eager to avoid the imposition of sanctions. Despite China's threat to retaliate with sanctions against American goods, Beijing has far more to lose than the United States does.
For its part, the Clinton Administration is anxious to put the last of a series of major confrontations with Beijing behind it, in hopes of ending a downward spiral in relations. Since March, the clash over China's harassment of Taiwan has faded and the State Department received a somewhat ambiguous assurance from China on nuclear arms that allowed Secretary of State Warren Christopher not to seek sanctions for a small shipment of nuclear materials to Pakistan.
Other arms-shipment issues remain, including questions about whether Pakistan is preparing to deploy Chinese-supplied M-11 missiles that could be nuclear-equipped. But the trade dispute over piracy is the largest point of friction outstanding.
"Obviously, we'd like to get past this," a senior Administration official involved in many aspects of the China relationship said this week.
But Ms. Barshefsky is under pressure to proceed with considerable caution, particularly because White House officials fear that any settlement will become fodder for Bob Dole's campaign for President.
As a result, Ms. Barshefsky must come home with something significantly beyond the closing of a dozen or so factories and China's assurances that it will increase border inspections and live up to a 1995 agreement to open its market to legitimate CD's and CD-ROM's.
"We don't need another agreement," Ms. Barshefsky said earlier this week. "We have an agreement. We need a system of enforcement."
The key to such a system may be drawn from arms-control talks of a decade ago: Inspection rights for American officials or the American recording industry. In discussions with her staff, Ms. Barshefsky has several times borrowed a line from President Ronald Reagan, who in turn had borrowed it from Soviet leaders: "Trust, but verify."
Assuring those inspection rights, however, may be difficult. Many of the factories are controlled by officials from provincial governments, not Beijing. Some are controlled by Chinese gangs, or the military. Some plants are not registered with the Chinese Government at all, though yesterday China published a circular warning that no new CD factories would be authorized, and that unregistered factories would be closed.
The circular also said that there would be severe penalties for importing presses that produce compact disks. Though their import is restricted by the 1995 agreement with the United States, there are widespread reports that presses have been smuggled into China through Hong Kong.
American officials say China has also not yet begun to seriously discuss opening its market to legitimate American CD's and CD-ROM's, an issue of particular sensitivity to the Chinese Government.
In the Kodak case, American trade officials said that on Thursday the United States would conclude an investigation into complaints by Kodak, finding that the Japanese Government has "tolerated anticompetitive practices" for years in the film market in an effort to protect the Fuji Photo Film Company.
But rather than threaten sanctions -- the Administration's tactic last year in an auto dispute -- officials said it would move to take the case to the World Trade Organization. That would give the Geneva-based arbiter of international trade disputes its highest-stakes case yet.
The decision is significant because the Administration appears to be bowing to complaints by its allies that it has threatened American sanctions too often and that it is undercutting the trade organization.
Japan itself has urged greater use of the organization, believing that it has a far better chance with its panels of judges than it does in direct negotiations with the United States. Such talks almost always have the overlay of the American-Japanese military relationship, giving the United States a never-articulated but substantial bit of leverage -- its role at the linchpin of Japan's national security.
Kodak urged the Government to take far tougher action, fearing that its complaint could be tied up at the trade organization indefinitely. And American officials fear that many of Japan's trade barriers are so indirect that the organization does not have the mandate or the power to change them.
Today, however, American officials maintained that in the 60 days of formal consultations that would precede the actual filing of a complaint with the organization, Japan might change its mind.
"I've heard and read that Japan welcomes our taking them to the W.T.O.," one official said. "But after they review our case, and see the degree to which we will bring many of their practices to light, they may feel differently about it."
At the core of the case is Kodak's assertion that Fuji has made deals with distributors that exclude Kodak film from the shelves, particularly outside Tokyo and Osaka, Japan's two largest cities. For a year, the two companies have exchanged charges -- Fuji maintains Kodak has pulled many of the same exclusionary tricks in the United States.

HEADLINE: Hard-Luck City Bets On Casino Riverboats

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: GARY, Ind., June 12

 BODY:
If enough losers come to town, this hard-luck city is betting that it can make a comeback.
Less than a generation ago, when the steel mills on the edge of Gary were going full blast day and night, people had money in their pockets and plenty of department stores and restaurants to spend it in. 
 But now, the mills employ a fraction of the workers they once did, and unemployment hovers in the double digits. Broadway, Gary's main business street, is a ghostly thoroughfare of burned-out and boarded-up buildings.
This city of 116,000 residents frequently has one of the highest homicide rates in the country, and the illegal drug trade is among Gary's biggest employers of its young and desperate. The local bail bondsman and the pawn shop do a brisk business, and last summer, Indiana state troopers were called in to help patrol.
So to change its luck, this city, like so many others across the United States, has turned to riverboat casino gambling. The enabling legislation was passed in 1993.
On Tuesday, along the rocky shoreline of Lake Michigan, two floating casinos, one of them owned by Donald Trump, officially opened for business. But because of a 1951 Federal law prohibiting gambling on Federal waters, including the lake, the boats are not allowed to leave the dock, which is about five miles from Gary's sad downtown.
Still, a steady stream of cars and vans, many of them from Chicago about 30 minutes away, made the trip down the new road leading to the boats, ignoring the cold, all-day rain and the thick morning fog.
And soon those cars may also be going to the nearby city of Hammond, Ind., where a riverboat will be owned Empress Casinos, and to East Chicago, Ind., where a riverboat operated by Showboat will open in the fall. The new riverboats will perhaps turn the coastline, marred by smokestacks, electrical lines and squat refineries,into a Vegas by the dunes.
In Gary, city officials say they expect to rake in more than $20 million in new taxes, Gary's cut from the losers at the blackjack tables and slot machines. Currently, the city's budget is $67 million, and it can barely afford to run its understaffed police department. Gary's 232 police officers are among the lowest paid in the country.
Scott King, the newly elected Mayor of Gary, said he plans to use most of the casino money for street repairs and to hire more officers.
"We're going to devote a lot of those dollars to public safety," Mayor King said. "But we're never going to make the mistake we made with steel and rely on one industry. If we use the money wisely, the city can draw a lot of different kinds of business to Gary."
Some here say allowing the boats is like making a deal with the devil and will bring even more crime to the city and little substantial economic development for the city or the individual boat workers.
And even Mayor King said that although he was "happy about the jobs," he "was concerned that there is some part of the population that might fall victim to the problems of gambling."
The former Mayor, Thomas V. Barnes, pushed hard for the boats because of the jobs, tourists and tax dollars they promised to pull in.
"We looked at it as an opportunity to pump some real money into Gary," he said.
Each boat will have a staff of about 1,000, and Mr. Barnes said the boat owners had agreed to hire at least 67 percent of them from the job-starved city. Mr. Barnes said that the boat owners had also agreed to a percentage of local ownership but that they have not followed through on the agreement and that a lawsuit has been filed. Mayor King dismissed the suit as an effort by "disgruntled individuals" to block the city's progress. There is a court hearing scheduled for June 20.
Don H. Barden, the owner of Gary's other boat, the Majestic Star Casino, said that more than 50 percent of his workers were hired from Gary and that that number would increase.
"There's no substance to the suit," he said, as he watched a couple of hundred people pour tokens into his slot machines. "The City of Gary will have enormous benefits from the boats."
Back in the heart of Gary, Vane Wilson, who has lived here for most of his 37 years and now teaches in a local high school, looked around downtown Tuesday and said, the boats "can't hurt."
"The boats will bring some jobs and those are desperately needed around here," Mr. Wilson said. "Those mills used to employ 30,000 people. Now, maybe 5,000 work there. The city has lost so many people, I don't know if we can ever recover, but we got to try something."
Indeed, the city has been trying to spruce itself up lately by spending more than $50,000 on putting up brightly painted false plywood fronts on some of the burned-out and abandoned buildings that line Broadway. Tom Grey, executive director of the National Coalition Against Legalized Gambling, says using casinos to boost a municipal economy is also a false front.
"They are using a poor community to leverage themselves," Mr. Grey said of the boat owners. "Gambling takes from those who can least afford it. It's a race to the bottom."
And it is a race, Chicago politicians may begin to think more about, especially after they see the parade of cars leaving their city for Gary, a place Cassander Singleton, a 30-year-old customer service clerk from Chicago's South Side, never thought about going -- until the boats came.
"There was nothing to do here before," Ms. Singleton said, sitting in front of the River Gambler slot machine, a plastic cup full of tokens in her lap.
Eleanor Jordan, 65, a retired secretary, drove from a suburb of Chicago to gamble in Indiana. Although Illinois has several riverboats, the boats in Gary are closer to Ms. Jordan's home. She lost $5 and decided to quit. When she told friends that she was going to Gary, many of them, especially her male friends, expressed surprise and dismay.
"They have the impression that if you go to Gary, you'll never come out," she said, shaking her heard. "But this is easy to get to. It's prefectly safe. Sometimes men are big chickens."
Because the boats are so far from downtown Gary, gamblers can spend all day on them and never see the city, that, despite its problems, has plenty of good people and pretty neighborhoods overlooking the lake.
"I don't know if we're trapped in Gary or we stay because we like it," Mr. Wilson, the teacher, said. "I stay because it's all I know and because I remember what it was."
Whether a boat full of gamblers will help Gary recapture its past, no one knows. Wendell Childs, a salesman at Gary Loan, a pawn shop on Broadway, puffed on a pipe and said, "Gambling might bring a little money to Gary, and it might make it worse." He added: "I don't gamble. I'm religious. I think a lot of people are going to lose their houses and everything. It might bring the pawn shop a little more business."

HEADLINE: Report on Consumer Prices Shows Inflation Is Well Contained

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
Inflation remains well contained, despite an increasingly robust economy and the lingering effects of pinched oil supplies earlier in the year, Government figures showed today.
In one of the few recent reports that closely matched analysts' expectations, consumer prices climbed three-tenths of 1 percent in May, with the so-called core rate that excludes energy and food rising still less. 
 Today's report on consumer prices followed one on Tuesday showing an unexpected one-tenth of 1 percent decline in prices at the producer level last month. Together, the reports would appear to ease the pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates this summer to check inflation.
"There's enormous price stability -- no inflationary pressures in the economy," Joseph E. Stiglitz, chief economic adviser to President Clinton, said in an interview. And the items that have caused nervousness in recent months, mainly energy and grains, are now unwinding and will "be taking taking away from inflation through the end of the year," he predicted.
Although consumer inflation for 1996 will very likely reach 3 percent for the first time since 1991 -- last year's was 2.5 percent -- there is little chance it will surge, analysts agreed. Today's report showed that the core rate was 2.7 percent for the three months through May, exactly the same as in the preceding three-month periods ending in February and November.
Such stability is "hardly cause for alarm," Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, a St. Louis consultant, told clients.
At Merrill Lynch & Company, Bruce Steinberg said concerns about overrapid growth was "understandable." But he dismissed this argument by saying it underestimates the economy's growth potential and fails to allow for the retarding effect of interest rate increases already in place.
The financial markets showed little reaction when the unsurprising report on consumer prices was released this morning. Later in the afternoon, however, bond prices fell, pushing the yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond to 7.19 percent, from 7.12 percent on Tuesday.
In a related report today, the Labor Department said average weekly earnings edged down one-tenth of 1 percent in May as higher hourly earnings were offset by higher prices while the length of the workweek was unchanged.
About one-quarter of the rise in the Consumer Price Index last month reflected a 1.1 percent jump in the energy component, the sixth consecutive increase but a smaller one than in March or April.
Energy prices fell, however, at the producer level in May and now also seem to be retreating at service stations. The Consumer Price Index is considered a lagging indicator, shifting direction only after movements in the economy at large.
Petroleum-based energy soared at a 40.8 percent annual rate during the first five months of the year, pushing prices up in transportation, housing and other components.
Food prices edged up slightly last month as a decline for fruit and vegetables offset increases in the other major grocery store groups. Cereal and bakery products rose six-tenths of 1 percent -- but are likely to decline in June to reflect this week's price cuts by Kellogg -- while beef prices fell 1.7 percent.
This was the sixth straight decline for beef, reflecting the forced sale of herds by farmers unable to feed them because of high grain prices.
Housing, which accounts for 41 percent of the Consumer Price Index, rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent as declines for electricity and fuel oil more than offset a rise for natural gas, while local phone service charges climbed 2.2 percent.
Local phone charges had dropped 2.4 percent in April, the erratic moves largely reflecting a one-time refund in the New York area and the return in May to regular rates.
Transportation costs surged seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, with motor fuel accounting for two-thirds of the increase. Gasoline was up 2.5 percent and would have been up nearly another full percentage point had it not been for a quality adjustment for gasoline meeting higher air-quality mandates in California.
Indexes for new cars and automobile finance charges moved negligibly higher but used cars skidded nine-tenths of 1 percent, the report also showed. Airline fares rose 2.3 percent, the main factor in a 2 percent increase for public transportation.
Medical costs climbed three-tenths of 1 percent for the third straight month, bringing the 12-month pace down to 3.7 percent.
Elsewhere, admissions to movies, theaters, concerts and sporting events rose 1 percent while tobacco and smoking products increased five-tenths of 1 percent.
The purchasing power of the 1982-84 dollar now stands at 63.9 cents, while that of the 1967 dollar stands at 21.3 cents.
At 156.6, the latest reading of the Consumer Price Index for urban consumers means that a basket of goods and services that cost $10 in the 1982-84 period now costs $15.66.

HEADLINE: Stocks End Mixed, With Dow Off by 0.37

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed yesterday as an afternoon slump in the bond market threw cold water on a rally led by semiconductor issues.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 0.37 point, to 5,668.29, after gaining more than 36 points earlier in the day.
The Dow's decline was led by Caterpillar, down 1 1/8, to 64 3/4; Boeing, down 7/8, to 84, and Exxon, down 7/8, to 84 1/8.
Broader indexes were also lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.93 points, to 669.04.
But semiconductor stocks rallied after an important barometer of chip demand rose for the first time in seven months.
The so-called book-to-bill ratio climbed to 0.84 in May from a revised 0.81 in April, suggesting to some that a turning point had been reached.
As a result, the Nasdaq composite index, which includes many of the largest semiconductor makers, rose 4.71 points, to 1,235.47.
Bond prices fell as a report showing moderate inflation at the consumer level failed to shake concerns that robust growth would accelerate inflation.
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for corporate and consumer interest rates -- rose to 7.19 percent, from 7.12 percent on Tuesday. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite direciotns.
Shares of drug and telephone companies also dropped, showing that investors are moving away from "consumer staples" and toward "cyclically oriented companies," whose earnings are more sensitive to the economy's expansion, said Phil Schettewi, managing partner at Loomis Sayles & Company in Washington, whose office oversees $4 billion in assets.
Bond yields rose to the highest levels in more than a year as investors could not shake concern that faster inflation might result from a quickening economic pace.
The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 7 basis points, to 7.19 percent, even as today's consumer price report showed May prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent, the smallest increase in three months.
The Hewlett-Packard Company, the computer maker, fell 3 1/2, to 102 7/8.
The Intel Corporation, Novellus Systems Inc. and LSI Logic Inc. were among the semiconductor shares that gained after the industry's ratio of new orders to shipments increased for the first time since October.
Intel rose 1 1/2, to 76 3/4; Novellus jumped 1 3/4, to 44 1/4, and LSI Logic gained 1, to 28 1/2.
The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index rose 3.98 points, to 197.87.
Still, chip stocks have room for improvement, said Jim Solloway, director of research at the Argus Research Corporation .
"Prices are still weak, and there's a lot of capacity, thanks to the very strong demand" in the last few years, he said.
Microsoft shares rose to another record. Its shares rose 2 7/8, to 125, ahead of a conference today at which it is expected to provide details of products for corporate networks using the Internet.
But Hewlett-Packard fell on concern that earnings would not meet earlier expectations. The computer maker fell 3 1/2, to 102 7/8.
Shao Wang, an analyst at Smith Barney, cut his earnings estimates for the fiscal third and fourth quarters, citing concern about its transition to new products and customer demand in the high-end computer market.
The Monsanto Company surged 1 3/4, to 32. The company's chairman told analysts at a meeting that new drugs, including one to treat arthritis, and pesticides could generate more than $4.5 billion in sales, said Donald Carson, an analyst at J. P. Morgan & Company.
The DSC Communications Corporation rose 1/4, to 29, after a Texas judge awarded the telecommunications equipment maker $136.7 million in a trade secrets lawsuit against the Next Level Communications Corporation and two of its co-founders.
Circuit City Stores Inc. rose 2, to 38 1/4, a day after the retailer detailed its plan to open 8 to 10 CarMax used-car dealerships in 1997 and operate more than 80 by 2001.
Everen Securities yesterday raised its rating on the stock to short-term "outperform" from "market perform."
The Kmart Corporation tacked on 13/16 , to 13 7/8, after Merrill Lynch reinstated coverage of the retailer's stock with a "buy" rating.
The Edmark Corporation shares fell 3 1/4 to 21 after the education software company warned that slow sales will cause earnings to be well short of analysts' estimates.

HEADLINE: Baptists Censure Disney For Gay-Spouse Benefits

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, June 12

 BODY:
In a striking sign that formal recognition of homosexual relationships is emerging as a bitter political flash point, the Southern Baptist Convention voted today to censure the Walt Disney Company in part for having adopted a policy last year extending health insurance benefits to the same-sex partners of employees.
The resolution, adopted overwhelmingly by the nearly 14,000 people attending the denomination's annual meeting in the Superdome here, stopped short of calling for an immediate boycott of the entertainment giant by the nation's nearly 16 million Southern Baptists. 
 But those at the meeting toughened the resolution's language by adding an amendment calling on Southern Baptists to "boycott Disney Company stores and theme parks if they continue this anti-Christian and anti-family trend."
Nancy Victory, the chairwoman of the denomination's resolutions committee who helped oversee the statement's drafting, said: "The Disney Company is not the same Disney that it was years ago when we were growing up. We find there is a philosophical shift at the highest levels of the company, which is not friendly to families and people of faith."
Shortly after the resolution was passed, Disney criticized it. "We find it curious that a group that claims to espouse family values would vote to boycott the world's largest producer of wholesome family entertainment," the company said in a formal statement issued from its headquarters in Burbank, Calif.
Because the statement carries no timetable for a boycott and because such resolutions are advisory in a denomination that includes 37,000 autonomous churches, its effect cannot be foreseen.
But Bill Merrell, a vice president of the denomination's Executive Committee, said a formal call for a boycott of Disney theme parks and products could take place in less than a year. "It is dependent on the response of the Disney Company to this action," Mr. Merrell said.
Southern Baptists, members of the nation's second largest religious body after the Roman Catholic Church, represent a politically and economically formidable group, especially in the Southeast and Texas.
Still, initial response from a sampling of Southern Baptists was divided. Suzanne Allen, a 35-year-old mother of four in Nashville, said she would take part in a boycott if one was called. Homosexuality as a sin "is cut and dried in the Bible -- it falls under the Ten Commandments as adultery," Mrs. Allen said.
But another Southern Baptist in Nashville, the Rev. Mark Caldwell, pastor of the 500-member Glendale Baptist Church, said he would tell his congregation on Sunday that he opposes the censure.
"I don't believe in singling out gay and lesbian people to be ostracized from anything," Mr. Caldwell said, rejecting as "mistaken" the belief that homosexuality is a sin. The Southern Baptist Convention, he added, needs to be "more Christ-like in this regard."
The resolution faulted Disney for "hosting" gay and lesbian "theme nights" at its parks. "In recent years, the Disney Company has given the appearance that the promotion of homosexuality is more important than its historic commitment to traditional family values," the resolution said.
In response, John Dreyer, a Disney spokesman, said, "What they are talking about is an event that's dubbed 'gay day' by its organizers," a gay and lesbian group in Orlando, Fla., that for several years has held an annual gathering of homosexuals at Disney World in late June. "Those who decide they're going to the park go out and buy tickets just like any other guest would."
Mr. Dreyer said company officials would be willing to talk with leaders of the Southern Baptist Convention. "However, we will not drop our new health program," he said. "We will not discriminate against people who come to our parks."
In a larger sense, controversy over the recognition of homosexual partnerships is becoming a highly visible point of contention in national politics. Congress is considering passage of a bill that would deny Federal recognition of same-sex marriages. And President Clinton has said he will sign the bill if it reaches his desk, a promise that has upset many politically active gay men and lesbians.
In Orlando, home of Disney World, the Rev. Steve Rayburn, 48, pastor of the Delaney Street Baptist Church, said he agreed with the convention that "there has been a shift in Disney's position of its traditional support of traditional family values." He also said that while he was unlikely to bring the issue before his congregation, he thought "the congregation would support the censure, because we have people here that are employed by Disney that are not happy with Disney."
Another minister in the Orlando area, the Rev. Mark Matheson, 41, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Windermere, said he would address the Disney censure with his 1,800-member congregation.
"I have dozens of employees at Disney World who are active members of my congregation and depend upon Disney for their livelihood," Mr. Matheson said. "They see their job as a ministry. It is important to separate corporate policy from the philosophies and beliefs of people who work at Disney."
Mr. Matheson criticized in particular the movie "Priest," by Miramax, a Disney subsidiary. The convention's resolution also mentions "Priest," which deals in part with a Catholic priest wrestling with his homosexuality, as a reason for censuring Disney.
But in Nashville, one Southern Baptist couple, Ron and Gwyn Bergthold, said the Disney movie their 4-year-old daughter, Carly, cares about is the animated feature, "The Lion King." "I tell her it doesn't have the same message as what the Bible teaches us," said Mrs. Bergthold, who objects to what she said was the movie's undercurrent of "nature worship."
Asked how he would explain a ban on seeing Disney classics like "Bambi" to, say, a 5-year-old, Rodney Schell, the minister for children at the Park Cities Baptist Church in Dallas, said: "That's not a 5-year-old's decision. As a parent, that's my decision."
Several Southern Baptist parents said they were concerned that Disney's policies helped legitimize homosexuality. "The key thing is communicating that we feel this is wrong," Mr. Bergthold said. "Censuring will do that."

HEADLINE: 'Out-of-Work' Dole Starts What He Calls 'the Real Campaign'

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY

DATELINE: OVERLAND PARK, Kan., June 12

 BODY:
Bob Dole commenced another campaign today, this one to sever the ties to the city he has called home for 35 years -- Washington -- and to run for President as an out-of-work American. This, Mr. Dole announced today, begins "the real campaign."
"I think sometimes, as I've said to my colleagues, we need to go out and listen to America," Mr. Dole told business leaders at a luncheon in Toledo, Ohio. "And now that I'm free from the United States Senate, I'm going to do a lot of listening to Americans. And that's what's going to happen in the real campaign." 
 "I am out of Washington," Mr. Dole declared.
From the moment he climbed the steps to his campaign plane in Washington this morning, Mr. Dole signaled his departure from a political environment that his aides had reluctantly concluded had been toxic to his Presidential candidacy. He jauntily pointed out to his wife, Elizabeth, that the plane's name, painted in blue to the left of the forward door, had been changed overnight from Leader's Ship to Citizen's Ship.
In Toledo, Mr. Dole was introduced by Gov. George V. Voinovich as Citizen Dole. At the end of a speech that stretched to 50 minutes and went far beyond the text, Mr. Dole plunged uncharacteristically into the crowd, a move that aides pointed out to reporters.
In addition, his three-day, eight-city trip was promoted as a trip to "the Heartland," as proclaimed on a blue-and-white banner draped behind Mr. Dole at an outdoor rally this afternoon in this Kansas City suburb.
Still, there were signs that Mr. Dole was adjusting to his sudden change from his life as a legislator for 35 years. He spent the morning in the front of the plane telephoning former colleagues in the Senate, keeping up with Trent Lott's victory to succeed him as majority leader. Mr. Dole, who had dabbled with campaigning tie-less after he first announced his retirement, today appeared, comfortably and without fuss, in business attire.
And while he at first joked about his new-found predicament -- "I'm going around the country to see where they have the best unemployment benefits," he said -- he turned poignant as he contemplated his new station on life, on a day where he was returning to his home state.
"My father told me that you can only sweep the walk and empty the garbage so many times a day in retirement," Mr. Dole said. "And there is sort of an empty feeling. I called my office this morning, and I got a recording. Said nobody's here."
Mr. Dole paused and grinned at his stilled audience. "I knew I wasn't there. But that chapter of my life is over, and another one has opened," he said.
Mr. Dole suggested here that he now shared a bond with other Americans who had lost their jobs or were fearful of losing their jobs, hinting that there might be unexpected political gain in his unemployment. "I told one reporter that I had a feel now for how the people who leave their jobs voluntarily or involuntarily feel," he said.
Mr. Dole inaugurated the new phase of the campaign with a combination of the muscular stump speech he had presented over the past two weeks and the less structured, more improvisational speaking style for which he is better known. "Holy Toledo!" Mr. Dole said in Ohio after taking the podium to applause.
Mr. Dole argued that the contest with Mr. Clinton was a fight "between the great liberal pretender and the party of principle." Mr. Dole continued developing the themes he had offered in recent weeks to contrast himself with Mr. Clinton, arguing that he was more experienced, truthful and conservative.
He noted that Mr. Clinton last week proposed a tax credit to cover some college tuition costs. There are "some phrases you should always be skeptical of," Mr. Dole said.
"The check is in the mail," he said. "I'll start my diet in the morning. Let's do lunch sometime. And how about this one: 'I'm Bill Clinton. I'm running for re-election and I'm going to cut your taxes.' "
With an eye to the Chamber of Commerce audience in Toledo, Mr. Dole sought to turn a persistent criticism of the Republican-controlled Congress he had just departed into an asset. "They say we're too business-oriented," he said. "But we want you to make a profit. We want to reduce some of the regulations. We want to reduce your capital gains rate."
But over all, Mr. Dole tried to keep his first day as a candidate from becoming too serious. When he came to the reporters' section of his plane to report the results of the Senate leadership contest back in Washington ("We're trying to keep you informed of late-breaking news."), he backed off when he was swarmed by reporters with tape recorders and note pads. Asked if he had any criticism of the Administration's policy in Bosnia, Mr. Dole said: "No, not right now. This is going to be a happy day."
And Mr. Dole suggested that he did not have much more in mind for the immediate days ahead beyond the tour of country-music halls in Branson, Mo., tonight and a paddle-boat ride down the Ohio River in Louisville, Ky., on Thursday.
"We're trying to get good pictures," Mr. Dole said aboard his plane this morning. "Don't worry very much about what I say."

HEADLINE: Consumers Gain Zero In Credit-Card Ruling

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Contrary to your June 6 editorial, allowing each state to limit the fees that banks may impose for a breach of contract, as distinct from the agreed-upon interest rate, focuses competition on the most important cost of credit: the advertised rate. 
 Such limits prevent banks from hiding the cost of credit in back-end fees disclosed only in the fine print. Without those limits, consumer comparison shopping becomes impossible, because banks do not compete on the basis that their back-end penalties are lower than another bank's.
The issue before the Supreme Court was whether a late fee, which does not vary based on the number of days and the amount of the late payment, is an "interest rate." The Supreme Court has held that it is.
If the Court had adopted the same meaning of interest rate that even your business section uses, Citibank would have had to compete on the same terms as other lenders in California rather than hiding its credit cost in delinquency charges.
Consumer organizations and more than 20 state attorneys general filed briefs supporting the cardholders in the Supreme Court. They recognize that the decision cannot be good for consumers.
 
MICHAEL D. DONOVAN
MICHAEL P. MALAKOFF
Pittsburgh, June 11, 1996
 
The writers represented the cardholders in the Court case.
