HEADLINE: Sticker Shock: Car Buyers Miss Haggling Ritual

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
Mark R. Smith was following the hottest trend in the auto industry two years ago when he plastered low, fixed prices on the cars and trucks at his family's Ford dealership here and banned haggling by his sales staff.
But the result was not what the auto executives in Detroit or the high-priced dealership consultants had predicted. For every customer who came in eager to dispense with the traditional, time-consuming and often distasteful dickering over the sticker price, there were four or five more who insisted on trying to knock several hundred dollars off the price. When the salespeople refused to budge, the customers stalked off. 
 So Mr. Smith abandoned fixed prices on his new cars last winter. The dickering resumed and the dealership quickly captured a bigger share of sales in the Kansas City market. "They've improved enough that we're not thinking of going back" to fixed prices, Mr. Smith said.
One of the most trumpeted trends in automobile retailing in years, the spread of fixed-price, "no haggle" new-car dealerships during the early 1990's, is now quietly in decline, according to dealers, auto makers and consultants. Despite all the complaints from car buyers about haggling with dealers, it turns out that many people actually enjoy bargaining and fear that they will pay too much if they don't do so. Dealers, on the other hand, found that setting fixed prices backfired when rival dealers nearby ruthlessly undercut them to capture sales.
"A bunch of us thought people would be willing to pay an extra hundred bucks" for the convenience of fixed prices, said John B. T. Campbell, a Saturn dealer in Santa Ana, Calif., who recently sold his fixed-price Ford and Mazda dealerships. "We found that didn't prove to be the case."
Fixed-price dealers do slightly better in rural areas, where there are few dealers nearby to undercut them. The consensus of Chrysler dealers, said Robert J. Eaton, the chairman and chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation, is that "one price works better when you don't have dealerships selling the same product quite close" together.
Close to 2,000 of the 23,000 new-car dealerships in the United States had one-price strategies in 1994, but only 1,000 to 1,200 still do, according to Mark Rikess, a consultant based in Los Angeles who works with fixed-price dealerships. Surveys by the Dohring Company, a market research company in Glendale, Calif., have found that the proportion of Americans preferring dealers who negotiate prices has climbed sharply over the last three years.
"Automotive consumers need to feel that they get a good deal when they purchase a vehicle, and, for most, the only way they feel that they can get a good deal is through negotiation," a new report by Dohring concludes. "Thus, the trend is toward more buyers preferring to negotiate their vehicle purchases and, while one-price selling will likely not disappear, it will remain the preference of a decreasing minority of car buyers."
A surprising number of customers at dealerships here actually say that they do not trust no-dicker stickers. "I'd much rather negotiate -- I feel like I'd get a better deal," Marilyn A. Murdock said as she shopped recently at Platte City Ford, just north of Kansas City, for a replacement for her 1985 Cadillac Fleetwood. "I need a low-end car; I don't want to pay a lot of money."
Though Saturn, a division of the General Motors Corporation, still requires fixed-price selling by all of its dealers, the withering of the trend at other car lines has disappointed some auto executives. Auto makers are barred by law from owning dealerships, and the business practices at some traditional dealerships have long dismayed auto executives, who fear that customers with bad experiences will go to another company for their next car or truck.
John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, predicted in early 1994 that fixed-price dealers would bring credibility to the industry. "Right now, the pricing can be all over the lot, low price to high price," he said at the time. "The customer's uncertain and can be scared by the process."
But Chevrolet, G.M.'s biggest car line, has found that many dealers tried fixed prices for only a few weeks before switching back. Even among dealers who tried fixed prices for six months, considered the minimum period necessary for a serious test, at least half have switched back, said Ronald F. Sobrero, Chevrolet's general sales and service manager.
G.M. is now pinning its hopes on what it calls value pricing, which involves heavily advertised vehicles laden with popular option packages that are offered at discounts. The discount shaves the profit a dealer can expect on a car in return for the promise of greater sales. While the slimmer margin leaves less room to dicker, dealers and shoppers are free to haggle on a final price.
Dealers who engage in fixed-price selling, on the other hand, set their prices below the recommended prices from the manufacturers. The size of the discount depends on the popularity of the model, and no bargaining is allowed.
Some advocates of fixed-price selling contend that other trends in auto retailing are making it less important. A fifth of all new cars are being leased, and many customers do not try to bargain on lease rates even though it may be possible. Car buying services are negotiating prices for many customers, taking away some of the stress of the process. And a growing number of car buyers are checking pricing guides for information to determine how much a dealer paid for a car, limiting the dealer's ability to charge a large markup.
"I have to believe the trend is toward a less negotiated deal," with a narrower range of prices that dealers quote for the same car, said Doris Ehlers, a partner at J. D. Power & Associates, the consulting firm, which publishes reports on car quality.
Mr. Rikess, the consultant to fixed-price dealers, said that set prices might come back into fashion if auto makers promoted the idea or if a sales slump left many dealers willing to experiment again. Indeed, while "no haggle" pricing had been around for years, it spread during the 1991-92 sales downturn.
But too many dealers underestimated the difficulty of abandoning negotiated prices, Mr. Rikess said. The move requires a completely new or retrained staff that is willing to shift its energies to wooing customers with detailed explanations of the features of new cars and trucks instead of haggling over prices, he said.
The decision by Mr. Smith, the Ford dealer here, to switch back to negotiated prices on new cars "just typifies how difficult it is" to make fixed prices stick, Mr. Rikess said, adding, "It's like if J. C. Penney got up one morning and tried to be Nordstrom."
True fixed-price dealerships are dwindling, particularly in cities, where they compete with dealers willing to negotiate the price of the same car, said George E. Hoffer, an economist at Virginia Commonwealth University who specializes in auto dealerships.
The negotiated-price dealers can charge high prices to unsophisticated buyers -- "hitting a home run," in dealer parlance -- while cutting prices to the bone for aggressive bargainers who compare prices at several dealerships. Fixed-price dealers try to maintain their profit margins by charging roughly the average of what the unsophisticated buyers and the aggressive bargainers pay.
The problem is that aggressive buyers often scribble down the prices at fixed-price dealerships and then wangle slightly better deals elsewhere. So the fixed-price dealers are stuck with selling cars to people who are too busy to shop widely and to unsophisticated buyers who might have been willing to pay more.
John B. Cates, the general manager of seven fixed-price dealerships in central Virginia, said that competing dealers had made a habit of driving by his dealerships at night and copying down the prices visible on the windshields, so as to undercut them consistently by $100 or so. The dealerships had to stop posting the prices as a result, he said, choosing instead to give sales agents a list of fixed prices that customers must request one at a time.
Buyers at Mr. Cates's dealerships pay slightly more, on average, than buyers at traditional dealerships. Mr. Cates said he had tried to make up the difference by improving the quality of his dealerships' warranties and service work and by emphasizing the ease of buying a car or truck at fixed prices.
"You end up with the people who value their time, and the service after the sale, over a couple hundred dollars," Mr. Cates said. Affluent buyers of expensive cars are among the few people who tell market researchers that fixed-price dealerships are clearly preferable, apparently because of a willingness to spend more money to avoid the hassles of negotiating with traditional dealers.
But over all, the Dohring Company found that 89 percent of car buyers heading for fixed-price dealers planned to take the quoted prices to negotiated-price dealers in the hope of striking a better deal.
Fixed-price transactions remain relatively popular for used cars. New entrants in the used-car market, like the Car Max chain, a unit of Circuit City Stores Inc., have generally adopted fixed-price sales policies. And even some dealers who have abandoned fixed prices for new cars, like Mr. Smith, the Ford dealer, have kept them for used cars.
The difference is that customers cannot easily take a price quote from a fixed-price used-car dealership and go to a traditional dealer for a better bargain, because no two used cars are exactly alike. "The cars are different; the mileage varies," Mr. Smith said.
Some dealers say fixed-price selling still has several advantages, even for new cars: Training and personnel costs are lower, as are advertising expenses.
Traditional dealerships require larger staffs to handle the hours of dickering with customers, Mr. Campbell, the Saturn dealer, said. And the hard bargainers who work in such dealerships also tend to be less willing to stay in one job for a long time, so that dealers are constantly having to pay for the training of new salespeople.
But for now, the surge of interest several years ago in fixed-price selling seems to have fizzled. Still, a few fixed-price dealers, like Daniel F. Ladd at Courtesy Chevrolet here, say that the advertisements they ran when they switched to fixed prices may make it hard for them to go back to traditional negotiations.
"We didn't call all the other dealers crooks," Mr. Ladd said, "but we poked fun at them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After experimenting with fixed prices for new cars and trucks at his family's Ford dealership in Kansas City, Mo., Mark R. Smith began haggling on prices again. The dealership quickly captureed a bigger share of sales in its market.
 
Chart: "Final Offer?"
Car buyers' distrust of "no-haggle" dealerships has prompted a swift retreat from the fixed-price strategy. From its peak less than two years ago, the number of no-haggle dealers by one estimate has already fallen by as much as 50 percent.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
A development of mansions -- around a Nicklaus golf course -- rises in Westchester estate country.

BYLINE: By Tracie Rozhon 

 BODY:
WHEN Tokio Kasuga looked for a huge property close to New York City to develop, it was the height of the real estate boom. By the time the right place -- for a championship golf course surrounded by mansions -- was found, a recession had set in.
Mr. Kasuga, who died in 1994, and his son, Masahiko, paid $46 million in 1990 for a 400-acre site in the Purchase section of the town of Harrison in Westchester County. Last week, the property they named Purchase Estates was ringing with the sound of hammers and electric saws. 
 The project is moving ahead: The 18-hole golf course, designed by Jack Nicklaus, is to open this summer and four houses of 7,500 square feet are being built on speculation at $2.45 million each.
Eight of the 11 lots in the first phase of the 73-lot development have been sold, all to builders, for prices ranging from $650,000 for 1.9 acres with road and corner frontage to $1 million for 1.6 acres on a cul-de-sac with views in winter. The houses under way are designed in what may be called the "grandiose" style.
The builder of three of the houses, Chris Demetriades of Demetriades Developers Inc., said he had put up close to 100 such houses in Scarsdale, Rye, Purchase and elsewhere in Westchester County -- all of them speculatively. He said he preferred that approach to custom building because he could build exactly what he wanted, "with no aggravation."
"You like it, you buy it," he said. "You don't like it, you don't buy it." Mr. Demetriades said he had built about 60 houses in Purchase, all in the $2 million range.
The three Demetriades houses rising at Purchase Estates are designed by Nadler Philopena of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The one that is furthest along has a multitude of dormers with turreted two-story bays.
Purchase Estates has strict guidelines spelling out such things as acceptable setbacks and building massing. Chain link fences -- unless they are around a tennis court -- are not acceptable. Stone walls cannot be over 4 feet high. "There shall be no religious icons, no elaborate holiday or festival displays such as flashing lights" and "no overbearing, offensive, eccentric, discordant or overly large sculptures on display," the guidelines say.
A panel will screen designs for houses, and there is a list of architects whose work is thought to be generally acceptable, although selection from the list is not mandated, according to Billie B. Prizio, a sales agent with Julia B. Fee Real Estate, who is the sales director for Purchase Estates.
Robert Cox, chief financial officer for Hickory Pine Associates, the owner-developer, said the site had once been part of a working farm owned by a family named Pforzheimer. While part of the land had been sold off, the company was able to buy the 400 acres from the Pforzheimer heirs and another seller.
Hickory Pine is an offshoot of Green Stamp America, a company controlled by the Kasuga family. Hickory Pine bought the combined property six years ago. "We knew things weren't rosy for real estate," Mr. Cox continued. "But traditionally, the high end hasn't been hit as hard as the rest of the market and it was something we wanted to do."
"We didn't build anything for a while," Mr. Cox said. A land-use consultant was hired and embarked on a round of environmental approvals: from the town, the state and the Army Corps of Engineers.
Of the 400 acres, about 80 are classified as wetlands -- "I'd prefer you didn't use the word 'swamp,' " Mr. Cox said. Although the wetlands are indiscernible for most of the year, the land is carpeted with moisture-loving wildflowers and will remain untouched. The developer received final approvals in September 1993.
Buyers of the Purchase Estates houses become members of a homeowners association, and pay dues that average $2,200 a year, not including golf fees. The golf course, known as the Country Club of Purchase, is recruiting members.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Retreats Against Yen And Mark in Light Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar dropped against most leading currencies yesterday, weakening after the German central bank left interest rates unchanged and a trade dispute between the United States and Japan intensified over photographic film.
But traders said volume was light, exaggerating the impact of currency movements. Many noted that the dollar's recent strength had made it vulnerable to a selloff and that the dollar's longer-term trend was up. 
 "Basically, what happened today was more of an excuse to sell the dollar," said Seth Cohen, a director of foreign exchange trading at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar stood at 108.75 Japanese yen, down from 109.05 yen on Wednesday. The dollar traded at 1.5267 German marks, down from 1.5325. The British pound fell to $1.5347 from $1.5355.
The catalyst for dollar weakness came from the Bundesbank, which did not lower short-term interest rates as some currency traders had expected during a regular meeting of its policy-making committee.
There has been resilient speculation that the Bundesbank must lower rates to stimulate Germany's economy. When it took no action, traders who had gambled on a lower mark bought the currency instead, pushing the dollar lower.
Further dollar selling came after the Clinton Administration said it would file a broad trade complaint against Japan with the World Trade Organization, contending that Tokyo had colluded with Fuji Photo Film to block film sales by Eastman Kodak and other foreign companies.
Although the decision had been expected and was mild compared with previous actions by Washington in trade disputes with Japan, the tone of the announcement worried some currency traders. United States trade officials said they would press their cause even if the trade organization ruled in Japan's favor. Ira Shapiro, a deputy United States trade representative, said that the Americans had an array of options to wage such a struggle.
"He said, 'If we can't fix things this way, we're going to do something else,' " said Liz Goldberg, a vice president of foreign exchange trading at the New York branch of Germany's Hypo bank. "That was interepreted as an exchange-rate measure."
Other traders said the trade dispute was a pretext to sell on the dollar's most recent gains. They noted that Japan's economy remained fragile, which would keep Japanese interest rates low and the yen weak.

HEADLINE: In America;
Nike's Bad Neighborhood

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The State Department, in its latest human rights survey, said of Indonesia:
"The Government continued to commit serious human rights abuses. . . . Reports of extrajudicial killings, disappearances and torture of those in custody by security forces increased. Reports of arbitrary arrests and detentions and the use of excessive violence (including deadly force) in dealing with suspected criminals or perceived troublemakers continued. Prison conditions remained harsh and security forces regularly violated citizens' right to privacy." 
 Welcome to Nike country. Of all the places on the planet, the world's largest sneaker company chose the human rights sinkhole of Indonesia as the spot where most of its footwear would be made. Atrocities, including the Government-sponsored murder of thousands of innocent civilians, can easily be overlooked if there is a large enough labor force willing to work for next to nothing.
There is no need to dwell on this. That is why God made advertising campaigns. We can avoid the bitter reality of Indonesia and concentrate on the magnificent image of Michael Jordan soaring, twisting, driving, flying . . . or Andre Agassi hitting a tennis ball with such authority and power it leaves the racquet like a rocket . . .
Nike can thrill us, amuse us, fill us with good feelings. We don't have to succumb to downers like the following excerpt from a 1994 Amnesty International report about killings in Aceh, a province in which the Indonesian Government has been fighting armed rebels:
"Some 2,000 civilians, including children and the very elderly, were killed by Indonesian soldiers in or near the province of Aceh between 1989 and 1993. Some died in public executions; others were killed secretly and their often mutilated bodies were left in public places. Scores of the dead were dumped in mass graves."
No need to dwell on that. Nothing to do with Nike, after all. Or with Reebok, Adidas, Converse or any other sneaker outfits doing business in Indonesia.
Except that it does.
Nike and the other companies would like to distance themselves from the grotesque activities of the Suharto regime. But they cannot. They benefit both directly and indirectly from the systematic oppression of the Indonesian people. The Government cites the need for stability and security (in the interest of economic development) as a justification for its murderous policies, and then turns a welcoming face to the multinationals.
The response of the multinationals? We don't want to know about the rough stuff, but we're with you.
According to the State Department survey, "The Government continued to impose severe limitations on freedom of speech, press, assembly and association." And, in a policy critical to Nike and the other corporations that are drawn to Indonesia like flies to garbage, the Government continued to suppress the development of "a truly free trade union movement."
Nike is the most vulnerable to criticism of the athletic footwear corporations because it is the biggest, the most visible and by far the most hypocritical. No amount of charitable contributions or of idealized commercial images can hide the fact that Indonesia is Nike's kind of place. The exploitation of cheap Asian labor has been a focus of its top executive, Philip Knight, for more than three decades.
While working toward his M.B.A. at Stanford in the early 1960's, Mr. Knight wrote a paper on the profit potential of manufacturing athletic shoes in Asia. By the mid-80's Nike (co-founded by Mr. Knight) was no longer making shoes in the United States. It was dealing with independent contractors in countries like South Korea. And when workers there began organizing and winning wage hikes, Nike was taking off for places like Indonesia and China, where the crackdowns on labor are swift and effective and the pay is suitably pathetic.
Nike executives know exactly what is going on in Indonesia. They are not bothered by the cries of the oppressed. It suits them. Each cry is a signal that their investment is paying off.

HEADLINE: Le Mai, 56, Dies; Vietnam's Voice in Relations With the U.S.

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 13

 BODY:
Le Mai, Vietnam's Deputy Foreign Minister, who for many years was his country's voice in its edgy postwar relationship with the United States, died of a heart attack on Wednesday, the Foreign Ministry said today. He was 56.
A junior member of the Paris negotiating team that secured America's withdrawal from Vietnam in 1973 and a chief architect of Hanoi's more recent campaign for diplomatic relations with Washington, Mr. Mai was fond of reminding Americans that "Vietnam is a country, not only a war." 
 Mr. Mai, who had two previous heart attacks, was stricken at home and died later at a hospital, The Associated Press reported from Hanoi, quoting the Foreign Ministry.
Mr. Mai, a highly visible figure in the ministry for many years and Deputy Minister since 1990, was a member of the Communist Party Central Committee, the nation's chief policy-making body, and had been seen as a possible successor to Foreign Minister Nguyen Manh Cam.
His long association with the United States -- beginning with meetings in Hanoi and Canada with antiwar activists during the war -- had also led to an expectation that he might become his country's first ambassador to Washington.
Fluent in English, Mr. Mai traveled often to the United States in his country's long postwar campaign to end economic sanctions and then to establish full diplomatic relations with Washington, a goal it achieved last year.
In a statement today, the United States State Department praised Mr. Mai for his "instrumental role" in "the ongoing process of normalizing the relationship between the United States and Vietnam." The statement called his death untimely and tragic, and said his contribution to bilateral ties will be missed. Mr. Mai was "a highly regarded diplomat and friend to many Americans," the statement said.
In his many contacts with Americans, Mr. Mai was an aggressive promoter of Vietnam's interests but also exemplified its pragmatism in putting past enmities aside.
"If we nursed all of our grudges with all of the powers that we have fought against, we wouldn't have relations with anyone," he said last year.
He argued that Vietnam's Communist Party was a home-grown nationalist movement immune from the collapse of Communism throughout much of the world. The Communist system meets an Asian need for unity and consensus, he said.
And he rejected American criticisms of Vietnam's human rights record, saying, "Foreigners who come here to press their ideas about human rights on Vietnam are not welcome."
"The United States considers itself a model for the world, imposing its way of living and thinking on other nations," he said in 1994. "They are always reminding the Vietnamese people they are dealing with a superior power. Sometimes we feel the United States doesn't treat us on an equal footing."
Le Mai was born in 1940 in the central coastal city of Hue and first worked as a journalist. At 25 he was sent for three years to China, during that country's Cultural Revolution, as a representative of the National Liberation Front, the South Vietnamese Communist political organization.
After North Vietnam's victory in 1975 and the reunification of the country, Mr. Mai worked in the American Department of the Foreign Ministry. From 1980 to 1984 he was deputy and then director of the ministry's Press Department, in which role he escorted some of the first groups of American journalists to visit postwar Vietnam.
He was Assistant Foreign Minister from 1984 to 1986 and was Ambassador to Thailand during a politically sensitive period from 1986 to 1989, while Vietnamese troops occupied neighboring Cambodia.
After his promotion to Deputy Foreign Minister, he was named to the Central Committee in 1994.
He is survived by his wife and two children.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Trade Threats? Say Ho-Hum;
Chinese in a Boomtown Busy Making Money

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: WENZHOU, China

 BODY:
To Wu Bangdong, a garment manufacturer in this booming coastal city, the danger that the United States and China will impose trade sanctions on each other seems a distant worry.
A ubiquitous make-money-any-way-you-can mentality drives nimble garment companies like Mr. Wu's to make decisions with speed and flexibility, shifting products and markets with little hesitation. Lately, domestic sales in China have grown more rapidly than any export market. 
 "We don't really care about sanctions," said Mr. Wu, who at 33 is general manager of the fast-growing George Garment Group. The company sold $30 million in suits, shirts and neckties last year and plans to sell $40 million this year. "Demand is growing so much faster within China," he said, where city dwellers have taken a fancy to dressing up for work and for Sunday strolls. "We have already decided to concentrate on the domestic market."
Facing a June 17 deadline, trade negotiators in Beijing and Washington are in a final round of brinkmanship over China's inability to control the piracy of American software, movies and musical recordings. If they fail to agree, $2 billion in sanctions will be imposed in each direction. But the indifference of factory managers like Mr. Wu, many of whose garments are in categories that America has threatened with sanctions, is a measure of how economically irrelevant, and arguably misconceived, such measures can be.
Despite solemn warnings from Washington that its $2 billion in new tariffs, the largest in United States history, will take a nasty bite out of China's economic growth, higher tariffs will actually affect just a small part of China's $48.5 billion in exports to the United States, let alone the nation's tens of billions in additional exports worldwide.
"In terms of the overall economy, the effect would be minimal," said Nicholas Kwan, senior economist at Merrill Lynch in Hong Kong. "Sanctions would hardly affect 1.5 percent of China's trade. That's really nothing dramatic."
Arguing that China has been lax in enforcing a landmark agreement on intellectual property rights reached in February 1995, the United States trade representative's office announced last month that it would increase tariffs on textiles, garments like those stitched together by Mr. Wu's factory, electrical goods like telephones and sporting goods like water skis and surfboards.
The sanctions are intended as a political stick to encourage Chinese leaders to get serious about the widespread piracy of American music, movies and software, since there is virtually no way to punish the pirates directly.
[Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States trade representative, flew to Beijing on Thursday amid indications that a Chinese crackdown on pirate software factories might prompt the United States to drop its sanction threat. "We hope the U.S. side will take note that the Chinese side has made tremendous effort," a spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry said in Beijing.]
In laying out the proposed sanctions, Ms. Barshefsky had said the list of items selected was designed to minimize the impact on American consumers. Popular merchandise from China, like footwear -- $6.1 billion worth was imported last year -- was omitted.
Textiles and garments were also chosen, United States officials said, because most of those factories are in southern China, where compact disk pirates operate, as if taxing one group would somehow increase pressure on the other.
A number of exporters of textiles and garments and electrical goods will obviously be hurt, and some possibly put out of business by the new tariffs. Economists in the Chinese Government have even warned that 500,000 textile industry jobs could be lost, though no one really knows.
Of course, trade sanctions can also create unintended results. Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, complained that Japanese and European companies were taking advantage of an anti-American mood in Beijing to win contracts that might go to American companies. Such cases are actually quite rare, though United States and Chinese officials often have their own political reasons for talking about them.
Yet here on the coast of southern China, in a city of three million where hundreds of garment factories have sprung up in old wheat fields, the consensus among many Chinese business leaders is that the threatened sanctions would have a minimal overall impact.
Some businessmen go further, saying that United States trade policy is arrogant and muddled, if Washington thinks it can hurt China's economy without damaging the benefits it derives from the $60 billion trade relationship between the two nations.
"Trade goes in two directions," said Chen Qingsheng, chairman of Lianyi Touring Goods, which shipped $1.5 million of sporting goods, or one-fourth of its total sales, to the United States last year. "These sanctions only stop a small part. It's not like they're revoking most-favored-nation status," referring to the preferential trade relationship that China now enjoys with the United States.
To Mr. Chen, and perhaps to anyone as far outside the Beltway as China, the rationale behind the Clinton Administration's trade action looks a bit murky.
Most-favored-nation status, originally designed to encourage Communist governments to allow freer emigration, is likely to be renewed for China -- a country that still restricts travel overseas -- principally because a significant jump in tariffs would be unacceptable to American businesses and consumers used to buying competitively priced garments, footwear, toys and electrical goods from China.
Yet at the same time, lesser trade sanctions are being threatened because of China's widespread piracy of intellectual property rights, an area the Chinese Government says it is actively working to control, if only with mixed results so far.
"I don't really understand the American Government," said Mr. Chen, whose conversation was continually interrupted by calls on the two telephones on his office desk and the mobile phone in his lap. "This approach doesn't make any sense. China and America need each other in the long run."
Despite his own reliance on exports to the United States, Mr. Chen said he was not worried because he expected a resolution to emerge from the Beijing trade talks.
Like many Chinese businessmen, he sees the negotiations over piracy as little more than a colorful charade, following the same script as in previous years, with accusations and counteraccusations by officials on each side who finally smile and shake hands when a last-minute agreement is struck.
Pressed about how he would cope with sanctions, Mr. Chen said that he would go through a few months of adjustment, shifting some production to nonsanctioned items and channeling merchandise to other foreign countries.
Many American companies with operations in China have objected to the threat of sanctions, worried about damage to the overall business climate. More specific concerns are voiced by American importers who already have contracts to buy items on the sanction list, like buyers for large department store chains. Such companies have paid for orders months in advance and will have to pay the new duties if sanctions are enacted.
"Nobody expects these sanctions to be long term, so we are carrying the new cost, while Chinese exporters aren't affected at all," said Jeffrey J. Macho, managing director in North Asia for Sears, Roebuck & Company, which buys millions of dollars of garments in China. "It's the reverse of what's intended."
Some American importers have already stopped orders for Chinese goods, United States officials have said, for fear that shipments in early June could be hit with new duties when they arrive in an American port after June 17, if there is no accord by then.
Other American companies would feel the blow of the $2 billion in retaliatory sanctions -- mainly on food products -- that China threatened after the United States trade representative's office formally published its list in Washington on May 15. The Chinese Government also warned that going ahead with sanctions would limit the access of American companies to China's market.
Although no exporter will say so publicly, one solution to higher American tariffs is to ship sanctioned items through a third country. Chinese garment makers who have contended for years with American quotas have already learned how to send almost completed trousers to Hong Kong or Latin America or even Mongolia, for example, where they get a final button or zipper stitched on before being shipped off to the United States. In that way, China is not listed as the country of export.
Here in Wenzhou, for decades an impoverished area, there is a self-reliance that makes for a robust economy. Ma Jinlong, vice director of the Wenzhou Economic Reseach Center, said that Wenzhou's annual growth rate averaged 27.1 percent over the last four years. The city has attracted nearly 800,000 laborers from the surrounding countryside during its tremendous expansion.
"With that kind of growth, sanctions would not be much of a shock here," said Mr. Ma, sipping tea in a noisy downtown restuarant. "A few sectors will be affected, though even they will find other markets. But it seems like there are a lot of American consumers enjoying Chinese-made goods. They lose, too, if sanctions come."
As for businessmen, they seem more eager to talk about investments than sanctions. "Do you know any American investors who would like to come to Wenzhou?" asked Chen Min, the general manager of the Jindingzhen Clothing Company, a $30-million-a-year manufacturer, who wants to expand rapidly so he can open stores in every major Chinese city. "We need extra capital."
Mr. Chen says he has no reservations about cooperating with American businesses. "I like Americans," Mr. Chen said. "They have lots of money."

HEADLINE: Senate Clears Way for Vote On Third Term For Greenspan

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
Senate leaders broke the logjam holding up the confirmation of the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to a third term today, with Republicans agreeing to Democratic requests for an extended debate on monetary policy over several days before the confirmation vote next Thursday.
Within hours of the agreement, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, the Democrat whose demands for a debate have held up Mr. Greenspan's confirmation, began making his case on the Senate floor that an excessive focus by Mr. Greenspan on reducing inflation was keeping the economy from growing to its full potential. 
 But even as the Senate undertook its most extensive arguments to date over the Fed chairman's record, both Republican and Democratic leaders said they expected Mr. Greenspan to win easy confirmation.
President Clinton renominated Mr. Greenspan to the job in February, and the Administration has remained firmly behind the nomination despite opposition from a few Democrats, led by Mr. Harkin. The Fed chairman's term expired in March, and he has been serving in an acting capacity since then. His new four-year term begins when he is confirmed.
The agreement also unfreezes the nominations of two other appointees to the seven-member Fed Board of Governors -- Alice M. Rivlin, the White House budget chief, whom Mr. Clinton named to be the central bank's vice chairman, and Laurence H. Meyer, a St. Louis economist. Both are expected to win confirmation, although some Republicans have criticized Ms. Rivlin in recent days for what they said were misleading statements to Congress about Mr. Clinton's proposed budget.
Senator Christopher S. Bond, a Republican of Missouri, said he wanted to ask Ms. Rivlin how the Administration could make public proposed long-term cuts in spending programs even as it "quietly tells political interest groups we're not going to make the cuts."
Responding to Mr. Bond, a White House official said that while President Clinton might shift spending between programs in future years, he would retain his commitment to reaching a balanced budget by 2002, and that the budget fight should not affect Ms. Rivlin's nomination to the Fed.
"We are confident that the Senate will confirm all the President's three nominees for the Federal Reserve, and we will work with Congress to answer any questions they may have," the official said.
The agreement to proceed with the debate and separate recorded votes for each of the nominees was worked out early today between the new Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, and the Senate minority leader, Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota. The Republicans had previously been unwilling to grant Mr. Harkin's demand for three days of debate, and were happy to have the Democrats fighting among themselves over the nominations. But there was increasing concern within the Administration and in the Senate that further delay could unsettle the financial markets, leading to higher interest rates.
"I hope we can have a good back and forth among those who believe we ought to have a much more aggressive monetary policy than we do," Senator Daschle said. "Once the Greenspan nomination is gone, we may not have that chance again for some time."
Mr. Harkin's argument that the Fed under Mr. Greenspan has taken its war against inflation too far has little support among economists. But it has been welcomed by some industrialists, who feel that high interest rates are cramping growth rates and that Mr. Greenspan does not appreciate how few upward pressures on prices the economy faces in an era of global competition.
"This debate about Chairman Greenspan's policies and their impact on the economy, about how we can get our economy to grow faster, about how we can create jobs and raise incomes, zeroes in on the most important issues we face," Mr. Harkin said.
Mr. Harkin said that Mr. Greenspan's "almost obsessive" concern with inflation had led him to misread the state of the economy and had "stifled economic growth and the income of average Americans."
Mr. Harkin said there was still some risk of inflation. But he said that unless the Fed was willing to "take a chance" on higher growth rates, the nation would never get a chance to see how fast the economy can expand without igniting inflation.
Defending Mr. Greenspan, Senator Charles Grassley of Iowa, a Republican, said the Fed chairman "has been pretty good at bringing confidence" to the financial system, and that the real economic debate should not be over monetary policy, but over balancing the budget.
"We ought to be putting our energy in this body not so much in fighting the reappointment of Chairman Greenspan, but in being more fiscally responsible," he said.
Mr. Greenspan was in Sweden today giving a speech on banking regulation. He has long defended his focus on reducing inflation as the best way to give the economy a stable foundation for growth. Mr. Greenspan has always said that he has no preconceived notion of how fast the economy can grow, and that he tries to stamp out inflation before it takes root by watching carefully for early warning signals of rising wages and prices.
With the economy growing at a robust pace this quarter and unemployment low, many economists expect Mr. Greenspan to push the Fed to raise interest rates in July or August. Mr. Clinton, clearly concerned that a rate increase could slow the economy heading into the Presidential election, said last week that the Fed should not raise rates if there is an absence of any signs of inflation.

HEADLINE: Bonds Stage Sharp Rally On New Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bonds rallied sharply yesterday, for the first time in a week, following data that suggested the economy was not growing at a fast enough pace to accelerate inflation and prompt an immediate Fed response.
The rally was prompted by Government reports showing a weaker-than-expected rise in retail sales and by an increase in initial jobless claims. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 23/32 , to 865/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 7.13 percent, from 7.19 percent on Wednesday and nearly back down to where it was when the week started.
Buying was encourged by the retail sales report, which showed a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent in May. Many economists had been expecting an increase of 1 percent. And excluding auto sales, the report was much weaker, leaving an increase of just three-tenths of 1 percent.
Margo Evashevski, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International in San Francisco, said the market rebounded because a strong retail sales report had already been priced into bonds. "It got a little confusing today," Ms. Evashevski said, "since there were some large April revisions in the retail report. In fact, we might have gotten a bigger rally out of the report had it not been for the revisions."
She said the market's recent sensitivity to labor data because of concern about wage pressures building made the rise in jobless claims a positive for the market.
The Labor Department said yeterday that initial claims for state unemployment benefits for the week ended June 8 rose by 6,000, to 360,000, from 354,000 the previous week.
"But as far as today's data is concerned, it did not alter market's expectation that the Federal Reserve will eventually raise short-term interest rates," Ms. Evashevski said.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, agreed that the two reports heartened the market.
"But a 0.8 percent jump in May retail sales on the heels of an upwardly revised drop of only 0.1 percent in April is most certainly not weak," Mr. Fine noted. "In fact, all categories showed gains except food stores, restaurants and bars, and unless the country has embarked on a permanent national diet, these food related components are likely to reverse in the upcoming months."
Mr. Fine noted that report showed strength in the sales of durable goods, including autos and housing-related products, suggesting that the rise in interest rates this year has yet to depress consumer spending in many important areas.
"Indeed, with the recently released payroll numbers indicating sustained employment growth that is likely above the Fed's comfort zone, with a slowly rising trend in the C.P.I. that is still not threatening but at the same time not as benign as many had thought, and consumer spending still forging ahead, the market's concept of a Fed tightening in the foreseeable future remains firmly in place," Mr. Fine said.
Lawrence J. Waldman, managing partner of the Long Island office of KPMG Peat Marwick, said the economy was continuing to expand, but that it was giving off mixed signals. That confusion paralyzed the market, he said.
Analysts said the market was also heartened as the Senate yesterday broke up the logjam that had been holding up the confirmation of Alan Greenspan, as chairman of the Federal Reserve. A vote on his third term as Fed chairman is set for next Thursday.

HEADLINE: U.S. Indicts Arizona Governor on Fraud and Extortion Charges

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, June 13

 BODY:
Gov. Fife Symington, whose multimillion-dollar commercial real estate dealings have been under Justice Department investigation for the last five years, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on 23 counts of fraud and extortion.
The Governor, a 50-year-old conservative Republican who is in bankruptcy, was accused of repeatedly making false statements about his net worth to financial institutions in order to obtain or renegotiate the loans with which he built a dozen commercial developments in Phoenix in the booming mid-1980's. 
 He also was charged with trying to use financial and political pressure to force union pension funds to release him from a $10 million loan obligation.
And he was charged with lying under oath during bankruptcy proceedings flowing from the collapse of his real estate empire in the recession that hit the Southwest in the late 1980's and early 1990's.
"He misrepresented himself," said Nora M. Manella, the United States Attorney who directed the investigation, in releasing the 39-page indictment, handed up by the grand jury early this afternoon.
The Governor, a descendant of a long and wealthy line of blueblood industrialists and public servants, immediately denied any wrongdoing, saying in a statement read at the capitol that the Federal Government "has accused me of criminal conduct I never committed or even contemplated."
"I am proud of my work and the properties that I developed," he said. "I never did any work in a spirit of deception. One day a jury will find me innocent." He refused to take questions.
While the indictment was not unexpected, given that the investigation had been public knowledge for at least five years, it nevertheless seemed certain to shake both the people of Arizona and the government here in Phoenix.
Likewise, it seemed likely that the Governor's standing in the polls, already bouncing on the bottom, would fall even further and that calls for his resignation, heard periodically in the past, would increase.
It has been less than a decade since another Arizona Governor, Evan Mecham, was indicted while in office. He eventually beat the charges -- that he accepted an illegal campaign loan -- but not before he was impeached by the state legislature and driven from office.
Two weeks ago, in Arkansas, Gov. Jim Guy Tucker was convicted of charges growing out of the Whitewater investigation. Mr. Tucker, a Democrat, resigned from office to pursue an appeal.
Ms. Manella said that because of variables in Federal sentencing guidelines and presentencing reports, it would be impossible to say how many years, if any, Mr. Symington might serve or be fined if convicted on one or more of the 23 charges.
Under Federal law, Mr. Symington will be arraigned in the next 10 days.
"We will not be arresting the Governor," Ms. Manella said.
Because Federal officials were aware of the impact today's indictment would have on the state, she said, the Justice Department decided to take its time with the investigation, studying more than a million financial documents and interviewing several hundred witnesses.
"We were maniacally careful," she said.
Most of the real estate dealings referred to in the indictment took place before the Governor was elected in early 1991. But some, including those involving the pension funds, took place after he took office.
According to the indictment, Mr. Symington sought approval of millions of dollars in loans between mid-1986 and mid-1991 by submitting at least eight sets of false statements about his personal worth to various banks, pension funds and investment advisers.
"He created different versions of a personal financial statement that had the same 'as of' date but which contained different net worths," the indictment says. The personal financial statements "materially overstated assets, materially understated liabilities and materially overstated defendant's net worth," it says.
At one point, the indictment says, Mr. Symington was putting his net worth at about $12 million, when in fact he was almost $24 million in debt.
Mr. Symington made the false representations and omissions of facts, the indictment says "to create the false and misleading impression that he was a successful real estate developer with substantial financial resources available to him, and for the purpose of influencing lenders in their decisions to provide millions of dollars in construction and permanent loans and to extend loans and lines of credit."
As for the extortion charge, the indictment says Mr. Symington represented to the unions that had lent one of his developments $10 million that he would "take or withold official action" that might do them economic harm if they did not ease the terms of the loan.
Specifically, the indictment charges, Mr. Symington threatened to "steer away" tenants and prospective tenants, including Arizona State University, from rental properties controlled by the unions.
The indictment also says he stated in bankruptcy proceedings that he had $400,000 in equity in one piece of property and $1 million in equity in another when, in fact, the value in both instances was "substantially less."

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Up 0.8% in May But Were Below Expectations

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
Retail sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in May, the third advance in four months, the Government reported today, partly because of an increase in auto sales.
Some analysts doubt the pace can be sustained. 
 "Consumer debt is now at a record 20.8 percent of income, and borrowing is slowing," economists at Merrill Lynch & Company told the investment firm's clients. "Credit-card delinquencies and personal bankruptcies are rising."
They also said temporary forces that increased spending in recent months -- a boom in mortgage refinancing, capital gains, early tax refunds -- were receding. As a result, the Merrill Lynch economists said, "we expect spending to slow in the second half."
Indeed, the eight-tenths of 1 percent increase in May was below the 1 percent that economists had expected. And excluding auto sales, the May increase was just three-tenths of 1 percent.
There are indications that job growth may already be moderating. The Labor Department said today that new claims for jobless benefits rose last week for a second week.
But the Commerce Department reported today that consumers remained active in May, when an unexpected 348,000 new jobs were created, increasing retail sales to a seasonally adjusted $205.5 billion from $203.9 billion a month earlier. Retail sales represent about one-third of the nation's economic activity.
The Commerce report also showed April sales were down just one-tenth of 1 percent, despite a 3.8 percent drop in motor vehicles. The department originally estimated that April sales fell three-tenths of 1 percent.
Sales in May were 5.5 percent above those a year earlier.
Auto sales, which account for about one-fourth of all sales, rebounded in May with a 2.1 percent increase.
Reflecting a strong housing market, sales of furniture and other home furnishings were up 1.6 percent. Purchases of building materials, hardware and garden supplies jumped 2.5 percent.
Over all, sales rose 1.9 percent on durable goods -- items expected to last more than three years -- erasing a 1.8 percent loss a month earlier.
Nondurable goods sales were unchanged in May after rising 1 percent a month earlier.
Department stores posted a 1.2 percent increase in sales on top of a 1.4 percent gain in April. Sales at apparel stores were up one-tenth of 1 percent and at drugstores nine-tenths of 1 percent. Receipts at gasoline stations rose four-tenths of 1 percent, but analysts said that increase was partly a result of rising prices.
Sales at grocery stores dropped five-tenths of 1 percent and at restaurants and bars eight-tenths of 1 percent.
The Labor Department report said new claims for unemployment insurance rose by 6,000 last week to a seasonally adjusted 360,000, highest since 372,000 in the week ended April 20. Claims had risen by 9,000 a week earlier.
As a result, the four-week moving average rose by 2,000, to 351,000, also the second consecutive increase after falling steadily from 394,250 at the end of March. Many analysts consider the less-volative four-week average a more accurate measure of labor conditions.

HEADLINE: Turkey Ponders Its Shift in Fortunes

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 12

 BODY:
When the Foreign Minister of Kyrgyzstan met with her Turkish counterpart at a recent international gathering, she asked him a question so painful and so blunt that it made front-page news in Turkey.
"When we got our independence, you gave us inspiration," said Rosa Otunbaeva, the minister from Kyrgyzstan, in Central Asia. "Turkey was our horizon. When we looked at Turkey, we thought we would one day be like you." 
 And then with tears in her eyes, she blurted out, "What has happened to you?"
This emotional conversation, retold to the newspaper Hurriyet by Turkey's Foreign Minister, Emre Gonensay, captured a mood shared by many Turks these days as they try to understand what has gone wrong with their Government, their politics and their ambitions to be a major player in a trouble-prone region.
Fehmi Koru, a newspaper columnist, recalled a 1993 speech by former President Turgut Ozal: "He said that Turkey in 10 years would be one of the 15 major countries in the world. Now if anyone heard that argument, they would just laugh. People have lost that confidence in themselves."
If three years ago Turkey seemed the model of a Western-looking, secular state that could lead the way for the Muslim republics of the former Soviet Union, its image today is quite different.
An ugly political stalemate has paralyzed important domestic initiatives, further damaging an economy already hit with double-digit inflation; a harsh war against a Kurdish insurrection in the southeast is no closer to an end, and Turkey's relations with Greece and now with Arab states have hit new lows.
"A lot of Western capitals are looking at Turkey with amazement and anxiety, wondering how seriously to take its crisis," said a Western diplomat. "But Turkey is a country that cannot afford not to be taken seriously."
It has been nine months now since Turkey had an effective government, a period that has been punctuated by two resignations, one round of elections and a cycle of back-room negotiations that have gone on so long that they have now begun to repeat themselves.
The crisis began last fall when Prime Minister Tansu Ciller, an American-educated economist, resigned after the collapse of her ruling coalition. In elections in December, an Islamic party took the lead for the first time in the history of the 73-year-old Turkish republic, throwing down a challenge so daunting that it has effectively paralyzed Turkey's fractured political center.
Now after the collapse of another weak government, Necmettin Erbakan, the leader of the Islamic Welfare Party, is once again coaxing his opponents into a partnership that each one, at some point in the past, has denounced as a dangerous precedent for Turkey's secular state.
This time he comes to the table with an even stronger political hand: recent municipal by-elections showed the Welfare Party getting more than 33 percent of the vote, compared with the 21.6 percent it won in the December national election. But his best card is the dismal performance of Turkey's two main center-right politicians -- Mrs. Ciller and Mesut Yilmaz, her foe whose three-month-old Government finally sank last week.
This performance, coupled with three continuing investigations into Mrs. Ciller's personal finances, has only reinforced widespread disgust with Turkey's mainstream political parties and increased the popularity of the Welfare Party.
As the political crisis drags on, the establishment's fear of the Welfare Party is slowly ebbing. Business leaders have signaled a new willingness to consider a government that includes the Welfare Party, and even the powerful Turkish military, which vigorously opposes any erosion of the secular state, has sent at least one conciliatory message.
But there are still deep doubts about the Welfare Party among Turkey's Westernized elite, doubts that put their democratic ideals squarely in conflict with their dedication to secularism.
"If the Welfare Party becomes a coalition partner, as a democrat I have to respect it, but it could be very painful," said a journalist who asked not to be identified. "It would be very sad after 73 years to surrender the Turkish republic to an Islamic party."
Political experts differ about the Welfare Party's long-term ambitions, and its ability, within a coalition government, to change Turkey's position as a staunch member of the Western alliance. Mr. Erbakan's own views offer little clue since they are constantly changing: in a recent interview in a Turkish newspaper he said he would not oppose Turkey's continued membership in NATO, or even its recent customs union agreement with the European Union, a different stance from the one he struck during his campaign in December.
But he has been consistently critical of Turkey's recently signed military pact with Israel. For many Muslims inside and outside Turkey, the five-year agreement with Israel is an act of betrayal and a symptom of policies that push Turkey away from the Islamic world toward an unsympathetic West.
Few doubt that the Welfare Party's political influence is on the rise, whether they make it into this government or wait for new elections to improve their standing in Parliament.
"Any solution without the Welfare Party will not live long, and will only strengthen the Welfare Party," said Erol Yarar, president of Musiad, a Muslim business association that represents 2,200 small and medium-sized companies, many of them Welfare Party backers. "Islamic issues are already being recognized by all parties, and you can say that Islamic issues will become more pronounced."
But there are some who fear that it will take Turkey's pro-Western establishment too long to come to terms with a changing political reality, wasting time the country can ill afford.
"We have lost many things in the last year, and if we cannot form a stable government now, we will suffer gravely," said Mr. Koru. "It is up to the establishment to find a way out of the situation. If they do not, they will have failed, and they will have to accept that fact."

HEADLINE: Colombia's Leader, Cleared by Congress, Still Isn't in the Clear

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, June 13

 BODY:
Although Congress has cleared President Ernesto Samper of charges that Cali drug dealers financed his election, the Colombian leader faces an uncertain future. The threat of impeachment has been lifted, but calls for his resignation remain.
The 111-to-43 vote late Wednesday night supported the 45-year-old President by a greater margin than expected. But rather than strengthening his hand, it underscored the gap between opinions in Congress and among the public. Polls show that a majority of Colombians believe the President is guilty, though they divide evenly on whether he should step down. 
 With Colombians complaining of a lack of depth in the investigation, the congressional debate appears to have done little to help them lay to rest their doubts about Mr. Samper.
"We're in the same place we were three months ago, or six months ago, or even on the day after the 1994 elections," said Juan Tokatlian, a political scientist at the National University here. "The crisis continues."
The President is expected to turn his efforts toward extending the congressional vote of confidence into a broad social one.
In a televised address tonight, he called Wednesday "one of the best days in these times" and praised the congressional investigation as thorough and unbiased. "Colombians can sleep in peace tonight knowing that they have an honest President," he said.
He pledged to propose tighter laws against money laundering, to increase penalties for organized crime and to promote state financing of election campaigns.
Leading business and industrial groups, facing forecasts of an impending recession, said today that despite his congressional backing, Mr. Samper lacked the "conditions of governability," meaning political legitimacy and support.
Business and civic leaders held anti-Samper meetings in Colombia's major business centers that drew unexpectedly large crowds. They pledged to bring citizens' complaints against congressional representatives who decided against passing the charges on to the Senate.
The Supreme Court here ruled recently that deputies who relied on political expediency, rather than the evidence, to judge Mr. Samper could be prosecuted for "neglect of duty," though the court did not say how the court would make such a determination.
The debate, during which 76 representatives spoke, cleared Mr. Samper of charges that included illicit enrichment, fraud, falsification of documents and obstruction of justice in connection with some $6.1 million that his election campaign was said to have solicited from Cali drug dealers.
In addition to its enduring turmoil on the domestic front, Colombia also faces a further souring of relations with the United States.
The State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said the decision by the Colombian Congress "leaves unanswered many questions regarding pervasive narcotrafficker influence on Colombia's institutions," adding, "It will not resolve the resultant crisis of confidence."
In March, the United States placed Colombia on a list of nations that failed to cooperate fully in fighting fight drug trafficking.
In the weeks leading up to the vote on Wednesday, American officials said they were considering sanctions against Colombia that could include revoking preferential trade tariffs or landing rights for Colombian planes.

HEADLINE: Trade Group Will Decide Kodak Case

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
As expected, United States trade officials said today that they would file three complaints with the World Trade Organization contending that the Japanese Government had colluded with the Fuji Photo Film Company to exclude film made by the Eastman Kodak Company and other foreign producers.
"Our comprehensive investigation of the Japanese film market has shown that the Government of Japan built, supported and tolerated a market structure that thwarts foreign competition, and in which exclusionary business practices are commonplace," a deputy United States trade representative, Ira S. Shapiro, said. 
 By going to the World Trade Organization, the United States will forgo, for the moment, using the threat of trade sanctions, a weapon that has been sharply criticized by other countries in previous trade disputes between Washington and Tokyo.
Today's announcement sets in motion a 60-day period of consultations between the United States and Japan mediated by the Geneva-based trade organization before the actual filing of the complaints. On Wednesday, United States trade officials suggested that Japan could change its mind during that period.
"What you are seeing the U.S. Government do today is they're using several tools or strategies to force the Government of Japan to negotiate" on this issue, said Charles Smith, Kodak's director of corporate media affairs.
The action does not go as far as Kodak had sought. The company, the leading American film manufacturer, wanted Washington to threaten sanctions against Japan, fearing that a complaint could be tied up at the trade organization indefinitely.
Over the last few months, however, when it became clear that the United States favored taking the dispute to the international trade group, Kodak backed away from this stance and welcomed any action.
"We got a positive determination that the Government of Japan has acted unreasonably and tolerated unfair practices for decades," Mr. Smith said. "We are happy with the total strategy being employed."
Shares of Kodak rose $1.50 today, to $79.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Fuji American depository receipts, traded on Nasdaq, rose 25 cents, to $30.75.
A lawyer for Fuji, Bill Barringer, said of the move: "We are displeased because we believe the facts presented don't justify W.T.O. action; it justifies doing nothing. However, it's an alternative we have said is acceptable. We will prevail if there is neutral fact-finding."
Kodak contends that Fuji, in collusion with the Japanese Government, blocked access to the Japanese film market through price controls, illegal rebates and intimidation. Fuji says that there is no collusion and that Kodak has full access to the Japanese photo film market.
Japan's film and photographic paper market is valued at $2.8 billion annually. Kodak estimates that the barriers in this market have cost it at least $5.6 billion in revenue since 1975.
Kodak has a 10 percent share of Japan's photo film market with sales last year of more than $1 billion. Fuji has approximately the same share of the United States market, while each company has a 70 percent share of its home market.

HEADLINE: Few Big Ripples Are Seen For the Global Economy

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
When a huge international financial institution like the Sumitomo Corporation announces that one of its traders has cost the company $1.8 billion in trading losses, Americans naturally ask how might this affect them. The answer seems to be that the impact will be negligible.
This is the third time in less than 18 months that a rogue trader has cost his employer $1 billion or more, and apart from the astonishment, the first two losses failed to leave much of a dent. A major British bank collapsed and various individuals were hurt, but national economies moved on basically unscathed. 
 "I don't believe this will have any noticeable affect on the United States economy," said Martin Bailey, a member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers.
Sumitomo announced late yesterday that unauthorized trades over a 10-year period by a former copper trader, Yasuo Hamanaka, had cost the company $1.8 billion. Sumitomo owns businesses around the world, including banks in the United States that lend money to corporations, but do not engage in retail banking.
"There can always be a panicky reaction to anything named Sumitomo," said Alan Blinder, a Princeton University economist, referring to the bank's huge size, "but that would be irrational."
Copper prices fell after Sumitomo made its announcement, and that drop might have resulted in trading losses for some commodity dealers who held copper contracts. But copper prices have been falling for a while, and the latest drop only exacerbated this trend.
The main effect of Sumitomo's losses, if there is any at all, might be to undercut public confidence in financial institutions, said Joel Prakken of Lawrence H. Meyer & Associates in St. Louis, an economic consulting and forecasting firm.
Sumitomo's failure to detect the trading losses sooner might prompt some Americans to wonder how well their local financial institutions handle oversight. That concern, in the unlikely event that it arises, might translate into temporary drops in the stock prices of some banks, or slightly higher interest rates for money they seek to borrow.
But Sumitomo is only the latest billion-dollar-plus loss for a major institution. Nicholas W. Leeson, a trader based in Singapore for Barings P.L.C., left the venerable British bank short by $1.3 billion in February 1995. The bank was forced to sell itself to the ING Group of The Netherlands, and the British economy was unaffected. Toshihide Iguchi, who worked for Daiwa Bank Ltd. in New York, left his employer short $1.1 billion, Daiwa disclosed last October, with no noticeable effect on the economy or the financial markets.
"Your first inclination is to say, 'My goodness, how could one individual have control over so much?' " Mr. Prakken said. "But traders regularly take big positions, and $1.8 billion is not very much in the huge flow of money through the world's markets."

HEADLINE: Dallas Opening Southwest's First Rail Transit

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 13

 BODY:
After decades of feuds and false starts in an automobile-addicted state that remains the hub of the world's petroleum industry, Dallas plans to introduce the first modern rail transit line in the Southwest on Friday.
The Dallas system, planned back when rail transit was seen as a nostrum for every urban problem, makes a late debut, with other cities sometimes disenchanted with the returns on their huge investments. 
 While some Dallasites hope their fellows will climb aboard and leave more highway space for them, few can see themselves abandoning their cars or trucks.
"It's probably a waste of money," said Paul Nadelman, a stockbroker who was among those learning to dodge trains on practice runs along a transit mall downtown. "It's kind of neat to see the trains go back and forth, but Dallas isn't New York," he said. And he, for one, needs his car to see clients, he said.
The carless, however, say the train will save them from some of the circuitous transfers they have to make on buses. "I'm so excited," said Ayesha El-Amin, waiting at a combination bus and train stop in the Oak Cliff area south of downtown to begin her long commute to Richardson, a northern suburb. "Once it gets going, people will appreciate it more."
At $860 million for a 20-mile line expected to attract only about 7,000 new transit riders, plus 26,000 switching from buses, critics love to calculate how many BMW's each of those new riders would receive if the money were divided among them.
The 11.2-mile section that Dallas Area Rapid Transit, or DART, is opening this week includes the downtown transit mall, paved with bricks, and two branches into mostly black and Hispanic neighborhoods south of downtown. Politicians from these areas challenged earlier plans for concentrating the rail system in white neighborhoods to the north that have more traffic tie-ups but lower proportions of transit riders.
Along the transit mall today, the light rail cars -- which look like sleek, youthful trolley cars back from a stay at the health spa -- glided past with a whirr and a few clicks instead of the screech and clatter of older systems. They brazenly passed in front of Thanksgiving Tower, where once, reputedly, oil barons like J. R. Ewing, and still various Hunt brothers hatch their plans for feeding the nation's craving for gasoline and oil.
Even in rush hour, trains will be three cars long. Off-peak, they will be shorter. Train tickets, with free bus transfers, are one dollar.
Dallas's transit plans went in for some weight reduction after a 1988 referendum, when voters rejected a high-capacity New York-style system with a downtown subway. The DART Lite plan that followed had only enough money for the transit mall downtown.
Today, transit police tried to keep trains, traffic and pedestrians safely separate. They blew their whistles, waved their arms and dressed down jay-walkers and traffic violators in tones otherwise reserved for serial murderers caught in the act. "I've been driving this road for a hundred years, making this left turn," complained one motorist who was pulled over after cutting across the tracks.
"Well, now you make this left turn and you're going to get killed," the officer shot back.
Not to worry, Mayor Ron Kirk said in an interview. "We'll learn," he said. "We're not the cultural or educational wasteland that some back East think we are. Most of us can recognize foreign objects on wheels that are larger than Chevrolet Suburbans. If we can operate heavy farm machinery, I assure you we can co-exist with trains."
The Dallas Morning News has helped out with daily "DART Smarts," or tips for novice straphangers, including the crucial differences between buses and trains. "The trains stop at every station," read one of the tips. "So unlike with DART buses, there is no need to signal the train operator."
Dallas joins St. Louis, Sacramento, Denver and Los Angeles in embracing rail projects over recent years to deal with problems like pollution, traffic congestion and decaying downtowns. The Clinton Administration has raised annual transit financing by more than a third, to about $5 billion, with tentative backing for a new light rail line through northern New Jersey.
"Why?" asked Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena, stuck in traffic coming into Dallas tonight from the airport. "The evidence is what's happening to me right now. People have realized you need other options besides the automobile."
But many academics, citing projects like the one in Los Angeles, say the trains have had a poor record of bringing urban revivals or attracting as many riders as expected.
"It's an 1890's idea and it's an 1890's technology," from the era before cars and urban sprawl, said Peter Gordon, associate dean of the University of Southern California School of Urban and Regional Planning. "To think this is the kind of thing we ought to be building now as cities are expanding and spreading out is crazy."
In Dallas, home to many of the nation's largest developers, real-estate interests have been consistent rail transit supporters. But downtown Dallas still has one of the highest office vacancy rates in the nation, with few signs that the yellow, white and black trains converging there will bring more tenants. Neither have speculators snapped up land around the rail stations as they still tend to do along new highways.
Houston has repeatedly considered but backed away from rail projects, relying instead on bus and car-pool lanes along the highways. Austin is toying with a plan for economical diesel trains only.
Dallas, aided by a 1 percent sales tax for mass transit that voters approved in 1983, plans to keep building. All 20 miles of the first phase, including a branch extending to the north, are expected to be open by May next year. By 2010, Dallas and its suburbs plan to have 53 miles of light rail, 98 miles of bus and car-pool lanes and 37 miles of commuter rail lines, including links to Fort Worth and the Dallas-Forth Worth Airport. The total cost would be $4.1 billion.
Ultimately, said Mayor Kirk, Dallasites will emerge from their autos. "I am reasonably confident," he said, "that once the metro area gets a firsthand look at the efficiency of transit, the debate is going to be, "When do you get to my neighborhood?"

HEADLINE: No Need to Abandon German Economic Model

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Klaus Friedrich (Op-Ed, June 10) writes: "Social peace and order may be worth a lot. But are they worth the price of stagnation?" Given the German experience, the answer is yes. 
 It is far from obvious that German comity is sufficiently robust to survive the intensified conflict Mr. Friedrich prescribes. Germans, especially Easterners, are already angry because of the perceived collapse of social equity, and the conflict over immigrants is not confined to a skinhead fringe. To exacerbate these conflicts by promoting greater competition, more unequal income distribution and the capitalism that is pushing Russia back toward authoritarianism is too risky.
 
CRAIG H. APPEL
Cambridge, Mass., June 10, 1996

HEADLINE: Weighing Political Words and Political Action;
On Medicare Costs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is specious for Speaker Newt Gingrich to argue (letter, June 9) that the Republican Medicare proposal covers the costs of the program. He reaches this conclusion by using the Consumer Price Index to calculate the inflation rate for the program.
But the Congressional Budget Office recognizes that factors like advances in technology and improved services help cause medical costs to rise at a faster rate than than the overall price index would suggest. 
 The budget office projected last month that "over the next decade, Federal spending per enrollee in Medicare and Medicaid will increase at more that twice the rate of inflation, as measured by the consumer price index for all urban consumers."
While the G.O.P. plan provides for some per capita increases in the Medicare program, these increases fall far short of what is needed to preserve currently provided services.
 
WALTER C. FURST
Washington, June 10, 1996
