HEADLINE: U.S. Industrial Production and Business Inventories Rise

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
American industries increased production for a second consecutive month in May and businesses showed signs of rebuilding depleted inventories, a move that could mean even greater output and more jobs.
"The economy clearly has rebounded from its weakness last year," said Gary Thayer, an economist with A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. 
 The Federal Reserve reported today that output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, the same increase as revised numbers showed for April. The Fed originally reported an increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent in April.
Many analysts had expected production to expand about five-tenths of 1 percent in May.
The advance was only the third so far in 1996 in the manufacturing sector, which has been struggling for most of a year.
There have been signs it may be shaking off its lethargy. Excluding the volatile transportation category, factory orders rose 1.9 percent in April -- the most in nearly two years and the third rise in four months.
The central bank also said that the nation's industries were operating at 83.2 percent of capacity in April, up from 82.9 percent a month earlier.
The rate suggested a lack of production bottlenecks that could cause shortages and higher prices.
But Elliott Platt, an economist with the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation in New York, contended that "despite the increase, capacity utilization remains a safe distance from any rate that may create manufacturing bottlenecks and ignite inflation."
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said that business inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April after posting a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent in March, the first since December. They totaled a seasonally adjusted $984.1 billion, up from $980.1 billion in March.
The increase was in line with analyst expectations. Many believe that businesses, after shrinking overbuilt stockpiles in recent months, will begin rebuilding them to meet anticipated demand. If so, that would set the stage for greater production and possibly more jobs.
"We had several quarters of inventory correction and we are now at the point where the economy is doing better and businesses are feeling comfortable holding bigger stockpiles," Mr. Thayer of A. G. Edwards said.
Sales shot up 1 percent in April, the third straight advance, to $711.2 billion from $704.3 billion.
The inventory-to-sales ratio was 1.38, down from 1.39 in March and the lowest since 1.37 in December 1994. The ratio meant it would take 1.38 months to exhaust stockpiles at the April sales rate.
Factory inventories were unchanged in April while those at retail outlets edged up one-tenth of 1 percent. Wholesaler stockpiles rose 1.3 percent.
Sales by manufacturers shot up 1.7 percent and sales by wholesalers were up 1.1 percent. While retailers sales slipped one-tenth of 1 percent in April, the Government reported on Thursday that they rebounded eight-tenths of 1 percent a month later.
In its report, the Fed said production at the nation's utilities surged 3.1 percent, more than erasing a 1.8 percent loss in April as warmer weather caused many consumers to use air conditioners.
But excluding utilities, output still rose five-tenths of 1 percent.
Manufacturing output rose five-tenths of 1 percent, slower than April's 1.1 percent advance, which reflected a rebound from the losses during a strike at the General Motors Corporation in March.

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Filing in Case of an Israeli Bank

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
An investor in a failed Israeli bank filed for personal bankruptcy in United States Bankruptcy Court in Los Angeles yesterday, listing more than $212 million in debts, much of it claimed by Israel.
The investor, Erwin Sussman, 70, was one of a number of foreign investors who helped capitalize the North American Bank Ltd. in 1977. Baruch C. Cohen, Mr. Sussman's lawyer, placed the size of Mr. Sussman's investment at $7 million. 
 The bank foundered in the aftermath of Israel's 1983 banking crisis, and was taken over by the Bank of Israel in August 1985.
The failure has prompted a rash of lawsuits and countersuits by the Israeli Government and by Mr. Sussman and the other foreign investors in the bank.
Among other things, the Israeli Government has contended that Mr. Sussman and the bank's other foreign directors were personally liable for North American's losses, even though the bank was managed by Israelis.
A number of prominent foreigners who invested in the bank were also named in the Israeli lawsuits, including David Goan of Switzerland, whose family is prominent in Jewish organizations; Joel Herzog, Mr. Goan's brother-in-law and the son of Chaim Herzog, a former President of Israel; Joseph Nakash, founder of the Jordache clothing empire, and Norman Allen, a wealthy investor from Birmingham, Mich. Mr. Sussman, a Swedish citizen, is a legal permanent resident of California.
Three Israeli lawsuits against Mr. Sussman are still outstanding, but have been put on hold and cannot proceed unless permission is granted by the bankruptcy court.
Mr. Cohen, Mr. Sussman's lawyer, said yesterday that the status of Israel's claims against the other defendants was not clear.
Israel is represented by the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.
A meeting of Mr. Sussman's creditors is scheduled for July 17. If an objection to the bankruptcy filing is not filed within 60 days from that meeting, the debt in question will be discharged.
A telephone call to Douglas Adler, a Skadden, Arps attorney involved in the case, was not returned.

HEADLINE: A Sumitomo Loss Felt Round the World;
Principles Fall Victim To Practice

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 14

 BODY:
The business principles of the Sumitomo Corporation, framed and hung on the wall in many of the giant trading company's far-flung outposts, warn against speculation. "Under no circumstances," they state, should the company "pursue easy gains or act imprudently."
Yet in an announcement that roiled commodities markets, Sumitomo said Thursday that it expected to suffer a loss of $1.8 billion -- equivalent to almost 10 times last year's net profit -- from what were apparently highly speculative and imprudent trades made by one of its executives on the world copper market over 10 years. 
 The loss shocked Japan, not only because of its magnitude but also because it involved Sumitomo, one of the country's oldest and proudest companies and one that is considered the most conservatively managed of Japan's trading giants. Sumitomo is generally financially more solid than its rivals, more timid in venturing into new businesses and longer on bureaucracy.
"Sumitomo is ridiculously rigid in control," said a businessman who has spent his career at a rival trading company. "We are always laughing at Sumitomo. They are not a trading firm. They are like an administrative company, trying to control the entrepreneurial spirit."
Still, the announcement, coming less than a year after Daiwa Bank Ltd. disclosed a $1.1 billion loss caused by a rogue trader of United States Treasury bonds, is likely to raise anew questions about the adequacy of internal controls at Japanese companies, which often tend to place a great trust on individuals at the expense of formal checks and balances. At the same time, since published reports five years ago raised questions about Sumitomo's copper trading practices, regulators are certain to give close scrutiny to the company's contention that the huge losses went undetected for so long.
Questions might also arise about whether it is possible for anyone to adequately manage Japan's leading trading companies, which are the biggest companies in the world and have been diversifying in recent years into numerous businesses that have little connection to one another.
Sumitomo had revenues of more than $150 billion in the fiscal year that ended March 31. It has more than 200 operating units around the world and trades in thousands of products, from pork to pipe, and aerospace equipment to fertilizer. It also invests in areas as diverse as oil production in Vietnam, steel and solar-cell manufacturing in the United States and industrial park development in Indonesia.
"They know their business is spreading out," said Tomoyasu Kato, an analyst for the Nomura Research Institute, talking about the big trading companies. "They are now strengthening control and management."
Sumitomo executives have not disclosed much about the motives and mode of operation of Yasuo Hamana ka, the 48-year-old head of its copper trading operations, who it said incurred the losses through unauthorized trading. Mr. Hamanaka was dismissed on Thursday.
But there do seem to be striking similarities between the Sumitomo and Daiwa Bank incidents.
In both cases, the losses were attributed to essentially one rogue trader acting over a decade or more.
Sumitomo executives said at a news conference today that it appeared that Mr. Hamanaka had started his unauthorized speculation to cover losses he incurred trading for the company's account. This was the same motive attributed to Toshihide Iguchi, the trader of Treasury bonds who was held responsible for Daiwa Bank's loss.
Another striking similarity: Both Mr. Hamanaka and Mr. Iguchi apparently handled the processing needed to enter their trades on the company books, a job that ideally should be done by another person. Without this crucial check in the system, the two traders could cover up their actions by falsifying accounts.
And while most people are rotated frequently in Japanese companies, both Mr. Iguchi and Mr. Hamanaka, who traded copper for 15 years, stayed in their posts for a long time, developing expertise that seemingly made them indispensable and made it difficult for others to challenge their actions.
To be sure, Mr. Iguchi was a little-known executive in the New York outpost of the Osaka-based Daiwa. Mr. Hamanaka was known throughout the world among copper traders. He operated in a core business of Sumitomo in Tokyo and was a big enough star that Tomiichi Akiyama, the company president, took time to meet him some years ago.
Sumitomo informed authorities in the United States and Britain within days after Mr. Hamanaka is said to have confessed on June 5, although it said it had suspicions about him from early May. Daiwa took about 10 weeks to tell American regulators that it suspected a big loss from Mr. Iguchi's trading, incurring a wrath that led to its American operations being shut down. Earlier this year, Daiwa Bank pleaded guilty in New York to charges that it covered up the trading losses and it agreed to pay $340 million in fines.
Mr. Akiyama said at today's news conference that Sumitomo's copper division was audited frequently but that Mr. Hamanaka's trades were done off the books and the accounting falsified, so it was difficult to detect the unauthorized trades. But he said Sumitomo's systems of checks and balances would be reviewed.
"The incident is regrettable as it happened despite Sumitomo's principle of placing a priority on trust," he said.
Only last month Sumitomo was embarrassed when a subsidiary announced it had suffered a loss of more than $70 million from the forging of its prepaid magnetic cards used to play the gambling game of pachinko.
One executive at Sumitomo said both the speculative copper trading and the involvement in the mob-connected pachinko industry reflected an undesirable move away from core businesses. He said company employees could not fathom how the $1.8 billion loss was possible with all departments auditing themselves twice a year. "This should never happen at Sumitomo," he said.
Analysts said Sumitomo would be hurt but not crippled by the loss from the copper trading. The company has about $4 billion in unrealized gains from securities it holds and can sell some of them to cover the loss, they said.
Still, the loss will knock 27 percent off the shareholders' equity, said Kota Nakako, an analyst in Tokyo with SBC Warburg, and could make it more difficult for the company to invest in new businesses at a time when it is trying to diversify into such areas as cable television and satellite broadcasting. "The company's risk-taking ability will be reduced," he said.
Sumitomo's bond rating, the highest among the trading companies at Aa3 by Moody's, is also likely to fall.
Mr. Kato of Nomura Research said there is a chance the loss could grow because Sumitomo might still have large positions in the copper market and would probably be vulnerable if the metal's price declines further.
Mr. Hamanaka was sometimes called "Mr. 5 Percent," because Sumitomo controlled as much as 5 percent of the world trade in copper. Sumitomo, which is involved in copper mining as well, buys copper to supply to customers that use it to make wire, automobile equipment and other products.
It was to hedge its risks from these transactions that the company engaged in copper futures trading in London, a spokeswoman for Sumitomo said.
Copper is, in a sense, the core of Sumitomo, which is based in Osaka but also has a big headquarters in Tokyo. The trading house was started early in the 17th century by Masatomo Sumitomo, who learned a new technique for refining copper that allowed silver to be extracted, greatly increasing profits. In 1690, the company opened a copper mine that became the base of its business until the late 1800's, when the company began branching out into a conglomerate known as a zaibatsu.
During the American occupation of Japan following World War II, Sumitomo and the other zaibatsu, particularly Mitsubishi and Mitsui, were broken up and the influence of the founding families diminished.
The Sumitomo Corporation is still at the core of the Sumitomo Group, a loosely affiliated collection of several dozen companies, known as a keiretsu, whose members include Sumitomo Bank, the steelmaker Sumitomo Metal Industries and the electronics giant NEC.
But in recent years, the traditional trading role has been diminishing. Japan's big companies can now import and export on their own and no longer have need for a middleman.
To stay alive, the trading companies have diversified, investing in a host of businesses to become manufacturers as well as traders. They have also turned to helping foreign companies penetrate Japan's market.
Risk-averse Sumitomo has been slower to diversify than its competitors and is still heavily dependent on trading in metals and other materials. But in the last few years, it has become more aggressive.
It is in a joint venture with Tele-Communications Inc., the largest cable television operator in the United States, to develop cable television and programming services in Japan. It owns three minimills making steel in the United States.
In copper, it opened a big mine in Chile in 1994 in a joint venture with the Sumitomo Metal Mining Company and the Phelps Dodge Mining Company of the United States. It is developing a large copper and gold mine in Indonesia with Newmont Gold of the United States. It also has mining interests in Arizona.
 
At the Start, a Family Smelting Business
 Long before the trading of Yasuo Hamanaka turned the world's attention to the copper market, the history of the Sumitomo Corporation was being written. The conglomerate, which had revenues of $150 billion in its most recent fiscal year, dates to the 16th century.
 Masatomo Sumitomo, left, who lived from 1585 to 1652, is considered the spiritual founder of the Sumitomo Corporation.
 In his first career, as a Buddhist priest, Masatomo Sumitomo wrote about how to conduct commercial activity. In 1891, his writings, lower left, were used as the basis of the company's business principles.
 Article 1 explains the necessity of acting in good faith in order to maintain another party's trust. Article 2 urges that social trends be studied to meet social changes with active responses.
 And Article 3, which is posted at many Sumitomo outposts, advises against being attracted to easy profits or hastily drawn to the promise of profits before fully investigationg the commercial viability of business ventures.
 Sumitomo's history can be traced to the lzumiya copper business established in Kyoto in 1590 by Riemon Sogo, Masatomo Sumitomo's brother-in-law. Until the late 16th century, copper ore was exported with its silver intact. The Sumitomo family is credited with revolutionizing Japan's copper market by learning Western smelting techniques.
 The family business was moved to Osaka, and in 1690 the family opened the Besshi Copper Mine, which was still profitable up to ther early 20th century.
 In 1897, the House of Sumitomo established the Sumitomo Copper Rolling Works to manufacture bare copper wire and by 1900 the company was making insulated wire. As early as 909, Sumitomo was testing cables for telecommunications.
 Nowadays, Sumitomo has more than 200 operating units around the world and trades in thousands of products, from pork to pipe, and aerospace equipment to fertilizer.
 It also invests in areas as diverse as oil production in Vietnam, steel and solar-cell manufacturing in the United States and industrial park development in Indonesia.

HEADLINE: Russian Campaign Ends but TV Films Are Telling Voters of Communist Horrors

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Saturday, June 15

 BODY:
After a frantic flurry of last-minute political ads, the Russian presidential campaign came to an abrupt halt at midnight on Friday.
Until the polls close on Sunday night, candidates are forbidden to make speeches or put up new posters, and all commercials on radio and television must be discontinued. 
 Instead, a weeklong anti-Communist television extravaganza will reach its peak. Television has been the biggest weapon in President Boris N. Yeltsin's campaign, and he is intent on squeezing his message into every last second of the air time he virtually controls.
"Burnt by the Sun," the harrowing 1995 Oscar-winning film by Nikita Mikhalkov about Stalin's terror, will be shown at 6 P.M. election eve on ORT, Russia's largest network.
Today's other TV highlights include "In Order to Survive," a 1992 thriller about the ties between organized crime and the Communist Party, on ORT. RTR, the second largest state-controlled network, will show "The Run," a movie based on Mikhail Bulgakov's novel about atrocities during the Revolution. NTV, the privately owned channel, will show a 1993 bleakly satirical film called "Stalin's Testament."
In contrast to the Communist horror movies, Mr. Yeltsin's own posters and television commercials radiate serenity and stability. But that optimism clashes with the mood of many viewers and an atmosphere of dark anxiety and alarm.
In recent days, a bomb went off in the Moscow subway, the Deputy Mayor of Moscow was wounded in an assassination attempt, and the Mayor of Zhukovsky, a small town near Moscow, was slain. With worries about other bombs and civil unrest, security all over Moscow is iron-tight.
The United States Embassy in Moscow issued a warning to American citizens to "avoid crowds" and "exercise caution," so as to not "inadvertently become caught up in a demonstration or other activity."
As they made their final pitches on Friday night, all the candidates stressed calm and quiet strength.
Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist candidate, who has not bought any paid TV time, took advantage of his remaining free television time to reassure viewers that he will not take the country back to Soviet rule. In one ad, shown on the St. Petersburg channel, Mr. Zyuganov staged a mock interview in which he calmly answered questions about confiscating private property and reopening the gulag.
"They are just trying to scare people," he replied. "All those dachas and garden plots, people got them thanks to Soviet power. We're not going to take them away; we're going to try to lower rents."
A few minutes later, on ORT, the only network that reaches all across Russia, Mr. Zyuganov had a famous movie director make his final campaign pitch.
The director, Stanislav Gavarukhin, an ardent nationalist, spoke scornfully of the pop stars, actors and directors who have campaigned for Mr. Yeltsin. "They do it for the money," he said. "Shameless to use state money in this kind of campaign.
The Yeltsin campaign followed, with a reply by Mr. Mikhalkov, the film director, who spoke about the "dehumanization" under Communist rule while the screen flicked between images of Stalin and hysterical Soviet crowds.
The popularity of Aleksandr I. Lebed, a hero of the Afghan war and former general who is running as a law-and-order patriot, has been rising in the latest public opinion polls. On Friday night, he was shown walking across a verdant field and speaking sternly about the "bribery and corruption" that have undermined economic reform and placed a "criminal nomenklatura" in charge of the country.
General Lebed has been a harsh critic of Mr. Yeltsin, but behind the scenes he has been assiduously courted by the President's men, who are worried that the unpredictable ultranationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky could make a deal with Mr. Zyuganov after the first round and hope to enlist General Lebed.
In his hometown, Yekaterinburg, on Friday night, Mr. Yeltsin hinted that General Lebed could someday be his political heir. He told reporters that his successor is among the current crop of rivals, and then recited a Lebed campaign slogan, "I know such a man."
Mr. Yeltsin also said that in his second term he would initiate a major Cabinet shuffle and fill his team with "new faces, fresh ideas."
Mr. Yeltsin's ad campaign, vignettes of ordinary older Russians talking about themselves through a montage of old sepia-tinted family portraits, culminated this week with the finale -- Mr. Yeltsin talking about his teen-age years and his courtship, against a backdrop of old pictures and sentimental music.
Some analysts suspect the Yeltsin campaign's all-out media blitz could backfire.
"Our research shows that people don't like it; they see it as burdensome," said Nugzar Betaneli, director of the Sociology of Parliamentarianism Institute, a public opinion research institute. His institute's latest polls suggest that Mr. Yeltsin's lead in the first round is narrowing, and that Mr. Zyuganov may pull ahead on election day.
Mr. Zyuganov has complained bitterly that Mr. Yeltsin's blanket coverage rivals the propaganda machine of the Brezhnev era. Some Communist leaders argue that the anti-Communist movie festival will hurt Mr. Yeltsin more than them.
"Such tactics will work only with those voters who cannot remember Soviet power," said Anatoly I. Lukyanov, the former chairman of the Soviet Parliament who is now the elder statesman of the Russian Communist Party.
"For the older generation, it will have a reverse effect," he said. "They associate Soviet power with the victory over fascism, the first space flight, electropower stations. They felt there was a great country at their backs."

Zyuganov, the Communist, staged a mock interview in which he promised not to return to Soviet rule.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rebounds on Bond Rally After Falling in Earlier Trading

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rebounded from early declines yesterday as bond prices rallied after economic reports in the United States eased some concerns on inflation.
"The bond market came up, and people said, 'Fundamentally, there's nothing wrong with the dollar. Let's buy some cheap dollars,' " said Kevin Lawrie, manager of foreign exchange at the Mellon Bank. 
 The dollar often takes its cue from the Treasury market because international investors need dollars to buy United States bonds and other securities. Its sudden turnaround surprised some traders, and buoyed confidence that it would rise in coming days.
Bonds jumped after a Federal Reserve report on industrial production suggested that the economy was not expanding as fast as some traders had thought, reducing concerns that inflation would soon accelerate.
After falling sharply against the Japanese yen and German mark in Asian and European trading, the dollar ended higher against both currencies in late New York trading yesterday. The dollar was quoted at 109.12 yen, up from 108.75 yen on Thursday, and at 1.5272 marks, up from 1.5267 marks. The British pound rose to $1.5375 from $1.5347.
Earlier, the dollar slid as growing optimism that President Boris N. Yeltsin would finish first in tomorrow's election in Russia bolstered the German mark.
The prospect of political stability in Russia helps the mark because of the close economic ties between the two nations.
"There seems to be buying of marks ahead of the election based on the polls, though heaven knows how much you can trust Russian polls," said Richard Koss, currency strategist at MFR Inc., a money management and consulting firm.
The mark also benefited in early trading after a former British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, said, "The Bundesbank is horrified by the thought of Club Med countries being part of the single currency," Market News Service reported. Mr. Lawson, at a conference in Cannes, France, was referring to southern European nations.
Signs of turmoil in Europe's plan to adopt a single currency in 1999 help the mark because of concern that it will lose its status as Europe's linchpin currency if a single currency is formed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Law Near to Require Children's Programming
A rule calling for television stations to broadcast three hours a week of educational programs for children became a virtual certainty as James Quello, one of the Federal Communications Commission members who had been blocking the legislation, said he would drop his opposition. Mr. Quello agreed to a compromise under which an absolute minimum of three hours might not be required, if stations could demonstrate that they had performed a public service for children that was roughly equivalent. [11.]
 
Industrial Production Rises Again
Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, a bigger increase than analysts had expected. The jump in production was the second straight, and businesses also showed signs of rebuilding depleted inventories, a move that could mean even greater output and more jobs. [Page 33.]
 
Bankruptcy Filing by Investor
An investor in a failed Israeli bank filed for bankruptcy, listing more than $212 million in debts, much of it claimed by Israel. The concern, North American Bank, foundered in the aftermath of Israel's 1983 banking crisis, prompting a rash of suits. [33.]

VW to Receive G.M. Complaint
In the continuing legal battle between General Motors and Volkswagen, the German auto maker agreed to receive a civil complaint filed in Detroit by G.M. VW denies the charges, which include industrial espionage, and is seeking to have the case transferred to a German court, where punitive damages are traditionally not awarded in civil cases. [32.]
 
Silver and Gold Prices Rise
The prices of silver and gold ended sharply higher in New York trading after an early tumble that was prompted by concerns over Sumitomo's losses in the copper market. [41.]

Bond Rally Continues
The prices of Treasury bonds rose for a second session. The yield on the 30-year bond, which moves inversely to the price, fell to 7.08 percent from 7.13 percent. [44.]
 
Ford said that its USL Capital subsidiary would auction almost $1 billion in municipal bonds as part of Ford's plan to shed its nonautomotive finance operations. [32.]

Another Drop For Blue Chips
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.50 points, the fifth consecutive drop, ending the week down 47.66 at 5,649.45. Technology shares fell as warnings about earnings unnerved investors, driving down the Nasdaq composite index by 12.47 points, or 1.02 percent, to 1,213.18. [32.]
 
Harassment Said to Continue
Federal officials investigating charges of sexual harassment at the American unit of the Swedish pharmaceutical giant Astra said that sexual abuse was continuing there. The company said the Government had submitted nothing to support the charges during a court hearing. [33.]
 
Bias Seen in Promotions
An official of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has found that Texaco failed to promote some black employees because of their race. But Texaco said that the official did not consider the full scope of its promotion policies. [33.]

Volvo to Sell Pharmacia Shares
Volvo, the Swedish car maker, plans to cut its stake in Pharmacia & Upjohn, the pharmaceuticals giant, to 4.7 percent from 13.7 percent. [33.]
 
Goat: The Other Red Meat?
Consumption of goat meat is at an all-time high in New York City, largely because of immigrants from areas where it is a popular dish. A farmer in rural New York State, recognizing the potential profits, is urging others to start herds. [21.]
 
Concerns Over Wisconsin Plan
Four weeks after President Clinton endorsed Wisconsin's proposal to abolish welfare, Administration officials say they have doubts about some of its most important provisions. But the officials said they still believed that an agreement could be reached. [1.]

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Rise Again As Reports Help Ease Fears

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday for a second consecutive session, encouraged again by a report suggesting that economic growth was moderate enough to restrain inflation.
A week ago, the bond market was roiled by an employment report showing unexpected strength. The report raised fears that the economy was growing at a pace fast enough to compel the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates when its policy makers meet early next month. 
 But reports on Thursday, on retail sales, and yesterday, on industrial production, helped quell some of the fears.
"The employment shock is wearing off," said Ram Bhagavatula, chief financial economist at Citicorp Global Finance.
Patrick Dimick, Treasury market analyst at CS First Boston, agreed, saying, "The market traded as if it was less fearful of a Federal Reserve tightening."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 14/32 , to 8620/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 7.08 percent, from 7.13 percent on Thursday, and down from the 13-month high of 7.19 percent on Wednesday. For the week, the yield was up 6 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point.
Prices of shorter-term maturities also rose, driving the yield on the 2-year note down 5 basis points, to 6.26 percent, and the yield on the 10-year note down 7 basis points, to 6.92 percent.
The market started off on weak yesterday amid uncertainty about the Russian elections and some concern about the effect of a huge trading loss in the copper market by the Sumitomo Corporation.
"That discomfort caused us to be down about half a point going into the Government's May industrial production report," said Waldo Best, senior economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Government Securities.
The Fed reported that industrial production rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, higher than previous expectations of five-tenths of 1 percent.
But capacity utilization, the portion of the nation's mines, utilities and factories employed in production registered 83.2 percent in May versus a revised 82.9 reading in April, the Fed said.
Many analysts say the Fed becomes concerned about inflation when the capacity utilization rate nears 84 to 85 percent.
As a result, the number was moderate enough to prompt some buying of bonds, traders said.
"This was not a number that meant the Fed would have to raise rates at its July meeting and it allowed some people to get more comfortable with the technical signals being sent that the market was oversold," Mr. Best said. The Federal Open Market Committee meets on July 2 and 3.
The short-covering rally that evolved let the market shrug off a stronger-than-expected final May report by the University of Michigan on consumer sentiment, he said.

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
The Hard Way

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
MY INFORMAL job title in the Nixon Administration was Rejected Counsel. That's because, as a speech writer, I would occasionally put my head into the Oval Office to say: "Mr. President -- Do the popular thing! Take the easy way!" Mr. Nixon would ritualistically throw me out of the office, allowing me to submit a speech draft that would truthfully report: "Some of my aides have suggested that I do the popular thing, that I should take the easy way. But I have rejected such counsel."
This happy memory came to mind as I listened to Bob Dole's eloquent announcement of his departure from the Senate to devote all his time to his Presidential campaign. In that talk, he referred briefly to his difficult travail as a wounded veteran in relearning to walk: "I trust in the hard way, for little has come to me except in the hard way, which is good because we have a hard task ahead of us." Later he recalled times of discouragement: "I have been there before, I have done it the hard way and I will do it the hard way once again." At the conclusion, he reprised the theme: "For the American people have always known, through our long and trying history, that God has blessed the hard way." 
 I reached Dole after the speech to ask who wrote it. He was at first reluctant to say because he didn't want the anonymous volunteer to get in trouble with his employer, but when I explained that it would only help the writer's career, and that people now understand that public figures get professional writing help, the Senator replied that drafts had come from Mark Helprin, a novelist who contributes op-ed pieces to The Wall Street Journal.
After I reported the source of this welcome change from the stilted style of most previous Dole speeches, the modest Mr. Helprin found himself inundated with media calls and requests for bylined articles. The Wall Street Journal proudly took a full-page ad in other papers reprinting its contributor's piece about Dole, demonstrating what little trouble his political involvement got him in. Only Richard Cohen of The Washington Post, one of the few pundits who have not had the exhilarating and instructive experience of having written for a politician, grumped that getting outside help made the Dole remarks less authentic.
Well, then -- as a longtime derogator of "the easy way" -- what can I con-tribute to the rhetorical origin of Mr. Dole's the hard way?
As the New Deal was rooted in card playing, the hard way is derived from rolling dice. In Damon Runyon's 1931 book, "Guys and Dolls," a character familiar with the world of gambling is quoted: " 'Charley,' he says, 'do you make it the hard way?' " In shooting craps, the hard way means "the most difficult way": narrowing the ability to make an even-numbered point by requiring the two dice to come up with a pair of equal numbers totaling the point. For example, if eight is the point to be made the hard way, the combination of neither six-and-two nor five-and-three will do; the hard way calls for two fours. What makes it "harder" is that the odds of achieving the point that limited way are higher. By extension, the phrase to learn the hard way means "through bitter experience," and to come up the hard way means "primarily by one's own efforts."
In an interview with Newsweek, Helprin re- called Dole's words when making the decision to leave the Senate: "If I'm going to run for President, I'm going to have to run for President."
This "if-then" construction has long been used in the expression of determination and grit. Said the 19th-century political economist William Graham Sumner, "If you ever live in a country run by a committee, be on the committee." Said Gov. Huey Long of Louisiana to a group of young politicians, "If you want some ham, you got to go to the smokehouse." Said Napoleon Bonaparte to a hesitant general, "If you're going to take Vienna, take Vienna."

Gazillion
At a White House correspondents' dinner, President Clinton turned toward Al Franken, author of "Rush Limbaugh Is a Big Fat Idiot," and said admiringly, "He's made a gazillion dollars on that book."
The counting began with a mere zillion, coined in 1930, about the time a Mr. Zilch appeared in the satire magazine Ballyhoo. In zilch, as in a sense of zip, the Z referred to zero. Looking at the productive morpheme illion, Fred Cassidy of the Dictionary of American Regional English notes that "Z, as the last letter of the alphabet, suggests 'as far as you can go,' therefore zillion, the highest possible number or variety." (In the other direction lies zilch, lower than which you cannot go.)
The escalation of zillion to gazillion took place, in as early a citation as John Algeo of American Speech can find, in a Feb. 25, 1980, Tom Shales column in The Washington Post referring to "gazillionaire Ellis Ikehorn." Says Shales now: "Using a made-up word instead of 'rich man' established a mocking tone. I could have used zillionaire, but I thought that ga- in front sounded funny."
Gazillion is in the 1996 edition of the Random House Webster's Dictionary, where it is defined as "an extremely large, indeterminate number."
To search Shales's linguistic subconscious: whence the intensifier ga-? Sol Steinmetz of Random House says, "The ga- derives from the Scottish prefix ker-, as in kerplunk and kerflop." The Oxford English Dictionary noted that ker- was the first part of an onomatopoeic formation to imitate the sound of a heavy body falling, and gives the variant ca-. Sounds to me that ga- is the newest variant.
Archimedes estimated the number of sands necessary to fill the universe at 1 with 51 zeroes after it. Mathematicians today can estimate with an overtone of infinity: a gazillion grains.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 38; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3034 words

HEADLINE: Keeping Secrets

BYLINE: By Maggie Scarf; Maggie Scarf is the author of "Intimate Worlds: Life Inside the Family" and is a senior fellow at the Bush Center in Child Development and Social Policy.

 BODY:
What happened to Linehan was no rare occurrence, for as managed-care organizations demand increasingly detailed justifications for medical treatment and file more and more data electronically, the cloak of confidentiality that once protected psychotherapy has become increasingly threadbare. A new bill, currently wending its way through Congress, represents the first comprehensive national effort to deal with this emerging problem. Introduced last November by Senators Robert F. Bennett, Republican of Utah, and Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, the Medical Records Confidentiality Act is intended, as Senator Bennett put it, to "create safeguards so that the folks who currently have access to your medical information cannot abuse it as it is being abused now."
The Bennett-Leahy bill would make it illegal for companies to use medical records to create marketing lists and would grant patients access to their medical records in states that do not already do so. But the question being debated among mental health professionals and patient advocates across the country is whether this bill will actually advance the cause of patient privacy or precipitate a confidentiality disaster.
WHAT HAPPENS BETWEEN THE PATIENT AND the therapist is singularly privileged. "A broken arm is usually not a secret, but an eating disorder or substance abuse problem often is one," says Dr. Herbert Pardes, a psychiatrist who is dean of the faculty of medicine at Columbia University and was director of the National Institute of Mental Health under the Carter and Reagan Administrations. "Obviously, there's a big difference between talking about how long it will take for an elbow fracture to mend, and talking with a patient about why all of his important relationships are failing, or about his alcohol problem or what the source of his or her sexual difficulties might be." 
 But at present it is unrealistic for people to assume that the raw and tender subjects they talk over with their therapists will go no further than the four walls of the consulting room. And many patients have become legitimately concerned about the possibility that the depression, suicide attempt, marital problem or alcoholism being discussed could return to haunt them in cyberspace. They are uncomfortably aware of the shadowy figures sitting in on their therapy sessions: the insurance administrator, the electronic file clerk, the case reviewer, other physicians within an H.M.O. -- even their own co-workers and supervisors.
For example, in a case documented by the National Coalition of Mental Health Professionals and Consumers in Commack, L.I., a patient filed a psychotherapy claim with the managed-care office of his self-insured employer. Shortly afterward, when the man applied for a promotion, it was denied. Not until much later did he learn, from a subsequent employer, that the reason he had been passed over was that he was the butt of so much office gossip and ridicule: some clerks in the company's insurance office were reading his therapist's reports and discussing all the spicy details of his private life.
In another instance, Mark Hudson, 37, who was at the time an employee of Blue Cross/Blue Shield of Massachusetts, realized that his own privacy was being compromised when, in the course of a computer training class, he called his medical record up on the screen. Hudson was startled to find himself staring at what he believed to be his confidential psychiatric file -- a record that included the amount and type of antidepressive medication he was taking at the time. "In that company," he says, "I can tell you unequivocally that patient confidentiality is not eroding -- it can't erode, because it's simply nonexistent."
"What you have to realize," he continues, "is that I could meet a woman at a party and decide that I'd like to know a bit more about her. I wouldn't even have to know her Social Security number; I could look her up by name. And if she's ever contacted Bay State Health Care" -- part of Blue Cross/Blue Shield -- "and asked about substance abuse counseling or whether abortion is covered, I, as an insider, can simply look through her medical record and say, 'Hmm, this is a person I am going to date, or am not going to date, because her record makes me think she's big trouble.' " Last August, two days after testifying for the plaintiffs in a class action suit brought against Bay State, Hudson was dismissed from his job.
The Linehan case was resolved somewhat differently. After she and several other patients went public with their complaints, the H.M.O. involved responded swiftly and responsibly. "We considered that a wake-up call," says Dr. Jennifer Leaning, medical director of the company's Health Centers Division. Within a matter of days, the H.M.O. had partitioned off all psychiatric files and put a lock on them, making them accessible only to mental health clinicians and selected medical staff members. Still, many privacy experts remain concerned about how secure such a lock on these or any other electronic files might be.
The very manner in which psychological services are now delivered is, moreover, causing problems not just for patients but for therapists as well. It is indeed raising the question of whom the clinician is actually working for -- the patient? The H.M.O.? The fee-for-service insurer? The employer-owned group insurance plan?
Consider a situation in which the therapist, in order to preserve patient confidentiality, refuses to disclose information to the third-party insurers. The case reviewer would probably decide that the patient's sessions cannot be approved without sufficient proof that psychotherapy is "medically necessary and appropriate." Result: the afflicted person, who may be under very real emotional duress, will not be able to get his mental health benefits.
The therapist is under pressure, too -- economic pressure -- to meet the third-party payer's demands for detailed patient information, or perhaps be dropped from the panel of mental health care providers. (The therapist has usually signed a contract stating that his services may be terminated at any time, without any reason given.) So to earn a living, and get their patients' sessions authorized, therapists are being forced to release information that under normal circumstances they would not.
As John Chiaramonte, a clinical social worker, describes the situation: "These days, you can't just put down the diagnosis -- say, 'depression.' No, you have to get very specific, to state that this woman is depressed because she's involved in a masochistic, self-destructive affair with her boss, or that this man has gotten depressed around a sexual dysfunction and hasn't been able to respond to his partner for the past few years."
Legally, there is no impediment to the therapist's release of such sensitive clinical material -- when an individual applies for insurance, he routinely signs a waiver allowing health care providers to share his medical information. Nevertheless, says Chiaramonte, who is vendorship chairman of the New York State Society for Clinical Social Work, "if patients realized how much personal information is actually being given out, I think that many of them would go ballistic. . . ." Then he adds glumly, "Sometimes I think they don't want to know, because they are in so much need, and they are suffering."
I N ALL FAIRNESS, THIRD-PARTY PAYERS ARE doing just that -- paying. In the ordinary course of events, an insurer's efforts to verify that requests for therapy are warranted are certainly legitimate. Third-party payers also have the right to maintain quality control -- to make sure that the therapists on their provider panel are offering appropriate, effective treatment.
But why is it that health care insurers and managers, who a mere decade ago required little confidential information beyond that contained in the patient's diagnosis, now insist upon becoming privy to so much potentially damaging personal material? Can't the third-party payer put a certain cap on the number of sessions to which a subscriber is entitled, and then simply use the clinician's diagnosis in order to authorize the patient's treatment?
I put this question to Dr. Saul Feldman, chief executive officer and chairman of U.S. Behavioral Health, an immense mental health care and substance abuse treatment management organization based in Emeryville, Calif., which provides services to more than 5.7 million people across the United States. He answered by saying that in his view the increased demand for detailed personal information is part and parcel of what first brought managed-care organizations into being -- the need for a sense of discipline and accountability, which was totally lacking in the mental health care field.
"What the managed behavioral health organizations see as their major responsibility," he told me, "is making sure that patients are getting the right amount of care in the right places, and that they are making progress. Managed care is itself a reaction to what had been going on for years -- people getting into outpatient therapy and literally spending years there, with no treatment goals and no concern about the resources being expended for the treatment."
Simply relying upon the clinician's diagnosis in order to authorize treatment (with an outside limit on the number of sessions permitted), Feldman says, is "an excessively rigid" approach to managing mental health care. "What we hope will happen, ideally -- and what is happening -- is that as clinicians begin to focus on cost-effective care, rather than care that's never-ending, their practice patterns will change."
Managed mental health care organizations like U.S. Behavioral Health insist upon relatively short-term, goal-focused therapy -- and they monitor the patient's treatment periodically along the way. "The things we want to clarify from the outset," Feldman explains, "are what goals the patient and therapist can agree to set for themselves, and how long reaching those goals is likely to take." Further down the road, care managers want to know how the treatment is progressing, and finally, at the end of the therapy, to make an overall assessment of whether those initial goals were achieved. "In brief," he says, "we're evolving from an emphasis on process to an emphasis on outcomes."
Not so, says Dr. Denise Nagel, a psychiatrist and president of the Coalition for Patient Rights of New England. In her opinion, third-party payers are in the process of managing psychotherapy right out of existence. Nagel takes the position that a better middle ground can and must be found between the insurer's need for documentation and the right of an individual in psychological pain to seek help without the threat of exposure. Laws can and should be written, Nagel says, to safeguard patient confidentiality in the face of insurers' ever-mounting demands for personal information and the headlong advance of computerized record-keeping. But a first and crucial order of business is, in her view, simply bringing these privacy issues into the forefront of our attention.
"One of the most powerful weapons we have is consumer awareness," she says. "People need to talk about this issue with their doctors. They need to talk about it with their health plans. . . . But by and large, they are not talking about these issues, or at least not making themselves heard."
CERTAINLY, NO ONE DISPUTES the fact that there is a need for clear-cut standards to control who may have access to sensitive, personal information, and how that information can be used. There is currently no Federal law that explicitly protects the confidentiality of medical records (although there is a measure protecting the confidentiality of video rental lists). And while a patchwork quilt of state-level regulations exists, the increasing electronic transfer of patient records across state lines has made such measures extremely difficult to disentangle, much less enforce.
The Bennett-Leahy bill is thus a welcome, well-intentioned first pass at establishing national standards, and it commands a good deal of enthusiastic support. One group, the Washington-based Center for Democracy and Technology, has been quite prominent in the continuing discussions of the proposed legislation. Janlori Goldman, the center's deputy director, said in testimony before the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee that the legislation represents "the most comprehensive and strong privacy bill the Congress has yet considered in this area."
Still, the center (which styles itself as a public interest group) is heavily financed, to the tune of hundreds of thousands of dollars, by a number of large computer, databank and telecommunications corporations, including Microsoft, AT&T, Equifax, I.B.M. and TRW. So you wonder: are these giant companies truly interested in protecting our medical privacy or are they interested in legitimizing the release-for-profit of confidential patient information?
It is important to recognize that immense profits can be reaped from aggregated medical records, and a number of computer database companies (Equifax, the huge credit reporting agency, is in the forefront) are already moving forward to stake their claims to this highly marketable information. An advertising agency handling a pharmaceutical company's account, might, for example, be interested in knowing the ages and ethnic and economic backgrounds of the users of a certain antidepressant. Or an employer might want to know the medical and psychiatric status of a potential employee. And insurers could make use of detailed mental health records to exclude particularly vulnerable applicants from their pool. Once such information is on line and accessible, it can be obtained, for a price, at the touch of a button.
A stated purpose of the Bennett-Leahy bill is "to promote the efficiency and security of the health information infrastructure so that members of the health care community may more effectively exchange and transfer health information in a manner that will insure the confidentiality of personally identifiable health information." But the bill's many fierce opponents -- including privacy and consumer groups like the Justice Resource Health Law Institute, the National Coalition of Mental Health Professionals and Consumers, the Electronic Privacy Information Center and the Coalition for Patient Rights -- complain that the bill would facilitate the development of health care databases containing huge amounts of personal information. Those with access to this privileged patient information would include not only the database companies but also a newly created class of "health information trustees" -- insurers, universities, medical researchers, employers, police and courts, state and Federal agencies and others.
As Jay B. Cutler, special counsel to the American Psychiatric Association, has said, "It's hard to figure out who wouldn't qualify as a so-called health trustee." Indeed, the psychiatric association dubbed the bill the Medical Records Disclosure Act because it would make access to so much personal, identifiable patient data legal. As the association's president-elect, Dr. Herbert Sacks, has observed, "Establishing a new class of 'health trustees' is rather like designating a special group of 'trustworthy foxes' and inviting them to come and set up shop inside the henhouse."
Perhaps most unnerving of all is a provision on the last page of the draft currently in circulation stating that "a health information trustee, or an agent or contractor to such trustee, who makes a disclosure of protected health information about an individual that is permitted by this Act shall not be liable to the individual for such disclosure under common law." In short, should you suffer injury because your medical privacy has been violated, you won't have any legal recourse.
WHAT, THEN, IS TO BE DONE ABOUT WHAT Nagel calls the "hemorrhaging" of so much privileged personal data (or what USA Today labeled "data rape")? What seems evident is that the medical records confidentiality bill must be reworked to be what its name implies -- a measure intended to safeguard the privacy of patients' records.
In January, Massachusetts (in large part as a reaction to the turmoil generated by the debacle of the Harvard Community Health Plan) enacted a modest but precedent-setting piece of legislation. This new law specifically prohibits insurers from demanding detailed information about their subscribers' life situations and psychiatric status before granting them their mental health benefits. The legislation, however, covers only the state-mandated benefits -- a rather skimpy $500, which in Massachusetts pays for about six therapy sessions. A more reasonable figure might be $1,200, which would allow for 12 to 15 sessions.
Still, it is a fine step in the right direction -- and others must follow. First of all, we must strictly limit the amount of clinical data that third-party payers can require of therapists (under the new Massachusetts measure, insurers can demand no information other than the patient's name, diagnosis, and date and type of treatment until the $500 nondisclosure ceiling has been reached). Then we must establish mechanisms for providing a genuinely confidential review in cases where the insurer disputes the "medical necessity" of the treatment. We must require informed consent from patients before their medical information can be entered into a computerized network. And finally, we must prohibit the penalizing of doctors and patients who refuse to disclose unduly sensitive data or who do not want their medical information filed in data networks.
Most workers in the field of mental health agree that a failure to tackle these issues promptly and forthrightly will have a destructive impact on their profession. To be effective, psychotherapy must be based on an assumption of mutual respect and confidentiality. If there is a threat that your most intimate confidences may go on line, who would ever be crazy enough to confide in a therapist?

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
CYBERSCOUT

BYLINE: By L.R. Shannon 

 BODY:

AIRLINE TICKETS
Sabre
http://www.amrcorp.com/sabrgrp
 I wanted to fly to Seattle the week after July 4. So I fired up the Sabre reservations system, the big flight data base used by travel professionals but accessible in easier on-line versions to the rest of us. This Sabre software went on line March 11.
First, I had to become a member, which does not cost anything. There was a form to fill out on the screen. You do not fill in a credit card number; that must be phoned or faxed to the company. 
 Then I was given six choices, one of them flights and prices, which promised "the lowest fares to anywhere." I entered the total number of passengers (2), the number aged 2 through 11 (0), and selected "low fare with restrictions."
On the next screen, I filled in that I wanted to leave from Newark for Seattle on July 8, a Monday, at around 10 A.M. and return Friday, July 12. I used only two segments of the form; there are six segments available for more complicated journeys.
Sabre found six choices of flights on five airlines leaving Newark on July 8 from 7:30 A.M. to 7:25 P.M. I selected Continental Flight 121, leaving at 8:15 A.M. arriving at Seattle, with breakfast and without stops, at 11:07 A.M. A new form gave me a choice of six return flights. I picked Continental again, mainly because it left at 12:15 P.M., with lunch and no stops. Then I was given a price of $2,828 for two round-trip tickets. Wow! Surely $2,828 was not the lowest fare available. A mouse click or two would have bought the ticket, but I backed out instead.
The whole process had taken about 50 minutes. Some of this time was in waiting for the Web, but, to be fair, some of it was occupied filling out the new-member form, which only has to be done once. Undoubtedly one would get better with practice.
Using my name and password, a travel agent of my acquaintance then sat at my computer and went into flights and prices. She knew that including a Saturday night stay in Seattle could bring the price down sharply. So she set the trip to start on Wednesday, July 10, and to end on Sunday, July 14. It was still Continental, still nonstop, but the total price was down to $920 for the two tickets. A further search found a Northwest flight, nonstop to Seattle, but a stop at Memphis on the way home, for $808.
This took her about 35 minutes. At the office, she said, with a direct connection to Sabre rather than a Web connection, it would have taken maybe five. Although I did not actually book the tickets, the next step was to supply such information as seat preferences and frequent-flyer status. The choices offered for receiving the tickets were by mail, buying directly from the airline or through a Sabre travel agent.
It should be emphasized that, although I picked a low fare with restrictions, I was never told what the restrictions were.
 
ECONOMY POINTERS
Shoestring Travel E-Zine
http://www.stratpub.com
 On the Internet, reading about travel is cheaper -- and simpler -- than booking a flight. Shoestring describes itself thus: "Information on how to travel on a limited budget. Contents are collected from E-mail sent by users and by entries selected from the travel newsgroups." Newsgroups are sites on the Internet, not the subsidiary Web, where people interested in a subject or pursuit exchange messages and information.
Eric S. Adler, the Shoestring proprietor, says the site is a "labor of love for me and is how I keep up with my hobby, traveling inexpensively."
A recent dip into the Travel E-Zine was more inspirational than informative. There was a short list of new Web sites of interest to the budget traveler, and a generic piece on documentation needed for foreign travel: passports, visas, proof of citizenship and tourist cards.. The "suggestion of the day" was to travel with well-used clothing, perhaps bought for the purpose at a thrift shop, and discard it during the trip, making more room in luggage for purchases. A list of available feature articles, somewhere between professional writing and letters from chatty friends, included: "A Bakery in Mexico City"; "Review of Bigworld Journal"; "Traveling on the Internet"; "British Columbia" and "Travel via Air Courier."
 
SWAPPING STORIES
Cyber Adventures
http://www.cyber-adv.com
Like the Travel E-zine, this is a Web site for exchanging tips rather than booking. According to the "welcome" screen, the accounts are by people who travel with laptop computers and send the stories into the Internet through local phone lines, at "cybercafes" or even via satellite. When I peeked in, there were 18 "strange but true travel stories" -- adventures and misadventures in Bulgaria, Warsaw, Bolivia, Paris, Russia and elsewhere. The account by a man returning from his honeymoon from the airport in Sofia, Bulgaria -- overcrowded airport, overbooked flight, unruly crowds -- might turn you into a dedicated armchair traveler. But if you, too, had a memorable experience in Sofia, you are welcome to add your comments. L.R. SHANNON

SECTION: Section 2; Page 28; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1954 words

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
A New Era in the Care and Feeding of Artists

BYLINE: By BARBARA JEPSON; Barbara Jepson writes regularly about music for The Wall Street Journal.

 BODY:
IN THE SCRAPBOOK OF MEMORIES shared by members of the classical-music industry, the artist manager Harold Shaw shows up in many guises: a triumphant impresario announcing that the pianist Vladimir Horowitz would join his roster and return to the concert stage in 1974 after a five-year absence; a devoted advance man tending to the considerable needs of the soprano Jessye Norman, another client; an urbane fixture in concerts halls and backstage areas for more than 40 years, known for his signature bow ties and berets.
But as the chairman of a major classical-music talent agency, he was not known for dropping bombshells. So it was doubly surprising to his staff, artists and colleagues when he announced last year that Shaw Concerts and its sister operation, Shaw Attractions, would cease operations as of this month. Mr. Shaw made the decision in May 1995, after learning that one of his top associates, Bill Capone, was leaving with 13 of the firm's clients in tow. "Rebuilding a roster takes about 10 years," the 73-year-old Mr. Shaw said recently. "At my age, I'd rather have a lot less responsibility." 
 Mr. Capone's departure was the latest in a series of defections that have begun to alter the artist-management landscape. Moreover, the removal of Shaw Concerts as a major player in the business coincides with several trends that will affect classical audiences as the next wave of agents and presenters introduce innovative strategies for artist promotion and concert programming into a shrinking marketplace.
During its "golden years," Shaw Concerts had a roster that included not only Horowitz but also such legendary artists as Nathan Milstein, Henryk Szeryng, Jacqueline du Pre, Pierre Fournier, Andres Segovia and Dame Janet Baker. Mr. Shaw had worked with many of them as a young salesman for the impresario Sol Hurok before starting his own agency in 1969. By the 1980's, he had a staff of about 20, a roster of about 100 and the finesse to deal with setbacks in inimitable fashion. "Caring for Mr. Horowitz has requirements that exceed those of other artists," he told The New York Times when the pianist defected to the giant Columbia Artists Management in 1981, "and I think that . . . I have done my share for the public. It seems only fair to me now that some other agency take up that responsibility."
Mr. Shaw spent his earliest days in the music business on the road as an unsalaried employee of the National Concerts and Artists Corporation.
"I paid my own expenses," he said in a conversation at his office near Lincoln Center. "I traveled around the country on a Greyhound bus, from Alaska to Key West, Fla., because Hertz had not quite been invented." Once, stranded at a bus stop during a blizzard in Hesston, Kans., he burned concert flyers in his briefcase to keep warm.
After opening Shaw Concerts, he often put his own capital at risk, renting a concert hall and taking a portion of the box-office receipts. "He's the last individual impresario," said Thomas F. Parker, who worked for Shaw Concerts before starting his own firm in 1990. Indeed, Mr. Shaw projected a gentlemanly veneer underlined by his passion for theater and British painting as well as classical music.
"He came across as one of the old-time managers, versus the typical corporate suit," said Walter Pierce, a prominent concert presenter on the national scene.
Mr. Pierce, who stepped down this month as director of the Celebrity Series in Boston, is another example of the slow but inexorable changing of the guard in the classical-music business so aptly symbolized by Mr. Shaw's retirement. William Judd, whose clients during a career of more than 40 years included the pianists Rudolf Serkin and Earl Wild, died in 1987. The veteran managers Harry Beall and Ann Colbert retired in recent years. Ernest Fleischmann, who has been the executive director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic since 1968, recently announced plans to retire in 1997.
Although some old-timers -- Thea Dispeker, in her 90's; Herbert Barrett, in his 80's, and Mariedi Anders, in her 70's -- still actively run their own agencies, the coming years will undoubtedly bring leadership changes in their firms as well. Ms. Dispeker and Mr. Barrett have already arranged for top employees to continue their companies.
The closing of Shaw Concerts may also herald a gradual decline in the influence of medium-size firms. "What's happening in the artist-management business is the same as what's happening in the grocery or telephone business," said Peter Pastreich, the executive director of the San Francisco Symphony. "When we 'shop' for artists these days, we do most of our business with the giant companies or the boutiques."
ALTHOUGH BOUTIQUE agencies have proliferated of late, they are not a new phenomenon. "The artist-management industry began as a bunch of boutique managements that eventually amalgamated into companies like National Concerts and Artists Corporation and Columbia Artists," Mr. Pierce said.
A more recent example of this cycle is IMG Artists, which began in 1978 as a boutique agency in the basement of Charles Hamlen, now the director of Classical Action, which raises funds for AIDS programs. In 1984, Hamlen-Landau Management was acquired by the International Management Group, a mammoth sports marketing and management company. Today, IMG Artists has a star-studded roster of nearly 100 artists in North America and more than 175 artists and attractions in Europe. Using its parent company's resources, it can arrange tours for major orchestras, coordinate events with office staff in six cities and package or produce special concerts.
Whether any of the current boutiques will follow such a pattern remains to be seen. The recent surge in boutique operations reflects several interrelated developments: the success of small, exclusive agencies like Frank Solomon Associates or Shirley Kirshbaum & Associates, which attract and retain important artists; the advent of computers and fax machines, which make it easier to conduct business away from the high-priced center of the industry around West 57th Street, and dissatisfaction with internal policies at leading firms. (Columbia Artists, for example, ended its policy of awarding stock options to favored employees, and Shaw Concerts lacked a clear-cut plan of succession.)
Boutique managers like Ms. Kirshbaum and Herbert Breslin offer optional public relations services as well, and newer "hybrid" agencies employ the latest computer technology to advance their clients' careers. International Artists Group, founded by the former Columbia Artists agent Sean T. Bickerton, maintains a web site on the Internet and provides electronic press kits and artist rosters to presenters.
"In the past, the large agencies had tremendous power," Mr. Bickerton said. "Presenters often booked their entire series from a few large firms because it enabled them to get the superstars they wanted. Now, the big agencies no longer have the lockup with stars. If you represent Cecilia Bartoli, you don't need to be a giant." In fact, the mezzo-soprano Ms. Bartoli is managed by Jack Mastroianni, also formerly of Columbia Artists.
What's more, after a period of expansion from the mid-1960's through the mid-80's, the classical-music business has been contracting. Financing cutbacks, increased competition for the leisure dollar, and a new generation of listeners raised on MTV rather than music appreciation have taken an economic toll. "By and large, the market for classical music is not as robust as it once was," said Jane Moss, a vice president for programming at Lincoln Center. Events and artists who in the past would have sold out immediately sell out more slowly."
While opera audiences grew by 35 percent between 1982 and 1992, according to Opera America, other segments of the classical-music business have declined. The market share for classical recordings has diminished steadily since the mid 80's, and many universities have reduced the number of classical-music events they book annually.
These developments are mirrored in the membership of the Association of Performing Arts Presenters. From 1986 to 1992, it included anywhere from 1,050 to 1,142 presenters or supporting organizations; by 1995, the total had dropped to 884.
Such trends have engendered signficant changes in the way classical performers are presented. "We're becoming more community-oriented," said Kenneth Fischer, the director of the Musical Society of the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, which is presenting about 60 concerts this season. "We used to be 'pedestal presenters.' It was enough to bring the great artists into our communities and present them well. Now presenters are taking responsibility for commissioning new work and educating our audiences, and we're asking much more of the artists. We'd like them to stick around, do a master class or post-performance chat. We think it's good for business."
On the managerial side, more agents are offering thematic projects, like Garrick Ohlsson's recent series of Chopin recitals and seminars at Alice Tully Hall, to attract presenters and audiences. They are also looking for innovative attractions with broad appeal, like "Stomp," an interactive theatrical piece with percussion, movement and visual comedy, presented by Columbia Artists. IMG Artists has been especially active in the packaging of celebrity artist collaborations.
"The pressure is on all of us in our business to be more imaginative not only in programming but in developing income opportunities for the artists and the agency," said Elizabeth Sobol, an associate director at IMG. "This is where the alchemy of the business is, not in trotting out the same repertoire over and over again."
Although the Shaw Concerts roster included theater and dance, it rarely partook of the avant-garde. Yet Mr. Shaw was prescient in discerning new business trends. He was among the first to focus on Japan as a potential market for classical music, drawing on contacts made in connection with the 1962 World's Fair in Seattle, for which he was the performing-arts director. Anticipating the more recent move toward worldwide representation, he opened a London office in the early 70's but could not sustain it.
Mr. Shaw's dry, understated wit could quickly turn sarcastic or condescending with staff members, but he was unflappable with artists. "He was the eye of a storm," said Mr. Parker. Twice he built up an extensive roster of vocalists, and twice associates left for potentially greener pastures at Columbia Artists, taking most of those singers with them.
In recent years, Mr. Shaw devoted most of his time to the career of Jessye Norman. He entrusted more responsibility to his senior executives, Mr. Capone and Hugh Kaylor, whom he named co-presidents in 1993. While employees had inquired about his eventual retirement plans on at least one occasion, Mr. Shaw said he was surprised by Mr. Capone's departure. After briefly considering other options, he decided to dismantle the firm's operations.
Mr. Kaylor, who opened his own company last September, has taken over the remaining engagements of Shaw Concerts. Mr. Shaw, who lives alone, said he planned to spend his winters near Palm Springs, Calif. and put his feet up. "While you're in this business," he explained "you're like a doctor on emergency call."
Mr. Shaw spent his final day of work packing boxes and attending to stray details. The last thing he did before turning in the key was remove the bold red letters that spelled his name on the door. "It was kind of a sad day," he acknowledged.
Mr. Kaylor took a broader view, saying, "It's the end of an era."
