SECTION: Section 2; Page 38; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1153 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
In Chicago, A Tale of Lost Magnificence

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
DETROIT WOULD KILL TO have a street like North Michigan Avenue. St. Louis surely seethes with envy at its prosperity. Omaha must look at it as the epitome of urban sophistication and chic. So why does North Michigan Avenue strike me as profoundly depressing? Perhaps because it is the clearest sign anywhere in the country of the desperate measures American cities must take if they are to save themselves.
This is a great boulevard, one of the finest in any American city, its noblest stretch -- the Magnificent Mile -- running from the Chicago River to Lake Shore Drive. This part of North Michigan once was the province of Chicago's most elegant shops, most of which were set in handsome, medium-size commercial buildings of limestone and brick. A few apartment buildings, some hotels and a couple of office buildings joined to create one of those truly civilized boulevards whose buildings are individually distinctive yet have enough in common to make a coherent whole. 
 The architecture was neo-everything: classical, Renaissance, Art Deco, Georgian. The styles worked together because the building scale was similar and the architects' intention was to play not a solo but a part in the larger symphony of the street.
That attitude is as relevant to present-day Chicago as Mrs. O'Leary's cow. North Michigan is now a street of malls, and if you think that is an oxymoron, come see this parade of suburban architecture metastasizing into a new kind of urban form. For that is what North Michigan is now: a series of suburban shopping malls turned on end to become vertical urban malls, with high-rise towers plopped on top. They march, one after the other, down the avenue, now less a true urban street than a funnel to carry cars and taxis past the line of monoliths.
The roots of all this go back to two buildings, each a full generation old: the John Hancock Tower by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, of 1969, a 1,1015-foot behemoth that brought gigantism to North Michigan; and Water Tower Place of 1976, by Loebl, Schlossman Dart & Hackl, a white-marble tower of 74 stories that contains a huge mall, a hotel and condominium tower and that marked the beginning of the mallification of the avenue.
Others followed, notably 900 North Michigan, by Kohn Pedersen Fox, a Water Tower Place knockoff made more elegant by a post-modern sheathing, and an immense tower with the pretentious name of One Magnificent Mile. The name as much as the architecture seemed a death knell for the old street: when you must advertise it so blatantly, the magnificence is surely over.
NOTHING EQUALED THE architectural importance of John Hancock, which, for all its unpleasant message to the street, was always a stunning object on the skyline. The buildings since then have merged Hancock's anti-urbanism with Water Tower Place's banality.
Now there are still more on the way: every time it seems as if the street is stabilizing, another project is announced, with another landmark building scheduled for demolition and another glitzy high-rise with a mall at its base taking its place. (Last year the news was 600 North Michigan, actually just a mall with movie theaters and no tower at all, but a complex that required the demolition of the Chicago Arts Club, with its famous Mies van der Rohe interior. Thus does Chicago care for its past.)
What kind of city do all these changes add up to? A new one -- more different from the old one than it might seem. It's not for nothing that I began by talking about Detroit; no one who cares about the future of cities has any right to deny the importance of the prosperity that the evolving North Michigan Avenue represents. People march up and down this street every day, buying things that almost everywhere else in America get bought in the suburbs . Yes, this is good. Yes, it is a lot better than an empty, abandoned street. North Michigan Avenue glistens, and only a fool would sneer.
But this is not the Chicago that was, or even the American city that was: this Chicago, for all its prosperity, should leave anyone who values urban form as we have known it deeply troubled. It is not just the malls, the sense of everything being indoors that is so disturbing; painful as it is to think of Chicagoans who had once browsed this great boulevard now shopping mainly around atriums, it's perhaps hard to blame them, the city's weather being what it is.
It's more that even the most sophisticated urban mall has a way of seeming suburban, a place too much like other places. Enter any one of these North Michigan Avenue malls and you could be almost anywhere. The stores are the same as the ones you see everywhere. The space seems the same. The merchandise looks the same. The food tastes the same. Even the tinkling piano keys intended to make us think we're in a cocktail lounge, not a shopping mall, sound the same. The special identity of this once-unique urban street is lost.
What is also troubling is the way North Michigan Avenue has been at the forefront of another trend in retailing, the movement toward vast, entertainment-oriented stores. Nike Town established one of its first beachheads here; so did the Sony Corporation with its Sony Gallery. These are sprawling places intended to sell by amusing us. We do not have to go to theme parks anymore; they will come to us. The theme park has taken over the urban streetscape.
Huge, granite-clad boxes, with stores at the bottom and rooms at the top: You can drive into almost any of them and avoid the street altogether. After all, what real appeal does the street have now? The fabric of North Michigan Avenue is gone. A handful of historic buildings remain -- the Water Tower, the one building that predates the Chicago Fire of 1871; the Fourth Presbyterian Church; the Art Deco 919 North Michigan Avenue (most recently the home of Playboy and originally the Palmolive Building).
But the truly special quality of North Michigan Avenue came not from buildings were extraordinary things in themselves, but from good buildings that together to create an extraordinary ensemble. It is that kind of building that is finished, gone or going fast, unable in today's economic climate to justify their continued existence.
For all of Chicago's generalized respect for architecture, there is no sympathy in its culture for the concept of "tout ensemble," as they say in New Orleans. The idea that the whole can be greater than the sum of the parts, that the greatness of a street or a city often comes from the cumulative total of its very good buildings fitting together, not just from a series of isolated landmarks, seems alien here.
The decline and fall of North Michigan Avenue represents, most of all, the loss in Chicago of the idea of the "tout ensemble." Too luxurious a concept for us today, by far, in an age when it is not only every man for himself; it is every building for itself, too.

Inset: The towers of the Fourth Presbyterian Church are dwarfed by John Hancock Tower at center and Water Tower Place, right. (Todd Buchanan for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 42; Column 3; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1119 words

HEADLINE: Look! Up in the Sky!

BYLINE: By Daniel Bluestone; Daniel Bluestone, who teaches architectural history and directs the historic preservation program at the University of Virginia, is the author of "Constructing Chicago."

 BODY:

RISE OF THE NEW YORK SKYSCRAPER, 1865-1913
By Sarah Bradford Landau and Carl W. Condit.
Illustrated. 478 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $50.
New York skyscrapers appalled Henry James. Returning to the city in 1904 after an absence of two decades, James found that skyscrapers had "cruelly overtopped" the spire of Trinity Church and "usurped" the place of distinguished civic and religious buildings on the skyline. The cityscape symbolized profound and troubling changes in American culture, James wrote in "The American Scene." Rooted traditions had given way to the shallow pursuit of money, and it was evident in the landscape. "Crowned not only with no history, but no creditable possibility of time for history, and consecrated by no uses save the commercial at any cost," James wrote, skyscrapers were the "most piercing notes in that concert of the expansively professional into which your supreme sense of New York resolves itself." In "Rise of the New York Skyscraper, 1865-1913," Sarah Bradford Landau and Carl W. Condit explore new historical dimensions of the buildings that James saw as lacking a claim on history. 
 Skyscrapers multiplied the space available on a single parcel of land. Earlier in the 19th century, New York builders had experimented with multistoried buildings, but the energies of most stair climbers tended to give out at four to five stories and so did the buildings. The expansion of white-collar work, concentrated in a downtown hemmed in by water, encouraged higher buildings, and a system of unregulated development and a series of technological inventions made skyscrapers possible. Skyscraper technology and architectural design are the primary focus of Ms. Landau, a professor of art history at New York University, and Mr. Condit, professor emeritus of history and art history at Northwestern. Starting with the 1868 Equitable Building, mechanical elevators, which had been initially developed for hoisting freight in warehouses and factories, transported people to levels higher than they could comfortably climb. Henceforth, white-collar and managerial workers would place a premium on upper floors, with their expansive views and removal from the noise, dirt and distractions of the street.
Taller buildings with more floors created the problem of greater loads. Thicker masonry walls, more substantial foundations and piers could support these loads but significantly reduced interior space, especially at the valuable ground-story retail level. Builders looked to structural iron to reduce the size of walls and piers. Ms. Landau and Mr. Condit closely trace these changes, along with new methods of fireproof construction, wind bracing and systems of heating, ventilation, plumbing and lighting.
The classical orders and other historic styles were not easily adapted to the skyscraper's unprecedented scale. Modernists advocated an architecture that would express the spirit of the industrial age with its new structural systems and materials. Many architects avoided this challenge. Some gathered groups of floors into multistory arcades based on historical styles. Others divided skyscraper facades into distinct horizontal units with a variety of stylistic treatments. Such gestures irked modernists like Louis H. Sullivan, who argued for greater design clarity and uniformity. Mr. Condit's earlier writings on skyscrapers shared the modernist assumptions of such critics; the current book significantly modifies that position. In one of their most alluring arguments, Ms. Landau and Mr. Condit sympathetically interpret the layered form of many early New York skyscrapers as a reflection of subtle changes in wall thicknesses prescribed by the 1892 New York City building code.
This book curiously slights the subject of design method. Concentrating on product rather than process, the authors are relatively silent about what led architects, engineers and builders to use one structural system or elevator technology over another. The book's narrative structure often turns on notions of "evolution" and the "maturity" of skyscraper development, as if the buildings simply grew and then grew some more; missing is an account of what went into the choices made among competing possibilities in technology and style.
Ms. Landau and Mr. Condit present a formalist account of skyscraper technology and esthetics. Matters like the skyscraper's economic and urban context are taken up, but with less rigor and consistency. Above all, skyscrapers concentrated people, but the authors attend to this human element unevenly. There are several fine sections that examine the criticisms and fears provoked by skyscrapers. The authors also discuss certain buildings as projections of a magnate's ego or of a corporate image -- a Woolworth, a Singer, a Metropolitan Life -- but they inexplicably neglect the experience of people who worked in and around skyscrapers and whose sense of urbanity revolved around those buildings. The New York Produce Exchange, designed in 1881 by George B. Post, offers a case in point. Ms. Landau and Mr. Condit scrutinize the articulation of the facades and the innovative structure that supported interior walls and spanned an exchange floor measuring 215 feet by 134 feet. But readers will have to go elsewhere to learn what business New Yorkers transacted in this building and why members of the exchange, who formerly had conducted their business on the street, even occupied this new space. Similarly, in the account of the New York Cotton Exchange Building, people are present only by implication: the building's system of vented water closets and urinals are discussed in detail.
New York had many skyscraper enthusiasts. S. Parkes Cadman, the charismatic minister and leader of the city's ecumenical movement, presided over the dedication ceremony for the Woolworth Building. He dubbed it the "Cathedral of Commerce." President Woodrow Wilson personally activated all of the building's lights for the first time. The New York Times reviewed the building's design as a monument to the nickels and dimes of the people and the rags-to-riches success of Frank W. Woolworth. Indeed, religious, political and civic figures often viewed skyscrapers as dramatic cultural icons, yet they cared little whether buildings had portal-and-arch bracing or knee bracing or caisson foundations. These leaders nevertheless articulated sophisticated social and esthetic reactions to the skyscraper form. When future critics and historians take measure of these aspects of the history of New York skyscrapers, Ms. Landau and Mr. Condit's account of the technical details will provide one important point of departure.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 16, 1996

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 2374 words

HEADLINE: Travel

BYLINE: By William Grimes; William Grimes is an arts reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
Fiction writers accept the notion that they follow in the footsteps of their predecessors. For travel writers, however, the metaphor suggests a serious problem. The whole point of travel writing is -- or was -- to describe a place few people have visited before.
Until quite recently, the earth offered many such places, unworked mines whose fat, tempting seams promised treasures to any brave soul with a strong back and a pick. Airplane travel and the cheap package tour put an end to all that. Now Tashkent, Nairobi and Kuala Lumpur all lie within a day's reach of New York. As Kingsley Amis pointed out in a tart little essay, travel's democratic age has spoiled things for a certain breed of writer, "the sort who for decades had been getting away with calling Spain a harsh, bitter land" or with nattering on about "the civilization of the delicate olive at the other end of the Mediterranean." 
 What to do? Some writers, unwilling to surrender the bragging rights conferred by novelty, have resorted to the gimmick book, in which the traveler sets himself a bizarre challenge (like walking the whole 3,000-mile coast of Baja California) or maps out an arcane itinerary (visiting, say, every town in the United States named Springfield). Others simply retrace the route taken by earlier adventurers, betting that the contrast between old and new will pay dividends. And lots of them, playing the Peter Mayle card, simply plop down in a cute village and wait for funny people to do funny things.
Mike Tidwell, the author of THE PONDS OF KALAMBAYI: An African Sojourn (Lyons & Burford, paper, $16.95), did none of the above, with brilliant results. As a Peace Corps volunteer, Mr. Tidwell spent two years in the grasslands of south central Zaire trying to spread the profitable message of fish farming to some of the poorest villages on the continent. This book is the record of his experience.
Mr. Tidwell arrives in Kalambayi with high hopes and a good plan. He will teach the local farmers how to dig ponds and raise fish, which will provide them with a source of income and add protein to a diet that consists mainly of fufu, a bland, squishy bread made of powdered corn and manioc. His task is not easy. One villager, for example, is convinced that fish will stock the ponds naturally, since they come to earth in raindrops. Others suspect that the fishponds are a new way for the white man to exploit their labor.
Gradually, Mr. Tidwell makes headway. But the heart of the story lies in his growing understanding of the people and the place he has come to. He picks up a spear and hunts with the men, to their great amusement. He wriggles out of the invitation when a local chief, taking pity on Mr. Tidwell's bachelor existence, offers one of his daughters in marriage. He protests in vain when his fish farmers routinely give away as much as half their harvest to relatives. Tradition, he finds, takes precedence over the profit motive. After a while, he learns to adopt the share-and-share-alike philosophy of a people who never have enough.
With a keen eye, he picks up on the fine points of building and maintaining a mukishi, a kind of scarecrow with a distinctly African twist: "To keep its spirit alert and savage, Kayenda began pelting its face every day with whatever sludge happened to be on hand -- mud, rotten fruit, ashes, flour. The process was something of an art form. One day I watched him pour a bucket of water over the mukishi's head while telling it that its mother was a prostitute."
For the most part, Mr. Tidwell tells a tragic story. Poverty, disease and failure hang over his villages. In the rainy season, as the stores from the previous harvest dwindle, death haunts the land. Mr. Tidwell does not flinch from tales of misery, but he lived long enough and closely enough with the people to know the whole story, the little triumphs and daily satisfactions as well as the defeats. Readers will be cheering for those fishponds.
The British travel writer Jeremy Seal also knows his territory, in this case Turkey, where he taught English for several years and developed an obsession with the fez, the real protagonist of his first book, A FEZ OF THE HEART (Harvest/Harcourt Brace, paper, $14). Subtitled "Travels Around Turkey in Search of a Hat," it takes the reader on a convoluted itinerary and a historical journey driven by Mr. Seal's ultimately irritating belief that the soul of Turkey can be found in the fez, the national headgear that replaced the turban in 1826 and, upon the orders of Kemal Ataturk, was outlawed in 1925 as a symbol of Turkish backwardness.
The Turks are a patient people. They submit to Mr. Seal's barrage of questions about the fez, not high on their list of interests, with good grace. Perhaps they, like the reader, suspect the fez is just a pretext. Mr. Seal needed an excuse to wander around Turkey, the fez is it, and his Turkish hosts simply have to make the best of it.
The book is better than its premise. Mr. Seal writes well, although he has a tendency to get purplish, and his little historical essays, scattered throughout the book, are fascinating and thoroughly researched. When he takes off his fez, so to speak, Mr. Seal does best. Although he is poor at describing scenery, he has the British gift for seizing upon absurdities, awkward situations and the miseries of travel. His description of a wretched waiting room for the ferry at Lake Van sounds the note of misery with genuine feeling:
"It was not for the occasional irksome delay but for hard-core uncensored waiting of the type with which the dockworkers there were evidently intimate. They cast glazed expressions at a television film featuring a dubbed Burt Reynolds. The room was heavy with cigarette smoke, distinct layers of it so thick you could almost read in it the stratified geology of the room's recent history and figure out with a fair degree of accuracy who had smoked what, where and when."
In the end, despite the fez he drags around like a ball and chain, Mr. Seal manages to shape his odd encounters and erratic pit stops into a convincing likeness of modern Turkey.
Giles Whittell, an English journalist, also had an obsession. His focused on Stephen Graham, a Scottish reporter for The Times of London who traveled from the Caspian Sea to Siberia in 1914. Mr. Whittell decided to take the same journey, more or less, making his way from Volgograd across central Asia to the towering peaks of the Altai Mountains, where China, Kirghizstan, Mongolia and Siberia meet.
Readers in search of deep historical knowledge or a complex view of the former Soviet Union should look for another book. EXTREME CONTINENTAL: Blowing Hot and Cold Through Central Asia (Trafalgar Square, $35) offers neither, but it is fast moving, footloose, sharply observed and very funny. Mr. Whittell races from one destination to the next, faster than Chichikov in Gogol's "Dead Souls," with barely enough time to pause for a thumbnail description, at which he is adept.
"On the map, Tajikistan is all frantic shading," he writes. "Tajikistan is where the deserts leap into the air, break open into chasms, grow glaciers, sprout forests, gush waterfalls and terrorize lowlanders with yaks, yetis, palpitations and edemas." In a spare sentence, he summons up Chardzhou, a hellhole in Turkmenistan: "It consists of rows of sad naked apartment blocks rising square off the desert like a bar chart."
Mr. Whittell pretty much forgets about the intrepid Stephen Graham about five pages into the book, but he does his man proud in the end. Diffident but amazingly persistent, Mr. Whittell shows up at Baikonur, the once top-secret Soviet space installation, and talks his way in to watch a rocket launching. One aspect of the episode, however, illustrates the adventure-resistant nature of the modern world. He pays by Visa card.
Christopher Hunt also makes a lively travel companion, although his itinerary is daunting: the Ho Chi Minh Trail. It takes a few pages of SPARRING WITH CHARLIE: Motorbiking Down the Ho Chi Minh Trail (Anchor/Doubleday, paper, $12.95) to accept Mr. Hunt as a guide. Breezy and casual, he overplays his hand as a regular guy. It does not inspire confidence when he describes postwar Vietnam as "the New York Mets of international economics." But Mr. Hunt, whose father, Richard P. Hunt, was a television reporter in Vietnam during the war, knows a little more than he lets on, and as he pops and sputters his way down the trail on a Russian motorbike, with side excursions into Laos and Cambodia, he shows real pluck and determination.
He describes a country so poor it received foreign aid from Cuba, a country in which water buffalo cool themselves in rain-filled bomb craters. He does not encounter animosity, which shocks him. "I saw every permutation of amputee. No legs in wheelchair. No legs without wheelchair. Prosthetics. Crutches. One empty sleeve. Two empty sleeves. Nobody ever pointed an accusatory finger at me."
Still, Mr. Hunt knows that powerful feelings run beneath the surface, despite the national habit of reticence. As he tours a minefield, a guide tells him: "I came here with the U.S. veterans. They remembered their friends and they cried. Vietnamese veterans also come here. They also cry." For the younger generation, though, America means money and fun, and Mr. Hunt is its ambassador. At a museum in Ho Chi Minh City whose exhibits show the full horror of the war, four schoolgirls approach him, ask his name and huddle to plot their next move. They return to him and say, "Chris, America No. 1."
In a bygone age, travel writers pursued their journeys for simple reasons, and reprints of their books often make the best reading today -- they combine the romance of travel with the romance of the past, offering, in effect, two trips for the price of one. More than a century ago, Capt. Frederick Burnaby traveled the length of Turkey in the dead of winter to answer a single question: "Were the Turks," as he put it, "such awful scoundrels?" The question came up in response to lurid newspaper accounts of atrocities committed against Bulgarian Christians in 1876. Burnaby, a resolute Victorian adventurer, was determined to find out. ON HORSEBACK THROUGH ASIA MINOR (Oxford University, paper, $13.95), which was originally published in 1877, presents his answers.
In the course of his travels, Burnaby inquired into the tensions between Christians and Muslims -- and Armenians, Kurds and Turks -- showing admirable skepticism and fair-mindedness as he listened to each side plead its case. He kept his ears open for news about the political intrigues of the Russians and his eyes open to see what British troops might have to deal with if England were drawn into war on Turkish territory. He also described Turkish society and customs. Best of all, for the modern reader, he took great pleasure in retailing the doings of his rascally Turkish servant, Osman, and the extended sufferings of his manservant, Radford, a military version of Mr. Pickwick's servant, Sam Weller. Radford has a thoroughly English sense of how people should behave. The Turks, especially Osman, frustrate him at every turn.
Burnaby traveled as a soldier with a mission, but just as often the gentleman travelers of the late 19th century pursued whim and fancy. George Gissing, the author of such bleak urban novels as "New Grub Street," headed for Calabria in 1897 in pursuit of a classical vision. "I shall see the shores where once were Tarentum and Sybaris, Croton and Locri," he writes at the outset of his journey. "Every man has his intellectual desire; mine is to escape life as I know it and dream myself into that old world which was the imaginative delight of my boyhood."
First published in 1901, BY THE IONIAN SEA: Notes of a Ramble in Southern Italy (Marlboro/Northwestern University, paper, $13.95, available in July) is a beautiful and touching book, the record of a golden interlude in a short life filled with hardship and bitter disappointment. Modern readers, following his journey, may wonder wherein the pleasure lay. Gissing travels across tough terrain. He describes vile accommodations and unspeakable food. It is a bit sad to see him discover that the river Galaesus, described in rapturous terms by Horace, is a piddling stream bordered by dusty fields and a few olive trees. But Gissing emerges triumphant. It is characteristic that when laid low by malaria, he sees exquisitely colored, detailed visions of the Second Punic War.
The journey inspired by whim can never be repeated. A travel writer following in the footsteps of Gissing would fail because without the temperament there's no trip. Ditto for the 120-mile walking tour that Robert Louis Stevenson undertook in 1878 through one of the most rugged and remote regions of France, a ramble that provided the material for his classic book, published the following year, called TRAVELS WITH A DONKEY IN THE CEVENNES (Marlboro/Northwestern University, paper, $12.95, available in July).
Ninety percent of any traveler's problems can be traced to transportation. Just as Burnaby struggled with short-winded horses in Turkey a century ago, so Mr. Hunt tinkered constantly with his motorbike in the 1990's. Stevenson's cross to bear was Modestine, a placid, stubborn, manipulative donkey with a sweet face and a low cunning that he could never quite get the better of. She is one of the great characters in travel literature.
In the course of his 12-day trip, Stevenson finds his loathing turning to love. When it comes time to say goodbye, he does so with regret: "She was patient, elegant in form, the color of an ideal mouse, and inimitably small. Her faults were those of her race and sex; her virtues were her own."
Stevenson, who was just shy of 28 at the time of his trip, dashed off his book in a few months to earn a quick check. The casual approach suited him. With a light hand, he ranges far and wide, serving up odd encounters, random conversations, his own reflections on God and man, and the compelling trivia of travel: food, drink, sleep and, in his case, the ever-fresh challenge of getting Modestine to move. It is the best of all possible trips.

HEADLINE: From a Hofstra Class Assignment to Her Novel

BYLINE: By MARJORIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
FOR Barbara Rogan, 45, a novelist in Farmingdale, the title of Thomas Wolfe's posthumous novel could have read: "You Can Go Home Again." After living for more than a decade in Israel, where she founded a successful literary agency, Ms. Rogan returned to her Long Island birthplace in 1985 to raise her family and pursue a career as a writer
"When I grew up here in the 60's, I thought Long Island was the most boring, pointless, suburban place to live," she said. "Now that I'm older, with kids, it makes sense. We love living here. I think I may even be the one that cheers loudest at my sons' soccer games." 
 Her latest novel, her fifth, "Rowing in Eden," (Simon & Schuster) the title taken from a line in an Emily Dickinson poem, has been optioned by Citadel, a television production company. The book was written as a response to a writing exercise she assigned to her adult fiction writing class at Hofstra University in 1994.
"I asked them to write five opening lines for a book," she said. "I often try out my own assignments. When I went home and wrote the line: Even though she'd asked for it, Sam Pollak could not help feeling guilty the day he killed his wife. I became so fascinated that I had to figure out what book would go with it."
Her novels have been translated into seven languages and have sold more successfully in Europe and Asia than in the United States Her last book, "A Heartbeat Away," set in a New York City emergency room and inspired by Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice," has sold 40,000 hard copy editions in Japan.
"My books seem to appeal more to a European sensibility." she said. "They usually have some political content or at least some emotive social awareness that comes from my living abroad for so many years. It could be that the books speak to them more than to Americans, but I live in hope."
Persistence, she said, is particularly necessary for a writer. Her early and only ambition was to become one. She grew up shy and solitary in Westbury, where she enjoyed horseback riding, but her world was in books.
"I remember sitting around the table Sunday mornings with my parents reading The New York Times. I was only 5," she said. "I used to walk to school reading. I thought the only point of having friends was to trade Nancy Drew books. By fourth grade, I had my first play produced in school, a parody of 'Oklahoma!' "
She chose a small liberal arts college for a basic education, St. John's College in Annapolis, Md., where she graduated from its campus in Santa Fe, N.M. She worked in publishing for a short time in New York before she emigrated to Israel at age 21. She had previously traveled there and fallen in love with the land. She intended to make it her home.
Day jobs supported her writing at night, and included work as a wrangler on a dude ranch in Galilee, and later as a nature ranger at a reserve in Ein Gedi near the Dead Sea. "It was a green lush area, nearby the same caves referred to in the Bible where King David is said to have hid from Saul," she said.
In Tel Aviv, the center of the arts and intellectual activity, she developed her own literary agency and represented American and European publishing houses for the sale of Hebrew language rights to books. She represented the publishers of many writers she still admires, like Alice Hoffman and Madeleine L'Engle.
" 'A Wrinkle in Time' was one of my favorite books as a child," she said. "I remember being so thrilled when that book crossed my desk as an agent." Her agency became one of the largest in Israel, responsible for 50 percent of the foreign rights. In 1980, she married Benjamin Kadishson, an Israeli jazz musician.
Her first novel, "Changing States," 1982, was published simultaneously in Israel, England and the United States and also coincided with the birth of her first son. The book was influenced, she said, by the many Holocaust survivors' stories that passed by her desk as a literary agent.
By 1983, Ms. Rogan decided to sell the agency to finally write full time. The arduous decision to leave Israel was a complex one, mainly owing to Israel's unstable economy, she said.
"My books are variable in style and content, heavily researched and generally don't rely as much on my own personal experiences, as they draw on the emotional underpinnings of experiences," Ms. Rogan said.
"Characters I write about seem to have suffered some kind of deep wound, or devastating loss and I am fascinated with those who are resilient enough to overcome it -- the survivors."
In "Rowing in Eden," Sam Pollak, a Jewish carpenter, marries the love of his life, Louise, a 30-something midwife. They live happily until she becomes terminally ill in a small fictional village called Old Wickham, based on Old Chatham, N.Y., where the Rogans have a second home. Sam, who lost his family as a child, in a tragic accident, knew the "only security is false security." During his marriage, he lived in a state of fear and paranoia: "What after all did they know of Eden? Two things only: it was perfect while it lasted and it didn't last long."
In writing and researching the book, Ms. Rogan called on the expertise of the staff at the Shaker Museum in Old Chatham for advice on carpentry, and for insight into arson and firefighting she gathered information from Old Chatham's fire chief, Dick Van Egghen.
To assist her in the moral and religious issues of euthanasia, she turned to Rabbi Robert Marcus of the Farmingdale Jewish Center, who also helped with biblical citations and Jewish protocol in the book. She said her view on doctor-assisted suicide, which she believes should be legalized, was changed as a result of writing the book.
"Sam does what many people would consider to be the right thing," she said. "He loves his wife who is suffering from terminal cancer more than anything in the world. He becomes her 'tool,' to help her die at her request. What I found out while writing the book is what a toll it took on him."
Ms. Rogan often employs a useful writing device when she tells a story. By using multiple points of view and interweaving their stories, she said it offered each more depth. Running parallel to Sam's tragic dilemma is the blight of Peter Quinn, a teen-age foster child who killed his father in self-defense. Both pay a terrible price, living out their lives suffering with their moral conscious for so-called "justifiable acts," she said. In the novel Peter says: "Isn't it strange, how you become the thing you did?"
The character of the defrocked Rabbi Haim Malachi appears first in the novel to recite kaddish ( a prayer for the dead) at Louise's funeral and arrives at pivotal moments throughout the book to add bits of wisdom and a touch of magical realism.
"He's kind of a Jackie Mason angel," Ms. Rogan said. Rabbi Malachi explains his appellation in the novel: "What is a defrocked rabbi? A rabbi what goes cold in the winter. A teacher who can't teach what he don't understand himself."
A similar kind of archetypical character often appear in various forms in her novels, which mostly end with some kind of positive reconciliation, she said.
Her next book, the first set on Long Island, is also her first thriller. "It has a female protagonist who is a writer; everyone will think this one is autobiographical,"she said.
Ms. Rogan appears to be rowing in her own kind of Eden. She's content "hunkering" down, tending to mothering and writing and "blending" into suburban life.
"I feel fortunate to be able to make a living at exactly what I want to do," she said. "I want to be a writer till I die, till I die."

HEADLINE: A Stratford Theater's Struggle to Stay Alive

BYLINE: By PEGGY MCCARTHY 

 BODY:
THE setting for this drama is a 14-acre, little-used state park overlooking the Housatonic River in Stratford. There are four boarded-up buildings on the land, one a former theater that once had an international reputation.
The main character is Louis S. Burke, a South African who co-produced and directed "Meet Me in St. Louis" on Broadway in 1989. He decided a decade ago, when he first saw the closed Shakespeare theater (with "rain dripping from the roof and bird droppings on the stage"), that "it was my destiny," he said. The plot concerns repeated, unsuccessful efforts to revive the theater, which opened in 1955 and has been dark since 1982, save for a short, 1989 summer season. In its heyday, theatrical greats, including Katharine Hepburn, performed there. 
 As the curtain rises, there is quiet on the stage of what is now called the Stratford Festival Theater. An announced summer production of "Twelfth Night" with James Earl Jones has been shelved.
Behind the scenes is Mr. Burke, who has spent most of his career in South Africa as an actor, director and producer, and who now spends much time in Connecticut telling people that he is a major player in the theater world. Mr. Burke was chosen last November as the preferred developer for the site after Gov. John G. Rowland decided to sell the property.
Negotiations for the purchase stopped for a couple of months while Mr. Burke was seeking a state lease to operate summer seasons this year and next in a temporary structure at the theater site, said Richard K. Clifford, chief of outdoor recreation for the State Department of Environmental Protection. The department, which has jurisdiction over the property, approved the lease in January under the condition that state building and fire code requirements be satisfied, Mr. Clifford said.
But, the lessees decided that meeting the codes for one production would be "financially unfeasible," said Louis D. Pietig, of Westport, a partner of Mr. Burke. He said that the last summer season in Stratford lost nearly $250,000. He said a summer season next year with several plays is a goal of Brickhill-Burke Productions, Mr. Burke's company.
Both state negotiators and Mr. Burke have said they want to resume negotiations soon. Mr. Clifford said he would seek establishment of a timetable "so it doesn't go on indefinitely."
Meanwhile, in the wings, choruses are forming.
There are supporters of Mr. Burke's efforts to resurrect the Shakespeare theater, including a booster group he formed called "Friends of Will," which has about 40 members and has attracted some 200 people to a clean-up of the theater grounds.
There are critics, like David Reed, a former marketing director of the theater and a losing contender to be preferred developer of the site.
And, there are skeptics, like Paul S. Timpanelli, president of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council. He says he wants to see the rebirth of the theater, but has growing doubts about it happening.
Mr. Timpanelli, a member of Mr. Burke's advisory board and its finance committee, said of the project, "I have concerns about whether or not it's real." He continued: "The most important thing that's given rise to these concerns is the absence of a solid financial plan with visible support and means of raising equity." Mr. Timpanelli explained that he and other board members asked for such information months ago and haven't received it.
"I love Louis Burke. He is absolutely magnificent. But, he's a theater guy, he's not a project management guy. What the team needs is an economic development person, a project management person, and a finance person to make the thing work," Mr. Timpanelli said.
Mr. Burke insisted that he has a team of financial backers and developers "involved in doing 300-million-dollar projects all across America, all across the world." He said "they've asked us not to announce their names" until after a purchase agreement is reached with the state.
"How do you think I have managed to keep this thing financed for five years? I've been working on this for five years. Who do you think has been paying for everything?" he asked, adding that he and his wife, the actress Joan Brickhill, "have been very successful" in theater for 35 years.
Meanwhile, Mr. Burke expressed concern about environmental problems he said exist in Selby's Pond in the vicinity of the theater, and from lead paint in the theater.
But, Mr. Clifford said, "as far as we know, there are no toxic materials on the state property."
Mr. Clifford maintained that the state does not own the pond and that the theater is not painted, but stained. He said if there is lead paint, it is in small areas like dressing rooms, which he said he did not consider a major obstacle. He pointed out, though, that there are environmental problems in nearby land that Mr. Burke plans to develop.
Mr. Burke was an unsuccesful bidder two years ago when the state selected a preferred developer to lease the property. That selection was scrapped last year after negotiations hadn't made progress and state officials decided to sell the land.
He was chosen preferred developer after bidding $1.5 million for the property. Mr. Reed had bid $1 million, and Stratford Upon the Housatonic, Inc., the preferred developer in the last go-round, bid one dollar, according to Mr. Clifford.
Mr. Clifford said, however, that the state was not obligated to accept Mr. Burke's bid and could seek another sum during negotiations. The state bought the property for $1 million in 1983 to save the theater from bankruptcy.
To help Mr. Burke, State Senator George L. Gunther, a Stratford Republican, proposed a $15 million state loan for the project, but the measure was not acted on by the legislature before it adjourned for the year.
Mr. Burke's $180 million plan calls for renovating the old Shakespeare theater and building two other theaters. It also includes development of 20 acres nearby with hotels, shops and restaurants.
Many officials and residents of Stratford have long been hoping for a resurrection of the theater, which had been a tourist attraction. Layoffs by Sikorsky Aircraft and a planned closing of Allied Signal's Stratford operation, have created a stronger thirst for such an economic boost.
"We feel we need to have some kind of alternate business structure here," said the Town Planner, David W. Killeen. "There are many people who feel very strongly the revitalized theater will play an important role in the future of this community."
But, there is also skepticism. The Stratford Town Manager, Mark S. Barnhart, said, "I think people would like to remain optimistic, but we have seen plans dashed so many times now, it's hard not to get a little discouraged by constant delays."
The Stratford Zoning Commission has approved a theater district. Under its rules, small inns would be permitted in the 300-property area in the Stratford Center Historic District, while hotels, restaurants and shops would be permitted in a nearby commercial area, Mr. Killeen said.
But the district's boundaries have not been drawn. Mr. Barnhart said "there's very little reason to move ahead and establish boundaries of a theater district, if there isn't a finalized theater. Let's be real."
Meanwhile, Mr. Burke is involved in several endeavors. They include a four-week theater workshop to take place at Stratford Academy, a public school, starting July 8; "Dangerous Illusions," a puppet and magic production with a drug abuse message for school children, and seeking affiliation with the nonprofit American National Theater and Academy to help bring credibility to a fund-raising effort for the Shakespeare theater reopening. Plans also include a Renaissance Fair proposed for July 27 on the theater grounds (which needs a special state permit) and readings of new plays undertaken in conjunction with Sacred Heart University in Fairfield.
Mr. Burke ran a theater in Johannesburg from 1974 through 1981. As an actor, he has played Shakespearean characters including Shylock, Iago and Macbeth. He is a member of the League of American Theaters and Producers and a Tony Awards voter.
He has named prominent theater people to his artistic advisory board including Paul Newman, Michael York, Stephanie Powers and James Earl Jones. And, he said his artistic directors are John Barton, founder of the Royal Shakespeare Theater Company in England, and Michael Langham, formerly director The Juilliard School's drama division.
"What more do I have to do, to prove who I am? I'm tired of having to prove myself to everybody who's trying to be a naysayer," Mr. Burke said.
Under state law, Mr. Burke would have three years from the time an agreement is reached with the state to put on a play. If he doesn't, the land will revert to the town. The law requires a 20-year commitment by the developer to use the site as a theater and produce at least one Shakespearean play a year.

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
At the Shore, Your T-Shirt Says It All

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
SARA GILLESPIE, 18 years old, held up a T-shirt from the bulging rack in a shop on the boardwalk in Wildwood. She and her best friend, Melissa Alvaro, had come for a few days to look for a summer job.
The shirt said, "Drink Till He's Cute." 
 Ms. Alvaro, 19, couldn't suppress a giggle, which she quickly covered with a frown. "Pathetic," she said.
Ms. Gillespie flipped through the hangers and found another. It said, in blurry letters: "I'm Not As Think As You Drunk I Am."
"Idiotic," Ms. Alvaro said dismisively.
"Can you imagine wearing anything like that?" Ms. Gillespie asked.
No, they could not. Off they strolled into the blazing sunlight, headed for an amusement pier up the boardwalk where a new $4 million wooden roller coaster with a 100-foot drop had just opened, to see if jobs were available. None were.
On many stretches of the Jersey shore, where public beaches are often blocked by property owners and economic classes are approaching a calcified level of segregation, the least welcome summer visitors are teen-agers and those in their early 20's. Routinely, you will hear words like "rowdies" and "be-boppers" tossed about to describe a generation of young people, not just the few who cause trouble.
As a result, the young people are actively welcomed only by the boardwalk towns, whose distinctive welcome signs are the T-shirt slogans that say as much about the towns as the kids who visit. So it was enlightening last week, for someone who still remembers being young once on the shore, to take a trip down the coast, visiting only the boardwalk towns.
Wildwood, unhappily, is a town where too many businesses and landlords have taken the profits over the years and run, leaving a deteriorating environment beyond the big amusement piers. Just north on the coast, though, is steadfastly respectable Ocean City, where the amusement rides are small, and the promenade is broad, lined with candy shops, toy stores, movie theaters, and even the occasional sushi bar.
Here the T-shirt slogans have an entirely different tone, like this one, on a tall young man: "Don't Wait For Your Ship To Come In. Swim Out to It." Or this, on a toddler: "If I Do Be Quiet, You'd Better Find Me." Or this, on a middle-aged father, in text designed to look like an entry in a dictionary: "College: A Bar With a $20,000 Cover Charge." Or this, worn by a young woman who looked like a college student: "It's Been Lovely, But I Have to Scream Now."
The boardwalk was invented in Atlantic City, but since the casinos came in the world-famous Atlantic City boardwalk has become as grubby as a street carnival. T-shirts here reflect the fact that few people under the legal gambling age of 21 give the town a second look. "I'm Retired and Spending My Children's Inheritance," one said.
In bar-crammed Seaside Heights, the message is both traditional and modern, reflecting the proximity to New York marketing experts of tens of thousands of potential young consumers on any summer weekend. While T-shirts still flap outside boardwalk shops with misogynistic wisecracks, the old mom-and-pop silkscreening shops responsible for the bawdy shirts are being pushed out these days by manufacturers with commercial tie-ins to corporate brands aimed at young people. The famous Bud Light commercials' "I Love You, Man" line is ubiquitous on T-shirts this year, for example. So are Absolut Vodka logos, and shirts with logos for Cheerios and Burger King.
Not that you see a lot of them beyond the store racks. "I wouldn't wear one of those ads unless they paid me to be a billboard," said one young man, taking his break from a summer job running a game booth, dragging on a cigarette under a huge electric Joe Camel sign.
At Point Pleasant Beach, the northernmost and smallest of the boardwalk towns, an 18-year-old named Kyle Schneider was reading a novel inside a beach-ticket booth. She has just finished her freshman year of college, and reclaimed the summer job she has had since high school.
"People think all boardwalk towns are rowdy, but that just isn't true anymore, except maybe for Wildwood -- where you don't even consider going at night," she said, shutting her book to watch joggers chug by. Behind her, a big red kite soared and plunged on wind currents above long, curling waves.
"T-shirts? You really don't see a lot of that here," she said.
But a little farther down the promenade, a girl on in-line skates glided by wearing a sweatshirt that had the message that finally seemed to capture the zeitgeist of the boardwalk summer of 1996.
"Whatever," it said.

HEADLINE: THE BIRTH OF A REVOLUTIONARY CLASS

 I once fed my wage history into my computer and determined that the Government was giving me a return of just 3 1/2 percent on the joint contributions I and my employers had made.

HEADLINE: THE BIRTH OF A REVOLUTIONARY CLASS

 BODY:
Social Security and Medicare would not have had a breath of a chance to become law if it weren't for the fact that everyone who pays in is entitled to benefits. Recent changes in the tax laws are evidence of an increasing dichotomy between what one paid in taxes and receives in benefits. For the highly productive, and therefore well-compensated, middle class, Social Security and Medicare are becoming a bad deal. 
 If these entitlement programs are allowed to become just another way of soaking the rich, the support for them will gradually erode.
 
ANTHONY E. MAAS, M.D.
Mechanicsburg, Pa.

HEADLINE: Shocklets of Recognition

BYLINE: By Susan Bolotin; Susan Bolotin is the assistant managing editor of Life magazine.

 BODY:

LEARNING TO DRIVE
By William Norwich.
214 pp. New York:
Atlantic Monthly Press. $22.
 New Yorkers are tripping over one another to get close enough to William Norwich to congratulate him on his first novel. Who will be first in position to whisper the question that tout le monde wants answered: Why did the perennially effusive gossip columnist for The New York Observer and editor at large for Vogue write a novel about a fashion magazine slave/tabloid columnist, if not to encourage the reader to fit fact to fantasy? But, then, this is one literary gamble (or is it more of a gambol?) that pays off. Just think of what it did for Truman Capote, Dominick Dunne, Tom Wolfe and Anonymous. 
 Here's the skinny: The fashion mag boss, Ines Spring, wears dark glasses indoors and favors Chanel. No need to hang out with Tina Brown -- or to know that the editor in question hails from the far side of the drink -- to recognize Vogue's always recognizable Anna Wintour. Or her boss, H. M. (If one pronounces S. I. Newhouse's name as Sy, does H. M. become Him? Or is it Hymn?) Let's leave this guessing game to Liz Smith!
 Anyway, back to the plot. Our hero, Julian Orr, who fiddles away his nights at launch parties for perfumes, his days in front of a computer screen, decides, at the age of 37, that he must learn to drive. He wants to visit his parents' graves in southeastern Connecticut, and his shrink has convinced him that hiring a car for a cemetery outing would be "too much of an 80's thing to do; too catered." Simply dying for company, he dragoons Ms. Spring-Wintour-Fall, who is also a vehicular neophyte. "Ines, we're going to learn to drive!" he tootles. "They'll have us at McCauley's."
 Ines takes to driving school like Kate Moss to ennui, but Julian, anxious, tormented by unresolved childhood issues, cannot get the hang of it. With his learner's permit about to expire like Blaine Trump, Patty Hearst Shaw, Caroline Herrera and Alfonse D'Amato after a late night at the Temple of Dendur, who should appear to play Fairy Godmother to his Cinderella? A McCauley's driving instructor named Hector, who, just that morning, had canceled his appointment to take Julian for his driving test, not caring one iota that Julian had already picked out the blue Armani!
 What would any self-respecting journalist do? Right: Julian threatens the driving school manager with negative press. And how would any media-savvy New Yorker respond, stuck between this Scylla of journalistic blackmail and that Charybdis of an uncooperative staff member? Right: he threatens Hector with unemployment. So Hector shows up. Too bad he loses it not long after, turning a trip to Sheepshead Bay into a Journey through Madness, Murder and Random Mayhem in the Outer Boroughs. (Tom Wolfe might be up for another tip of the hat about here.)
This part of "Learning to Drive" is quite a ride -- bewildering, and sometimes uncomfortably bumpy. Mr. Norwich writes: "Fatigued by my half-baked days, I went to bed early except for a brief spurt of energy during the Studio 54 disco days that left me exhausted, physically and financially, when the dancing feast moved to places like the Mudd Club and Area." Whew! Well, Andy Warhol wouldn't have cared if a sentence didn't parse.
 Scattered among the excess clauses, like Kennedys around Hyannisport, are charming set pieces about Julian's youth. The boy lived a melodramatic childhood (deaths, car crashes, drownings, homosexual seductions) with people who spent "almost perfectly speechless days" together. Julian's recollections of that time have an opaque quality -- did he never ask why his neurasthenic mother slept alone, while his father "rolled me in his arms" at night? -- but Mr. Norwich's descriptions have a sweetness that is very appealing.
 Indeed, what most comes through "Learning to Drive" is how appealing Mr. Norwich is. You want to like a gossip columnist whose self-esteem is such that he's constantly having his alter-ego gossip columnist apologize for being a gossip columnist. "I learned the column wasn't about writing -- no one cared about the writing -- it was about tabulating names." Really, there's no need to apologize. Just as there's no need to have a childhood friend ask of Julian, "If you're really a writer, why don't you write?"
 Simone de Beauvoir once said that female friends look to each other for "the affirmation of the universe they have in common." Gossip, when done without malice (or at least without overt hostility), serves the same purpose. Really, there's simply no need to apologize.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Commercial Market at Midpoint: Holding Its Own

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
LATE last year, when AT&T announced it would lay off 6,000 workers in New Jersey and split into three companies, real estate executives feared that the state's largest employer would shed some of its 23 million square feet of space. But there appears to have been no great effect on the market.
For as much space as AT&T gave back in some buildings, it or one of its spinoffs took space in others, keeping the company's occupancy at a status quo, said Ritch Blasi, its spokesman. 
 In the last six months, in fact, the market has been left in a slightly better position as many tenants repeated the space-swapping pattern of AT&T in every segment of the state's commercial market. And indications are that the market will stay the course through the year, brokers and industry analysts say.
As a corollary, 1996 "is expected to be a reasonable if not a headline-grabbing growth year for New Jersey," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Boustein School of Urban Policy and Planning at Rutgers University in New Brunswick.
A steady pace of leasing is whittling down available office space and nudging up rents, brokers say. They also say that small and midsize companies are the market's mainstay tenants as the supply of big blocks of space thins.
The squeezing of space has led to a trickle of speculative building after a six-year lull in some of the tightest markets, such as the Interstate 78/287 corridor. It has also forced tenants who bypassed weaker markets with significant vacancies, such as Piscataway in Middlesex County, to look to them again.
In the retail sector, where there have been bankruptcies of such discounters as Bradlees and Jamesway, new companies, like Target, are entering the scene. And with drugstores, supermarkets and movie theaters increasing their appetite for space the market has regained stability.
There is also new development, stoked mainly by big-box retailers, which continue to expand in the state. For instance, a 90,000-square-foot project for Toys "R" Us, Kids "R" Us and the new Babies "R" Us is under way in Elizabeth. Nearby, work has begun on a 1.2 million-square-foot outlet center; others are planned in Jackson Township and Carteret. Though the days of building regional malls seem over, some are expanding. One proposal would add 250,000 square feet to the Bridgewater Commons Mall.
"The climate is more upbeat than it was in January," said Matthew Harding, senior vice president at the Levine Management Corporation in North Plainfield. "Rents are stable and the vacancy rate remains flat at 6 percent." But the long-term retail outlook is uncertain, Mr. Harding added.
Ted Kraus, who runs a retail advisory firm in Mercerville, agreed. "What we're seeing now is a game of replacement, not growth," he said, "New stores will open. But they will rob customers from competitors and there will be some losers."
As for industrial property, a demand for modern warehouse and distribution space produced a spate of such projects for specific tenants. Most are around Exits 10 and 8A of the New Jersey Turnpike, and are being sought by firms expanding or consolidating from scattered sites to increase efficiency.
One is Volkswagen of America. It moved distribution operations from Orangeburg, N.Y., and the Washington area into a 320,000-square-foot distribution center just completed at the Centerpoint business park, straddling Monroe and South Brunswick in the 8A region.
Over all, industrial leasing slowed, and some markets, like the Meadowlands, saw space returned, especially in older buildings where some of it may never get leased, brokers say. But they insist that the lull in the market is temporary.
The space swapping will continue as will building activity, although more slowly, said John G. Orrico, senior vice president of the local offices of the Grubb & Ellis brokerage. The vacancy rate will stay at 9.7 percent, he said, adding, "It's a tight market."
While the office market remains the most active of all three sectors, concern lingers.
AT&T's breakup has so far had less harsh an effect on the market than expected. But that reshuffling, as well as continued downsizings and mergers -- particularly in the banking industry -- are sure to result in the return of space to the market and jobs losses.
"A decrease in jobs is still anticipated," said Mr. Blasi of AT&T. "And that will probably mean less office space."
Yet, Dr. Hughes of Rutgers said, companies have been downsizing for the last four years and there are 190,000 more jobs in the state now than in 1992, as companies with high growth rates pick up the slack. That is expected to continue this year, he said, adding that the state would gain as jobs as it did in 1995 -- 33,000 -- and possibly more.
That bodes well for the office market, "which has entered a period of modest but steady improvement," said S. Harold Appel, senior vice president and managing officer of CB Commercial's New Jersey offices.
The vacancy rate for the 11-county northern New Jersey market fell from 19.4 percent at the end of 1995 to 18.7 percent in the first quarter this quarter, the lowest this decade, according to the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield. "If all pending deals go through, it could slip below 18 percent by next month," said Donald P. Eisen, the brokerage's senior managing director.
With rents creeping up and concessions vanishing, there are hints of a switch to a landlord's market from one favoring the tenant, he said. Expanding companies, notably in the computer and communications industry, are helping the market.
Bay Networks, a maker of computer-networking equipment, expanded to 60,000 square feet in Parsippany in Morris County, among the strongest markets. The Interstate-287/78 corridor, wooed one of the few new arrivals, B.E.A Systems Inc., a computer software provider in Sunnyvale, Calif., which leased a 62,250-square-foot building in Bernards Township for its East Coast base.
ALSO stoking the activity are hospitals and health maintenance organizations, which "are increasingly prevalent players in the market," said Jonathan B. Shultz, president of the brokerage services group of the Woodbridge-based Schultz Organization. An example is the purchase of a 30,000-square-foot former bank headquarters in Long Branch by Modern Health Affiliates, a group of doctors from the Shore Medical Center in Neptune. The building will be used for outpatient care.
Cable operations also want to move to the state, said Norman B. Baker, senior managing director at the Edward S. Gordon offices in Saddle Brook. MSNBC, a venture of Microsoft and NBC, leased the 110,000-square-foot former Jamesway warehouse in Secaucus for its cable-news network. And Mr. Baker said four media companies were scouting space at Fort Lee Executive Park, which his firm represents.
The activity has left the market with a scarcity of large blocks of space. A few developers have responded with speculative projects. The Bellemead Development Corporation of Roseland is constructing a 207,727-square-foot building in Warren Township in Somerset County, which just landed Hoechst Celanese of Bridgewater as its single tenant. The new space will allow Hoechst to expand its operations.
Bellemead also plans to start a 107,000-square-foot speculative building this summer in Parsippany.
In Bridgewater, SJP Properties of Parsippany plans to start a 240,000-square-foot building this fall at the 118-acre Somerset Corporate Center, which is set at a four-way interchange of I-287, just south of I-78. "This is one of the tightest markets," said Steven J. Pozycki, SJP'S president. "And there are tenants looking for large blocks of space."
But these projects do not signal a full-scale return to the heady days of the mid-80's. "The market is moving to positive ground," Mr. Eisen of Cushman & Wakefield said. "Only it's moving slowly."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 13; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1030 words

HEADLINE: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
Beneficial Capitalism, R.I.P.

BYLINE: By ALEXEI BAYER; Alexei Bayer runs his own economic consulting firm, Kafan FX Information Services, in New York.

 BODY:
WHEN Russian voters go to the polls today, they may end up returning to power a regime that only five years ago they so joyously overthrew.
That Russians should pine for the past is understandable: they lost economic security enjoyed under Communism and are faced with collapsing social services, a widening gulf between the rich and the poor and a slew of other economic and social problems. 
 But Russians do not have a monopoly on nostalgia. While Americans, their cold war rivals, are enjoying the fruits of political victory, dissatisfaction with economic conditions in the United States is widespread as well. How did that happen?
Since the end of the cold war, the death of ideology has been repeatedly proclaimed. Indeed, as a basis for social organization, ideology is being replaced everywhere by economic efficiency and free-market principles. But Communism was not the only creed that went down in defeat. The West, too, had an ideology -- a capitalist ideology, as it were -- that also perished under the New World Order.
If the Communists win today, it will not be a victory for their old ideology. The creed's appeal is so limited that Gennadi Zyuganov, the Communist candidate, had to spice up his rhetoric with nationalism, anti-Semitism, support for private property and even tolerance for Christianity -- concepts that are not just alien to Marxism but directly inimical to it.
While there is no reason to mourn the death of Communism, that is not true for the capitalist ideology, which had its roots in the great battle of ideas that broke out after World War II. Based on Marxism, Soviet propaganda insisted that, as capitalism developed, workers would become progressively impoverished. Broad-based prosperity was impossible, it said, unless property was communized and workers themselves ran the machinery of the state.
The United States took upon itself to disprove these claims. Just as Communism had to be contained physically -- for example, in Greece, Iran and Korea -- it had to be defended on the ideological front. America had to demonstrate that capitalism provides a good life for workers and that standards of living in an open, democratic and capitalist system would surpass anything possible under a Communist regime. The system that emerged was meant to insure that increases in the common economic pie would be distributed widely among participants in the economic process. Owners of capital, management, government and employees would all get their fair share.
The system functioned remarkably smoothly, in part because postwar economic growth created an ever-expanding pie and in part because of faith in capitalist ideology, which quickly imbued all classes and united Democrats and Republicans in Congress and the White House. Trade unions, which in other countries often advocated radical change, were among the staunchest defenders of the American way. They gave management a free hand to run companies; in return, management let workers share the success.
The capitalist ideology reached its apogee in the 1960's, with the Great Society programs. President Johnson set out to prove that capitalism not only could improve the lot of workers but also eradicate poverty altogether. It was natural, therefore, that Johnson pursued the Vietnam War: a president who pushed the capitalist creed to its final frontier at home was determined to curb Communist expansion abroad.
Arising in response to the Soviet threat in the postwar decades, the Great Society was both the high noon of capitalism and the beginning of its twilight. In the late 1960's and 1970's, when the ideological threat of Communism began to recede, the capitalist ideology also went into decline. Statistics show that in the early 1970's, average household incomes in the United States started to stagnate and then fall; income distribution began to polarize. Remarkably, the onset of this trend coincided with President Nixon's first visits to Beijing and Moscow.
Factors usually blamed for declining average incomes and skewed income distribution -- inflation, the oil shock, technological change and the flight of jobs abroad -- are merely challenges thrown up by the economic system. The weakening of capitalist ideology, however, shaped our responses to those challenges. Over the past two decades, there were periods of economic growth as well as contraction. In good times and bad, owners of capital and upper management consistently benefited at the expense of wage earners.
In the 1980's, Brezhnevite stagnation in the Soviet Union was mirrored in the United States by an accelerating decline of the capitalist ideology. Although inflation fell and growth returned after 1982, economic gains were divided unevenly. The old myth, that rising productivity would lead to higher living standards, was shattered as mechanisms for a more equitable distribution of incomes were dismantled. Managerial commitment to employees waned. In recent years, the benefits of economic growth have gone entirely to owners of capital, senior managers and upper-income individuals; worse, wage earners continue to lose ground even as the overall economy expands.
In 1992, when the Soviet Union collapsed and political scientists declared victory for capitalism, what they failed to notice was that capitalism as it was known in the postwar period was also dead. Instead, the free market emerged triumphant.
True, the capitalist ideology owed its success to the free market that underpinned economic growth. But the free market alone could not have achieved the broad-based prosperity this country enjoyed in the 1950's and 1960's. It was not the case in the 19th century, when free-market forces advocated by the "Manchester school" liberals wreaked havoc with the living standards of the early industrial work force, nor is it happening now, when the return of an unfettered market is undermining the living standards of the working poor in the United States.
In retrospect, the capitalist ideology was a rare breed: it was benign and inclusive, and it aspired to provide a decent life for the largest possible number of people. Its passing should be mourned.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Gloves Embellished By Women's Visions

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

DATELINE: SUMMIT

 BODY:
FRAN WILLNER and Lois Shapiro threw down the gauntlet to 70 female artists they knew. The two curators had come into possession of a motley collection of gloves belonging to someone who had acquired them over a lifetime and was about to enter a nursing home. They mailed off one glove to each of the artists, about 50 of them New Jerseyans, asking them to transform the gloves into art. The results are "The Glove Project" at the New Jersey Center for the Visual Arts.
The show is good-natured and warm-hearted, and more than a few of the submissions even pass muster as art. In their printed statement, the curators give themselves an out when they describe the glove recipients as being "of varied interests and talents." Artistic activity of this sort, in which a range of artists is given the same item to work with, is always revealing, for the way it tests imagination and invention. It's not surprising that some artists score higher than others. Hard work counts for a lot, too. 
 Viewers are met by Phoebe Frank's "Glovis Erectus," around which she has woven a whole mythology. Her creation is an extinct spotted creature that was able to self-procreate. Captured in a small glass-fronted box, it looks out with a wily expression. Not far away, Irene Steglitz shows some rebelliousness by rejecting the glove that was sent her; she fashioned an ersatz one out of paper. "The gloves were mailed out randomly," the curators write. "Many didn't like the glove they got."
Many proceeded just to embellish their gloves, covering them with glitter, baubles and, more prosaically, buttons. Several artists painted fingernails on their gloves or slipped on gaudy rings. In this regard, a drawback of the concept is revealed: an artist may have thought she was doing something singular and had no way of knowing that many others had come up with the same idea. (All 70 are on display.)
Gloves that work well have an edge to them, like the spindly daddy longlegs out of thin wire that Mary Olive Stone simply placed on her dark blue bequest. Not surprisingly, several cliches are illustrated, literally, among them "Bite Hand," by Meredith Turshen, a set of yellowing false teeth clamping down on the glove's fingers. Fortuitously, she was sent a white specimen, and the trickle of blood she stitched with red thread is very visible.
It's very likely that a punning title preceded the fabrication of a piece, and too many artists found it irresistible to rhyme "glove" with "love." A doll emphasizing a glove's splayed fingers by Gail Fishberg is "Lady Chatterley's Glover." More artists than did could have animated their gloves, showing them in arrested action; one who did so is Evelyn Simpson, who placed chopsticks correctly between two fingers for "I Think I've Got It."
Several artists saw a glove as a tree with the fingers as branches, but Shary Skoloff bent the fingers of her gloves so that they project outward, holding a nest with three eggs. She calls her creation "Nature's Promise." Some of the artists accomplished thorough transformations, as Diane Price did with "Quirky Whimsical Birdhouse." Perhaps her title includes too many adjectives, but she was economical in her method, inverting her glove to expose the finger holes and making one cavity the opening to the dwelling. She also bunched the body of the glove around a post and added a perch under the entry hole.
T HE most immediately winning pieces are gloves turned into animals. Two horses are in the group: Joelynn Trilling's rearing "Handhorse" and an elaborate Victorian rocking horse by Jaqui Jacobs, who made three fingers of a white glove into a stylized mane. The most impressive animal, seemingly accomplished through a process resembling origami, is the rooster by Renee Hayman, who folded the fingers of a brown glove to form a proud tail. Even the egregious puns constituting her title, "Hand-some Rooster Looking for His Chick," don't mar the simple artistry.
Several artists, dealt black gloves, knew how to bring out their inherent mysteriousness. Pulling out all the horrific stops, Ms. Shapiro calls her black glove with its splayed fingers and snake slithering between two of them "Out of the Crypt." Vicki Parker's "Between Two Worlds," an elaborate construction, is essentially two open cubes lined with religious symbols, actually features two black gloves; one clutches a cross, the other a totem pole. A working man's shiny, slick black glove abets Laurel Clark's aims. Adorned with objects related to American Indians, the glove, which looks as if it has emerged from water, is titled "Resurrection."
That title has something to do with the two works that make the most trenchant social comments. Clara Manheim added a syringe and some rubber tubing to her glove. The resulting "War of the 90's" is meant as a statement about AIDS. On the other hand, as it were, Nancy Wimmer affixed a packet containing her own red blood cells to her glove. Ms. Wimmer, who has recovered from a bone marrow transplant, titles her work "(B+) Be Positive."
 
THE GLOVE PROJECT
 New Jersey Center for Visual Arts
68 Elm Street, Summit
Through July 7. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and 7 to 9 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 4 P.M.
