HEADLINE: A Widow's Pique

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
Milio Azcarraga Milmo usually travels with an entourage befitting the most powerful media mogul in Mexico. With his baronial bearing and distinctive appearance -- a stripe of white hair bisects his jet-black mane -- Mr. Azcarraga lives up to his nickname, "El Tigre."
On a bright, cold morning in January, however, Mr. Azcarraga turned up alone at the home of Mary Anselmo in Greenwich, Conn. And on that day at least, the tiger acted more like a tabby. 
 Mr. Azcarraga had known Mrs. Anselmo and her late husband, Rene V. Anselmo, over four turbulent decades. Through his company, Grupo Televisa S.A., he had backed Mr. Anselmo's bold effort to break into the satellite business. Now, though, Mr. Azcarraga wanted Mrs. Anselmo to sell her husband's creation, PanAmSat, which had become the world's largest private satellite network, so he could liquidate his investment.
After a brief, subdued conversation in front of a crackling fireplace, Mrs. Anselmo acquiesced. She has been in agony ever since.
"I'm not sure Rene would have approved," Mrs. Amselmo said in an interview at her home, an elegant chateau modeled on the Petit Trianon at Versailles. "I think he would have thought this was precipitate."
Indeed, the 66-year-old widow's reluctant decision has set off an emotionally charged drama involving her family, Mr. Azcarraga and PanAmSat's 188 employees. Behind everything hovers her late husband, a charismatic but combative man who seemed to spy an enemy behind every satellite dish. Though Mr. Anselmo died of heart failure in September at 69, his tangled legacy looms large over the family and the family business.
So great were his passions and so fierce his feuds that Mr. Anselmo still seems to be pulling strings from the peaceful grotto behind his home where he is buried.
"Rene was a fighter and a scrapper," said Mark Fowler, who, as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission under President Ronald Reagan, helped Mr. Anselmo pierce the monopoly in satellites. "He was crazy like a fox."
Mrs. Anselmo has retained Morgan, Stanley & Company to solicit offers for PanAmSat. People familiar with the process said Morgan had already attracted a blue-chip list of potential buyers: Hughes Electronics, General Electric, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, Loral, Lockheed Martin, and SES, a European satellite company. Morgan hopes to present a menu of options to the family in mid-July.
With its necklace of four satellites that float in stationary orbit 22,300 miles above the equator and beam channels like CNN, HBO, and MTV to more than 100 countries, PanAmSat is a crown jewel in the rarefied world of global satellite networks. It now has a market capitalization of $2.9 billion, and several investment bankers estimate that it could command a price between $3 billion and $4 billion.
Mrs. Anselmo, however, frets that a new owner may sunder the close-knit team of sales executives and engineers that her husband gathered around him in the 12 tumultuous years that he built PanAmSat from a far-fetched concept into a public company that trades at a gravity-defying multiple of 25 times 1995 revenues.
Prominent among these executives is Frederick A. Landman, president and chief executive, who began working for Mr. Anselmo fresh out of college in 1973 and married his only daughter, Pier, four years later. Mr. Landman, 48, and Pier Anselmo were recently divorced, but he retains close ties to Mary Anselmo. The couple have two daughters, Rissa and Chloe.
"My husband was very paternalistic, and I've inherited that," said Mrs. Anselmo, whose sad eyes and weary tone bespeak a woman struggling with the pressures of settling her husband's estate. "It makes this really tough."
If Mrs. Anselmo does not receive an attractive offer for PanAmSat, she has the option of doing a secondary stock offering instead. Under the company's shareholder structure, she is all but guaranteed to have the final say on any deal. And if Televisa tries to sell its stake without her consent, the stock would lose its special PanAmSat voting rights.
But a stock offering would raise less money than an outright sale. That may not suit Televisa, which needs to fix a balance sheet battered by the collapse of the Mexican peso in 1995. Televisa's $200 million investment in PanAmSat now has a market value of $1.17 billion.
Although Televisa recently raised $700 million through a private debt placement, the company has not wavered from its desire to cash out of PanAmSat. "The refinancing does not in any way change our position," said Guillermo Caneda White, chief financial officer of Televisa and Mr. Azcarraga's principal representative on the PanAmSat board.
Though Mrs. Anselmo says she, too, wants a premium price for PanAmSat, an attractive offer clearly means more than cold cash. She said she would also like to honor the memory of her husband.
And that's where things get sticky. Mr. Anselmo, the son of a Massachusetts postal superintendent of Italian descent, served as a young Marine tail-gunner in World War II. Throughout his life, he relished a good fight and nursed old grudges -- against competitors, suppliers, partners, even his neighbors in Greenwich. "When I get mad, I just never give up," he said in a 1990 interview.
Now, the battles Mr. Anselmo fought during his life could ensnare the sale of PanAmSat after his death.
For example, Hughes is perhaps the most logical buyer. The company is starting a direct-to-home satellite service in Latin America that could be folded into a rival Latin American service being started by PanAmSat, Televisa and several media companies. Hughes is also no stranger to PanAmSat; it built three of its satellites.
The catch? Hughes deeply offended Mr. Anselmo when it opted to go head-to-head with PanAmSat and Televisa in Latin America. He told Hughes executives he would never buy another satellite from them and promptly switched his contract to Loral.
The bitterness persists. Shortly after her husband's death, Mrs. Anselmo got a condolence letter from C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of Hughes. After expressing his regrets, however, Mr. Armstrong segued into business -- offering to buy the company if Mrs. Anselmo put it up for sale. "It was a clumsy move," she said.
Reverge C. Anselmo, her 33-year-old son, who used to work for PanAmSat and is now one of its five directors, is more frank. "We don't like Hughes," he said. "They betrayed my dad, and they betrayed Azcarraga."
A spokesman for Hughes declined to comment on Mr. Armstrong's letter or on whether Hughes planned to bid for PanAmSat. One top Hughes executive, who declined to be identified, acknowledged that "it makes for a strained relationship when your satellite manufacturer is also competing with you as an operator." But he added that Mr. Anselmo's past clashes with the company would not influence its decision to bid.
NOTHING dramatizes the late Mr. Anselmo's mix of vision and vitriol more than his roller-coaster relationship with Mr. Azcarraga.
The two men met in Mexico in 1954, where Mr. Anselmo settled after graduating from the Great Books program at the University of Chicago in 1951. Mr. Anselmo was directing theatrical productions while Mr. Azcarraga was dabbling as a theatrical financier. Mrs. Anselmo, who married Mr. Anselmo soon after he moved to Mexico, remembers the young Mr. Azcarraga as a "playboy," though she said he worked hard and had the drive of a locomotive.
Mr. Azcarraga prodded his father to recruit Mr. Anselmo to build a television network that would cater to the mushrooming Hispanic population in the United States. The company he created, Spanish International Network, eventually strung together more than 300 affiliates. Together, Mr. Azcarraga and Mr. Anselmo also acquired five stations.
In 1985, though, the F.C.C. refused to renew the station licenses after ruling that their foreign parent company, Televisa, exercised too much control over them. Over Mr. Anselmo's strident objections, the younger Mr. Azcarraga agreed to sell the stations and the network. Mr. Anselmo pocketed $80 million, but he broke off relations with the younger Mr. Azcarraga.
From broadcasting, it was a small leap for Mr. Anselmo to satellites. His debut as a satellite executive has already passed into lore -- as celebrated in this tight-knit industry as Ted Turner's risky foray into round-the-clock news is among cable programmers.
In 1988, Mr. Anselmo gambled the bulk of his fortune, more than $60 million, to buy a used satellite and launch it with inadequate insurance and no clients on an unproven Ariane rocket. A three-pack-a-day smoker, Mr. Anselmo missed the launching in French Guiana because he was in Greenwich recovering from quintuple bypass surgery.
While Mr. Anselmo scrambled to sign up clients -- his first coup was a contract to transmit CNN to Latin America -- he waged an epic and victorious battle against Intelsat, a consortium owned by more than 100 governments that dominated the global satellite business.
President Reagan had declared in 1984 that private operators ought to be allowed to compete with Intelsat in global satellite communications. But Intelsat lobbied long and furiously, both at home and abroad, to keep PanAmSat out of the business. Mr. Anselmo retaliated with a blizzard of letters to F.C.C. officials and lawmakers that lampooned Intelsat's monopoly with humor that sometimes bordered on the scatological.
"We were all amused to read those letters," said Mr. Fowler. "They were either the product of a very clever mind or a very demented one."
Alfred C. Sikes, one of Mr. Fowler's successors as F.C.C. chairman, said there was a method to the madness. "Discussing satellite policy is like watching paint dry. He took it out of the abstract."
In Congressional testimony, Mr. Anselmo played to the hilt the role of scrappy underdog. Bernard L. Schwartz, the chairman of Loral, recalls sitting next to Mr. Anselmo at a 1994 House hearing. Asked what he thought of a treaty restricting overseas satellite transmission, Mr. Anselmo ripped up a piece of paper with a flourish.
Mr. Anselmo created a cartoon dog named Spot as a mascot for his crusade. Spot was usually pictured lifting his hind leg -- a less-than-subtle metaphor for Mr. Anselmo's contempt for monopolies. Spot showed up in letters, newspaper advertisements, even emblazoned on the nose cone of the Ariane rockets that carried PanAmSat's satellites aloft. Even today, the company's stock trades on Nasdaq under the symbol SPOT.
Emboldened by his early success, Mr. Anselmo agreed to pay $721 million in 1991 to build, insure, and launch three more satellites. After a fruitless search for investors, Mr. Anselmo went back to Mr. Azcarraga with an offer to sell Televisa 50 percent of PanAmSat for $200 million. Despite the six-year rupture in their friendship, Mr. Azcarraga agreed.
With Mr. Azcarraga's money in his pocket, Mr. Anselmo set off on a wild ride to turn PanAmSat, which then had one satellite, into a global network able to sign up a wide array of clients and beam their programming virtually anywhere in the world. Over the next three years, Mr. Anselmo kept expanding despite a failed satellite launching, an initial public offering that was pulled at the last minute and ever-worsening health problems that led to another major operation in 1994.
By the time of Mr. Anselmo's death -- the day before the company's shares began trading on Nasdaq -- PanAmSat had become a genuinely global player. The company had expanded beyond its core clientele of American cable networks to sign up foreign broadcasters like China Central Television, Doordarshan of India, and NHK of Japan.
"They came at a time when there was no good alternative," said Robert M. Zitter, the senior vice president of technology operations at HBO. "And they developed a system that meets the needs of the television market." HBO leases capacity on three PanAmSat satellites to beam its channel to Latin America, Asia, and, soon, India.
In 1995, PanAmSat's revenue rose to $116.1 million, almost twice the $63.7 million it recorded in 1994. More than half of last year's revenue, $66.1 million, is operating cash flow -- money the company can theoretically reinvest in the business. In the first quarter of 1996, PanAmSat's results continued to soar: revenues hit $50.4 million, while cash flow jumped to $36.6 million.
PanAmSat's horizon is not completely cloud-free. With the explosion of satellite communications, private companies are sprouting here and abroad to challenge its cozy franchise. And Mr. Anselmo's pell-mell expansion saddled the company with $575 million in long-term debt.
But Andrew Hornick, a media and communications analyst at Citicorp Securities Inc., said the debt load was manageable because the company would generate a reliable flow of revenue from long-term contracts worth a total of $3.2 billion. Once airborne, he pointed out, satellites are inexpensive to maintain.
These unusual economics -- large starting costs offset by low operating expenses and lofty margins -- have made PanAmSat's stock buoyant. After going public in September at $17, the company's shares slipped briefly and then rose to a high of $33.25 in April. Since then, they have settled in the high 20's; on Friday, the company's stock closed at $29.
PanAmSat's four satellites already reach 98 percent of the world's population. But Mr. Landman, the chief executive, said PanAmSat intends to launch two more satellites next year and a third by 1998 to expand its capacity to carry TV programming, plus some telephone and data traffic. When finished, PanAmSat will have eight satellites aloft -- four over the Atlantic and two each over the Pacific and Indian oceans.
WHILE Mr. Landman talks excitedly about these plans, his mood darkens when the conversation switches to a potential sale. Like other senior executives, Mr. Landman owes his career to Mr. Anselmo. While Mr. Landman's seven million shares are worth $203 million, there is no other job he wants aside from running his former father-in-law's company.
"This has been a very emotional time for me," he said, "Rene Anselmo was my mentor in every sense of the word."
For Mrs. Anselmo, the potential payoff from a sale is even greater. But so, too, is the emotional strain of worrying about employees like Mr. Landman. The Anselmo family together controls a 40.5 percent stake in PanAmSat, which is worth $1.17 billion, and elects three of the company's five directors. Although Televisa also owns 40.5 percent, it elects only two directors. And in the event of a split among the Anselmos, Mrs. Anselmo alone gets to cast the tie-breaking vote.
Two of Mrs. Anselmo's three children -- Pier and Rayce, a son who has worked in television and lives in California -- profess not to be interested in the business. But Reverge Anselmo, who attended the decisive meeting with Mr. Azcarraga in Greenwich, is keen on diversifying his family's holdings.
"My family has a lot of talent, and there are a lot of other things we could do," Reverge Anselmo said in an interview from his home in Capitan, N.M. "Let's get our noses out of the solar panels for a while."
Reverge Anselmo worked as a sales executive for PanAmSat in Miami for several years, and Mrs. Anselmo said her husband harbored hopes that he would make a career in the family business. But Mr. Anselmo quit abruptly 18 months ago, after clashing with Mr. Landman, then his brother-in-law. Though Mrs. Anselmo said her husband was chagrined, he was not willing to side with his son over Mr. Landman.
"It was a case of the heir apparent coming up against the heir," said Mrs. Anselmo with palpable regret.
Mr. Anselmo is now completing a novel that grew out of his experience as a Marine in Beirut during the 1982 terrorist bombing.
Edward J. Landau, Mrs. Anselmo's lawyer, is also gently prodding her to consider a sale. "No matter how good a company is, to have 95 percent of your net worth in one stock is not a good thing," he said.
People familiar with the process said that at least one company, Loral, had made a preliminary offer for PanAmSat and had indicated it might negotiate. As Mrs. Anselmo watches the players maneuver, she is doing her best to soothe the fears of PanAmSat's employees. After saying she would consider a sale, Mrs. Anselmo reassured employees in a conference call that she would try to take care of them.
In a rare break from her husband's practices, she threw a companywide Christmas party last December at her home, which employees jokingly refer to as the "big house." (Rene Anselmo always hated Christmas parties, according to employees.)
"A lot of us viewed Rene as a father figure," said Lourdes Saralegui, a 34-year-old executive vice president, who joined PanAmSat only 12 years ago as a temporary secretary. "Now, Mary is taking on the role of a maternal figure."
That's no easy task. Just as Katharine Graham struggled to take the reins of the Washington Post and Loida Lewis grappled with the job of running TLC Beatrice International after the deaths of their husbands, Mary Anselmo has found it daunting to step into the breach. "My mother has never had anything other than being Mrs. Anselmo," Reverge Anselmo said.
Smoking one cigarette after another just as her husband had done, Mrs. Anselmo said the other day that she had rarely been involved in her husband's business and that she knows precious little about satellites. Asked how she was handling all the pressure, she responded, "Not too well, obviously."
For example, she expressed surprise in the interview that Morgan Stanley, PanAmSat's financial adviser, was also playing a big role in Televisa's efforts to raise some quick cash. Given her ambivalence about a sale, some of Morgan Stanley's rivals say the bank may be wearing too many hats.
Yet Mr. Landman said Mrs. Anselmo was being too modest. They said she kept well-informed about the financial mechanics. "Don't let her fool you with the I-don't-know-anything-about-business line," he said. And Mrs. Anselmo has continued her vocation: the upkeep of her chateau in suburbia. The Anselmos bought the house in 1967, and she and her husband supervised a never-ending series of landscaping and construction projects dreamed up by Mr. Anselmo.
MR. ANSELMO'S drive to beautify his surroundings extended beyond his front gates. For years, he paid to plant thousands of daffodils and tulips along North Street, where his house is located. In 1990, he was arrested for spray painting over a neighbor's "For Sale" sign that he contended was unsightly. The town later dropped the charges.
Soft-spoken and gracious, Mrs. Anselmo would not use such ham-handed tactics. But she is starting to put her own imprint on the house that Rene built. Mrs. Anselmo just bought the six acres adjoining her 12-acre lot to prevent anyone from building a house there. She said she would like to build a pond and a pavilion on her expanded grounds.
It's the skies -- and the satellites that rove silently through them -- that Mary Anselmo may not have as much control over.

PUB-DATE: June 16, 1996

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 950 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

SPENDING
 
And the Poor Get Plastic
The economy's on a roll, all sorts of jobs are being created, inflation's tamed -- so why didn't you pay that credit-card bill? O.K., not all of you, but a lot of you aren't even paying that bare minimum that keeps credit revolving and that sky-high interest mounting. In fact, as reported last week, credit card delinquencies are at their highest level since the recession year of 1981. What's going on? The answer, as one theory has it, is not a pleasant one: The rich get richer and the poor get bills they can't pay. Yes, the economy's overall numbers are good, but those at the top, gleeful at rising stock prices, are pulling up the averages. Those on the downhill side of the great divide are trying to live on plastic.
 
TRADE
 
Blasting U.S. Cuba Policy
The United States has this thing about Cuba. Maybe we just can't shake the fear that Fidel Castro is going to invade and eat our babies. Or maybe it's pride -- we just can't stand this society, right over our back fence, that refuses to sing the American tune. If it didn't have to get wet, the F.B.I. would probably put on its little ear radios, surround the island, and wait grimly for Mr. Castro to come out. Canada and Mexico, though, don't seem to fear for their babies, for last week they both lashed out at the American law that would penalize foreign companies that trade with Cuba. Canada, in fact, has passed a law banning its companies from complying with the American law. So now all eyes are on July 15, the date when President Clinton must decide whether the law will start being enforced on Aug. 1.
 
CAR DEALERS
 
No Haggling? Un-American!
Imagine buying a candy bar and, instead of just shelling out 60 cents, telling the clerk, "I know the store paid 40 for this, so I'll give you 48 -- 6 for overhead, 2 for profit." (Imagine, too, the irritation of those behind you in line.) Absurd, yes, but that's the way Americans like to buy cars -- dickering and calculating has evolved into a bizarre national sport, with masters of this game proudly draining precious weeks from their lives to whittle that last $50 off a deal. Some foolhardy souls dared to tamper with this sacred rite, offering "no haggle" prices. (There's a price and you pay it? Positively un-American!) For a time the idea looked promising. But car buyers, it seems, have to haggle: of 23,000 new-car dealers nationwide, 2,000 had fixed prices two years ago, but that's down closer to 1,000 now. And that chocolate bar? Not a penny more than 51!
 
BOOKSTORES
 
Megabook Triumphant
For a few years, it was the Little Bookstore That Could. After a mammoth Barnes & Noble plopped itself down nearby, Shakespeare & Company at 81st and Broadway in Manhattan hung on valiantly even as other independents gave up. But a core of loyal customers could prop it up only so long when readers could walk a block or so and find every book imaginable, often at 20 to 30 percent off, with easy chairs and a coffee bar thrown in. Not to mention that street vendors have turned that stretch of Broadway into one long bookstore. Last week, after 15 years, Shakespeare & Company said it would close that store, though it has others in the city. It's "a big loss," said Toni Morrison, "melancholy and outrageous." One sad reader, normally a Barnes & Noble shopper, said he "bought three books out of guilt." With the price of books these days, guilt fits in precious few budgets.
 
THE INTERNET
 
Phone? TV? No, Chaos!
There's this new monster in town, and no one can quite figure out what it is. Is the Internet more like a telephone, or a TV, or a newspaper, or what? And, semantics aside -- this is the sticky part -- where does it fit into the whole free-speech puzzle? The Government tried to turn it into a beast it could tame, creating a law aimed at controlling indecent material (though it was never clear how that taming would be accomplished). But last week a Federal court resoundingly hit the delete key on that law, calling the Internet "the most participatory marketplace of mass speech" ever seen. It's made of "chaos" that should be celebrated, one judge wrote. And some observers, struggling to put a name to the beast, called it "unique" and "the telephone writ large."
 
KICKING THE CAR
All Aboard, Mr. Ewing!
Not many years ago, the question was, Who shot J.R.? But the question in Dallas today is, Will J.R. ever ride a commuter train? And a burning question it is, for Texans, perhaps even more than other Americans, just love to burn up the local cash crop -- petroleum -- to move themselves around. But last week a most un-Texan sight appeared in Dallas: the first stage of a 20-mile, $860 million rail transit line. The next step: getting people to use it, which may be tough considering the advanced case of automobile addiction. Dallas's mayor is "reasonably confident" that the efficiency of the line will eventually bring people around. But who said being addicted to cars is reasonable?
 
MIXED VALUES
 
What Is a Disney Family?
It's odd how the same term, "family values," can be applied to beliefs at the violent extremes of today's testy society. Walt Disney, a family-friendly outfit if ever there was one, defined "family" broadly last year, extending health benefits to workers' gay partners. But last week, also waving the "family" banner, the Southern Baptist Convention voted to censure Disney for that policy and even threatened a boycott. It's "cut and dried in the Bible" that homosexuality is a sin, said one Southern Baptist, while another, a minister, defended Disney, saying his church should be "more Christ-like in this regard."

LENGTH: 315 words

HEADLINE: State's Garbage Strategy Is Ripe for Overturning

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Theodore Schwartz's essay "What a Waste" (Soapbox, June 2) ignores some important facts in support of the dubious proposition that New Jersey's cities and towns should submit to the state's "flow control" strategy for garbage disposal. 
 First, the strategy, as embodied in the state's solid waste law, violates the United States Constitution, which prohibits individual states from hoarding an article of commerce -- in this case, garbage -- to the exclusion of other states.
Second, Mr. Schwartz suggests that flow control is economical. In fact, the system has resulted in the highest disposal rates in the nation. In 1975, disposal costs amounted to a few dollars a ton. Today, they average more than $100 a ton, which is used to feed the bureaucratic monoliths called county utility authorities.
Small wonder that the Mayors Task Force Against Flow Control was formed to bring some rationality to a system that has utterly destroyed any notion of competition.The task force numbers 240 strong, including mayors from 7 of the largest 10 cities. It believes that mayors must be able to contract with the most cost-effective yet environmentally sound vendors they can find. In some instances, communities can save hundreds of thousands of dollars with the stroke of a pen, simply by dealing directly with the same vendors the county authorities deal with now.
The argument that without flow control we risk the type of turmoil experienced 25 years ago overlooks advances in environmental enforcement over that period, as well as the empirical evidence in other states. And the suggestion that mayors are too unsophisticated or myopic to understand this issue is insulting to the men and women who serve their communities and, quite simply, absurd.
 
RONALD S. BERGAMINI
Glen Rock
 
The writer is a lawyer with Riccardelli & Hoonhout in Montclair.

HEADLINE: Finding the Arms Factories;
Iraq Isn't Doing So Well at Hide and Seek

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
CAN Iraq really hide a nuclear, biological or chemical arsenal, however skillfully it can run and duck? The answer seems to be: Not anymore, or not for long. Between a skillful human intelligence operation and an unparalleled inventory of high-tech snooping and testing devices from air sniffers to a U-2 spy plane, the Iraqis seem to have little room for maneuver beyond obstruction.
When the war in the Persian Gulf had ended and the world had to decide how to deal with Saddam Hussein, the United Nations Security Council set out the rules: Resolution 687, adopted on April 3, 1991, demanded the elimination of all Iraqi weapons of mass destruction and of Iraq's ability to make more. Otherwise, Iraq would continue to live under economic sanctions so severe it was hard to see how Saddam Hussein could stay in power. 
 But Mr. Hussein turned out to be more stubborn in testing and defying the U.N. -- and more resilient in power -- than anyone had guessed he could be. The United Nations prepared the most sophisticated and comprehensive technological and human monitoring system ever imposed on a country. But it took Iraq more than two years to agree to allow it to be installed, and it was another two years before the system was up and running. Iraq has periodically harassed inspectors by threatening them or denying them documents and access, while trying to cut diplomatic deals with sympathetic nations behind the backs of the United Nations Special Commission, the oversight body created to watch Baghdad.
And last week, even as the United Nations was preparing to let Iraq sell limited quantities of oil to ease the effects of sanctions on its civilians, a new crisis flared: Iraq put whole installations off limits to missile specialists on the ground of national security. This prompted a warning from the Security Council that the whole 1991 cease-fire agreement could be in jeopardy.
 
 
 
How It Works
 The commission, with about 100 people based in Iraq and visits from specialist teams, has spun a net of monitoring devices over much of the country, working in tandem with the International Atomic Energy Agency, which has its own systems for tracking nuclear material. The Special Commission looks for chemical and biological weapons, missile delivery systems and any suspicious manufacturing process that might be turned to arms production.
"The concept of monitoring is a web of systems because we realized that any individual element or component can be fooled," said Charles Duelfer, an American who is deputy chairman of the commission (the chairman is Rolf Ekeus of Sweden). "But we believe that the overall collection of elements does provide a fair amount of confidence that we will be able to detect efforts by Iraq to reconstitute its programs. We have designed our monitoring system based on sites we want to be attentive to."
"We also monitor imports and exports of materials to Iraq, and that's a key feature at this point," he said. "This will allow us to keep track of the development of industry in Iraq to allow us to understand where the end users are. And if our inspectors happen across an item that is not declared, we have the authority to confiscate and destroy it."
More than 200 sites in Iraq have been identified for close monitoring. Experts in Baghdad -- and at U.N. headquarters in New York -- can monitor them by video. "We also make house calls," Mr. Duelfer said. The experts work with equipment supplied by the United States, Germany and other technologically advanced nations.
Every six months, Iraq must provide the commission's office in Baghdad with details of any changes in the sites and account for all the personnel, materials and activities there. Experts talk regularly to site managers.
Sensors are installed at many locations. These include air-sampling devices to detect any chemical traces in the atmosphere. This insures that secret production of banned materials cannot take place at night or in an obscured area.
The video monitoring system employs more than 130 cameras deployed around the country to provide instantaneous transmission and taped records. The center in Baghdad can call up a site and turn on a camera at any time. The tamper-resistant cameras are connected to the center through microwave radio links under international control.
The team in Baghdad has the use of an American U-2 spy plane to survey broad areas and identify changes on the terrain -- new construction or changes in structures than may have been missed at ground level. There is also a helicopter detachment, whose aircraft ferry inspectors around Iraq and conduct lower-level aerial inspections. An airborne photographic team provides very detailed imagery -- showing, for example, piping around a building or bunkers in the earth. From time to time, the helicopters are equipped with ground-penetrating radar for special probes.
On the ground, inspectors carry video and still cameras, making images that can be gone over again and again for possibly forgotten or overlooked details. Atomic experts use water testing equipment to look for traces of nuclear material. Now and then, they install gamma ray detectors on helicopters and go on patrol.
The use of people on the ground has never been a minor part of this unprecedented and intrusive operation, and Mr. Ekeus has been a master at accumulating scraps of information from many foreign and Iraqi sources with which to confront the Iraqi Government or catch it in a falsehood.
And the freedom of movement for specialist inspectors remains very important. "There are very few people in the world who could walk through a factory and be able to identify Scud missile parts or biological weapons parts," Mr. Duelfer said. "There is a special expertise that is required." (Last week Iraq suggested that it might open some barred sites to, of all people, diplomats. The idea was rejected as absurd.)
With all the resources available, Mr. Duelfer said, the question remains: "How do you know you are capturing everything?" There is, he says, a pretty clear answer: "Of course we don't. But we are constantly on the lookout for new sites, new facilities. A lot of anomalies would show up. At least over time there is a high probability that we would detect them."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
A Carrot and Stick For Parenthood

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON is calling for curfew laws and a computer chip and rating system that would prevent children from watching TV programs their parents find objectionable. The Christian Coalition and some conservatives are advocating laws asserting the rights of parents to raise their children as they see fit at the same time other conservatives are pushing laws holding parents responsible for children go astray.
Like the old adage about war being too important to leave to the generals, parenting is now viewed as too important to leave to the parents. 
 The approaches may differ. But most experts agree that the posturing and proposals over parental rights and parental responsibility reflect an extraordinary ferment about society's views on parenting that is driven by interrelated economic, social and political trends.
"Families are extremely fragile right now," said Theda Skocpol, a professor of government and sociology at Harvard University, "and I think that leads to all kinds of tensions as to who's responsible for children and whether children are being adequately socialized. The bills about parental rights and parental responsibilities are spreading now because conservatives have been emboldened by the victories in the 1994 election, but they speak to broad social worries about the formation of families and their ability to control their fate and to control their children."
Whether parenting was once the preserve of utterly stable, firm-but-loving Ozzie and Harriet Nelsons and June and Ward Cleavers is open to question, but the signs of strain are numbingly familiar.
 
Litany of Woes
The divorce rate is high. Violence is common in many schools. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released a study last week of 105 violent school-associated deaths from July 1, 1992, to June 30, 1994. Of those, 85 were homicides and 20 were suicides. In a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll, 72 percent of the respondents said parents should be held legally accountable for crimes committed by their school-age children.
Family issues increasingly are becoming legal ones. A jury last month convicted Susan and Anthony Provenzino of St. Clair Shores, Mich., of violating a city ordinance that requires parents "to exercise reasonable parental control" over children under 18 after their son repeatedly defied his parents in public, smoked marijuana and stole $3,500 from the church the family attends. The Provenzinos were fined $100 each and ordered to pay $1,000 each in court costs.
In recent years, half the states have written or toughened laws making parents liable for their children's actions. Numerous communities have passed similar statues.
At the same time, many religious right and conservative groups are promoting so-called parental rights laws, including a bill pending in Congress that would make it illegal for schools or government agencies to act contrary to the wishes of parents in areas like counseling and sex education.
To some critics, the two trends are contradictory.
"What we have now is two movements which are in complete conflict with one another," said Daniel Katz, legislative counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union. "The irony is that if they are both enacted, the parental rights laws could be used to overturn the parental responsibility laws."
Many conservatives deny there is a contradiction. "Both of these approaches assume one thing -- that parenting is extremely important, that parents have the right of parenting certainly but also the responsibility to fulfill those rights," said Jeffrey Bell, president of Of the People, a national group lobbying for parental responsibility laws. "If they fail, there are cases when the government has to step in and do some semblance of active parenting in place of the parent."
Barbara Bennett Woodhouse, an expert on family and constitutional law at the University of Pennsylvania, said that in other times of social change, the same issues and contradictions played out over issues like mandatory schooling or child labor laws.
"The battleground is shifting, but the battles are similar to ones we've seen in the past, the 1920's, for instance," Ms. Woodhouse said. "They all involve this necessity to come out with some kind of public-private partnership in raising children so that the family as a traditional institution maintains its strength and vitality but somehow fits into a larger democratic society."
Experts cited multiple explanations for the upsurge in parenting legislation. One is simply political. With conservatives in ascendance, their solutions -- even conflicting ones -- are proliferating. Poll-conscious Democrats like Mr. Clinton are getting in on the act, but most of the impetus is coming from the right.
 
The Search for Causes
"Conservative advocacy groups, some of them tied to the Christian Coalition, others around family concerns of various kinds are there, the organizations are there, the funds are there," Ms. Skocpol said. "They're all looking for causes to take up so they can give a concrete manifestation of the general program."
Yet everyone agrees that real social problems are inflicting family distress. Different experts cite the pressures caused when both parents must work, which often leaves children home alone. Violent crime among youngsters has reached epidemic proportions. Homes headed by single parents have increased dramatically, as has the number of children born out of wedlock.
Some experts on families doubt whether the parental rights or parental responsibility laws are realistic responses to family issues.
"The parental responsibility statutes are not going to be effective in controlling crime, and the parental responsibility laws will allow a small but vocal band of parents to thwart programs that have proven effective in preventing social problems such as teen pregnancy, the spread of H.I.V. and sexually transmitted diseases," said Mark Soler, President of the Youth Law Center, a legal organization involved with juvenile justice issues.
But he agreed with Mr. Bell that such laws reflected a positive and renewed focus on what it takes to be an effective parent.
"I think there's a wide consensus," Mr. Bell said, "even when people disagree about the specifics, on the need to reactivate parents in some way."

LENGTH: 1428 words

HEADLINE: Majority Rules;
But, Will Whites Vote for a Black?

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ONCE again, four white Justices and one black Justice have ruled that legislative districts drawn to increase the representation of racial and ethnic minorities are unconstitutional if race was too dominant a factor in their design. And now that the Supreme Court's hostility to racial gerrymandering is clearer than ever, the country will soon have to face a practical question that all those legislative contortions were intended to avoid: will whites vote for black candidates? 
 The Court's 5-to-4 decision last week striking down three Congressional districts in Texas and one in North Carolina raises related questions: Are blacks and other minorities better off politically concentrated, or with their influence more spread around? Are there means other than redistricting that can insure black and Hispanic representation? But the more elemental question is whether black candidates can appeal to whites, and how much they will have to bend to do so.
 
 
 
Success Stories
 Those who cheered the Court's decision feel that blacks can and should reach beyond the confines of majority black districts. They point to an increasing number of black candidates in recent years who have won in elections where white voters made up the majority: L. Douglas Wilder as Governor of Virginia, Norman Rice as Mayor of Seattle, Carol Moseley-Braun as a Senator from Illinois and, in the House, Gary Franks of Connecticut and J.C. Watts of Oklahoma.
"It can happen," said Mr. Franks, who like Mr. Watts is a conservative Republican. "We have to show courage enough to run, raise the dollars and get your message out. But that's the same thing that any candidate has to do."
Conservatives like Mr. Franks say that one reason black candidates tend not to appeal to whites is that many are too liberal, and, having been able to run in predominantly black districts, have felt the need to make strong appeals to race. If black candidates have to move toward the center, these conservatives say, they will find greater acceptance among white voters.
"There are so few black candidates who will wade into the biracial waters," said Abigail Thernstrom, a scholar at the Manhattan Institute who specializes in voting rights. "If Colin Powell clones ran in majority white districts in the South, would they win? The answer is of course."
Traditional civil rights advocates and others on the left of the political spectrum are not so sure. They say focusing on the success of people like Mr. Franks or Mr. Wilder is wishful thinking with anecdotal evidence. In the early 1970's, they note, 2 percent of majority white state legislative districts in the 11 states of the old Confederacy were represented by black lawmakers. In the 1980's, the figure was 1 percent.
 
 
 
White Resistance
 "There is still a great deal of resistance to the election of black officials by whites in the country as a whole," said Chandler Davidson, a professor of sociology at Rice University who edited "The Quiet Revolution in the South: the Impact of the Voting Rights Act, 1965-1990" (Princeton University Press).
"If you look carefully," he said, "you will see that blacks are quite underrepresented in terms of their population in the North as well as the South. But the difference is only a matter of degree."
Thanks to reapportionment after the 1990 Census, in which many states purposefully carved out majority-black and majority-Hispanic districts, the number of blacks in Congress rose from 26 to 39 in 1992 and 41 in 1994. Only a few majority-white districts, notably the Republican districts that elected Mr. Franks and Mr. Watts, have sent black or Hispanic Representatives to Congress.
It may be apparent soon whether white voters will support the blacks elected in 1992 and 1994: the North Carolina and Texas districts invalidated last week must be redrawn, though it is not clear how soon that can be accomplished. The Court had already struck down Georgia's racially gerrymandered districts, and is going to review the new map --which leaves only one black-majority district -- next term. A similar case from Louisiana is also pending.
 
 
 
Conflict of Interests
 While many of those opposed to concentrating minority voters say whites will vote for centrist black candidates, the question arises whether that means these candidates sometimes have to betray the wishes of their black constituencies.
While black voters tend to be fairly conservative on issues like prayer in schools, gay rights and even school vouchers, public opinion surveys show that African-Americans remain one of the country's most liberal groups, especially on the large issues such as the role of government, tax policy and spending on domestic social programs.
Recent surveys conducted by the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies showed that while 75 percent of all voters believe the Government spends too little money on schools, 87 percent of blacks feel that way. Blacks also favor smaller tax cuts and place more trust in the Federal Government than do whites. And while 72 percent of the general population supports the death penalty, only 48 percent of blacks do.
Although redrawing electoral maps might force some movement toward the center by conservative white politicians as well, David Bositis, a senior fellow at the Joint Center, said most of the burden is on blacks.
"Why is it there are white leaders who can represent extreme positions within the white community and that's O.K.?" he said. "Why is it that black officials have to move to the center?"
And some of the black politicians who have built strong biracial constituencies were able to do so only after gaining the advantage of incumbency by winning in majority-black districts.
Mr. Wilder, for example, launched his career by winning a State Senate seat from a district in Richmond that was 60 percent black. The late Representative Barbara Jordan, whose profession of her dedication to the Constitution during the Nixon impeachment hearings stirred whites as well as blacks, twice was defeated in races for the Texas House of Representatives in majority white districts. She finally prevailed in a district that was predominantly black and Mexican-American.
Given the Court's antipathy toward the use of race in redistricting and the history of white reluctance to vote for black candidates, many people are wondering if there other ways at helping minorities elect representatives that mirror their views without packing blacks and Hispanics into majority-minority districts.
 
 
 
Other Ideas
 A few experts in voting rights law say that, rather than our current system of single-member Congressional districts that choose representatives under a winner-take-all system, there are other means to insure the political clout of minorities -- racial, religious, or even ideological ones. Some of these mechanisms include the creation of larger, multi-seat Congressional districts in which each voter has a number of votes that can be distributed among several candidates, or the use or preference voting, by which voters can rank voters in order of preference.
When Lani Guinier, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania Law School whose nomination as Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights was withdrawn by President Clinton in 1993, put forward these ideas, she was denounced in some quarters as an anti-democratic radical. But a year later, another noted black wrote these words: "In principle, cumulative voting and other non-district-based methods of effecting proportional representation are simply more efficient and straightforward mechanisms for achieving what has already become our tacit objective: roughly proportional allocation of political power according to race."
The author of those words, in a Supreme Court opinion in a voting rights case, was Justice Clarence Thomas.
Surveying the wreckage of the concept of majority-minority districts in the wake of last week's Supreme Court ruling, and the continued existence of racially polarized voting, Ms. Guinier said it's time for new thinking in the area of minority voting rights.
"On some level these black districts are like the canaries that miners used to carry to tell them when the air in the mine is dangerous," she said. "They are alerting us to a problem with our democracy. The solution, to me, is not simply special rights for the canary. The canary is signaling a problem that we should all be listening to, all of us, without regard to whether we are yellow."

HEADLINE: Corporate Greed, Meet The Maximum Wage

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
NOW that liberals have pushed a higher minimum wage onto Congress's agenda, some of these descendants of George McGovern are agitating for another idea to narrow the gap between haves and have-nots. It's called a maximum wage.
There's a moderate version that would limit executive salaries to, for example, 50 times what a company's lowest-paid worker earns -- last year C.E.O.'s at the largest 500 companies earned $4.06 million on average, or 197 times as much as the average worker. 
 There's also an extreme form that would bar any American -- be it Michael Jordan, Bolton, Eisner or Milken -- from earning more than, say, 25 times the minimum wage, which would mean a maximum of $212,500. Some radicals even advocate a maximum of $85,000 -- or 10 times the salary for a minimum-wage worker.
But the chance of passing a maximum wage these days is about the same as that of a snowball in Speaker Newt Gingrich's Georgia backyard barbecue.
 
Listen to Aristotle
The rich will no doubt howl that these proposals are anti-free enterprise and roundly un-American. But supporters claim a pedigree for their idea that reaches back to Franklin D. Roosevelt and, farther still, to Aristotle. President Roosevelt, concerned about war profiteering, proposed a maximum income of $25,000 in 1942 with a 100 percent tax on all income above that, but Congress shunned his idea. Aristotle wrote that no one should have more than five times the wealth of the poorest person. So there.
And advocates say a maximum wage just might catch fire at a time when politicians from Patrick J. Buchanan to Jesse Jackson have roused supporters by asserting that something is rotten when executive pay has soared while wages for the average American have stagnated. Such stratospheric compensation sticks in the craw, especially among those who have been downsized.
But Sam Pizzigati, a union publicist who is the chief proponent for the maximum wage, readily acknowledged that the notion was unlikely to take Mr. Gingrich's neo-revolutionaries by storm. "True, it's a bit meshuga in the current political climate," Mr. Pizzigati said, while also pointing out that the income tax was once considered a radical idea.
Mr. Pizzigati, who wrote "The Maximum Wage" (The Apex Press, 1992), said that a ratio linking the income of the rich to that of the poor would insure that a rising economic tide lifted all boats, and not just the yachts, as many economists say the current economic expansion has done. "You'd have a very interesting situation because for the first time the richest and most powerful people in the country would have a vested interest in raising the wages of the lowest paid," Mr. Pizzigati said.
A 50-to-1 ratio would mean that a $1-million-a-year corporate chairman who was eyeing a $200,000 salary increase would have a big incentive to raise the $20,000 salary of the company's lowest paid worker to $24,000. Under most maximum-wage proposals, the ceiling would include not just wages but also stock options, dividends, interest and capital gains.
"It's a statement of values, that there should be relationship between the top and bottom in an economy," said Representative Martin Sabo, a Minnesota Democrat who is the author of a bill, with 30 sponsors, that would bar companies from deducting that part of an executive's compensation that is more than 25 times that of the company's lowest paid worker. Senator Jeff Bingaman, a New Mexico Democrat, has called for awarding tax benefits to companies that hold executive compensation to under 50 times that of a company's lowest paid worker.
Fans of an unfettered free market like this idea as much as they like Karl Marx. "This is just another manifestation of the politics of envy," said William A. Niskanen, chairman of the Cato Institute and once President Reagan's chief economic adviser. "You can do all sorts of mischief with something like this. People who make these proposals have not begun to think through the problem of unintended consequences."
Those consequences would no doubt include more cheating on taxes, more maneuvering by executives to defer income until retirement and more deposits of paychecks in secret offshore accounts. The stock market might well head south because the wings of the rich would be clipped, and real estate values could plunge on the Upper East Side and in Beverly Hills. Then there's the specter of inflation because a maximum wage might heighten pressures to raise pay for low-paid workers.
With a ceiling on their income, Americans might feel less of an incentive to be the next Steve Jobs or Bill Gates, undermining America's role as the epicenter of innovation. Similarly, a maximum wage might encourage venture capitalists to venture offshore or close shop altogether. Zillion-dollar-a-year basketball stars might even lobby the N.B.A. to relocate outside the country.
There are economic arguments for income-equalizing too, of course. One is that greed can strangle a free market; to keep it healthy, the poor and middle class need enough money to sustain consumer demand.
But even some outspoken critics of high executive salaries argue against a maximum wage for fear it would hobble the economy. Greg Mueller, Mr. Buchanan's communications director, said, "He would be for using the bully pulpit to focus on people who get million-dollar bonuses while laying off thousands of people, but having the government getting involved in wage scales, I don't think he'd be for that."
Not to worry. Graef Crystal, an expert on executive compensation, said that even with a maximum wage, Americans would strive to excel and the economy could still prosper. "People will brave real danger to rise and become, say, a four-star general even though it doesn't mean tremendous pay," he said. "I can't believe Bill Gates and others would sit back and play tennis all day."
A ceiling on executive compensation "might not be such a bad idea," Mr. Crystal said, because shareholders have done little to restrict it. But there is a reason powerful institutional investors like Fidelity Investments and others are A.W.O.L. on this issue.
"The problem is these shareholders often have a conflict of interest," he said. "Why don't they do anything? Because their executives and fund managers make millions themselves. They're not about to criticize high pay lest attention be focused on them."

HEADLINE: The Rebirth of a River

 BODY:
Every so often something happens to suggest that energetic citizen action and carefully drawn government regulation can turn a hopeless cause into a resounding success story. A case in point is the remarkable transformation of the Hudson River, documented last week in an authoritative two-part series by The Times's William Stevens and Andrew Revkin.
Only 30 years ago, this magnificent river was little more than a 350-mile sewer stretching from the Adirondacks to Manhattan's Battery, choked with untreated human waste, industrial chemicals and agricultural runoff. Today the Hudson pulses with life. True, many of its fish still carry contaminants and not all of its waters are swimmable. But the Hudson is no longer a stinking mess. Fish populations are healthier than they have been in years, while cities and towns that once turned their backs on the river are realizing that they can build a new economy around tourism and recreation. 
 All this is striking evidence that political leadership and an active citizenry can do wonders to atone for past indifference. As the series notes, there was no single magic bullet. But on the government side of the ledger, two initiatives deserve huge credit. One was Gov. Nelson Rockefeller's $1 billion Pure Water Bond Act in 1965, which underwrote modern sewage treatment plants along the riverbanks.
The second was the Federal Clean Water Act of 1972, which mandated tough controls on municipal and industrial waste and provided billions of dollars in Federal aid. House Republicans have passed a law that would weaken the act as part of their broad attack on the country's environmental statutes. If the Senate needs a good reason not to replicate the House's foolishness, it need only examine what the act has meant to the Hudson.
The 1960's and 70's also saw the birth of a powerful environmental movement dedicated to saving the river. The catalyst was the Consolidated Edison Company's 1963 proposal to build a hydroelectric plant on Storm King Mountain just south of Newburgh. Encouraged by success in the courts, a lively coalition of fishermen, naturalists, townsfolk and environmental groups was soon in full cry, thwarting power projects along the riverbanks and filing endless lawsuits to close leaking landfills.
Two historical economic trends -- the gradual decline in manufacturing along the river and the reforestation of abandoned farms in the watershed -- have also helped the river. But the Hudson is not home free. The fact that it is now so much more attractive than it was 30 years ago -- and thus a magnet for heavier recreational use and residential development -- could impose new burdens on the ecosystem. In this era of tight budgets, it may also be more difficult to find money for sewage treatment and other protective efforts.
Finally, there has been no resolution in the continuing controversy over whether to dredge the "hot spots" containing PCB's deposited years ago in the upper river by the General Electric Company. These are the chemicals that make an otherwise healthy and growing striped bass population generally unfit for human consumption.
Still, this river has come a long way. Further progress will require continued vigilance by those who have fought long to save it, careful planning by development-minded communities and a sense of stewardship from a new generation of politicians.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: U.S. Budget Cuts Imperil Remote Town's Lifeline

BYLINE: By JIM ROBBINS 

DATELINE: RED LODGE, Mont.

 BODY:
Much of the prosperity of this scenic mountain village depends on when the plows break through the giant snow drifts that block the Beartooth Scenic Highway.
A terminus of the road is here in this tourist town, and each year thousands of people come to drive the highway that Charles Kuralt, the CBS News correspondent, called "the most beautiful drive in America," and to leave their money behind at local businesses. 
 But with Federal budget cutbacks and unusually heavy snow this year, the town's economic lifeline just opened on Friday morning, two weeks later than usual. Many in this town are dismayed.
"People have come here from all over the world to go over that highway," said Angela Beaumont, general manager of the Pollard Hotel and a director of the Red Lodge Chamber of Commerce. "And they haven't been able to."
Visitors have not been able to traverse the highway this year because the Park Service, which plows the road -- even though it is a state highway outside the park -- cannot afford to pay overtime, and so the opening has gone slowly.
With the road closed, Ms. Beaumont estimates that business is off about 40 percent at the Pollard, a historic 36-room hotel.
The highway climbs 5,445 feet over the Beartooth Mountains. Much of the two-lane road is above 10,000 feet in altitude, and for most of the year is locked in snow and ice.
Even worse for the people in Red Lodge and Cooke City, on the southern end, is that the highway is becoming an unwanted stepchild.
The Park Service has always plowed 43 miles of the 67 miles of highway, including the toughest section with wind-packed 30-foot snow drifts, in part because it has the needed equipment.
But Yellowstone officials say that in the next few years budget cuts could well mean that the $175,000 plowing job will be left to the two states, Montana and Wyoming, which say they cannot afford to plow it, or the drifts will be left to melt on their own.
"If we're closing things in the park," said Tim Hudson, chief of maintenance for the park, "why are we doing things outside the park with money that hasn't been appropriated?" Two museums and a campground inside the park have been closed and personnel cut.
The road is expensive to maintain and needs millions of dollars in repairs. But with Federal money drying up, no one knows when that work will be done.
"If you take a year with snow like this it could be the first of August before it opens up," said Jean Farrell, owner of the Coffee Factory Roasters, in downtown Red Lodge.
"If that happened," said her husband, George, "this place would be a ghost town."

HEADLINE: Senate Leadership Change Stalls Minimum-Wage Legislation

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
An increase in the Federal minimum wage, which seemed to be heading toward passage as recently as last month, has been thrown into jeopardy with the departure of Bob Dole from the Senate, senior Administration officials say.
Mr. Dole, who was the Republican leader before he left the Senate to focus on his Presidential campaign, opposed the Democrats' proposal to increase the minimum wage to $5.15 an hour from $4.25, but in late May he said he would be willing to move ahead with a vote. 
 The House approved the proposal on May 23 by a vote of 281 to 144, and if the measure had been brought to the Senate floor, it would almost certainly have been passed and signed into law by President Clinton. It would be the first increase in the minimum wage in six years.
But Mr. Dole never scheduled a vote. Now the bill's fate in the Senate rests with Trent Lott of Mississippi, the new majority leader who is an even bigger foe of the minimum-wage increase than Mr. Dole.
Mr. Lott said this week that he was not sure when a vote on the minimum wage would come. But his top deputy in the new Republican hierarchy has voiced strong opposition to the measure, saying it would cost jobs. "I'm still not in favor of it," Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the new majority whip, said in an interview on Thursday.
The Senate's top Democrat, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, has vowed to bottle up the Senate until it approves the wage increase. "We will again be offering minimum wage to every bill that comes before the Senate unless we have a guarantee or the assurance that this matter is resolved successfully," Senator Daschle said on Thursday.
Mr. Lott and Mr. Daschle met on Friday to discuss the minimum wage, health-care insurance and other legislative priorities, but they did not resolve their differences, aides said.
Some Republicans said the wage issue could hurt them in the Congressional and Presidential elections.
Administration officials said that the more conservative new Republican leadership in the Senate might not feel the same election-year pressures to to act on a minimum-wage increase as Mr. Dole.
"With Dole gone, it may be harder to pass," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview. "He has been under enormous pressure on the minimum-wage issue, as well as other economic issues. There's still a good chance of winning the day on this, but the political pressure to raise the minimum wage won't have the same focus as when a Presidential candidate is sitting there in the Senate leading his party."
Some Republicans say that blocking a vote on the popular wage increase could backfire on the party in the November elections.
"It already has hurt Republicans," Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, said in an interview. "We know ultimately there is going to be an increase. We have to be just a little more realistic as to where the issue is going and not try to make amends too late."
Supporters of the measure have the votes to win on the Senate floor. Eight Republicans voted with all 47 Democrats in late March to support ending debate on the wage question.
Some of the eight Republicans who voted with the Democrats on that procedural vote might not vote to raise the hourly wage. But at least four are on the record supporting the measure: Senators Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, James M. Jeffords of Vermont and Mr. Specter.
If the Senate votes on the minimum-wage increase, lobbyists and lawmakers say, it will most likely come as part of an agreement brokered between Mr. Lott and Mr. Daschle. A deal might call for a vote on the minimum wage in exchange for a vote on bills that Republicans want and President Clinton does not, such as deep tax cuts for small businesses or a labor measure called the Team Act that would allow companies to form labor-management groups outside the collective bargaining process.
Small-business backers in the Senate are also likely to offer an amendment that would exempt some small businesses from paying any new minimum wage and from paying overtime to future employees. The House defeated this proposal by a vote of 229 to 196.

HEADLINE: Buses Again Trouble Civil Rights Veterans

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala.

 BODY:
The tarnished silver buses that lumber along the avenues of this city are outdated, some of them 20 years old, but the cracked and faded seats are precious to many people. In Montgomery, where Rosa Parks made history by refusing to give her seat to a white passenger on Dec. 1, 1955, these buses are seen not only as a service but also as a civil right.
Johnnie Carr, who took part in the bus boycott here in 1955 and 1956, recalled, "I remember that I would be too proud to sit, so I would just stand" rather than face the indignity of having to give up her seat to a white passenger. "I stood all the way home, some days," she added. 
 Now 85, Mrs. Carr does not ride the bus anymore, yet every time she sees one rumble by she is reminded of the sacrifices it took to force the city to allow people like her to ride them with some dignity. Now, 40 years later, she and other aged civil rights veterans are battling the city again, to keep the buses running.
Across the South and around the nation, cities are trimming bus service or closing down public transportation systems. Elected officials have responded to sharp cuts in Federal financing precisely as feared by the people who ride buses, and instead of financing bus systems with local tax dollars, many city officials have decided to let riders -- usually poor, elderly, handicapped and often minority -- do without.
In Greenville, S.C., the city has done away with bus service entirely. In Birmingham, Ala., the bus system teeters at the edge of financial collapse. Here in Montgomery, service has been cut by more than half.
That means Kody Chester-DesRosiers, a 31-year-old single mother with a 9-year-old daughter, spends one-fourth of her $200 weekly take-home pay to get to work by taxi because the bus schedule does not match her work hours. Some weeks, "we have nothing in our refrigerator," Ms. Chester-DesRosiers said.
It means that Mary Powell, 53, had to drop out of a literacy program in which she was learning to read for the first time in her life.
It means that 27-year-old Anna Walker, nine months pregnant, has to walk two miles from the public health clinic to her home, because the buses run only one way.
It means that Frank Jackson, a 42-year-old laborer, has to quit work three hours early to catch the last bus home, because the taxi ride would cost him even more; that Dorothy Woods, a 51-year-old housekeeper, has to beg for a ride to work, smothering her pride, and that Mary Moore, 85, has lost what independence she had left and relies now on her daughter to get groceries.
"I feel awful," Mrs. Moore said about city officials' cutting bus service. "I could curse them out."
All around the city, elderly black women wait for hours at bus stops after spending their days cooking and cleaning for wealthy white families. One woman, her knees swollen by arthritis, said she had to walk two miles in the morning and two more every evening to catch the bus.
Some people have resorted to buying old cars they cannot afford, others paying neighbors to drive, but some have no way to travel except on buses, spending $1.50 each way.
"We came to see public transportation as part of life, something we earned," Mrs. Carr said. "It's just what the city should give its people."
To advocates who are trying to persuade the city to restore service, the Montgomery city government, long dominated by Mayor Emory Folmar, is either uncaring of the poor people who depend on buses or just hopelessly out of touch.
"Out of one side of their mouth, they're saying people should work," said Mrs. Carr, who has attended City Council meetings and helped organize protests. "But they're denying people the way to get to work."
Mr. Folmar, whose bid for governor in 1982 was thwarted in part because blacks voted for an old nemesis, George C. Wallace, rather than see the rigidly conservative Mr. Folmar in power, declined to comment.
But Councilman Charles W. Jinright, chairman of the Council's Transportation Committee, said that in a time of shrinking tax dollars, the city could not afford to "throw them away" on buses that benefit just 2,200 of the city's 190,000 people. The city's bus system is "like the horse and buggy," Mr. Jinright said.
"We have found that a lot of the time the poor people even feel like it's an insult to ride on public transportation because of the negative connotation attached to it," said Mr. Jinright, who owns an insurance and brokerage business in Montgomery.
Such thinking, riders and advocates say, is wrong because poor people need the buses. As Mrs. Moore said, "We can't get nowhere."
Montgomery, 42 percent black and 56 percent white, has a bus system like that of many around the country. The ridership here, mostly black, is shrinking, making the system an economic liability. And the nine-member City Council, with five whites and four blacks, lacks enough votes to continue all-day bus service if the service is losing money.
Paul Queen, general manager of the transit system, said Mr. Folmar instituted a "shared-pain" plan when Congress sheared aid for transit last year. In Montgomery, the hardship means that the bus system has dropped from a weekday schedule of 17 routes with 12 to 13 hours each day to 6 hours. There is virtually no weekend service.
"You get to a point where you say, 'Do I want to fund one more bus route or do I want to buy three more police cruisers?' " Mr. Queen said. "With crime rampant and people prisoners in their own homes, that's not a hard decision to make."
It seemed so to Ms. Powell, who grew up poor, working in the cotton and peanut fields, never learning to read. Last year she enrolled in a literacy and skills program, but after the bus schedules were cut, she dropped out. She could walk for miles and wait three hours on another bus, but she raises her 9-year-old granddaughter, Ashley, and has to rush home to care for her.
"I wanted to learn, and get me a good job," Ms. Powell said. It don't make no sense. They want us off the welfare, but. . . ."
Sister Leanne Sitter, a Catholic nun who is the program's executive director, said the participants "want to so badly" to learn to read. "They want to acquire some skills so they can go out and earn a living," Sister Sitter said. "But how can they do that if they can't get here?"
For Ms. Chester-DesRosiers, a secretary with take-home pay of $800 each month, the buses were a tool for building a solid life along with 9-year-old Jaanicia.
"I make $80 too much for food stamps," she said. Unable to afford a car, Ms. Chester-DesRosiers relied on the buses to get to work, to the doctor's office, to church. The cash she saved had provided little luxuries like a pizza or a movie for mother and daughter. But cab fares have robbed them of that.
"I've missed church twice" because of the expense, Ms. Chester-DesRosiers said. She had to take a job in a convenience store on weekends to meet her bills.
For others, the cuts in service have made it much harder to take care of themselves and their children. Many of the riders are young women who rely on welfare and the buses as essentials of life, or older people who, for one reason or another, have no family available to take care of them.
For Ms. Walker, the long walk home from the public health clinic makes her back ache, and the strain is bad for her pregnancy.
County health departments in the Southeast provide childhood immunizations, screenings for tuberculosis and other diseases, nutrition counseling, prenatal care, family planning, treatment of sexually transmitted diseases, and other medical services, all to people who cannot afford a doctor elsewhere.
The cuts in bus service, some health officials fear, have curtailed some preventive care.
"They're people trying to bring kids in for shots, people trying to keep prenatal appointments," said Dr. Laurie Dill, the Montgomery County Health Officer. "If you can't get there, there's an increased tendency to let it slide."
Although Dr. Dill said she was grateful for the money the health department gets from the city and county, any reduction in transportation creates a serious barrier to treating the county's poor.
To Mrs. Carr, who has been agitating for people less fortunate than herself for 40 years, "it's the children you worry most about." Last year, she was named "Citizen of the Year" by the local newspaper, The Montgomery Advertiser.
She said she had always hoped that as she grew old she would see the society around her become kinder, more generous, but from her perspective it had grown less feeling in the last few years.
"I could close my eyes and not see these things," Mrs. Carr said. "But I do. The Bible says, 'The poor you will have always.' "
In Montgomery, many of them will be walking.
