HEADLINE: SYSTEM GOVERNING ELECTION SPENDING FOUND IN SHAMBLES

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
The 22-year-old system of Federal limits on campaign donations and spending is falling apart because candidates, parties and unions have figured out how to get around the rules established by the Federal Election Commission, using First Amendment protections carved out by the Supreme Court.
The system invented after Watergate is almost as porous as its predecessors, and there are many examples: Bob Dole's gymnastics on the edge of the Presidential spending limit, the "issue advertisements" that both parties are running with their Presidential candidates' faces dominating the television screen, the "educational advertisements" that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is buying with union dues and the soaring "soft money" contributions frequently from corporations or unions. 
 One goal of the 1974 Federal Election Campaign Act, and a weaker 1971 law, was full disclosure of campaign contributions, and that has worked well. That is especially true since 1991, when public disclosure of soft-money contributions began. They are donations that are exempt from most Federal rules and are funneled from national to state parties.
But the law was also intended to curb the impact of special-interest money, particularly after the discovery of the suitcases of cash the Nixon campaign had collected from corporations. That has failed.
"I don't know anybody who thinks the system works," said Don Fowler, national chairman of the Democratic Party.
Scholars, self-styled reformers and an occasional savvy politician speaking on condition of anonymity say the collapse of the system is encouraged by the certainty that Federal authorities will never act before an election is over, a fact that encourages taking chances.
"As one of my dear friends used to say," said a high-ranking national politician, " 'Remember, they hold the trials after the election.' "
But the frankest analysis of how little the laws inhibit current election practices was offered by Steve Rosenthal, political director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Discussing the television advertisements that the organization is running to attack vulnerable House Republicans, he said, "If somebody handed me a magic wand and said there is no election law, I would do exactly what I am doing now."
The labor federation's advertisements censure Republicans for votes on the minimum wage and Medicare, but never use the words "vote for" or "vote against." That enables them to be treated as "educational," not "political." But, Mr. Rosenthal argues, that is a much more effective way of persuading a voter than just telling him or her what to do.
Experts offer various prescriptions to repair the system that they agree is sick.
Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, said, "Spending limits not only do not work, they have the perverse effect of making special interests more powerful and more influential" because they find ways around the rules and their unlimited donations have greater impact. He would retain reporting but abolish the limits on contributions -- $1,000 for individuals and $5,000 for political action committees -- and on spending -- $37 million through the conventions for Presidential candidates.
David Boren, president of the University of Oklahoma and for 12 years one of the Senate's most consistent advocates of new campaign laws, said he believed the "system is in total collapse." He said that if ordinary Americans were ever to have their faith restored in the idea that everyone's vote counted equally, the First Amendment should be amended to permit limits on campaign spending and to let Congress write laws to spell out what limits were needed.
Specifically, he would want limits not only on contributions and spending, but also on unlimited spending by rich candidates and curbs on so-called independent expenditures, spending by individuals or organizations without any contact with the candidate or party being financed.
A more moderate approach is urged by several scholars. David Magleby, a professor of political science at Brigham Young University, said the Presidential system could be improved by raising the spending limits for campaigns, which are adjusted for overall inflation but have not kept pace with the steeper rise in campaign costs.
Herbert E. Alexander, head of the Citizens Research Foundation at the University of Southern California, said the contribution limits, stuck at $1,000 since 1974, had become hopelessly out of date.
But some of the problems of this year's campaign are out of Congress's reach. Mr. Dole overspent largely by fighting off the independent candidacy of Steve Forbes, who spent as much of his own fortune as he wanted. In 1976 the Supreme Court said any attempt to limit what an individual could spend for himself violated the guarantee of free speech.
The Court has also said that advertisements have free-speech protection and has defined as issue ads almost anything that does not include phrases like "vote for" and "elect," or "vote against" and "defeat." By running such advertisements, the two national party committees can evade the $12 million limit on direct help to their candidates.
The loopholes these definitions have created even bemused Mr. Dole. Last week he was discussing Republican Party advertisements that the Republican National Committee is running showing his biography. Speaking to television executives, he said, "It's called 'generic.' It's not 'Bob Dole for President,' " he said. "It never says that I'm running for President, though I hope that's fairly obvious, since I'm the only one in the picture."
Lee Ann Elliott, chairwoman of the Federal Election Commission, defended such advertising, saying, "We have been begging people to listen. We have been begging people to talk about the issues. Now that it is happening, I don't see this as a bad thing." She said she thought attack advertisements were very useful because "the people look to the negative advertisements because they get information from them."
She took no stand on speeding up commission procedures to make it possible to deal, before Election Day, with the formal challenges to the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s activity -- of which polls show the majorities of union members disapprove -- or to the Dole's reliance on state parties to pay most of the costs of his events. "From a commissioner's point of view," she said, "that would be nice. But from a candidate's point of view, just in the heart of a campaign, to have to stop, review everything and answer that, makes it very, very difficult."
Fred Wertheimer, an architect of the 1974 law, disagrees and blames the Supreme Court for the loopholes in the laws, saying the Court's definitions of issue advocacy "provide a license to cheat" and the Justices were utterly out of touch, employing "a Mars concept when it comes to this issue advocacy stuff."
The Court is expected to rule soon on whether state parties can attack opponents in "issue advertisements" that do not count against spending limits. The National Republican Senatorial Committee is assuming the Court will allow that practice, counting its advertisements attacking Democrats as part of an unlimited get-out-the-vote account.
But Mr. Wertheimer blames Congress for blocking incremental changes, especially those to curb soft money. The parties collect vast sums, like the $1,583,228 that Philip Morris, the tobacco and food conglomerate, has given Republican committees since Jan. 1, 1995, or the $250,000 that Stanley Druckenmiller, a bond trader, gave the Republican National Committee on Aug. 30, 1994.
Mr. Wertheimer said, "What we are dealing with is not a constitutional question, it's a matter of political will."
Those huge contributions, now coming in at double the 1992 rate, are spent in those states where they would be legal. Prof. Michael Malbin of the State University of New York at Albany said they "raise all the issues that people were concerned about when they first looked at the system after Watergate."
Professor Magleby blamed the press, too, for not probing into the motivations for enormous contributions. He said sweeping changes were inevitable when the next disgrace caught public attention. "What is going to trigger this is going to be a scandal," he said. "It will happen. The only question is when."
 Scott Thomas, a member of the election commission, said he hoped the agency could serve as "that dog that keeps gnawing at the ankles," with the 1996 election enabling it to make the rules clearer in the future.
But Congress is the only entity that decides how much can be spent regulating it.
 Each year the staff of the election commission's general counsel's has to be cut, Mr. Thomas said.
 Soon post-election fines will become not just a "cost of doing business," he said, but "more in the nature of 'I don't even have to worry about any cost whatsoever because I probably won't get caught.' "

HEADLINE: A Hartford Program to Put Fathers Back in the Family

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 15

 BODY:
A few weeks ago, when Benjamin Compton walked through the door of his apartment, his 2-year-old son dropped his toy, squealed "Daddy" and ran into his arms.
For many fathers, this would be a commonplace, if tender, ritual. But for Mr. Compton, a towering 22-year-old who was in prison during Benjamin Jr.'s birth, the moment meant much more. It was the first time his son had called him "Daddy." 
 "It felt good," Mr. Compton, a soft-spoken man, said Thursday, appearing almost embarrassed by his own affection. "Father's Day is going to be different this year."
The change can be credited to an unusual new program run by the Hartford Housing Authority, which Federal officials are seeing as a blueprint for a national model. Its goal is to reunite fathers with their families in the projects here, where about 85 percent of the households are headed by single mothers. Most are on welfare. The rest, like Mr. Compton's girlfriend, struggle to survive on low-paying jobs.
The three-month-old Family Reunification Program is still small -- only nine men -- but it represents a new way to move people from poverty to self-sufficiency. The program offers fathers $22-an-hour demolition and asbestos-abatement jobs at the projects, along with other incentives. In return, the fathers take their children off welfare, and, if possible, move in with their partners.
In a nutshell, the program seeks nothing less than restoring some traditional families in communities where they have almost ceased to exist. The Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, Henry G. Cisneros, is encouraging housing authorities nationwide to develop their own versions. A similar and even larger program, aimed at the partners of pregnant women, is under way in Baltimore.
"We need to take steps to actively reconnect fathers with their families," Mr. Cisneros said. "When these fathers have established a bond with their sons and daughters, some deeply spiritual transformation occurs. They see the waste of guns and gangs and drugs, and they leave that life behind."
The Hartford program was the brainchild of John Wardlaw, the executive director of the Hartford Housing Authority, who was inspired to create the program after the Million Man March in Washington in October with its call for black men to be accountable for their actions. Not only has it been embraced by the Clinton Administration, but Gov. John G. Rowland's Republican administration has also supported it.
The Hartford program seems to solve the debate over welfare reform by agreeing with both sides. It subscribes to the liberal idea that people fall into poverty because of larger economic forces over which they have no control, forces the government can intervene to improve. It also accepts the conservative notion that individuals must take responsibility for their actions and that welfare has perpetuated dependency.
For instance, the program's founders realized that the housing policy of setting rent at 30 percent of a family's income discouraged fathers from moving back in, so in the program, when a father returns, the rent is frozen for 18 months.
Although the potential of this program, here and in other cities, turns on whether there are jobs to give, Mr. Wardlaw is confident that the program will grow. The Hartford Housing Authority, with 15,000 tenants, has at least $45 million to tear down units and rebuild, and it plans to require contractors to hire more of these fathers.
No one questions that it will be an uphill battle. Many fathers cannot even be found. Already one man has dropped out of the program, and others are likely to follow. The hard jobs could wear down even enthusiastic fathers. So could family life.
"A lot of them don't know how to be fathers yet," said Victor Rush, the program's administrator. "They're still learning."
Indeed, on Thursday afternoon, in a group interview, Mr. Compton and another program participant, Juan Ramos, compared notes about dressing their children. "It's scary," Mr. Compton said. "He's so little."
"You're worried you'll break something," Mr. Ramos chimed in. "But it's O.K. They're flexible."
"Not me," Mr. Compton insisted. "I'm not going to touch him."
Yet later that night, in his apartment at the Bowles Housing Project, Mr. Compton held his son, gave him a raspberry on the neck and squirted him with a water pistol. Then he plunked the child onto a rocking horse that he bought a few weeks ago, crying "Yee-hah" as Benjamin Jr. laughed.
Only a few months ago, the little boy clung to his mother's legs when his father entered the room, and cried if he tried to touch him. Mr. Compton, who then was living with his mother, was working at a warehouse at minimum wage, and the boy's mother, Tommicka Riley, feared that he might return to the drug dealing that had landed him in jail. "He was distancing himself because he wasn't able to do what he had to do," Ms. Riley said in a telephone interview. "Now, he's able to provide, and that makes any man feel bigger."
For Mr. Ramos, 37, who said he had spent years selling crack cocaine, the job is a step toward getting out of the Stowe Village projects and achieving the program's ultimate goal: home ownership.
Next month, for the first time since 1994, Christina Rodriguez, the 20-year-old mother of two of his children, will not get a welfare check. As required by the program, Mr. Ramos notified the welfare office of his new income shortly after starting his job in May and had his name added to his girlfriend's lease.
"I'm here to stay," he said late Thursday afternoon, as he waited for his girlfriend to call from the doctor's office, where his 8-month-old daughter was being checked for an ear infection. He fidgeted nervously in his chair and added: "It feels strange being here alone. I've gotten used to them being around." The phone rang and he jumped. "Is she O.K.?" he asked and looked relieved when told she just needed to take some medicine.
Mr. Ramos said that he would have moved in months ago, but that the job he had then -- as a maintenance man at an apartment -- paid only $7 an hour. That modest income would have disqualified his girlfriend and the children from receiving welfare. Although he tried to visit as often as he could, he worried that spending too much time there could draw the attention of the Housing Authority. "The system kept me away," he said. "This is the chance I've been waiting for."
Not everyone in the program has moved in with a partner -- the decision is left to the father and mother -- and in at least one case, a child remains in troubling conditions.
Jesus Benitez, who turns 19 in two weeks, offered no hope that he and the mother of Jesus Jr. could be reconciled. Earlier this month, he stopped by to pick up his son, whose second birthday was Tuesday, only to find that the state had taken custody. The mother's boyfriend had been accused of breaking the child's arm.
Mr. Benitez, a former member of the Los Solidos gang who has his street name, "Sycho," tattooed on his arm, broke into tears. He said he was determined to win custody of his son and bring him to the project apartment where Mr. Benitez lives with his mother.
Mr. Benitez had planned a special birthday for his son at a Chuck E. Cheese restaurant. On Thursday, the birthday present he had bought -- a battery-powered four-by-four truck that his son could ride -- sat on a shelf in Mr. Benitez's room. "This job has put me in a place where I can take care of my son," he said. "I was trying to do the things he wanted, let him have the fun I never had."
Fathers voluntarily enter the program. The criteria are that the father has children in the project and is ready to sign a contract pledging to strive to be a role model, to move his family off welfare once employed and to try to participate in his children's activities. It demands that he not use drugs and submit to regular drug tests. If a father fails to abide by the rules, he can lose his job.
Mr. Rush, the Hartford Housing Authority official, who is also an ordained minister, said he had been moved by the fathers' efforts in the last few months. To honor them, he had wanted to help celebrate what for most of them would be their first true Father's Day and throw a Sunday brunch for the group. Much to his surprise, the men turned him down. "They all wanted to be alone with their families," he said.

LENGTH: 1637 words

HEADLINE: Critics See Whitman Dismantling State's Tough Environment Policy

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON

DATELINE: TRENTON, N.J., June 15

 BODY:
When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman paddled down the Wading River in a canoe last June, she was joined by leaders of environmental groups who warmly praised her for responding quickly to their concerns.
But on a canoe trip this year, Governor Whitman was greeted by some of those same leaders, standing on a bridge, waving placards criticizing her policies. In recent weeks they have stepped up their attacks with a radio advertising campaign saying she is rolling back New Jersey's strong environmental protection measures. 
 Mrs. Whitman has taken a new approach to environmental issues. In keeping with her campaign promise to make New Jersey "more business friendly," she has proposed easing some of the regulations governing water quality, hazardous waste and solid waste. She has also recommended budget cuts at the Department of Environmental Protection, particularly among lawyers who prosecute offenses and the scientists who monitor air, water and soil.
Dozens of states, including New York, as well as the Clinton Administration, are trying to work more closely with the business community and environmentalists to reach consensus on setting and meeting standards for environmental quality. But many environmentalists here say that the Whitman administration is moving too quickly to relax the state's traditional tough stance. For the last 25 years, the state has had the nation's most stringent regulations and heaviest fines.
Voters are well aware of the stakes. New Jersey's economy has long been dominated by petroleum refining and pharmaceutical and chemical manufacturing that have operated close to densely populated residential areas and waterways. There are more Superfund sites here than in any other state, and 85 percent of the state's waterways remain unfishable or unswimmable.
Senior Whitman administration officials have expressed concern that the mounting criticism is beginning to resonate with voters. Democrats view the Whitman stance on the environment as one of the few areas where the popular, tax-cutting Republican Governor could be vulnerable in next year's gubernatorial campaign.
Governor Whitman acknowledges the power of the attacks. "Sure, they hurt, particularly because they are not true," she said in a recent interview. "The doomsday scenario that is being painted by the people putting out the ads is simply not an accurate portrayal of what is going to happen."
Mrs. Whitman says she is seeking to reduce burdensome regulations, arguing that the traditional approach of closely regulating what comes out of the discharge pipe and the smokestack is no longer effective. Instead, she says she is trying an approach similar to the one the Netherlands has used since 1988, in which government, environmental groups and industry agree on standards for air and water quality and land use. Then industry comes up with its own plan on how to meet those goals and monitors its own progress. Regulators would check the general results but not oversee every step in the process.
"We haven't sold out to business or the business community," Mrs. Whitman said. "Are we trying to get away from this game that says somebody always loses to win? Yes. We are trying to say that business is not the enemy of the environment, necessarily.
"Do we have an extra concern here? Absolutely. Do we have a responsibility to preserve what we have? Yes. And I believe that we are going to continue to do that but in a way that says you can have a clean environment and you can have a thriving economy that allows for jobs and growth because you simply have to have that."
Critics say the old ways work and the proposed changes are untested.
"She is changing the state's environmental policies in a very subtle manner," said Dolores A. Phillips, legislative director for the New Jersey Environmental Federation. "She is doing it behind the scenes in a way that is deceptive to the average New Jersey citizen, through changes in regulations and budget cuts."
Hal C. Bozarth, spokesman for the Chemical Industry Association of New Jersey, said that environmental groups fail to understand "the need for government to be smarter and more efficient and the compelling need for New Jersey to be competitive for manufacturing jobs.
"No one talks about lowering the standards," Mr. Bozarth said. "All we ever talk about is the process, streamlining it, making it less costly, and making us more competitive. We are more than willing to take the most stringent standards in the country for air and water, and comply with them. All we ask for is for a competitive regulatory structure that allows New Jersey to bring more jobs into the state."
Environmental leaders say that, in particular, they oppose proposed changes in New Jersey's regulations governing water quality. While all sides agree with the administration's plan to move toward a "watershed approach" -- managing all sources of pollution, such as runoff from a pesticide-laden farm, as well as industry discharges into the waterways -- environmental groups believe more has to be done to prepare a plan and detailed environmental standards for the waterways.
In the more than 1,500 pages of proposed changes in water regulations, the administration would allow more toxic substances to be discharged into the waterways. Heavy fines and penalties would be reduced. And sewage treatment plants automatically would be allowed to increase their discharges, within their permit levels, but without further study about what impact that would have on the waterways.
Governor Whitman denies that the changes in the water quality regulations would hurt the public's health. Administration officials say that 12 additional chemicals would be prohibited from being discharged into the waterways under the regulations. And the decision to allow more toxic pollutants into the waterways, they say, stems from the latest scientific data that allows the department to measure more accurately the pollutants while keeping within the parameters of cancer risks of one in a million.
"Obviously, I have relied on the department for the technical aspects of this," Mrs. Whitman said. "One of the reasons I extended the comment period for another 60 days is to allow for a longer opportunity to assess what's real here and what isn't. That is not something that we would allow to occur."
Another worrisome issue to environmentalists and some business leaders is proposed budget cuts at the department. The agency's budget has been cut by more than 20 percent in the last two years, and this year Mrs. Whitman proposes cutting 11 percent more. More than one-third of all of the 600 layoffs in state government are scheduled to hit the department.
Environmentalists worry that cuts will weaken the agency's ability to monitor and enforce existing state rules. Even business leaders are concerned about budget cuts, but their fear is that they will threaten the state's innovative approach to cutting government red tape. Mrs. Whitman has championed a program that issues a single, facility-wide permit to a company instead of dozens of individual permits as an example of the state's ability to protect the environment while giving industry more flexibility.
Much of the Governor's new approach can be seen in the budget cuts. Take, for example, the 30 percent cut this year in the number of lawyers designated to prosecute environmental offenses. The administration is cutting back on litigation in favor of resolving disputes with industry through mediation.
Governor Whitman contends that the state spent so much time in the court system battling industry that state regulations were not getting enforced, fines were not getting assessed, and bad environmental practices continued as both sides fought in court.
In a memo prepared for the Governor's office, the administration anticipated criticism over a proposed $2.7 million cut in the amount budgeted for permit reviews. The memo urges the Governor to stress "more efficient processing now," adding, "Alert: Both the business community and the environmental community will be distressed, feeling, respectively, that review time will lengthen and reviews will be less thorough."
Other proposed cuts, including reductions in pesticide programs, medical waste programs, and shutting down state laboratories and laying off scientists, have caused concern among some lawmakers. Seven Republican State Senators asked Mrs. Whitman to restore the budget cuts in a letter this week, saying the cuts undermined the agency's ability to safeguard the environment.
"If you take away the scientists who find the problems, then you can't find the problems," said Timothy P. Dillingham of the Sierra Club. "Then you don't have to devote resources to resolving them."
In New York, Gov. George E. Pataki has been the target of criticism for his environmental cuts, but sensing the political importance of the issue, he recently counterattacked by staging a statewide publicity campaign for a proposed $1.5 billion environmental bond act.
Last year, Governor Whitman supported a similar bond act providing $340 million to purchase land for conservation. In fact, in the first two years of her administration, she has received high marks for her record on land-use issues. She signed legislation putting $10 million aside to help purchase Sterling Forest. And on air quality, she supports a tough auto emissions law that the legislature sought to roll back.
In the latest environmental controversy, over dredging New York Harbor, Mrs. Whitman points out that she has not backed away from her position to refuse to allow the toxic dredge soils to be dumped into the ocean. "If I were solely interested in business and jobs," she said, "believe me, that's where the heaviest pressure is coming."

HEADLINE: Dole the Candidate Returns to State and Raises Funds

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: Edison, N.J., June 15

 BODY:
Signaling how important New Jersey is to his Presidential hopes, Bob Dole returned to the state tonight for the third time since Memorial Day to appear with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman at the state Republican Party's annual fund raiser.
Speaking to more than 3,200 of the state's most active and loyal Republicans, Mr. Dole said that Mrs. Whitman's gubernatorial win in 1993 was President Bill Clinton's first referendum in New Jersey. "My election in 1996 will be the last referendum on Bill Clinton," he said. 
 Mr. Dole, who had just ended a three-state tour through the Midwest and the South, also said that he was proud to have Mrs. Whitman on his team and that he expected to be campaigning in New Jersey every week until Nov. 5. "And we are going to carry New Jersey," he said.
Members of the audience, who paid $1,000 a plate to attend the dinner, interrupted Mr. Dole's 10-minute speech several times with applause. But he was also forced to speak over a loud din of conversation at the more than 300 tables that filled the New Jersey Convention and Exposition Center. After his remarks, he waded into the crowd for about 10 minutes, shaking hands and chatting with party regulars before departing for home in Washington.
In her introduction of Mr. Dole, Mrs. Whitman described him as a "good and honest man" who speaks with convictions. "The big issue in this Presidential election is not just the economy, stupid, but who will support the policies that will nourish economic growth," she said.
Mrs. Whitman said earlier this evening that the party had been very happy that Mr. Dole had decided to attend the fund raiser, which was expected to raise $4.3 million and is billed as the largest state party fund raiser in the nation. "Having Senator Dole, former Senator Dole, back in the state so soon, re-emphasizes the importance he puts on New Jersey," she said.
Mrs. Whitman, who supports abortion rights, has strongly supported Mr. Dole's promise to include a "a declaration of tolerance for divergent points of view" on abortion in the party's plank. Mrs. Whitman said she was hopeful that Mr. Dole's stance would end talk of a floor fight at the party's national convention in August.
On Memorial Day, Mr. Dole marched alongside Governor Whitman in a parade in Clifton and attended a picnic in Kenilworth. He returned just two weeks ago to campaign with Mrs. Whitman at the 25th annual Polish Heritage Festival in Holmdel, where he worked the crowds, who were chanting, "Every Pole is for Dole."
"He will be here more times than you can imagine," said Chuck Haytaian, the state Republican chairman.
Mr. Clinton has made four visits to the state, which he captured in 1992 with 43 percent of the vote.
The latest voter registration figures suggest why both Mr. Dole, the apparent Republican Presidential nominee, and Mr. Clinton have both been campaigning hard here.
Registered independent voters outnumber those registered in Democratic and Republican Parties combined, according to the latest figures. The number of independents is up nearly 20 percent since 1992, to 2.1 million from 1.7 million, according to the latest figures. The number of registered Republicans has risen more than 10 percent since 1992, to 844,034 from 765,631 in 1992. The number of registered Democrats has fallen over the same period, to 1 million from 1.1 million.
With so many registered independent voters, and as the state's politicians like to say, "independently minded" voters, campaign strategists view New Jersey as a bellwether. Since the 1920's, New Jersey has failed to pick the next President only twice.
The $4.3 million raised at tonight's dinner will be used to not only bolster Mr. Dole's chances in November but will also be poured into the races of Congressional candidates.

HEADLINE: As Battle Looms On Rent Law, Skirmishing Has Begun

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
IN their own modest ways, Barbara Thompson, a tenant, and Denis Gittens, a landlord, are at the center of an already brewing storm over whether a half-century of rent regulation in New York State will end -- or be significantly altered -- precisely one year from today.
Each fits the billboard image that contending sides in the debate choose to project. And yet, while neither fully reflects the constituency they supposedly represent, their struggles, and those of thousands like them on both sides of the rent-regulation divide, cannot be denied. 
 Mrs. Thompson lives in a fashionable building on the Upper East Side, but she is not one of those affluent Manhattanites whom landlords like to cite as having hogged $500-a-month, rent-regulated penthouses for decades. She is a pensioner who pays 42 percent of her fixed, modest income on rent.
Mr. Gittens also does not fit a caricature, that of the mustachioed, black-hatted landlord ordering the widow out; nor is he one of those headline-name developers who owns dozens of buildings with thousands of apartments -- and would benefit enormously from any further loosening of rent regulation. Mr. Gittens, a native of Grenada, has owned the 90-year-old, 14-unit apartment building at 1578 Union Street in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, for 10 years, and bends his back into much of his building's maintenance work just to break even.
It is in the name of Mrs. Thompson and Mr. Gittens and their like that tenant and landlord lobbyists have staked out their positions as the final year of the Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1993 begins to tick away.
Landlords will be pressing for a full phase-out of rent regulations or, at least, a lowering of the income and rent thresholds on so-called "luxury" decontrol, while tenants -- wary of a Republican in the Governor's mansion -- are gathering their forces.
Rent regulation is an issue that resonates throughout New York City, where 1.1 million of the state's 1.2 million regulated apartments are situated and a block of voters estimated at more than 2 million is directly affected. The controversy strikes dissonant chords in the classic debate over how much -- and, on the question of renewal, even whether -- government should counter free-market forces to protect certain essentials of a citizen's life. And this year the volume has been turned up by the Republican resurgence on both the national and state levels.
After much tumult and arm-twisting, the 1993 law renewed rent regulation until midnight on June 15, 1997, but included provisions that, among other things, allowed for the decontrol of "luxury" apartments for the first time since the late 1950's, and, for the first time ever, used tenant income as a determinant for deregulating an apartment.
Under the law's provisions, slightly modified by the New York City Council, apartments renting for $2,000 or more that became vacant after Oct. 1, 1994, would be decontrolled, as would occupied apartments with rents of $2,000 or more where the household income exceeded $250,000 in each of two consecutive years.
Having seen what they consider the first brick yanked out of the dike, tenant advocates have started to organize what they hope will be a large-scale campaign to block further erosion of that wall of protection.
On May 21, 80 buses carrying 2,500 renters from the city -- many of them decked out in pink and white painter's caps bearing the logo "I'm a Tenant and I Vote" -- arrived in Albany for a mass demonstration and to buttonhole legislators in their offices and hallways.
"Nobody knows what the landlords are cooking up," said Michael McKee of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, which represents 137 tenant groups. "The real estate lobby has adopted a strategy of keeping things as quiet as possible downstate so they can catch us off-guard at 10 minutes of midnight on June 15, 1997, at which point it will be too late, which is why we are organizing now."
Mr. McKee, not one to mince words, pointed to the seismic shift in the political landscape since the renewal battle of 1992 and said, "We now have George Pataki instead of Mario Cuomo, and that's a big danger, and Joe Bruno as Senate Majority Leader."
Mr. Bruno, a Republican from Rensselaer County, "is Attila the Hun" on tenant issues, Mr. McKee asserted.
The landlords, too, have bared a few teeth. Members of the Community Housing Improvement Program, an association of about 2,500 city building owners, are raising funds for a television advertising campaign aimed at upstate cities in the fall and next spring. The campaign logo, a raging red apple with furrowed brow and jagged incisors, says: "Don't Let the Big Apple Take Another Bite Out of You! Stop Rent Regulation Now!"
"The problem," said R. Bonnie Haber, president of CHIP, "is that people who live in New York State are paying $30 million in taxes for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, and most of it is to administer New York City's rent regulations."
"We're talking about enabling a drug dealer to keep his apartment while serving time in jail, if they can get him to jail," Ms. Haber said, "because he wasn't found dealing drugs in the apartment."
THE clarion call to rent-regulation combat was sounded in a confidential memo by Governor Pataki's Transition Housing and Community Development Committee in December 1994, even before he was sworn into office. "The administration's goal," it said, "must be to dismantle a system that does not work by adopting decontrol of all rent-regulated apartments upon vacancy."
With that as the longterm goal, the report called for intermediate steps like "reducing the rent and income thresholds for decontrol of luxury apartments," elimination of regulation on buildings with less than 20 units and "legislation to require payment into escrow of legal rents by tenants contesting eviction." Mr. Pataki did not respond to several requests for an interview on whether he was still pressing for those goals; nor did Mr. Bruno respond to requests for an interview on the subject.
But Joseph Strasburg, president of the city's largest landlord advocacy group, the Rent Stabilization Association -- and the Governor's recent nominee to the boards of the State Housing Finance Agency and the State of New York Mortgage Agency -- said that, "at a minimum," landlords will be pushing for:
* Vacancy decontrol of all apartments so that "whenever a vacancy occurs the owner will be free to ask whatever the market will bear."
* Reduction of the existing income level for luxury decontrol from $250,000 "closer toward $100,000 a year" and of the current $2,000-a-month rent threshold to "something like $1,500."
* A gradual phase-out of all rent regulation.
"Because of broken promises," Mr. Strasburg said -- particularly the repeal of an earlier, and broader, vacancy-decontrol system after a three-year period in 1974 -- "a lot of developers don't trust government and there has been a movement of investment dollars out of the city to other geographical areas where there are no rent regulations."
Vacancy decontrol was lifted in 1974, he said, because then-Governor Malcolm Wilson, a Republican, "was running for re-election and wanted to curry favor with the voters." Tenant advocates, however, say the repeal took place because rents of many decontrolled apartments skyrocketed, and some landlords forced people to vacate by creating uninhabitable conditions.
"In order to encourage development dollars back to New York," Mr. Strasburg said, "the state must address the unfairness of the landlord-tenant relationship, which presently does not create a level playing field for the owners."
Asked if landlords would be pressing for complete deregulation at the sunset date next year, Mr. Strasburg said, "No comment."
The chairman of the Assembly Housing Committee, Vito J. Lopez, a Brooklyn Democrat, contended that deregulation would "economically ghettoize" the city and prove "politically suicidal" for Republicans.
"It would impact 2 to 3 million residents," he said, "and each of those people would be subject to rent increases and fear of removal from that apartment because they would lose their right to tenancy."
Both parties to the dispute paint portraits of hardship to illustrate their points. "Our members are mainly midsized owners of older, six-story elevator buildings, many in the outer boroughs," said Ms. Haber, the president of CHIP. "Because of rent regulation, people don't want to buy regulated buildings and people who own them don't want to invest money that they can't see a return on."
"The real estate lobby," Mr. McKee counters, "paints a picture of rent-regulated tenants which is distorted by concentrating on the very small number of high-income people living in rent-regulated apartments, when the typical regulated tenant is struggling to survive."
There are, to be sure, grand-scale landlords who would profit mightily from the termination of all rent regulation or a further lowering of the income and rent thresholds for decontrol of luxury apartments.
When asked what the impact of luxury decontrol on rents has been, the reaction of Samuel J. Himmelstein, a tenant lawyer, was: "Whew!"
Mr. Himmelstein's firm, Himmelstein, McConnell and Gribben, has handled 15 luxury decontrol cases, he said, "and I've seen rents jump from $2,000 to $6,000 and more."
Sherwin Belkin, a partner in Belkin, Burden, Wenig and Goldman, a law firm that represents many major landlords, pointed out that the longevity of the occupant and the size of the apartment are the "principal factors" determining the rent of a luxury-decontrolled apartment. "An apartment that has been occupied a long time but is a large, valuable apartment, may very well see a deregulated rent that is two or three or more times than the rent under regulation," Mr. Belkin said. "A small apartment that has had a significant turnover" -- and, therefore, several vacancy allowances -- "may not see a deregulated rent significantly above what the regulated tenant was paying."
While larger landlords and affluent tenants would, in dollar terms, be most affected by changes in the rent laws, the plight of those smaller owners and poorer tenants so often held up as symbols is undeniably grounded in hard reality.
Mrs. Thompson, for example, has lived in her rent-controlled, one-bedroom apartment on East 90th Street for 28 years. She retired from her job as a research librarian for a financial firm six years ago. Her fixed income from her pension and Social Security is $1,521 a month, or $18,252 a year. When she retired, Mrs. Thompson's rent was $423 a month; it is now $651.
"Don't make this sound pathetic," she said, "but you can't meet friends for lunch because you can't afford it. I used to have grand nieces and nephews come visit to show them the city, but that's impossible now. Just to get on the bus it's $1.50. I don't like using the phrase, 'I can't afford it,' so you just sort of withdraw."
MR. GITTENS is also squeezed. All 14 apartments in his Crown Heights building are rent stabilized. "I had one rent-control," Mr. Gittens said. "Thank God, I kissed them goodbye three years ago. They had a three-bedroom and were paying $186." Of the remaining tenants, one pays $685, another pays $587, and the rest are in the mid-$400 range.
For the last two years, the city's Rent Guidelines Board has set citywide increases for stabilized apartments at 2 percent for one-year leases and 4 percent for two-year leases. "If a big guy has an apartment that rents for $1,500 or more, that's a good increase for him," Mr. Gittens said. "But what is 3 or 4 percent of $400?
"Until I get an average of $500, it doesn't make sense," he said. "I'm at the breaking-even point."
The degree to which Mrs. Thompson and Mr. Gittens represent constituencies in the rent-regulation struggle is subject to debate and dueling studies.
There are 1,013,097 rent-stabilized apartments and 101,798 rent-controlled units in the city, according to the 1993 Housing and Vacancy Survey of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. The survey, which is the latest available, said the city's vacancy rate had dropped to 3.44 percent in 1993 from 3.78 percent two years earlier, compared to a national vacancy rate of 7.6 percent in 1993. New York's rent regulations are, by statute, mandated when the vacancy rate is below 5 percent.
OF the 1.1 million regulated apartments, the survey said, 23.6 percent were in buildings, like Mr. Gittens's, with less than 20 units. At the same time, the median household income for all tenants in rent-stabilized apartments was $20,150, and it was $14,400 for households in rent-controlled units.
Peter D. Salins, a professor of urban affairs at Hunter College and co-author of "Scarcity by Design" (Harvard University Press, 1992), a condemnation of the rent-regulation system, said, "The worst thing is that it misallocates housing stock," by rewarding longterm tenancy and raising rents significantly each time an apartment changes hands.
"Affluent tenants are determined to stay in their apartments as long as possible," Dr. Salins said, "and if they don't they will sublet illegally or try to maintain their nominal tenure through misrepresentation."
But Andrew Scherer, a housing specialist at Legal Services for New York and author of "Residential Landlord-Tenant Law in New York" (Lawyers Cooperative Publishing, 1995), said Dr. Salins's "primary concern is that there are people who may not need the benefit of rent regulation who receive its protection. I would say the worst problem is that the system provides inadequate protection to those who need it most.
"He seems to maintain there's something wrong with a system that fosters longevity of tenure," Mr. Scherer said. "Enabling people to stay in their homes and communities is a valuable goal for public policy. And what is often overlooked is that rent regulation also provides protection to tenants so they cannot be evicted for arbitrary reasons."
Dr. Salins cited a report by Harvard University's Joint Center for Housing Studies that showed that, in 1987, affluent tenants in Manhattan's more fashionable neighborhoods paid rent of $368 to $432 less than they would on the free market, while market rents in the city's poorer neighborhoods averaged $9 less a month than those allowed under rent regulation. "And if we had this huge discrepancy in 1987, it can only have widened since then," Dr. Salins said.
Mr. Scherer pointed to the Housing and Vacancy Survey, which reported that households earning less than $20,000 pay approximately half of their income for rent and that 70 percent of households receiving public assistance pay rent in excess of their housing allowance. At the same time, middle-income tenants in regulated apartments also experienced increases in the percentage of their income devoted to rent, the survey said: from 20 percent in 1970 to 31 percent in 1993.
Miriam Thompson (no relation to Barbara Thompson on the Upper East Side) is one of the thousands of middle-class tenants who occupy the broad center of the rent-regulated spectrum. She pays 40 percent of her "low-40's" salary for rent.
The director of a worker's education project at Queens College, Mrs. Thompson is concerned about "downsizing," she said. "You know what's happening at CUNY."
A tenant in Kew Towers, a seven-story elevator building in Flushing, Queens, Mrs. Thompson said: "I have two children I'm putting through college. I'm caretaker for my parents. I'm divorced. This is all on me. To have rent eat up more of my income would just be a financial disaster."
But if the market were given free rein, said Mr. Strasburg of the Rent Stabilization Association, only fashionable neighborhoods in Manhattan, and certain other communities like Riverdale in the Bronx and Brooklyn Heights, would experience significant rent increases. "Our position is that there are many affordable units in Brooklyn and Queens," he said, "and that, with the ability of people to move around, if rent regulation was eliminated, more units would become available and rents would drop according to demand. The market does work."
Dr. Salins added: "One of the things that makes it so difficult for politicians to contemplate deregulation is the almost universal intuitive belief that deregulation will cause all rents, not just those of the affluent, to rise. Opponents of regulation like myself can only offer economic theory or the experience of other unregulated cities. Until we have a large, controlled experiment in the city, probably the case will not be persuasive enough."
THE end of rent regulation in cities like Boston, Brookline and Cambridge, Mass., has been "too recent to have generated data that would show the impact on rents," said Chester Hartman, a former professor of housing policy at Harvard and now president of the Poverty and Race Research Action Council in Washington. "But why else are landlords and their political supporters so avid to end controls?"
Rent increases under deregulation "will not be universal," Dr. Hartman said. "The low incomes of so many tenants will make it impossible to squeeze more out of them. But the result of ending regulation, beyond any doubt, will lead to thousands more poor tenants paying 50, 60, 70 percent of their income for housing."
Assemblyman Lopez said that deregulation would impact not only on the poor, but thousands of elderly and middle-class tenants who could not afford market-rate rents in upscale neighborhoods. "The landlords themselves have admitted that if they went to complete deregulation there would be a mass exodus of people who cannot afford Manhattan and other high-rental areas like Riverdale and Brooklyn Heights," Mr. Lopez said. "Right now you have integrated communities based on age and economics."
And, so, the battle lines have been drawn.
"This is not going to be decided on the merits," Mr. McKee said. "It's going to be decided on the relative strengths of the real estate industry versus the tenant movement. In a nutshell, they have the money, we have the votes."
There are, however, some slivers of ground for compromise. The tenants' coalition, Mr. McKee said, is prepared to propose a streamlining of the system so that rent-controlled apartments -- now subject to rent increases as well as fuel and labor pass-along charges -- would fall under the less-onerous annual increases ordered by the Rent Guidelines Board for stabilized apartments. And the coalition is proposing a formula under which small landlords could apply for hardship rent increases when they are not making a minimum return on their equity investment, including the value of work they do themselves.
"Sounds wonderful," said Mr. Strasburg of the landlords' group. "We'd be interested in seeing a written proposal and understanding what they are advocating. The devil is in the details."
 
The Two Faces of Rent Regulation
 Rent control applies to apartments in buildings constructed before Feb. 1, 1947, in which the tenant or an authorized successor has been in continuous occupancy since before June 30, 1971 -- the date when vacancy decontrol for rent-controlled apartments took effect. Rent-controlled tenants are subject to 7 1/2 percent rent increases in most years as well as fuel and labor cost pass-alongs that can result in actual annual rent increases of a maximum of 15 percent.
Rent stabilization, which went into effect in 1969, covers buildings constructed between 1947 and 1974, as well as formerly rent-controlled apartments in pre-1947 buildings that are added to the rent-stabilized category when the units becomes vacant. Some post-1973 buildings have also opted to become stabilized in return for tax abatements.
Stabilized apartments are subject to rent increases set annually by the Rent Guidelines Board, which is appointed by the Mayor. Over the last decade, stabilized rent increases have ranged from 6 percent for a one-year lease and 9 percent for a two-year lease in 1986, to 2 and 4 percent increases in each of the last two years. Increases of 5 and 7 percent have been proposed to go into effect Oct. 1, following a vote by the full board on June 24.

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the controversy surrounding renewal of New York State rent regulation laws misstated the date after which apartments renting for $2,000 or more a month were decontrolled upon vacancy. It was Oct. 1, 1993, not 1994.

HEADLINE: Reality of G.M. Closing for Good Sets In

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: NORTH TARRYTOWN

 BODY:
ALL along Beekman Avenue here there are signs that these are the last days before General Motors shuts its doors for good.
The Catering Deli last week delivered the final Saturday lunch order to workers on the weekend shift. Badie Gergis, owner of the Off-Broadway Deli, announced that he would no longer be open 24 hours a day. 
Michael Rivera, an assembly-line worker, sadly bid goodbye to his friends at Corona's Luncheonette across the street from the plant. "I'm history," he told them.
Indeed, the 81-year history of General Motors in this river village will officially end on June 28 after the last Chevrolet Lumina minivan rolls off the plant's assembly line and the Detroit-based company leaves town. Nearly 2,100 employees will be displaced -- some forced by the plant closing into early retirement, others assigned to jobs in different places and some short-term workers simply let go.
In the workers' absence, some small businesses near the plant will suffer, and others are likely to close. As Neasy Corona, owner of Corona's Luncheonette, said, "Maybe we will survive this, maybe not."
Meanwhile, no firm plans for the future of the 97-acre riverfront site are in place, although re-use studies are under way. There is similar uncertainty about what lies under the ground after years of possible industrial contamination by General Motors, and that, too, must be resolved.
Yet Sean Treacy, the 39-year-old, part-time Mayor of this village, remains optimistic. "This is not another Flint, Mich., story," he asserted recently, referring to a well-publicized General Motors plant closing that left an entire region and its residents devastated. "There are many reasons for hope in our case."
When Mr. Treacy looks down the length of Beekman Avenue, as he is wont to do recently, he envisions the plant gone and in its place a residential and commercial area along the river, which he describes as "a kind of Sleepy Hollow Seaport."
He said he has heard "every kind of proposal for the property from the wacky to the serious." One company wanted to build a virtual-reality theme park where the plant now sits, and the Mohawk Indians suggested a gambling casino, he said.
But the Mayor and members of a task force appointed four years ago by then Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to study future options favor residential and commercial uses.
Before officials can move on to the next stage, however, the automaker must complete the shutdown here, which is part of "an accelerated consolidation and closing of selected plants in the United States and Canada to bring capacity in line with market demand," said Marsha Hall-Jenkins, a spokeswoman for the General Motors midsize and luxury-car group.
The company must complete an environmental evaluation of the site, which it first occupied in 1915 when it built 4,902 Chevrolets. (Last year, the automaker rolled 91,599 Chevrolet, Pontiac and Oldsmobile plastic-bodied minivans off the assembly line here.)
Besides the environmental review, Mr. Treacy said the automaker "must create a green field" -- in other words, it will have to demolish the 2.8 million-square-foot factory, which is equal to one-and-a-quarter World Trade Centers, and clean up any pollutants.
The village has passed its own Environmental Protection and Abandoned Industrial Property Reclamation Law, meant to prevent General Motors from leaving behind hazardous waste on the prime waterfront site.
The automaker had filed, but subsequently dropped, a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Manhattan seeking an injunction against the ordinance.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman and Commissioner of Empire State Development, New York State's umbrella organization for economic development, said his first order of business when he took over last year was to "patch up ill feelings" between the town and G.M.
"It had become an uneasy relationship, but it was time to move forward and accept the realities of G.M.'s departure," Mr. Gargano said.
Plans to close the assembly plant were announced four years ago, when 3,450 workers were employed here, and the shutdown was originally set for last year. But a reprieve was later granted because the minivans, which are manufactured at this plant, were selling well.
The closing is an especially bitter pill to swallow for residents and officials here because former Governor Cuomo, along with James McDonald, then president of General Motors, announced in 1987 a "historic private-public sector agreement" to bring a major automobile manufacturing project and jobs to this village of 8,000 people.
Mr. Cuomo said then that he was "all but guaranteeing these jobs for the rest of this century, jobs for the workers of today and perhaps for their sons and daughters as well."
Clearly, that has not turned out to be the case. Now the company is offering permanent, full-time employees a $60,000 severance payment and $16,000 in vouchers and cash toward a new car. It will also give the full-timers $1,000 a month for two years while they look for new jobs.
Also, many full-time workers at the Local 664 office have been offered employment in other General Motors plants. Manuel Serrano, a union representative who has worked at this plant for 19 years, has accepted a job on the assembly line at a plant in Doraville, Ga., and he will relocate there with his wife and two daughters.
But not all families will make the transition together, Mr. Serrano said, and some of his fellow workers will move to their new jobs alone, unable to persuade their wives to move so far away.
"More than just a plant closure," Mr. Serrano said, "this is turning out to be a breakup of lives."
Many older workers have also decided not to relocate. "I'm tired," 59-year-old Jaime Ortiz, said. "My whole body is tired. I don't have the energy to relocate." He said he would seek work as a painter or security guard near his home in the Bronx until he is 62, when his full retirement benefits are activated.
For those who choose not to relocate and for temporary workers who have not been offered a severance package or full-time work elsewhere, the county opened a federally financed job center last week in Tarrytown to help with the transition.
Kathleen D. Gulotta, a spokeswoman for County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's office, said the center would offer re-employment testing for the workers along with information on how to conduct a job search, write resumes and go on interviews.
The outlook is poor for workers who do not accept transfers, according to the State Department of Labor, which reported recently that there are few assembly-line jobs left in the state for transportation workers. Most full-time assembly-line employees at General Motors earn $18 to $20 an hour. Ms. Gullota said most workers would likely have to "look outside of the area" for employment.
Tomorrow, the Governor's Task Force will make public the findings of its reuse study. The $100,000 study, completed by Arthur Andersen Real Estate Services Group, will recommend a mixed use of homes, shops, a marina, public esplanade and light industry.
The state had recommended using the existing structures for another industry, Mr. Gargano said, adding that "we are not, however, going to dictate to the community what to do."
Back at the benefits office of the United Auto Workers here, Donald Carey struggled to keep up with the ringing telephones and address the workers' concerns. "They will go on," he said, referring to the officials who are orchestrating the closing and its aftermath. "But for us, it is the end of an era."

HEADLINE: The World;
Tension With Japan Rises Alongside China's Star

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
WHEN the world's athletes converge on Atlanta for the Olympics this summer, there will be one person who Chinese fans fervently hope will lose, will humiliate herself, maybe even have a heart attack during play. She is Chire Koyama, Japan's table tennis champion, a strong contender for the gold medal. Her sin is that she was born Chinese but then moved to Japan, married a Japanese and joined the Japanese national team.
"Chinese all hate her," explained a Chinese woman living in Japan. "After, all, she married a Japanese." 
 The Chinese fury with Mrs. Koyama is not diminished by the fact that she has an excuse for going to Japan. She claims that when she served on the Chinese national team, her coach ordered her to lose a game in the 1987 world championships so that a teammate could advance to the finals. Instead, she beat the teammate, and her Chinese coaches reportedly punished her by refusing to allow her to compete in the 1988 Olympics. Still, when she began playing for Japan and defeating Chinese players, China's official newspapers denounced her as having been selfish in refusing to throw the match, and as having betrayed her motherland.
The venom underscores the antagonisms that bedevil the delicate relationship between China and Japan, neighbors with histories that have been intertwined for 2,000 years. These are the giants of East Asia, two points of a strategic triangle with America, and their relationship is central to continued stability in what is economically the most dynamic part of the world. Yet their shared past is more a source of division than of unity, and today distrust is growing rather than receding.
The distrust grew a bit more this month, after China ignored repeated Japanese warnings and conducted a nuclear test underneath its Western desert. Because of its memories of the atomic bombs at Hiroshima and Nagasaki, Japan is bitterly hostile to nuclear weapons, and so, perhaps too self-consciously, it interpreted the Chinese nuclear test as a direct insult.
"We are very disappointed," declared Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto as Japan lodged an official protest. In Japan's Parliament, there are growing voices for more than just words. More and more legislators complain that the Foreign Ministry officials are yowagoshi, roughly meaning spineless, and that politicians must intervene to teach China some respect. In particular, some politicians would like to curb Japan's huge loan program to China, while others urge a more aggressive Japanese assertion of ownership over disputed waters and territories. The Japanese Government has discouraged Japanese oil companies from exploring for potentially rich deposits of petroleum in waters between the two countries, but some politicians argue that there is no need to be so circumspect.
 
 
 
Hardening Toward Beijing
 "There's a growing attitude in Parliament that we need to take a tougher line toward China," said Kazuo Aichi, a former Cabinet member and prominent member of Parliament. "Whenever anything happens, the Japanese Government takes too gentle a position, and that's why this impatience is spreading in Parliament."
Yet Mr. Aichi, like almost every senior Japanese official, adds that "the relationship with China will be the major issue for Japan." It is difficult to have a conversation with a senior Japanese policy maker for more than about 30 minutes before the conversation turns to China, for there is a growing sense that Japan's long-term future is almost as dependent on decisions made in Beijing as in Tokyo. "For the last 100 years, our focus in foreign affairs has been on America," said one top official. "From now on, it will have to be China."
The concerns in Japan run the gamut: A civil war in China could send tens of millions of boat people fleeing to Japan; a continuing industrial revolution in China could raise global oil prices significantly and send acid rain and other pollutants across the sea to Japan; Chinese adventures against Taiwan or in the South China Sea could interfere with Japan's oil lifeline and cripple economies throughout Asia; an increasingly nationalistic China could seize Japanese islands and confront Japan militarily. In America, half a world away, China's rise seems awesome and exciting; in Japan, next door, it also seems awesome but a bit ominous as well.
 
 
 
Suspicion Is Mutual
 China, on the other hand, is equally suspicious of Japan. Chinese note that whatever its recent problems near its borders, historically China has not been particularly aggressive to its neighbors, while in this century Japan tried to colonize everyone in sight. Chinese officials often argue that America is being naive about Japanese militarism, and that Beijing and Washington should team up to contain Japan before it is too late. Chinese suspicions are reinforced because Japan always seems half-hearted about apologizing for the deaths of up to 20 million Chinese during World War II.
To be sure, for all the mistrust, Japanese companies have been thrilled by, and shrewd in exploiting, the Chinese market -- somewhat to the chagrin of the Americans, who would prefer allied solidarity in forcing China to respect trade accords. Japanese salesmen tend to serve longer tours in China than American counterparts, tend to speak better Chinese, tend to devote more efforts in smaller provincial cities, and, Americans sometimes complain, tend to sweeten deals by making generous "gifts" to Chinese officials. But even this interaction stirs Chinese resentment. Many Chinese say they would prefer to buy American products, and in 1986 Chinese university students demonstrated against what they called Japan's "economic imperialism."
Such tension belies the ways each side has enriched the other historically. Japan was the biggest beneficiary; it learned rice farming from China and much of its language consists of Chinese words. It is impossible for a Japanese to converse without using Chinese words, and Japanese culture benefited hugely from Chinese poetry and philosophy. "It is because of the Chinese that we are human beings," acknowledged a Japanese official. "From them we got writing and even civilization."
The Chinese are also indebted to Japan, for Chinese intellectuals traveled to Japan late in the 19th century and early in this century to study the ideas of the modern world. Indeed, most of the Chinese political vocabulary was imported from Japan, including the Chinese words for democracy, politics, economics, government.
These days, some Japanese can be patronizing, even contemptuous, of modern Chinese society. But they do not hate Chinese. In China, however, local people sometimes tell foreigners that the Chinese character "hen," or hatred, can be defined by "the feeling we Chinese have for the Japanese." Many Chinese are willing to let their children marry Americans, but a marriage with a Japanese can be a neighborhood scandal.
 
 
 
Looking to Washington
 The alarm about China's long-run intentions may be leading Japan to put a greater premium on its security relationship with the United States, since cooperation with America is politically and economically more feasible for Japan than building a first-class army of its own. Former Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa says bluntly that without the security partnership with Washington, Japan might fully rearm and acquire nuclear weapons. Yet like some other senior Japanese officials, Mr. Miyazawa is anxious that alarm about China could become self-fulfilling, by alienating and angering China into becoming just the disruptive force that some fear. "Let's not treat China as an enemy," Mr. Miyazawa said. "Let's try to engage China in dialogue."

HEADLINE: Income Found to Predict Education Level Better Than Race

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
A study that tracked 25,000 teen-agers over six years has found that family income counts more than race, ethnicity, sex or scores on achievement tests in determining the expectations and future education of the group.
The conclusion is one from a study by the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago that focused on potential barriers to choice and access in higher education. 
 Although a variety of interpretations are possible, the head researcher said the findings indicated that adequate financial aid could give students from low-income families equal access to higher education.
The researcher, Allen Sanderson, also said the study showed that students may form their aspirations even before they reach high school.
In the national study, students were tracked from 1988, when they were eighth graders, to 1994, when many were college sophomores.
The study showed that 48 percent of those in the lowest income group attended two-year community colleges and only 37 percent in that group attended four-year institutions.
In contrast, 74 percent of those in the most affluent quarter of the group attended four-year schools and 23 percent in this group attended two-year institutions.
While the study's findings may not sound surprising, said Professor Sanderson, the senior study director for the center, "it's not bad to have science backing up common-sense conclusions."
He said he believed the study showed "that aspirations have solidified by the eighth grade."
"The evidence suggests that students coming from more privileged backgrounds, whether black or white, or male or female, have done uniformly well with their opportunities," Professor Sanderson said.
"The challenge for us as a society," he continued, "is to insure that a greater proportion of young people share those opportunities."
At least in theory, he said, financial aid could be used to help level the economic playing field to provide some of those opportunities.
In the study, eighth graders were asked how much they expected to be earning at the age of 30. Those in the highest income group said they expected on average to be earning almost $63,000 a year, while those in the lowest income group said they would earn an average of $46,000.
Differences along racial and ethnic lines were, once again, much less significant. In fact, blacks not of Hispanic origin on the average assumed that they would be earning about $67,000 at the age of 30, while whites not of Hispanic origin expected to be earning an average of about $53,000.
The study also offered indications about the group as a whole. Among them were these:
*In 1988, 66 percent of the eighth graders said they expected to earn at least a bachelor's degree, while 22 percent said they anticipated taking some form of post-secondary education.
*By 1994, nearly 63 percent had attended some sort of post-high-school education. Of those, about 57 percent attended a four-year institution, 36 percent attended a two-year institution and 7 percent participated in a trade or technical school for less than two years.
*More women than men reported in 1992 that they expected to obtain bachelor's degrees or higher degrees. Women also reported being more concerned than men about the prestige of the institution they chose.
*Asians and Pacific Islanders, more than members of any other racial or ethnic group, said they expected to earn bachelor's degrees or higher. And more of them than in any other group in the sample had graduated from high school and enrolled in postsecondary education by 1994.
*Hispanics, more frequently than any other group, enrolled in public two-year institutions.
*Blacks enrolled in private four-year colleges at rates comparable to Asians and whites.
Conducted under contract for the United States Department of Education, the National Opinion Research Center study employed a variety of methods to follow students who were relatively easy to keep in touch with while in high school but much less so once they scattered after graduation.
Polling techniques included self-administered questionnaires, computer-assisted telephone interviews and live field interviews and telephone interviews.

HEADLINE: Down to Wire For U.S. Talks With China

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Monday, June 17

 BODY:
China and the United States reached the brink of a broad agreement early today on how to fight the piracy of music, movies and computer software, and negotiators appeared ready to call off $2 billion in trade sanctions that are scheduled to take effect later today.
The acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, and China's deputy trade minister, Shi Guangsheng, remained at the negotiating table all morning. But officials on both sides said they were virtually certain to reach an agreement before the end of the day. 
 "An agreement between the two countries on the issue of intellectual property rights is likely," the New China News Agency said at midday.
An American official added: "We're going to get there. It's just a question of at what hour."
True to the brinksmanship that often characterizes trade negotiations, officials on both sides maintained tough-talking postures in public until the final day, and kept negotiating until early morning before breaking, then resuming again at midmorning. Ms. Barshefsky's plans to fly to Washington this morning were postponed.
"We are pressing up against a deadline, and the deadline will not be extended," Ms. Barshefsky told reporters as she left her hotel for the midmorning talks. She and other American officials were vague about when the deadline would pass, apparently to give themselves some discretion in the final hours of negotiations.
On Sunday morning, Ms. Barshefsky warned that "substantial additional progress is going to have to be made." Late in the afternoon she said, "We're still trying."
By evening, other American officials said that the end seemed to be near. Ms. Barshefsky would not have come to Beijing three days before the trade sanctions deadline, they said, if she did not feel she could bring the talks to a conclusion.
In February 1995, Ms. Barshefsky went to the brink of trade sanctions as she negotiated a landmark agreement on intellectual property rights. This year, the overriding issue is how to enforce it.
Officials said one area on which Ms. Barshefsky concentrated was how to verify that compact disk plants that were shut down did not simply reopen a few weeks later, or operate clandestinely at night, as some factories have done during the last year.
The Chinese side pledged to reregister every compact disk producer, to introduce stricter licensing procedures and to improve on-site supervision.
Until an agreement is reached and made public, however, it will remain unclear whether such efforts offer any hope of genuine improvement.
While officially opposed to intellectual property violations, China's central Government has seemed to lack the political will to sort through intricate webs of influence among local officials and military officers that often surround pirates in southern China. Enforcement is a touchy issue, since Chinese officials bristle when foreigners tell them how to conduct legal affairs.
During the last year, enforcement has been expanded, but it has largely been carried out by local officials who have often gone through the motions while leaving the real pirates unaffected.
The piracy of American copyrights and trademarks in China -- soap brands, fast food logos, even whole cars are copied -- is actually so common that it is impossible to quantify. American officials have focused on compact disk production precisely because it was a high-profile area that seemed quantifiable. But it is now evident that it can not be measured accurately either.
Negotiations over the number of compact disk factories China would have to close to satisfy the United States, some American officials concede, has become a somewhat irrelevant exercise. Other officials insist that it is still useful.
Washington has favored encouraging American music industry companies to enter joint ventures with Chinese compact disk plants. But it is unclear whether any reputable American music company would willingly enter a partnership with a company known to be pirating.
Blocking export of compact disks copied within China has also been an area of major concern to the Americans. Policing the border with Hong Kong, where many pirated disks are transported, is yet another problem.
Chinese officials have been reluctant to let it appear as if the protection of intellectual property rights had been forced on them and have tried to portray periodic crackdowns as unrelated to talks with the United States. But the issue has nurtured a growing recognition within China that it is a serious problem, and that the biggest victims are actually other Chinese companies.

HEADLINE: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, with a 52-week bill to be auctioned on Thursday.
By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.06 percent and a six-month bill was 5.26 percent, while the 52-week issue was 5.45 percent.
