HEADLINE: 2 Neighboring Schools Are Worlds Apart in Facing Fiscal Woes

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
Five blocks separate two very different public schools in New York City. One, Public School 9, has soared to popularity and academic success through the sweat equity of assertive middle-class parents. The other, P.S. 166, struggles with discouraging test scores, parental apathy and impoverished, low-achieving students.
In the success of one school and the difficulties of another lies a tale of how budget cuts have altered the fabric of the public schools, leaving a system in which fourth and fifth graders monitor kindergarten students in the schoolyard, a teacher pays $800 for her own copying machine and well-heeled parent groups serve as a kind of shadow government, buying everything from paper and glue to good teachers. 
 On paper, the two elementary schools on the Upper West Side are not that far apart financially. P.S. 9, on West 84th Street, with 755 students, receives $3,058 per child from the Federal, state and city governments. P.S. 166, on West 89th Street, with 552 students, receives $3,006 per child. But the ways in which they have responded to the budget cuts are worlds apart.
P.S. 9, one of the top-ranked schools in the city, lost the services of a music teacher for two days a week. But the Parent Teacher Association, which raises nearly $50,000 a year, was able to pay the salaries of two part-time teachers. When the school lost two remedial aides in reading and math, the P.T.A. hired a writing teacher to work with children and coach teachers. As class sizes crept up to 28 children in first grade, the P.T.A. supplied four assistant teachers to replace aides that were lost last year.
P.S. 166 on West 89th Street has had a different experience. Once a premier school, it has fallen academically and drawn a poorer population as prosperous families in the neighborhood have sent their children elsewhere.
As class sizes rose to as high as 35 children, teachers received no additional help. The school was forced to rescind a newspaper advertisement it had placed for an assistant principal because the position could not be financed. The school secretary, Beverly Prince, has taken on many of those administrative responsibilities, handling crises with parents and problems over teacher payrolls and benefits. With the schedules of school aides shortened by an hour a day, teachers fill their places . At P.S. 166, where many children are bused in from as far as Washington Heights, and nearly 87 percent of the students are at or below the poverty level, parental involvement is low.
"In the schools where children seem to do well, there seems to be active parent participation," said Ernestine Roach, a Community School Board member in District 3. "P.S. 9 parents come to all the school board meetings. They speak up. We haven't had that same type of parent participation, not just at 166, but the majority of schools in the district. The squeaky wheel gets the oil."
Two decades ago, the aggressive approach of the P.S. 9 parents was more widespread. After deep budget cuts forced the layoffs of thousands of teachers during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, the angry reaction included huge teacher strikes, parent demonstrations and lawsuits. But in recent years, the cuts have become a more nagging and gradual presence. At P.S. 9, P.S. 166 and many other schools in the city, departing teachers, assistant principals and secretaries have not been replaced.
"It's not like closing a school or a hospital, but an erosion of resources," said Richard Halverson, the city's deputy comptroller of the budget and a former deputy schools chancellor. "It's the problem of attrition. It doesn't attract as much attention. In a way, it's harder to fight when a decline happens over a long period of time."
P.S. 9, with an economically and racially diverse student body, is ranked 28th in the city in reading scores and first in the district. Less than a decade ago, the school was in much the same shape as P.S. 166. But the school acquired several programs for gifted students, magnet programs that lured parents and teachers, who built them into significant attractions.
Recently, a plan to move a program for gifted and talented students from P.S. 9 this fall to P.S. 166, beginning with the kindergarten class, was temporarily derailed by angry parents at P.S. 9, who organized a campaign of letter writing, candlelight vigils and behind-the-scenes negotiations. In a compromise, P.S. 9 will retain its program for now and P.S. 166 will start its own program for the gifted and talented.
In other, often incalculable ways, the P.T.A. at P.S. 9 has been able to generate resources.
"You have schools that are empowered and you have schools that have no power at all," said Gerald Gliber, the school's P.T.A. president, who was just elected to the Community School Board. "Inequity is not an intentional thing. What we are talking about is people who are exposed by virtue of the lives they live, and they can't bear any guilt for what they do. I don't bear any guilt for knowing how to write a grant."
At a well-attended P.T.A. meeting recently, a motion was on the floor to spend $800 toward the hiring of a part-time art teacher. The parents also voted to buy a $750 drying rack for artwork. In all, the P.T.A. has provided $3,000 this year for the school's art budget. The finishing touches were also made for the annual spring fair last month, which raised $7,000 this year and is the school's single largest fund-raiser.
Through book sales, the parents raised $3,100 last year for the library. Though budget cuts closed an after-school program several years ago, the P.T.A. has started one of its own.
P.S. 9 is a hot school. Parent volunteers bustle in and out of the nondescript three-story building. Openings for teachers bring a flood of inquiries. There are hundreds of applications every year for a few dozen jobs as teachers of gifted kindergartners.
P.S. 166, meanwhile, has room to spare. About 200 children are bused in from overcrowded schools in Washington Heights to fill its classrooms. To try to restore the school to its former prominence, the building was picked for a $12 million renovation that has dragged on for four years, with disruptions of classes and jarring construction. The modernization will make the five-story building accessible to the handicapped, improve the electrical wiring and provide new computers.
A banner in the building exhorts children to "Reach for the Stars" and "Welcome to 166 Where We Read to Succeed," though reading scores have slipped. Last year, 38.3 percent of students could read at or above the national average, from 39.8 percent in 1994 and a high of 40.6 percent in 1993. The school ranks 422d in the city.
The P.T.A. president at P.S. 166, Elizabeth Hittenmark, said the organization raises $5,000 a year. She said she is lucky to get the five or six members on the executive board to attend meetings that are usually held once every several months. They work the telephones to drum up a turnout.
"It's going to take that personal touch," said Ms. Hittenmark, who has a second grader at the school. "You call them up and make them feel good about coming to the meeting. It gives them a feeling we're not a clique."
The school's principal, Jack Regan, who came to the school as a teacher in 1969 and was named principal in 1983, said parents are doing the best they can in hard times. The P.T.A. has bought a new computer for the library and a television set for a bilingual class.
"You're talking about very ordinary people with very ordinary jobs," Mr. Regan said. "Parents are supportive, but they struggle like everyone else."
Mr. Regan has been controversial. Some parents and teachers have complained that his dictatorial style is a chief reason the school has not done better, but Ms. Hittenmark credits his toughness with keeping the school from sinking further.
In some ways, the efforts of P.S. 9 and P.S. 166 to cope with dwindling resources were overshadowed in recent months by the controversy over the program for the gifted and talented, which brought charges of elitism and racism. Parents at P.S. 9 suspected that the plan to move their program was an attempt to improve P.S. 166 at the expense of P.S. 9. But James E. Mazza, superintendent of Community School District 3, said the program needed to be moved, one grade a year, because P.S. 9 is not accessible to the handicapped, and P.S. 166 will be soon.
But some parents and teachers at P.S. 166 questioned whether the objections of parents at P.S. 9 had more to do with not wanting their children to attend a school most of whose pupils are black or Hispanic. The P.S. 9 parents said that their program is divided almost in thirds among black, white and Hispanic or other minority children.
While the renovations and the new program give hope that P.S. 166 will reclaim its former stature, for now the school continues to struggle.
Budget cuts have kept Mr. Regan on his feet, in the schoolyard, in the cafeteria, and not the places he would like to be. "Something has to slide," he said. "You have to let go of something." He said the curriculum has probably suffered because he does not have more time to spend with teachers.
Budget cuts have meant that one teacher, Jacque Schneider, is doing kindergarten duty in the playground instead of holding an extra period of art class. She supervises as many as 100 kindergartners from 8 to 9 A.M., a job suited for a school aide if one was available. To make her job easier, Ms. Schneider has trained fifth and fourth graders to assist her.
"They are like my eyes in the back of my head," she said. "I talk to them about responsibility and how to deal with young children. If children are screaming with one another, I tell them to come to me."
The cuts have meant that Monica Pena, who teaches a bilingual class, has 33 fourth and fifth graders and no teacher aide in her classroom. There were 17 children in her class in the early 1980's. Like many teachers, she pays for paper, art supplies and books out of her own pocket. It amounts to about $100 every other month.
Ms. Pena said it is hard enough to grade assignments and make copies for 33 students, but the last straw came when she was told to limit the amount of copying on the school machine. She paid $800 for a copy machine, which is now in her living room.
"You start adding it up and it's overwhelming," she said.

HEADLINE: Radio Is Trying to Court Youngsters and Advertisers

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
Heather Hogan is a full-speed-ahead chatterbox of a 14-year-old who does not yet know what she wants to do for a career. But she already has the kind of corporate title many might envy.
Ms. Hogan is "vice president of fun" at the Children's Broadcasting Corporation here, as well as a popular part-time D.J. at WWTC-AM, the flagship station of the corporation's fledgling children's radio network. 
 The network, which the company calls Radio AAHS (as in oohs and aahs, get it?), stretches from KYAK, Anchorage, to WZKD, Orlando, Fla., and fills 70 percent of its day with music, including reggae, rock, country, classical, folk and jazz. The other 30 percent is filled with stories, jokes, call-in and quiz segments, interviews and child-oriented news.
"It's my job to suggest kid issues and what kids want," Ms. Hogan said.
The target audience for Radio AAHS is children 12 and younger. And while it seems to be drawing listeners -- last year it logged more than three million telephone calls, not to mention assorted E-mails and letters -- the tougher task is convincing advertisers and station owners that there really is a commercial niche for national radio programming aimed at young listeners.
So far, the company is not making money, and eight stations that tried the programming have dropped it.
"We were surprised and upset by the lack of response," said Carmen V. Nardone, whose WMXH-AM in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., broadcast Radio AAHS and other children's programming for three months, starting in July 1993. His station jumped to 15th from 39th in local rankings after switching back to an adult-oriented format, Mr. Nardone said.
No one doubts that the 49 million youths are a potent market many advertisers would love to reach. They spend $7.5 billion annually and influence another $130 billion in household purchases, according to James McNeal, a professor of marketing at Texas A & M University.
The prevailing wisdom, though, is that today's youngsters either ignore radio or listen to the rock stations of their older siblings. Advertisers direct about 70 percent of the more than $1 billion they spend trying to reach children on television and almost all the rest on magazines.
Ratings services like the Arbitron Company do not even track the listening habits of youngsters.
"Convincing a mature industry that there's a demand for something like this that they never believed existed is a big undertaking," conceded Christopher T. Dahl, founder and chief executive of the Children's Broadcasting Corporation.
But he has company. Kidstar Interactive Media Inc., based in Seattle, is trying to build a similar network from a flagship station in Seattle (KKDZ at 1250 AM). Kidstar says it hopes to be in the 10 largest markets by the end of the year.
Unlike Children's Broadcasting, which went public three years ago and now trades on Nasdaq, Kidstar is privately held. Its backers include: Vulcan Ventures Inc., an investment group for Paul Allen, the billionaire co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation; Bandai, the Japanese toy company that makes Mighty Morphin Power Rangers; the CSK Corporation, the largest shareholder in Sega; Benesse, a major Japanese publisher, and NTT America Inc., a unit of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone.
Kidstar says that it is more of a multimedia experience, with its magazines, on-line services and open phones making it "two-way radio." "We're both out there with machetes in the forest carving a new market for media buyers," said Julie Diamond, a spokeswoman.
At AAHS, Gary Landis, the company's executive vice president, is a 20-year network radio executive who was lured from Los Angeles in 1994 to enliven programming.
"There's a misperception that children's radio is Barney and Raffi, which we don't play," said Mr. Landis, who operates out of an office overrun with Gumby figures, toys and his young sons' art. His latest program: "What's Up With Evan Roberts?" is a quirky, call-in show broadcast Thursday evenings from the Woodmere, L.I., bedroom of 12-year-old Evan Roberts.
Children's Broadcasting reckons it is at least a year away from achieving its first profit. Last year it reported a net loss of more than $6 million and total revenue of $5.1 million. Some 42 percent of the revenue came from four small company-owned stations that have not switched to the Radio AAHS format.
But there have been encouraging developments. Its public offering three years ago found a solid market at $11.50 a share, though it closed Friday at $8.25. It managed to raise another $19.5 million in a secondary offering at $10 a share in February.
The Radio AAHS network has grown from WWTC to include six other company-owned stations and 20 affiliates that broadcast to about a third of the nation. That includes the recently acquired WJDM-AM, an Elizabeth, N.J., station that reaches much of the vital New York City market. The station operates at the 1530 and 1660 frequencies -- the latter is in the so-called expanded band that only newer radios are equipped to receive.
Most importantly, Children's Broadcasting has been able to form alliances with some entertainment heavyweights like the ABC Radio Network, the Walt Disney Company and Time Warner Inc.
Disney has given Radio AAHS the chance to broadcast weekend shows live from its theme parks and to develop other tie-ins. Time Warner's computers host the network's Internet site (www.radio-aahs.com). ABC provides audience research, advice in adding affiliates and a place in the inventory of programming that ABC offers national advertisers.
One major new advertiser on AAHS is the Southland Corporation, the Dallas-based parent of 7-Eleven stores. Southland's media buyer had turned Children's Broadcasting down after a presentation because it could not provide ratings numbers. But Marva Cathey, 7-Eleven's national advertising manager, approached the company on her own after learning about it and listening to the Dallas affiliate.
"It became obvious to me that if something was to develop, it had to be seen as an investment," said Ms. Cathey, who in April signed a one-year agreement providing 7-Eleven with on-air advertising space on the Radio AAHS Internet site, opportunities to plug into the network's interactive phone system, special joint promotions and several dozen live broadcasts from 7-Eleven stores around the nation.
"The kids' market is an economic time bomb waiting to explode for radio," William T. McClenaghan, senior vice president of research and development for ABC Radio Networks, said in a recent report.
Mr. McClenaghan's optimism is based in part on his assessment that almost half the nation's 5,000 AM radio stations are losing money and desperately seeking new formats. But that view may be out of date.
"Specialty formats like talk radio have made them more successful," said James Blackburn, a radio station broker in Alexandria, Va.
Mr. Dahl is working to cobble together a larger network of affiliates. "We need more than 50 or 60 percent of the national market to put us on the radar of national advertisers," he said.

HEADLINE: Big New Loss Makes Japan Look Inward

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 16

 BODY:
In the last several years, at least five Japanese companies have suffered huge losses from trading complex financial instruments, the most recent being the Sumitomo Corporation, which disclosed last week that a single copper trader had cost it $1.8 billion.
The stunning loss inevitably raised concern as to what other potential time bombs might be lying around on the balance sheets of Japanese companies. And amid the gleaming office towers here in Tokyo, many people are asking: Why Japan? 
 Among the answers they hear are that Japan's regulatory mechanisms have not kept pace with the country's extraordinary economic growth and that Japanese values tend to discourage investigatory disclosures.
"It's the Japanese mentality, the bureaucratic system that places more importance on harmony rather than reality," suggested Masao Miyamoto, a social psychologist and author of a best-selling critique of Japan called "Straitjacket Society."
His reasoning is that the Japanese are not so much more likely to make trading errors as they are less likely to uncover them before great damage has been done. And that happens, Mr. Miyamoto says, because institutions do not try to ferret out errors or rogue trading.
"If mistakes come out, if the group recognizes that the playing out of reality jeopardizes group harmony, they try to put a lid on it," Mr. Miyamoto adds.
While societal factors may play a significant role in the way corporations operate here, some experts say the various staggering losses are an offshoot of the decades of phenomenal economic growth in Japan since the end of World War II.
That growth built upon an archaic structure of regulations, business customs, a code of protection and weak controls that did not change sufficiently as the country's postwar economy began to bloom.
Some management consultants, scholars and executives say that while traders register losses everywhere in the world, in Japan accounting practices are outdated, risk-management systems are often vague, and auditing and control systems are not always strictly enforced.
Two huge losses have come to light in the last nine months alone. Toshihide Iguchi, a bond trader at the New York offices of Daiwa Bank, covered up $1.1 billion in losses absorbed over 11 years. As a result, Daiwa, one of the world's largest banks, was forced by regulators to get out of the banking business in the United States.
And now, Yasuo Hamanaka, a copper trader at Sumitomo, is accused of hiding losses of $1.8 billion from his superiors for a decade.
Many business people suggest that Japan's opaque and rudimentary accounting system does not exert sufficient discipline in bookkeeping. Assets, for example, are stated at their acquisition price rather than at their market value, as in the West -- no matter how long ago they were purchased or how much their value has increased.
That means that Daiwa Bank, Sumitomo and other companies can accumulate huge amounts of unstated profit over the years, even decades, in which they have held assets. So while the $1.8 billion copper-trading loss attributed to Mr. Hamanaka represented 10 times projected net profit for this fiscal year and 27 percent of the company's net worth, Sumitomo also has several billion dollars in cash and perhaps about $4 billion in unrealized gains from marketable securities and real estate assets, according to analysts.
While a market-value accounting system would not necessarily catch a trader who was falsifying trading slips outright, it does impose a kind of discipline.
"They have huge hidden assets and so they are always very generous in checking or controlling risk," Yushiro Ikuyo, a senior financial analyst at Smith Barney International, said about Japanese companies. "If the company did not have such hidden assets, then they would have to be very careful and cautious in their trading operations."
A rigid corporate hierarchy and inflexible compensation system also contribute to the problems, putting uncommon pressure on star performers to derive reward from reputation rather than salary.
Beyond that, loyalty to the company -- an aspect of the old Japanese practice of lifetime employment -- is deteriorating and, experts say, without the necessary checks and balances to replace it, relationships in companies are sometimes founded too much on trust and permissiveness.
"It's a village mentality," said Mikio Kawamura, a finance professor at Tama University. Anyone who proves successful is admired, and it is considered rude and a sign of jealousy to poke around and double-check whether the achievement is as solid as it seems, he said.
Professor Kawamura, who has had extensive experience in managing metals trading, said this sense of the village often clashes with the discipline required for maintaining good internal auditing systems.
While in many Japanese companies, there is supposed to be a firewall between the front office, which trades, and the back office, which processes the transactions, that wall is frequently not very high. The back-office and front-office workers are often friends. When a trader executes a purchase or sale, he sends the slip to the back office and his trading counterpart sends a confirmation slip, which should go directly to the back office.
"In Japanese companies, often that letter goes to the people who do the trades," Mr. Kawamura said. In the cases of Daiwa Bank's Mr. Iguchi and Sumitomo's Mr. Hamanaka, both were in charge of the trading as well as the accounting of their trades.
When a specialized trader becomes influential, like Mr. Hamanaka, he does not necessarily earn a fatter paycheck. Instead, he enhances his reputation, expands his territory, and others back away.
And the bosses are often generalists, moving from one department of a company to another, and rarely achieving a deep knowledge of the field they are managing. When their subordinates are stars, the checking systems can break down. In specialized markets like copper, it might be "very difficult" to check on a trader regarded as very successful, a senior Japanese executive said.
Yet some people here dispute the notion that Japan's trading losses are peculiar to their country.
"I am astonished that this happened at a company like Sumitomo," said Minoru Makihara, president of the Mitsubishi Corporation, one of Sumitomo's rivals. "This is not something due to Japanese culture."
But Haruo Shimada, an economics professor at Keio University, said that undiscovered catastrophes might well be lurking at other corporations. "This is an outgrowth of the huge success in Japan," he said. "The most dreadful thing is that I'm sure there are 200 other problems of this kind that are still implicit in Japanese companies."

HEADLINE: Budget Deal: Spending Cuts Overwhelmed by Rising Costs

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Austerity never looked so good.
By the time they finished haggling over where to make more than $1 billion in spending cuts and whether to put off promised tax cuts, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the Democrats of the City Council hammered out a budget last week that will spend at least $200 million more in the coming fiscal year than in this one. They also agreed, with much ado, to borrow $1.4 billion over the next four and a half years to repair New York City's decaying public schools, giving Mr. Giuliani, in particular, something to point to when his critics say he has not kept his new pledge to make children a priority. 
 This is a fiscal crunch?
In fact, it is. The outward robustness of the new budget -- adopted by the City Council last week with a mere 4 dissenting votes out of 51 cast -- only masks the underlying problems that have dogged the city throughout the 1990's and that Mr. Giuliani has yet to resolve after two and a half years in office.
The budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1 now flirts with $33 billion, the largest ever and $1.5 billion more than the last one prepared under Mayor David N. Dinkins. Mr. Giuliani had to cut spending sharply in most of the city's departments -- for the third year in a row -- just to keep it from growing any larger.
And to pay for it, the Mayor had to ditch all but a few of his cherished tax cuts and to extend beyond December the city's temporary surcharge on the personal income tax -- something his senior aides had ridiculed as a tax increase only a few months ago.
He also had to rely heavily on one-time infusions of revenues, or "one shots," like the sale of the commercial license for WNYC, the television station the city has owned since 1962. The city's fiscal monitors abhor the idea, because next year the city will have to find some other way to raise the money or make other cuts.
That means that, short of an economic miracle, the seemingly endless cycle will continue -- billion-dollar budget gaps, cuts and a few feeble restorations, a general sense of gloom among advocates for myriad services -- as Mr. Giuliani enters his presumptive re-election campaign next year. In fact, the Council had barely gone home after this year's deal when the Mayor's budget director, Joseph J. Lhota, vowed that more cuts would come.
"It keeps going on and on," said Jeffrey L. Sommer, the first deputy director of the state's Financial Control Board, which put out an unusually strong critique of the budget just as the Mayor and the Council were negotiating in earnest. "They have not dealt with any of the underlying problems."
The problem is simple and little understood.
The city's expenses continue to rise faster than the Mayor and the City Council cut. And so overall spending keeps growing even as budget cuts further erode municipal services. (The city has not actually cut its budget in absolute terms since 1979, when it was still scrambling to rebound from the fiscal crisis.)
At the same time, the city's projected revenues -- from taxes, fees and state and Federal aid -- are rising more slowly than expenses and are expected to continue to do so as the city's economy trudges toward the end of the century.
If the city's finances were in order, its projected expenses would grow at roughly the same pace as its projected revenues. That is what is known as "structural balance." And it is that balance that the fiscal monitors say the Republican Mayor, like his Democratic predecessor, has not yet found. Mr. Giuliani has certainly cut, but he has yet to make fundamental changes that would reduce the growth of the city's costs to a level comparable to economic growth over the long run, the fiscal monitors and bond raters say.
Since taking office, for example, he has reduced the size of the city's payroll by about 20,000 workers, or nearly 9 percent. And yet, the cost of wages and benefits for the 200,000 or so that remain has continued to grow and will balloon in the years ahead when the recently negotiated raises kick in. That, essentially, explains how the new budget reduces the police force by 1,589 officers and yet trims the Police Department's overall budget only marginally.
"It's not that he's a big spender," said Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, an advocacy group supported by business leaders. "He's controlling expenditures but losing ground in the fight for structural balance."
The Mayor's aides argue that they have done all that they can, echoing the laments Mr. Dinkins made when the city's budgets began their unraveling after the boom years of the 1980's. Much of the city's problem, they say, is driven by the state and, to a lesser degree, the Federal Government. Among the fastest-growing parts of the city's budget, for example, is Medicaid. The city must by law pay a portion of Medicaid's cost and yet can do little directly to control its steady growth. (And the State Legislature has balked at Gov. George E. Pataki's efforts to try to control it.)
But it's not all out of the Mayor's hands. During his first year in office, Mr. Giuliani actually succeeded in cutting what is known as city spending, the portion of the budget that excludes state and Federal grants. In his second budget, however, city spending resumed its typical increase, and the new budget has it growing by $1 billion, as large an increase as those under Mr. Dinkins.
It is not entirely a coincidence that the new budget includes more than $1 billion in the one-time revenues that cover higher spending, but only for the time being, according to the Financial Control Board's report.
Without those one-shots, Mr. Giuliani and the Council would have had to make still deeper cuts in spending. Instead, the two sides bought some room to restore money for services like libraries, urban park rangers and preventive services for abandoned or neglected children.
And they pushed some costs into the future. The plan to borrow $1.4 billion for school repairs, for example, will add costs to budgets for the next three decades, rather than paying for it now, as the Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, originally proposed.
To end the chronic gaps, the Mayor and Council would have to give up politically popular proposals like the one for schools. Or raise taxes. Or make still deeper cuts. Or all of the above. In other words, they would have to do what few politicians ever want to do -- and what the public would probably not accept.

HEADLINE: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: WASHINGTON;
Russia-Watchers in U.S. Feel Bipartisan Anxiety

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
Richard Nixon, who built his career on anti-Communism, maintained until the end of his life that America's most important relationship in the world was with Russia, no matter who ruled it or how, because it was the one country with the capacity to destroy the United States.
In a speech last year, Senator Bob Dole, now the Republican presidential candidate, recalled one of Mr. Nixon's last tours of the foreign-policy horizon. "The Soviets have lost the Cold War," Mr. Dole said Mr. Nixon had told him. "But the United States has not yet won it." 
 As Russians voted today in their first presidential election since the collapse of the Soviet Union, both Democrats and Republicans would agree with Mr. Nixon's assessment. A great deal is at stake in this election, including relations with the United States, which has become far more concerned than before with the policies of Boris N. Yeltsin's Government.
"The future of this country, Russia, is uncertain," said Strobe Talbott, Deputy Secretary of State and the main architect of President Clinton's Russia policy. "This Administration is ready for any conceivable outcome," he said protectively on Friday and again today, on the ABC News program "This Week with David Brinkley."
About 60 percent of the returns from today's vote indicate that Russians were setting up a stark choice: a runoff for the presidency between Mr. Yeltsin, who promises both stability and a softer continuation of market economic reform, and the Communist Party leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, who promises a return to great-power nationalism and tighter state control over the economy.
But while Republicans and Democrats have differences on relations with Russia and the newly independent countries of the former Soviet Union, those differences are now mostly of emphasis and degree. Since 1992, just after the collapse of the Soviet Union, fundamental policy has generally been bipartisan, beginning with President George Bush's efforts to promote stability and democracy in the chaotic new Russia by pouring in American emergency aid and then another $500 million for what he called the "Freedom Support Act."
Senators Sam Nunn of Georgia and Richard Lugar of Indiana, a conservative Democrat and a liberal Republican, led the way, starting a program of aid to Russia and the three other former Soviet republics with nuclear weapons to dismantle those weapons and to safely manage the nuclear materials extracted.
The Nunn-Lugar financing, representing about $1.2 billion through fiscal year 1995 ($612 million for Russia), is among the most prominent of the programs that from the end of 1991 through September 1995 has seen the United States obligate some $15 billion for Russia and the other newly independent states. Some $8.7 billion was in aid (of which Russia has received about $3 billion) and $6.3 billion in credits (of which Russia has received about $4 billion).
More than 30 Federal agencies run more than 130 programs in the former Soviet Union, and the United States has pushed the International Monetary Fund to grant Russia more than $17 billion in loans to promote economic restructuring and anti-inflationary budgets.
While Democrats -- and Mr. Dole -- criticized Mr. Bush for what they said was too much uncritical support and aid for Mikhail S. Gorbachev, then the Soviet leader, and his policies, Republicans -- including Mr. Dole -- have criticized Mr. Clinton the same way regarding Mr. Yeltsin.
Republicans have been more vocal than Mr. Clinton in criticizing Mr. Yeltsin's haphazard style of democracy, whether firing tank shells at Parliament in October 1993 or waging war in Chechnya. Many Republicans think that Mr. Clinton has tried too hard, and spent too much, in a badly organized effort to promote internal democratic and market change inside Russia, while worrying too little, especially in the first part of his term, about Eastern Europe and the former Soviet republics.
The Democrats had a more optimistic notion of "partnership" with an emerging, democratic Russia, leading the Republicans to charge the Clinton Administration with "clientitis" toward Mr. Yeltsin, trying to protect perceived Russian reformers willing to take American advice while hesitating to confront them on difficult issues like Chechnya or NATO expansion.
On Saturday, in a statement on the Russian elections, Mr. Dole urged the Clinton Administration to base its relations with Russia less on "any one individual" and more on "realism" about "our interests and our values" in the face of "troubling Russian behavior toward other independent states of the former Soviet Union." Mr. Dole charged that "our interests have been neglected" and he again urged the rapid expansion of NATO. But on the key issues of American foreign policy -- nuclear safety, nuclear disarmament, European security, the independence of Ukraine, the Baltics and other post-Soviet nations -- there is little real difference between the Clinton Administration and Mr. Dole.
Because of the Republican critique and Mr. Yeltsin's own move toward what he perceives as the nationalist Russian center, the Clinton Administration has shifted too. Its early idealism has been deflated by reality, domestic politics and a shrinking foreign-aid budget.
The days of big spending on Russia are long over. Priorities have shifted. Today, not counting the multilateral International Monetary Fund, Ukraine receives more direct American aid than Russia, which is getting only $160 million this year.
On Friday, Mr. Talbott listed American national interests in a way that Mr. Dole would generally support. The most important issues on which to judge a future relationship with Russia, Mr. Talbott said, are continued cooperation on nuclear disarmament; continued respect for Russia's new borders and the independence and territorial integrity of new, ex-Soviet states; continuing adherence to international treaties on everything from nuclear arms reduction to chemical weapons, and continued progress toward real democracy and market reform.
The expansion of NATO to Central and Eastern Europe, Mr. Talbott said, was another of those key American interests.
"The United States has a vital national interest in the political stability, the regional peace and the consolidation of democracy in those parts of Europe, and indeed those parts of the former Soviet Union, that used to be under Communist rule," he said.
Mr. Dole wants to expand NATO faster, but he has so far not committed himself to any specific policy that would clash with the Talbott list.
Both Republicans and Democrats are rooting against Mr. Zyuganov, the only candidate with a real chance to defeat Mr. Yeltsin. For the next few weeks, at least, that bit of fundamental bipartisanship should hold.

HEADLINE: We All Stand to Lose in Orange County Fiasco

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Contrary to "Orange County: Hard Lesson in Safety of Municipal Debt" (Business Day, June 13), bankruptcy typically does reduce the payment of obligations. In most cases, only part of the obligation is ultimately repaid. 
 Moreover, Orange County bondholders are not getting "paid in full." In any bond agreement, interest and principal payments are promised on a strict time schedule. When that schedule is not met, the value of the bonds falls, and interest is lost because funds are unavailable for reinvestment.
The Orange County case represents the first instance in modern history when a municipality that had the ability to meet its obligations simply decided that it would try to avoid doing so, by making use of the bankruptcy laws and suing its investment bankers, accountants and others.
The contrast between Orange County and the New York City experience in the 1970's is meaningful. New York City was more burdened with taxation, had a deteriorating infrastructure and suffered from a long-term weakening in its economy.
Where the response in Orange County was to run for cover, in New York, government, business and labor leaders came together to avoid bankruptcy. There was never any temptation to avoid meeting the city's obligations, nor any temptation to work out the problem other than in cooperation with creditors.
If the result of Orange County is, as your article suggests, more involvement by the Securities and Exchange Commission and other regulators, more rules, more lawyers and litigation, investors may be protected from future Orange Counties. But we as a society will have lost.
 
THOMAS S. JOHNSON
Flushing, Queens, June 14, 1996
The writer is chairman and chief executive of the Greenpoint Bank.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
$1 Billion Less, Please

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The time has come for Israel to do itself and the U.S. a major political favor -- volunteer to take less American economic aid, or none at all.
That strikes me as such a good idea that I wrote it three years ago. Israeli economists were beginning to talk about it quietly. I thought a column would give the idea a push with the Labor Government and it did -- right into oblivion. The reaction I got from Rabin-Peres people was that it was a typical piece of troublemaking for Labor from a voice of the right. 
Labor's refusal to act is Benjamin Netanyahu's opportunity, made to order for his beliefs and personality. Given the choice, the Prime Minister-designate would like to focus his leadership on his economic path for Israel -- rapid privatization of the economy, cutting the trade imbalance and deficit, selling land owned by government, reducing government and political involvement in business.
He won't have the luxury of focusing only on that kind of thing. Peace with security is why Israel elected him, and that will be his chief job. And from left to right are political and religious groups that count on government money; they like things as they are, only more so.
Some of his advisers say he has enough on his plate without passing up more than $1 billion a year. Others tell him that reducing or eliminating American aid fits in with his own goals of capitalist self-sufficiency -- so do it.
Israel gets about $3 billion a year from the U.S. About $1.8 is military -- loans to buy American weapons and technology. This money, and the special pipeline that goes with it, are essential to Israel. Alone, it would be hard for Israel, perhaps impossible, to compete with the scores of billions the Arab nations can spend on arms from all over the world, including Chinese missiles, and the weapons they buy from the U.S.
In an important sense, the military component of the U.S. package for Israel allows Washington to keep up its continuous flow of arms to the Arab nations. A militarily weak Israel surrounded by militarily strong Arab nations would be a security disaster for America. Without the Israeli ballast, American military credibility would sink fast in the Mideast.
About $1.2 billion of American aid is economic. It is a grant used by Israel to pay interest on past American military loans. In a way it is bookkeeping -- money from the U.S. to Israel and back to the U.S. But it is a very nice kind of bookkeeping for the borrower -- grants to pay interest on loans.
Mr. Netanyahu does not think the Israeli economy is as thriving as Labor likes to make out -- too much debt and regulation, per capita income nowhere near its potential. And the $10 billion in U.S.-guaranteed loans that Washington denied to a Likud Government but allowed for Labor is running out.
Still, the only reason to give or accept any economic handout is dire need, for a nation as for a person. Happily, Israel is not in that position anymore.
No country has done more for Israel than the United States -- good times, bad times. The best way to say thank you is to say it -- and then show you don't need it anymore. I spent Father's Day weekend at the home of a son and his wife in New Jersey. He bought me a steak dinner in a nice restaurant, gave me a computer lesson, whipped up a barbecue the next night and sent me home in a limousine. It was worth all that tuition and we both knew it.
For Israel, giving up the billion would be more than a political gesture and excellent public relations. It would -- or should -- free up that much more money for those who need it a lot more: poor countries, political prisoners, refugees. Or women abused by their own societies -- $1 billion spent fighting female genital mutilation could save millions of young women and girls, many not yet born, from that torture.
Maybe that would not happen. Maybe the money would just disappear into some American budget morass. Still, giving up that billion it could use, but does not vitally need, would be a pride for Israel, just fine for America and one more bond of respect between the two countries.
Going by his record and beliefs, I think Mr. Netanyahu will do this thing during his time in office. Early would be lovely.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Trade Surplus Slows for an 18th Month

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 17

 BODY:
Japan's global trade surplus slowed in May for the 18th consecutive month, declining 61 percent, and the surplus with the United States narrowed 40 percent, the Finance Ministry said today.
Economists said the trade surplus would continue to decrease. But they said they expected the rate of decline to slow because the yen had weakened against the dollar and Japanese economic recovery had not yet built up much steam. 
 The Finance Ministry said the surplus fell to 231.69 billion yen, or $2.1 billion, last month from 586.99 billion yen in May 1995. Exports increased 14 percent, to 3.406 trillion yen, from 2.982 trillion yen a year earlier, and imports rose by nearly one-third, to 3.174 trillion yen from 2.395 trillion yen. However, Japanese traders in May still exported more than they imported.
The surplus with the United States, often a source of friction between the two countries, narrowed to 167.68 billion yen, or $1.5 billion, from 277.51 billion yen. Exports to the United States rose 11 percent, to 898.20 billion yen from 808.19 billion yen, while imports into Japan increased 38 percent, to 730.53 billion yen from 530.67 billion yen. The United States is Japan's biggest trading partner.
The dollar fell to a postwar low of 79.75 yen in April 1995. It has gained in stages since then, trading around 109 yen late today.
One reason for the declining surplus is that many Japanese manufacturers have shifted some of their production abroad, where costs are lower, thus reducing the amount of exports from Japan. Another is that imports into Japan have been growing as consumer spending recovers and manufacturers of electronic goods import larger quantities of microchip parts.
Still, economists expect a slowing in the rate at which the trade surplus is declining. With the yen's decrease in value against the dollar in recent months, the value of Japanese exports has risen. And although Japanese consumers are buying more goods, the persistently weak domestic recovery has restrained import growth to a degree, the economists said. Japanese companies are likely to try to earn more money from exports if the economy continues to recover slowly, they added.
As the yen weakens, the cost of Japanese exports declines in terms of other currencies, making the exports more attractive. At the same time, foreign sales denominated in other currencies translate into a greater number of yen, inflating the export figures.
And a weaker yen makes imports into Japan more expensive. A Government official said the yen's weakness had helped increase vehicle exports in May. In yen terms, they rose 8 percent -- the first increase in 18 months.
The volume of total exports rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, the first increase in four months.
Soichi Okuda, senior economist at Nippon Credit Bank, said, "The trade surplus is unlikely to show a year-on-year rise for the time being, but with the yen's weakness now established as a trend, it may stop falling at the current pace."

HEADLINE: Goldman, Sachs Earnings Register a Strong Increase

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Heralding strong second-quarter earnings for Wall Street firms, Goldman, Sachs & Company earned $709 million before taxes for the three months that ended May 31 1996, John A. Thain, the firm's chief financial officer, said yesterday.
These earnings represent a 25.5 percent increase on the previous quarter ended Feb. 29, when Goldman made $565 million in profits before taxes, and are more than double earnings for the quarter a year earlier, when the firm made $346 million before taxes. 
 Wall Street firms, like Goldman, are benefiting hugely from relatively low interest rates and buoyant financial markets as the stock market continues at record levels. Later this week, Lehman Brothers will state its results, the first of the publicly traded Wall Street firms to report earnings for the most recent quarter.
Mr. Thain, who is based at the firm's London office, and other Goldman officials said the good second-quarter earnings, the firm's third best quarter ever, reflected broad strength across the company's various businesses, including the issue, sale and trading of equity and debt, as well as advice on company mergers, acquisitions and corporate finance. The firm's financial year ends on Nov. 30, meaning that the second quarter ends May 31.
Most of Goldman's 171 working partners who are based in New York City met yesterday afternoon at the firm's Manhattan headquarters for their monthly partners meeting to discuss the results. Goldman, which was founded in 1869 and is Wall Street's last big investment banking partnership, also has 110 limited partners who are former working partners who have retired from the firm. As a partnership, the firm states its results before taxes as each partner files individual taxes for his share in the company's profits. During the quarter, Goldman earned revenues of $1.67 billion and paid expenses of $961 million. So far in the first half of its financial year, Goldman has earned $1.27 billion from revenues of $3.13 billion.
The partnership's capital has also continued to grow and totaled about $5.2 billion at the end of the firm's second quarter, up from about $4.9 billion at the end of last year.
During its second quarter Goldman advised on several big mergers, including the Chase Manhattan Corporation's merger with the Chemical Banking Corporation, as well as Indosuez's merger with Credit Agricole. And Goldman, along with Salomon Inc., advised on Mexico's exchange of its Brady bonds to give that nation greater flexibility in managing its debt.
Goldman predicts good prospects for its major businesses. "The outlook is very strong," Mr. Thain said, referring to the firm's backlog of business in its major markets. The firm also expects to grow overseas, particuarly in fast-expanding Asian financial markets, he added.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
After Orange County, MBIA's bond insurance is in demand.

BYLINE: By Sharon R. King 

 BODY:
FOR more than a year, shares of MBIA Inc. have been buoyed by expectations that the Orange County bankruptcy would be good for business. The stock rallied sharply after MBIA insured the California county's offering of nearly $900 million of new bonds this month. And yesterday, MBIA, the nation's largest insurer of municipal bonds, closed at a 52-week high of $79.875.
The Orange County deal garnered MBIA about $29.5 million in fees and brought new interest in the stock. Before the sale, a Salomon Brothers analyst, Caitlin F. Long, issued a "buy" recommendation, citing the prospects of heftier premiums on some of the bonds MBIA insures. 
 But others have a less sanguine view of the company's near-term prospects. An analyst at Merrill Lynch, Louise Costikyan, last week reinstated coverage of MBIA but gave it only a "neutral" rating. (She did rate the stock a "long-term buy" for value-seeking investors, however.)
Diversification has taken MBIA into money management for municipalities and insuring asset-backed and international securities. But MBIA still derives more than 80 percent of its revenues from municipal insurance -- guaranteeing the payment of principal and interest on bonds sold by state and local governments. The insurance gives the bonds the highest investment-grade rating of triple-A. It also reduces the borrowing costs of municipalities even after they pay the insurance premium.
"I think it will be a long time before these other areas rival the revenue and income impact that the municipal bond insurance has," said David Litvack, senior director of the financial guarantees group at Fitch Investors Service. "I think you'll have to temper the growth expectations."
Merrill Lynch foresees at best only modest growth in municipal bond issuance in 1996 and 1997, with no significant drop in interest rates to spur refinancings and put extra revenues into the company's coffers. MBIA earns a portion of its insurance premiums each year until a bond matures. But when a bond is refunded or retired early, MBIA gets all of those revenues at once.
Like most bond insurance companies, MBIA's stock price tends to track adjusted book value, trading in a range that runs from a 15 percent discount to a 35 percent premium to that figure, Ms. Costikyan said. Adjusted book value is a calculation of a company's liquidation value and takes into account the present value of future premiums. By this measure, MBIA is trading at a 5 percent premium, just below its historic average of 7 percent, Ms. Costikyan said. She would need to see a rise in the volume of new municipal issues or see the premium drop to a discount to raise her recommendation to a buy, she said.
In February, the market was offered 3.5 million shares of MBIA stock, an amount that included 2.86 million shares sold by the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, which had held about 3.8 million MBIA shares in its investment portfolio. The sale by Aetna was negotiated as part of the agreement by Travelers Inc. last November to buy Aetna's property and casualty insurance unit. As part of that deal, Aetna agreed to pare its $1 billion equity portfolio to about $400 million to accommodate a different investment philosophy at Travelers, which is more heavily skewed toward bonds than equity, said Keith Anderson, a spokesman for Travelers.
"We advised them in the way in which we wanted the equity portfolio structured," Mr. Anderson said. He declined to give any specific reasons why the MBIA stake was pared. The MBIA sale produced $200 million for Travelers.
Although MBIA has been able to increase its share of the insured market annually, it has done so at a price. In some instances the company charged lower premiums than competitors to snare business -- such as the recent Orange County deal. It has also foraged in the realm of double-A rated bonds, which are one rank below triple A and produce lower premiums than the typical insured bond, which is in the range of single-A to triple-B. And with the rate of growth in volume of newly issued municipal bonds waning and a surge in refundings unlikely, it seems doubtful to some analysts that the company will strongly outperform the market. Moreover, it has begun to insure unsecured corporate debt, a move out of its traditional business that has caused some uneasiness on Wall Street.
David H. Elliott, chairman of MBIA, counters that the company's diversification and growing share of the insured municipal bond market justify greater optimism. About 43 percent of new-issue municipal volume was insured in 1995, with MBIA dominating the market with a 42 percent share of the business, up from 40 percent in 1994. As for the foray into unsecured corporate debt, Mr. Elliott said the company was staying with high-quality issuers and short maturities.
Despite its record, the company faces increased competition in some of its new lines of business. For example, Ms. Costikyan of Merrill gives a "buy" rating to a competitor, Financial Security Assurance Inc., because it derives about 38 percent of its revenues from insuring asset-backed securites and its stock is trading at a discount to its adjusted book value of about 89 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Profits Rose in Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Profits of manufacturers rose strongly at the beginning of 1996 after a weak finish in the closing quarter of 1995, the Commerce Department said today.
A quarterly survey of about 7,900 companies showed that profits rose to a seasonally adjusted 5.8 cents a dollar of sales from a revised 5 cents in the fourth quarter last year. 
 Manufacturers' profits after taxes in the first quarter were a seasonally adjusted $52.81 billion on net sales of $905.43 billion. That was 18 percent higher than fourth-quarter profits of $44.61 billion, when net sales were $895.49 billion.
Previously, the department said fourth-quarter profits averaged 5.1 cents a sales dollar. But it revised that downward.
Despite the solid increase in profits in the first quarter this year, they remained below levels a year earlier, when manufacturers had higher after-tax earnings of $53.70 billion on lower net sales of $868.03 billion.
Producers of both durable goods, like cars and refrigerators, and nondurable goods, like food and paper products, made higher profits in the first quarter this year than they did in the closing months of 1995.
Durables producers' profits after taxes were up to a seasonally adjusted $24.35 billion in the first quarter from $22.93 billion in the fourth quarter. Companies that make nondurable goods had profits of $28.45 billion in the first quarter, up from $21.68 billion in the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: IN WASHINGTON;
U.S. Officials Praise Outcome And Express Guarded Optimism

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Heaping praise on Boris N. Yeltsin and congratulating him on a "strong showing" in the first round of Russia's presidential elections on Sunday, President Clinton today all but endorsed Mr. Yeltsin in his coming head-to-head contest with the Communist candidate, Gennadi A. Zyuganov.
The Clinton Administration has been careful not to formally anoint Mr. Yeltsin as America's choice, but officials were exultant today that the Communists had been beaten into second place, no matter how narrowly, and had been unable to expand their constituency beyond a third of the electorate. 
 American officials also expressed quiet confidence that, barring an unforeseen event, Mr. Yeltsin would be re-elected.
"The important result, despite the sheer fact of Yeltsin going ahead with this election and putting his future on the line, is that Zyuganov came second," a senior American official said today.
The United States Ambassador in Moscow, Thomas Pickering, was more explicit than most officials today, saying on ABC's "Good Morning America:" "I have felt for a long time that in a runoff between Mr. Zyuganov and Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Yeltsin would continue to have the edge. I haven't changed that view."
Mr. Clinton congratulated Mr. Yeltsin for observing his Constitutional duty to hold an election. He said he looked forward to speaking to Mr. Yeltsin soon by telephone, saying: "I want to congratulate him on the election, not only on the strong showing that he made but also on the fact that he really supported the Constitution, he supported the institution of the electoral process, and the very fact that it occurred in such a vigorous fashion is, I think, a real credit to him."
The two men will meet later this month at an economic summit meeting in Lyons, France, where Mr. Yeltsin will, between voting rounds, bask in the approval of other world leaders, including some, like the German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, who have endorsed him explicitly.
Mr. Clinton's presumed Republican opponent, Bob Dole, said today that "I should think Yeltsin would feel pretty good about it."
"At least the forces of democracy prevailed yesterday by a very narrow margin. We don't want to step backward," he said, then repeated his charge that Mr. Clinton is moving too slowly to expand NATO, saying: "We ought to move ahead with Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. President Clinton is sort of dragging his feet."
Anders Aslund, an economist, Russian scholar and senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment, said that Mr. Zyuganov was unlikely to win much more than 40 percent of the vote in the runoff and that Mr. Yeltsin had already laid the groundwork for an endorsement by Aleksandr I. Lebed, the gruff former general who ran a solid third on a platform of order, civic morality and patriotism.
Mr. Aslund expected Mr. Yeltsin to move toward a more nationalist position between rounds to appeal to supporters of Mr. Lebed and of the nationalist Vladimir Zhirinovsky. Peter Reddaway of George Washington University agreed, but said he expects Mr. Yeltsin to move quite sharply to "a lot of nationalist and anti-Western rhetoric."
American officials today seemed unfazed by the prospect, saying that they expected Mr. Yeltsin to hold to anti-inflationary policies and a program of general cooperation with the United States and the West.

HEADLINE: Abraham Rosen, 85, Harlem Store Owner, Dies

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
Abraham Rosen, who founded a Harlem discount store that has survived recessions, fire and unrest among people of different heritage and skin color, died on Sunday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. He was 85.
A resident of Fort Lee, N.J., Mr. Rosen came to the United States from Poland as a boy. He had been a merchant in Harlem since 1938, when he and his brothers, Sam and Irving, opened separate businesses in the neighborhood. 
 In 1961, Abraham Rosen founded Bargain World at 8 West 125th Street with about a dozen employees. Today, it has 40 to 50 employees selling "everything except clothes and food," in the words of his son, Arthur, of Bergen County, N.J., who now handles the business.
Until late last year, the hardest time for the Rosens and their business was probably the late fall of 1980, when an electrical fire gutted the store and the insurance turned out to be inadequate. Weeks later, father and son were mugged in front of the store. Abraham Rosen was pistol-whipped, and his son was shot.
In an interview last year, Arthur Rosen reminisced about rising, quite literally, from the ashes. "I had a burned-out building that the family owned in the middle of Harlem and a business that had supported us all these years," he said. "So we put it all back together again."
Abraham Rosen retired in 1983, his son said, but he still put in appearances in the Christmas shopping season. He was there last Christmas Eve, not long after a gunman walked into Freddy's, a clothing store a few doors away, shot four people and set a fire, killing eight people, including himself.
The day after the attack, which the police say was racially motivated, protesters stood in front of Bargain World -- like Freddy's, a white-owned store in a black neighborhood -- and promised to drive it out of the neighborhood.
But many other shoppers in Harlem stopped to greet his father and offer words of support, Arthur Rosen said yesterday.
Besides his son, Mr. Rosen is survived by his wife, Sheva; a daughter, Leta Gordon, of Bergen County, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Canada Warns U.S. on Law Penalizing Cuba Commerce

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 17

 BODY:
Canada threatened retaliatory measures today against a United States law that penalizes Canadian and other foreign companies doing business in Cuba.
Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy called his Government's action "the beginning of a chain reaction among other countries in developing a collective response" to the law, the Helms-Burton Act, which has been sharply criticized by American allies and other friendly nations since President Clinton signed it in March. 
 The move comes as Canada and Mexico, the United States' closest trading partners, have stepped up their opposition to the law, which, among other things, requires foreign companies to report any property they have in Cuba that was confiscated from American owners by the Government of Fidel Castro.
The law opens the way for such companies to be sued for compensation in United States courts.
Canada and Mexico also announced today that they would file a complaint against the Helms-Burton Act under the North American Free Trade Agreement.
They discussed the possibility of joint action when Mexico's President, Ernesto Zedillo, met with Prime Minister Jean Chretien last week. European and other Latin American nations are among those also stating their unhappiness with the American law.
Mr. Axworthy and International Trade Minister Arthur Eggleton said the Cabinet was introducing legislation to allow Canadian companies to countersue American companies in Canadian courts.
Many American companies have property in Canada and would thus be vulnerable to such countersuits. "This certainly provides a measure of confidence to Canadian business," Mr. Eggleton said to reporters.
Thomas d'Aquino, president of the Business Council on National Issues, which represents leading Canadian companies, called the response appropriate, adding that "they've done the best they could under the circumstances."
Sherritt International, a Canadian company that owns half of a nickel and cobalt mine in eastern Cuba along with the Castro Government, is among those that stands to be affected by the United States law. A New Orleans company, Freeport-McMoran Inc., says it owned the Sherritt property before the Cuban revolution in the late 1950's.
Mr. Axworthy and Mr. Eggleton said legislation would be introduced this fall ordering Canadians not to comply with the Helms-Burton Act. Under an amendment to a 1985 Canadian law, the Foreign Extraterritorial Measures Act, Canadians who do comply with Helms-Burton could face $10,000 fines, five years' imprisonment or both. Canadian officials pointed out that the maximum American fine under Helms-Burton provisions is $1 million.
The law also allows the United States to deny entry to senior executives of such companies, putting them in the same category as political militants or convicted felons.
Canada does not intend a response to the denial-of-entry sanction, and Mr. Eggleton said he would pursue the matter as a violation of the North American trade agreement -- in which Canada and Mexico are the United States' two partners.
Mr. Eggleton said he was requesting a high-level meeting of the North American Free Trade Agreement's governing body to take up his complaint that such denial of entry violated Chapter 16 of the accord, providing for access to member countries for business purposes.
The two Canadian Cabinet ministers indicated they hoped that their tough response today would deter a full trade war. "We do have the time over the summer to go through a period of consultations," Mr. Eggleton said. "I think the fact we put this legislation into effect will cause American companies to pause before taking action."
The Helms-Burton Act was introduced by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Representative Dan Burton of Indiana, both conservative Republicans. It was passed after the downing in February of two civilian aircraft flown by anti-Castro Cuban-Americans, and it includes a provision giving the President discretion to exempt nations from the sanctions if he concludes that such a step is in the national interest.
Mr. Axworthy and Mr. Eggleton said the Canadian legislation was being held back until the fall to give President Clinton a chance to use his discretionary authority.

HEADLINE: Average Car Price $20,000? Not Quite, It Seems.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 17

 BODY:
When the Commerce Department calculated in late 1994 that the average price of a new car had broken the $20,000 level for the first time, the result was an immediate outcry over whether cars had become too expensive.
But now it turns out the numbers were wrong. The average price for all cars, including sharply discounted sales to rental car fleets and other larger purchasers, never reached $20,000. Even the average price of cars sold to individuals only briefly touched $20,000 in late 1994. And average car prices have actually drifted lower in the last year and a half, as makers have been raising prices less often and more buyers have been choosing cheaper cars. 
 Prices paid by individuals peaked at $20,247 in the third quarter of 1994 and have since slipped to $19,459, according to revised figures from the Commerce Department. The department recalculated its figures with much greater precision this year after protests from auto makers here, who were upset by the suggestion that they were pricing themselves out of the market.
When sales to fleets are included, the average car prices actually peaked in the third quarter of 1994 at $18,993 and have declined since then to $18,055 in the first quarter of this year, according to the new calculations. Headlines about car prices hitting an average of $20,000 began appearing at the start of 1995 and were based on sales that included fleets as well as to individuals.
The new Commerce Department calculations include manufacturers' rebates, along with discounts that auto makers offer to customers who buy packages of options. The department also began tracking sales of specific models -- drawing distinctions between the Ford Taurus GL and the higher-cost Taurus SHO midsize sedans, for example -- and made other refinements.
Auto industry officials who have noticed the change have welcomed it. "What it does show is that all the excitement about $20,000 was overblown," said Joel H. Pitcoff, a market analysis manager at the Ford Motor Company, the auto maker most criticized over the past year for raising prices.
But even if the average price of a car is not $20,000, the average price of all new vehicles is slightly more because of the growing popularity of sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and trucks. The average price for mini-vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles is now about $22,000, and these vehicles now account for 42 percent of all new light vehicles sold in the United States.
The Commerce Department figures are also bad news for the auto industry to the extent they show the pressures on auto makers to cut prices. For example, the new figures show a 4.3 percent drop in average car prices since the third quarter of 1994 as Americans bought more sub-compacts and some luxury-car makers cut prices.
The Consumer Price Index, which is calculated separately by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, shows that prices for comparable cars have edged up over the last several years. But the rate of increase in new-car prices has slowed sharply, from 3.4 percent in 1994 to 1.4 percent in the 12 months ending last month, or half the rate of inflation in the overall economy.
Competition has become increasingly fierce over the last several years in the car market, which suffers from overcapacity as many buyers have switched to mini-vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles. Japanese auto makers are now becoming even more aggressive in offering discounts or slashing base prices, as the falling yen has reduced their costs in dollar terms.
Gerald A. Donahoe, the Commerce Department's associate director for national income expenditures and wealth, said that the auto industry's complaints had prompted the agency to review its methods of calculating auto prices. But he insisted that auto industry pressure played no role in the agency's eventual decision to choose a new method for its calculations that happens to produce a result more pleasing to auto makers.
"I don't think there was any influence -- in fact, we would have liked to have gotten more help from them" with detailed sales information, Mr. Donahoe said. The Commerce Department did not refine its figures sooner mainly because of a lack of resources, he added.
Tod Reese, the Bureau of Labor Statistics' new vehicle analyst for the Consumer Price Index, said that his agency had long taken into account the manufacturers' rebates and other details that the Commerce Department is only now incorporating in its calculations. The Commerce Department's changes will have no effect on the reported rate of inflation, said Patrick C. Jackman, an economist at the bureau.
