HEADLINE: The New Buzz: Growth Is Good;
Latest Strategy for Business Is a Positive Spin on Layoffs

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
What a difference a few months make. When they agreed to merge this spring, Bell Atlantic and Nynex pointedly passed up an opportunity to announce the elimination of 3,000 "overlapped" jobs. New markets would open for the merged company, they insisted, saving the workers from layoffs. "We think we will create enough new jobs to redeploy most of those 3,000 people," said Ivan G. Seidenberg, Nynex's chairman.
The emphasis -- and even the buzzwords -- are shifting. The rhetorical trumpeting of layoffs, as if they were a badge of honor, is disappearing. The negative publicity that descended on AT&T after it announced in January that it would eliminate 40,000 jobs was a turning point. Now, companies are choosing to highlight the potential for new hires down the road. Announcements are increasingly in the style of Bell Atlantic and Nynex, with their focus on growth to save jobs, and only a footnote-like nod of acknowledgment that the 3,000 workers might be laid off if the growth fails to materialize. 
 Rather than focus on shedding workers and lowering costs -- billed until now by companies like I.B.M., Sears, Roebuck and Xerox as the unpleasant but necessary means to the end of building sales by becoming more competitive and eventually adding jobs -- the rhetoric is changing to emphasize the end rather than the means. Corporate America, and the consultants who help executives devise both the strategy and the rhetoric that describes it, are softening their earlier, harsher language, with its stress on sacrifice and survival.
But while the words are changing, reality hasn't, at least not yet. American companies are still cutting jobs, if more sotto voce. "The pace of layoffs is way ahead of last year at this time," said John E. Challenger, president of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a Chicago firm that tracks announcements of job cuts. They reached 230,350 through May, up 34 percent from the 171,924 in the corresponding period last year.
The shifting rhetoric is a reaction in part to the criticism leveled at AT&T, and in part to a political climate that has prompted candidates in this election year to lament downsizing. But the shift also reflects an economic reality: At many companies, surveys show, job cutting has failed to bring the promised growth and hiring. The new rhetoric is an attempt to deal with this shortcoming, in language if not in deed.
The new approach shows up at companies like Allied Signal Inc., the huge manufacturer. Allied has taken pains lately to make clear that for every job eliminated or worker laid off in a shrinking division, like auto parts, a job is added, and usually a worker is hired, in a growing one, like chemicals, plastics and fibers, a point unstated before. Conagra Inc., the food processor, while announcing in May that 6,500 workers would soon be laid off, noted that, in the words of Lynn Phares, a vice president, "Our employment has grown by 10,000 since 1992, and we aren't eliminating as many jobs as we've created."
SBC Communications Inc. and the Pacific Telesis Group, which announced a merger on April 1, made no mention of layoffs. Quite the contrary, their press release spoke of creating 1,000 jobs at the new headquarters location in California "over what otherwise would have been the case if the merger had not occurred."
The shift reflects a new mantra, still being developed by management consultants, for how to justify corporate reorganizations that still cost jobs. "The consulting industry is pushing growth much more than in the past," said William Matassoni, a partner at McKinsey & Company Inc., the consulting firm. "There was too much emphasis on let's cut back, let's get rid of people, and not enough on how to grow once companies become leaner and more efficient."
The new rhetoric features such jargon as "growing the revenue line," which means increasing sales so that jobs can be added as business expands. "Execute growth-capturing actions" appeared on many of the slides that Braxton Associates, a consulting arm of Deloitte & Touche, showed at a "growth conference" in Chicago in late April. And there is "corporate anorexia," increasingly used to mean too few employees left after layoffs to make growth possible.
Hoping to add to the repertoire, Michael Hammer, the consultant and best-selling author, is pushing, in a book to be published this month, a phrase that he recently coined: "the process-centered organization," meaning a company that coordinates each employee's task into a single process that "drives out costs and errors and promotes growth." Little attention is given to layoffs, although in his most famous book, "Re-engineering the Corporation," of which Mr. Hammer was the co-author, job-cutting was clearly an important tool.
Downsizing and the rhetoric that goes with it were born in the early 1980's, when John F. Welch Jr., the new chairman of the General Electric Company, began to revamp that huge, pacesetting company and in the process gave birth to the phenomenon that exists today. Its spread, from General Electric through corporate America, is really the story of how the nation's executives, struggling with inefficiencies and weak profits, collaborated with management consultants to create a strategy and a justifying story line.
The consultants spread the new concepts like bees in summer pollinating flower after flower. "I even think of myself as a bee," said William Dauphinais, who heads Price Waterhouse's consulting practice in the Northeast. "We are always aggressively selling our ideas, at seminars, in our writings, in client presentations." And gradually the downsizing announcements pollinated by consultants took on the uniformity of language evident today.
The goal of downsizing has always been growth. From the outset, the emphasis on cost-cutting and layoffs suggested that once a company became more efficient, new markets would be conquered, sales would expand and new hiring would occur. In the meantime, the cost-cutting would bring a quick spurt in profits, pleasing shareholders. Now, post-AT&T, the rhetoric skips over the cost-cutting and gets right to the growth.
But some mantras born in the 1980's remain as much a part of the lingo as ever, each still intended to give a positive spin to layoffs. "Managing your own career" came into vogue to describe, euphemistically, the job hopping that befell those laid off. "Lifetime employability" replaced job security, the message being that in the "new social contract," employers would give "flexible" workers enough training to qualify for other well-paying jobs, if they were laid off.
The shift in emphasis in describing downsizing is reflected in the changing language of Jeanette Zang, a partner at Towers Perrin, a consulting firm. In an interview last September, she insisted that companies must "come to grips with their labor costs." Shrinking staff and holding down wage costs, she counseled then, were prerequisites for the reorganization that would bring growth.
Now, drawing on the new phrases emerging from her business -- and helping to shape them -- she and others at Towers Perrin highlight reorganization, which means to bring growth by changing the way employees work, developing new marketing techniques and introducing new products, or at least new twists on old ones.
"Layoffs have got to be rational," Ms. Zang said. "You initially saw downsizing because companies were fat. They went from obese to losing weight, and many companies have to downsize more to become fit. But I do see corporate anorexia setting in, companies with too few employees, which is not going to benefit anyone. We are stressing that companies should pay more attention to growing the revenue line."
But if shedding workers is losing status, the growth fad might not last either. The robust expansion of the economy suggested by the new slogans probably is not likely, if only because it would raise fears of inflation and that would prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, thus slowing the economy. Without that robust growth, Lawrence A. Bossidy, chairman of Allied Signal, is not certain the new emphasis on trying to build revenue can stave off job cutting indefinitely.
Still, he has embraced the new language. Allied has shed nearly 10 percent of its work force since 1991, when Mr. Bossidy became chairman. But in the last two years, employment has remained steady at 77,500. Last October, Allied announced the elimination of 3,100 jobs in its auto parts division. No mention was made in the press release that new hires in chemicals, plastics and fibers were in fact offsetting these job cuts. Only lately has Mr. Bossidy made that point. "I have told our people that the only justification for cost-cutting is to get more business and add jobs," he said in an interview.
But if that business does not materialize, Mr. Bossidy suggests, then the head count could shrink again.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Companies took notice when AT&T was besieged with negative publicity after announcing in the second paragraph of a January 2 press release that it would elimate 40,000 jobs, above. Some more recent press releases, such as the one shown at right, from Conagra Inc., bury the job cuts rather than seeming to trumpet them to investors.
 
Chart: "Talking the Talk"
 Through most of the 1990s, the vocabularies of management consultants and their executive clients were littered with stern stock phrases that connoted shrinkage. Corporations were to become "lean and mean" through "re-engineering" and "downsizing." But that lexicon is quickly being replaced with a new set of buzzwords, as these recent samples suggest:
 
"If you cut too many people out, you lose the core capability that is necessary to grow the revenue line. You suffer from corporate anorexia." -- William Matassoni, partner, McKinsey & Company.
 
"Rethinking how you work let's you do a better job for your customer and or grow the revenue line. That is where most re-engineering is focused now and has been for 18 months or so." -- Michael Hammer, author of Re-Engineering the Corporation
 
"I do see corporate anorexia setting in, companies with too few employees, which is not going to benefit anyone. We are stressing that companies should pay more attention to the revenue line." -- Jeanette Zang, a partner at Towers Perrin.

HEADLINE: Dole Expresses His Confidence Of Healing Split on Abortion

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WALNUT CREEK, Calif., June 17

 BODY:
Bob Dole said today that he was trying to heal the rifts on abortion within the Republican Party and that he expected his efforts to pay off.
"Piece of cake," Mr. Dole told reporters today on his campaign plane as he headed to California for his third visit since he wrapped up his party's Presidential nomination in March. 
 It was not entirely clear what he meant, but the suggestion was that he was making an effort to appease the abortion opponents whom he alienated last week with his proposal to include language signaling "tolerance" of abortion-rights advocates in the party platform.
"I know the press will be unhappy, but we'll work it out," Mr. Dole said. "You won't be able to write about it anymore."
Mr. Dole said he expected to meet on Friday with Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, an influential abortion foe who is chairman of the party's platform committee. Mr. Hyde had threatened to quit as chairman last week after Mr. Dole surprised his staff -- and everyone else -- by saying that he would apply the language on "tolerance" to the party's plank on abortion but not to the entire platform.
This infuriated abortion opponents, who said they were being singled out as a liability to the party, and many threatened to do battle with him at the convention.
But Ralph Reed, executive director of the Christian Coalition, implied in a television interview on Sunday that he was meeting with the Dole campaign and expected to work out some sort of accord.
One option apparently being considered is to attach "tolerance" language to other issues, including trade, gun control and term limits, all of which have ignited fierce debate within the party.
But Mr. Dole's campaign believes he has benefited in polls from being perceived as "fighting for tolerance" against the right wing of his party, and so it was not clear how far Mr. Dole might go in trying to appease abortion foes.
Nonetheless, he seemed confident that something would calm the waters.
"We're going to have it all resolved before the convention," Mr. Dole told a local television reporter today at a refueling stop in Rockford, Ill.
Looking ahead to his three-day swing across California, he repeated how important the state was to his campaign.
"Big. Big. Fifty-four votes," he said, referring to the state's electoral prize, the largest in the country and central for both parties' campaign strategies.
"Having our convention there," Mr. Dole added. "A lot of time out there." He plans to return in early July to raise money and may meet with former President Ronald Reagan.
When Mr. Dole landed in Oakland and made his way to this upper-income suburb east of San Francisco, he left the abortion debate behind and delivered a harsh attack on President Clinton.
He told his audience of several hundred people standing in a park under the hot sun that Mr. Clinton had made great promises to the people of California but had waged "war" on the state.
Mr. Clinton, he said, had raised the gasoline tax, refused to help the state bear the costs of immigration and failed to put together a coherent policy on agriculture. But he leveled his most caustic charges against what he said was the President's failure to "maintain a strong military" and his opposition to a missile defense system that could be a boon to California's important defense industry.
"The Administration's hostility is like a Stinger missile aimed right at the heart of California," Mr. Dole said. "It's cost at least 130,000 jobs directly related to the defense industry and thousands and thousands or more are at risk."
Joseph Lockhart, press secretary for Mr. Clinton's re-election effort, responded by arguing that California's economy had improved under Mr. Clinton's leadership. He said that nearly 550,000 new jobs had been created over the last three years.
"Bill Clinton is waging war," Mr. Lockhart said, "but it's on the Republican recession that ravaged the California economy, and it's a war we're winning."
Mr. Clinton has visited the state two dozen times since his election. Poll Track, part of an electronic national political reference service that monitors media polling around the country, said in a report on June 5 that Mr. Clinton was leading Mr. Dole in California by 12 points. That is an improvement for Mr. Dole since March, when a poll by The Los Angeles Times put him 21 points behind the President.
At his speech today, Mr. Dole summed up the election contest. "On one side is this great pretender," he said referring to Mr. Clinton. "He talks right, governs left, and he talks to you as a friend in California while he's waged war on California the last three and a half years.
"In the other corner is this middleweight Bob Dole, who fights every day, every day, for common-sense values of growth, opportunity, family and freedom."

HEADLINE: Treasuries Continue To Advance

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose for the third consecutive session yesterday as uncertainty mounted over whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates next month.
There is a growing view among market participants that the reaction to recent strong economic reports may have been overblown. 
 Indeed, there are even some who think that a bearish market would do much of the Fed's work in pushing interest rates higher and slowing down the economy. Still, most traders and analysts expect that the Fed will soon raise rates, the question is whether the rate increase will come when Fed policy makers meet early next month.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 8/32, to 86 28/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, slipped to 7.06 percent, from 7.08 percent on Friday.
With little economic news yesterday, Treasury prices stayed in a narrow trading range throughout the session, traders said. There was not much to provide investors with direction. In one economic report, the National Association of Builders yesterday said that its housing market index for June fell 2 points, to 61, from 63 in May. While the index was lower, the overall number still suggested strength.
The Treasury market also shrugged off higher oil prices on news that Iraq was refusing to admit United Nations inspectors for weapon production checks. Margo Evashevski, fixed-income analyst with MMS International, San Francisco, said she did not see this week's economic calendar as offering anything that could potentially alter the market's view of the economy.
Tomorrow, the Fed will release an assessment of current economic conditions, known as the beige book, On Thusrday the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia will release the results of its survey of regional business conditions. But Ms. Evashevski said the lack of important reports could give the market a chance to find solid footing. "The market's improvement late last week has helped settle some nerves," she said.
Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said: "There is a new asymmetry that has developed in the bond markets with the current negative sentiment. Bonds will sell off on even hints of bad news, but they will rally only on hard evidence."
Hamilton Davis, a vice president of government trading at Everen Securities Inc., in Chicago, said a Knight Ridder news headline elevated prices in the afternoon, after it carried comments by unnamed Fed officials saying that despite pockets of wages and price pressures, inflation is surprisingly subdued.
"On a relatively quiet news day with the market having a slight bias towards higher prices, it gave the market a little fuel to close higher," he said.
"You're always a little suspicious of anonymous Fed stories," Mr. Hamilton said, "and they have to be taken with a grain of salt. But if it is true it calls into question where the Fed has adopted a unanimous bias toward tightening."
At the Treasury's weekly bill auction, which was down about $4 billion in size from last week's sale, rates were slightly lower than market expectations as investor demand appeared decent. Ahead of the auction the expectations were that rates would come in at 5.09 percent for a three month issue and 5.26 percent for a six-month bill.
